. O

Fetal O

and O

. O

reaction O
( O

) O

has O
enabled O

( O

. O

. O

. O

Enrichment O
for O

and O

by O

) O

The O

has O

; O

, O

, O

Fetal O

during O

, O

Emphasis O

USA O
, O

of O
which O

non O
- O
invasive O
methods O
of O
prenatal O
cytogenetic O
diagnosis O
. O

Methylation O
- O
specific O
PCR O
allows O
for O
fast O
diagnosis O
of O
X O
chromosome O
disomy O
and O
reveals O
skewed O
inactivation O
of O
the O
X O
chromosome O
in O
men O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
remains O
the O
most O
common O
, O
yet O
often O
undiagnosed O
, O
chromosomal O
aberration O
in O
men O
. O

Early O
diagnosis O
and O
treatment O
can O
improve O
the O
health O
of O
patients O
with O
KS O
. O

The O
aim O
of O
this O
study O
was O
to O
evaluate O
the O
inactivation O
pattern O
of O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosomes O
. O

The O
secondary O
aim O
was O
to O
design O
a O
reliable O
and O
cost O
- O
effective O
molecular O
test O
for O
detection O
of O
X O
chromosome O
disomy O
. O

Methylation O
- O
specific O
polymerase O
chain O
reaction O
( O
M O
- O
PCR O
) O
, O
with O
primers O
for O
familial O
mental O
retardation O
( O
FMR1 O
) O
and O
X O
chromosome O
inactive O
- O
specific O
transcript O
( O
XIST O
) O
genes O
, O
was O
used O
to O
detect O
the O
presence O
of O
X O
chromosome O
disomy O
in O
men O
. O

Seventeen O
fertile O
males O
, O
12 O
females O
, O
and O
35 O
males O
with O
KS O
( O
28 O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
, O
and O
7 O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
/ O
46 O
, O
XY O
mosaics O
) O
were O
included O
in O
the O
study O
. O

Results O
of O
the O
karyotype O
were O
compared O
with O
the O
results O
of O
semiquantitative O
M O
- O
PCR O
. O

Inactivation O
of O
X O
chromosomes O
was O
measured O
by O
XIST O
/ O
FMR O
- O
1 O
methylation O
ratio O
. O

Differences O
in O
the O
methylation O
patterns O
of O
FMR1 O
and O
XIST O
genes O
between O
46 O
, O
XY O
men O
and O
men O
with O
X O
chromosome O
disomy O
allowed O
for O
rapid O
detection O
of O
the O
presence O
of O
an O
additional O
X O
chromosome O
, O
achieving O
100 O
% O
sensitivity O
and O
specificity O
using O
M O
- O
PCR O
. O

The O
methylated O
: O
unmethylated O
FMR1 O
amplicon O
ratio O
allowed O
the O
detection O
of O
1 O
additional O
X O
chromosome O
per O
100 O
normal O
XY O
cells O
( O
1 O
% O
of O
XX O
/ O
XY O
mosaicism O
) O
. O

In O
our O
series O
, O
50 O
% O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
men O
showed O
skewed O
inactivation O
of O
the O
X O
chromosome O
. O

Men O
with O
KS O
can O
have O
incomplete O
inactivation O
of O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosomes O
. O

M O
- O
PCR O
is O
a O
sensitive O
, O
specific O
, O
fast O
, O
and O
relatively O
inexpensive O
test O
for O
the O
diagnosis O
of O
X O
chromosome O
disomy O
. O

Rapid O
diagnosis O
of O
aneuploidy O
by O
high O
- O
resolution O
melting O
analysis O
of O
segmental O
duplications O
. O

Several O
molecular O
methods O
, O
such O
as O
quantitative O
fluorescence O
PCR O
and O
multiplex O
ligation O
- O
dependent O
probe O
amplification O
, O
currently O
serve O
as O
important O
adjuncts O
to O
traditional O
karyotyping O
for O
the O
diagnosis O
of O
aneuploidy O
; O
however O
, O
the O
performance O
or O
throughput O
limitations O
of O
these O
methods O
hinder O
their O
use O
for O
routine O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
and O
population O
- O
based O
postnatal O
screening O
. O

We O
developed O
a O
novel O
approach O
, O
called O
" O
high O
- O
resolution O
melting O
analysis O
of O
segmental O
duplications O
, O
" O
to O
detect O
common O
aneuploidies O
. O

In O
this O
method O
, O
similar O
sequences O
located O
on O
different O
chromosomes O
are O
amplified O
simultaneously O
with O
a O
single O
primer O
set O
; O
the O
PCR O
products O
are O
then O
analyzed O
by O
high O
- O
resolution O
melting O
. O

Aneuploidy O
- O
associated O
dosage O
abnormalities O
produce O
different O
ratios O
of O
similar O
amplicons O
, O
which O
produce O
melting O
curves O
that O
are O
detectably O
different O
from O
those O
of O
samples O
from O
unaffected O
individuals O
. O

We O
applied O
this O
method O
to O
DNA O
samples O
isolated O
from O
individuals O
with O
trisomy O
21 O
( O
n O
= O
48 O
) O
, O
trisomy O
18 O
( O
n O
= O
10 O
) O
, O
trisomy O
13 O
( O
n O
= O
3 O
) O
, O
45 O
, O
X O
( O
n O
= O
8 O
) O
, O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
n O
= O
14 O
) O
, O
and O
from O
unaffected O
controls O
( O
n O
= O
48 O
) O
. O

As O
judged O
by O
the O
karyotyping O
results O
, O
our O
method O
attained O
100 O
% O
diagnostic O
sensitivity O
and O
99 O
. O
6 O
% O
diagnostic O
specificity O
. O

Moreover O
, O
our O
method O
was O
able O
to O
detect O
a O
change O
in O
chromosome O
dosage O
as O
low O
as O
1 O
. O
05 O
- O
fold O
. O

This O
novel O
method O
clearly O
differentiates O
samples O
of O
patients O
with O
common O
aneuploidies O
from O
those O
of O
unaffected O
controls O
, O
while O
markedly O
simplifying O
the O
assays O
and O
reducing O
time O
and O
costs O
. O

The O
assay O
has O
sufficient O
throughput O
to O
meet O
the O
demands O
of O
large O
- O
scale O
testing O
, O
such O
as O
population O
- O
based O
postnatal O
screening O
, O
and O
is O
thus O
suitable O
for O
routine O
use O
. O

Behavioral O
and O
social O
phenotypes O
in O
boys O

syndrome O

. O

. O

. O

. O

Advances O
in O
research O
on O
the O
neurological O
and O
neuropsychiatric O
phenotype O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
is O
the O
most O
common O
chromosomal O
aberration O
among O
men O
. O

It O
represents O
a O
naturally O
occurring O
human O
model O
for O
studies O
of O
both O
X O
- O
chromosome O
gene O
expression O
and O
potential O
androgen O
effects O
on O
brain O
development O
and O
function O
. O

The O
aim O
of O
this O
review O
is O
to O
combine O
available O
brain O
imaging O
and O
behavioral O
data O
to O
provide O
an O
overview O
of O
what O
we O
have O
learned O
about O
the O
neural O
underpinnings O
of O
cognitive O
, O
emotional O
and O
behavioral O
dysunctions O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

The O
behavioral O
phenotype O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
is O
characterized O
by O
language O
, O
executive O
and O
psychomotor O
dysfunction O
, O
as O
well O
as O
socioemotional O
impairment O
. O

The O
prevalence O
of O
schizophrenia O
, O
attention O
deficit O
hyperactivity O
disorder O
, O
autism O
spectrum O
disorders O
and O
affective O
regulation O
problems O
is O
increased O
. O

Neuroimaging O
studies O
of O
children O
and O
adults O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
syndrome O
show O
characteristic O
structural O
changes O
from O
typical O
individuals O
. O

There O
are O
increases O
in O
the O
grey O
matter O
volume O
of O
the O
sensorimotor O
and O
parietooccipital O
regions O
, O
as O
well O
as O
significant O
reductions O
in O
amygdala O
, O
hippocampal O
, O
insular O
, O
temporal O
and O
inferior O
- O
frontal O
grey O
matter O
volumes O
. O

Widespread O
white O
matter O
abnormalities O
have O
been O
revealed O
, O
with O
reductions O
in O
some O
areas O
( O
including O
anterior O

, O
bilaterally O
) O
but O
increases O
in O
others O
( O
such O
as O
left O
parietal O
lobe O
) O
. O

Mechanisms O
underlying O
these O
developmental O
anomalies O
could O
include O
imbalance O
in O
gene O
dosage O
relative O
to O
typical O
men O
or O
women O
, O
as O
well O
as O
the O
potential O
consequence O
of O
endocrinological O
deficits O
. O

Studies O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
could O
generate O
important O
information O
about O
the O
impact O
of O
anomalies O
in O
sex O
chromosome O
gene O
regulation O
on O
the O
development O
of O
cerebral O
grey O
and O

matter O

, O
on O
human O
behavior O
. O

Constitutional O
complex O

in O

. O

Clinical O
and O

of O

. O

To O

of O

syndrome O
in O

of O

in O

. O

A O
total O
of O
179 O
men O
with O
non O
- O
mosaic O
47 O
, O
XXY O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
of O
the O
1876 O

males O
who O

the O

of O
our O

between O

and O

. O

Their O

, O

profiles O
, O

of O

Thirty O

. O

The O

was O

not O

of O

but O

. O

. O

, O

. O

In O

were O

. O

. O

. O

[ O
Importance O
of O

syndrome O
in O
the O
pathogenesis O
of O
male O
infertility O
] O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O
the O
most O
knowning O
hipergonadotrophic O
hypogonadism O
, O
is O
associated O
typically O
with O
two O
X O
chromosomes O
and O
one O
Y O
chromosome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

The O
signs O
and O

of O
these O
conditions O
typically O
become O
more O
severe O
as O
the O
number O
of O
X O
chromosomes O
increases O
. O

To O
preveal O
the O
role O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
in O
pathogenesis O
of O
male O
infertility O
. O

The O
study O
included O
20 O

hospitalized O
and O
treated O
in O
the O
Endocrinology O
Clinic O
, O
Ia O
ş O
i O
. O

The O
age O
of O
patients O
was O
between O
19 O
years O
and O
44 O
years O
. O

They O
made O
next O
investigations O
: O
clinical O
, O
biological O
and O
semen O
examination O
, O
testis O
echography O
and O
biopsy O
, O
test O
Elisa O
, O
Barr O
' O

test O
, O

evaluation O
and O

- O

. O

Diagnosis O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
is O
made O
by O
examining O
chromosomes O
for O
evidence O
of O
more O
than O
one O
X O
chromosome O
present O
in O
a O
male O
. O

All O
patients O
are O
characterized O
by O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
, O
small O
penis O
, O
small O
firm O
testicles O
with O
hyalinization O
and O

of O
the O

tubules O
, O
underdevelopment O
of O
secondary O
sexual O
characteristics O
, O
abnormal O
body O
proportions O
( O
long O
legs O
, O
short O

) O
, O
sexual O
problems O
, O

, O
infertility O
and O
increased O

excretion O
of O
gonadotropin O
. O
14 O
cases O
had O
gynecomastia O
and O
2 O
cases O
presented O
anti O
- O
sperm O
antibodies O
. O

The O
following O
test O
results O
may O
be O
found O
: O
karyotyping O
chromosome O
shows O
47 O
XXY O
; O
positive O
test O
Barr O
; O
semen O
count O
- O
low O
; O
serum O
testosterone O
- O
low O
; O
serum O

hormone O
( O
LH O
) O
- O
- O
high O
; O
serum O
follicle O
stimulating O
hormone O
( O
FSH O
) O
- O
- O
high O
; O
serum O
estradiol O
levels O
( O
a O
type O
of O
estrogen O
) O
- O
high O
, O
testicle O
size O
measurement O
< O
10 O
cc O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
is O
a O
chromosomal O
condition O
that O
affects O
male O
sexual O
development O
, O
preventing O
the O
testicles O
from O
functioning O
normally O
and O
reducing O
the O
levels O
of O
testosterone O
. O

Low O
Testosterone O
can O
lead O
to O
breast O
development O
( O
gynecomastia O
) O
, O
decreased O
libido O
, O
incomplete O
masculinization O
with O
female O
body O
hair O
distribution O
( O
sparse O
facial O
, O
armpit O
, O
and O
pubic O
hair O
) O
and O
an O
inability O
to O
father O
children O
( O
infertility O
) O
. O

The O
decreased O
testosterone O
also O
causes O
an O
increase O
in O
two O
other O
hormones O
, O
follicle O
stimulating O
hormone O
( O
FSH O
) O
and O
luteinizing O
hormone O
( O
LH O
) O
. O

The O
increased O
amount O
of O
FSH O
and O
LH O
cause O
hyalinization O
and O
fibrosis O
, O
the O
growth O
of O
excess O
fibrous O
tissue O
, O
in O
the O
seminiferous O
tubules O
, O
where O
the O
sperm O
are O
normally O
located O
. O

As O
a O
result O
, O
the O
testicles O
appear O
smaller O
and O
firmer O
than O
normal O
. O

Men O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
are O
infertile O
because O
they O
cannot O
make O
sperm O
. O

Testosterone O
therapy O
may O
help O
to O
produce O
more O
normal O
development O
including O
more O
muscle O
mass O
, O
hair O
growth O
and O
increased O
sex O
drive O
. O

Testosterone O
supplementation O
will O
not O
increase O
testicular O
size O
, O
decrease O
breast O
growth O
or O
correct O
infertility O
. O

There O
is O
no O
treatment O
available O
to O
change O
chromosomal O
makeup O
. O

Routine O
screening O
for O
classical O
azoospermia O

of O

in O

. O

Abnormal O

Mosaic O

9p O

with O

The O

. O

, O

report O
a O

Our O

Sperm O
cryopreservation O
in O
male O

due O
to O

. O

Certain O

and O

, O
such O

( O
47 O

In O

or O

represent O
a O

tool O
for O

However O

. O

Variation O
in O

A O

with O

We O
abstracted O
type O
of O

and O

of O

procedure O
, O

, O
and O

of O

to O

. O

were O

- O
square O
test O
. O

Potential O

variables O
were O
controlled O
for O
using O

regression O
. O

Overall O
, O
there O
were O
833 O
patients O
who O
had O
fetuses O
with O
aneuploidy O
. O

In O
our O
study O
population O
, O

rate O
of O

was O

% O
: O

and O

( O

) O
( O
p O
< O
0 O
. O
001 O
) O
. O

were O

( O

. O

Type O
and O

of O

of O

' O

- O

of O

. O

[ O
Chromosomal O
disorders O
in O
the O
background O
of O
azoospermia O
] O
. O

Nowadays O
more O
and O
more O
couples O
face O
the O
fact O
that O
they O
cannot O
have O
babies O
in O
spite O
of O
many O
years O
of O
trying O
. O

The O
male O
factor O
can O
be O
identified O
in O
about O
half O
of O
these O
cases O
. O

The O
aim O
of O
this O
study O
was O
to O
analyse O
chromosomal O
alterations O
in O
patients O
with O
azoospermia O
. O

These O
patients O
may O
be O
candidates O
for O
testicular O
sperm O
retrieval O
and O
intracytoplasmatic O
sperm O
injection O
. O

Preoperative O
evaluation O
included O
routine O
andrological O
investigation O
with O
2 O
semen O
analysis O
, O
ultrasound O
, O
hormonal O
and O
genetic O
examination O
. O

Traditional O
histological O
examination O
and O
embryological O
diagnostic O
of O
tissue O
samples O
was O
performed O
. O

Cryopreservation O
of O
retrieved O
testicular O
tissue O
was O
also O
done O
. O

Between O
January O
2001 O
and O
June O
2005 O
73 O
biopsies O
were O
performed O
in O
71 O
patients O
for O
testicular O
sperm O
extraction O
. O

In O
order O
to O
obtain O
an O
exact O
diagnosis O
, O
the O
traditional O
cytogenetic O
methods O
and O
fluorescence O
in O
situ O
hybridization O
analyses O
were O
performed O
in O
combination O
with O
molecular O
genetic O
techniques O
. O

Patients O
were O
offered O
to O
participate O
in O
the O
assisted O
reproduction O
programme O
on O
the O
base O
of O
their O
genetic O
results O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
the O
most O
characteristic O
cases O
were O
numerical O
deviations O
, O
such O
as O
47 O
, O

( O
2 O
cases O
) O
, O

47 O
, O
XXY O
/ O
49 O
, O
XXXXY O
( O
1 O
case O
) O
, O
47 O
, O
XYY O
( O
1 O
case O
) O
and O
mosaic O
46 O
, O
XY O
/ O
45 O
, O
X O
( O
1 O
case O
) O
karyotypes O
. O

Non O
- O
obstructive O
azoospermia O
was O
diagnosed O
in O
53 O
patients O
( O
79 O
% O
) O
. O

Authors O
emphasised O
the O
importance O
of O
cyto O
- O
and O
molecular O
examinations O
in O
cases O
of O
genetical O
disorders O
. O

The O
results O
provide O
a O
chance O
for O
patients O
to O
be O
spared O
from O
long O
- O
drawn O
moreover O
psychological O
burdening O
examinations O
. O

In O
addition O
the O
costs O
of O
different O
clinical O
intervention O
could O
be O
saved O
too O
. O

Premature O
fusion O
and O
excessive O
calcification O
of O
coronal O
sutures O
in O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

The O
purpose O
of O
this O
paper O
is O
to O
report O
on O
radiographic O
features O
of O
the O
cranial O
vault O
abnormalities O
frequently O
seen O
but O
not O
yet O
described O
in O
detail O
in O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Our O
studies O
comprised O
72 O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

The O

of O

in O

( O

) O
/ O

( O

% O
) O

De O
novo O

in O

. O

We O
describe O
a O
case O
of O
de O

. O

A O

of O

47 O

was O

. O

After O

and O

disappeared O
and O
the O

. O

To O

. O

Results O
of O

Chromosome O
aberrations O
in O
a O
schizophrenia O

. O

to O
the O

for O

. O

We O
have O

on O
134 O

. O

. O

of O

. O

incidence O
( O

Our O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
: O
expanding O
the O
phenotype O
and O
identifying O
new O
research O
directions O
. O

The O
purpose O
of O
this O
study O
is O
to O
summarize O
new O
data O
on O
etiology O
and O
clinical O
features O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
in O
order O
to O
derive O
research O
priorities O
. O

This O
study O
was O
conducted O
using O
critical O
reviews O
of O
selective O
topics O
, O
emphasizing O
less O
well O
- O
recognized O
clinical O
findings O
. O

The O
phenotype O
of O
the O
prototypic O
47 O
, O
XXY O
case O
is O
well O
recognized O
: O
seminiferous O
tubule O
dysgenesis O
and O
androgen O
deficiency O
. O

Less O
well O
appreciated O
is O
the O
varied O
expressivity O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O
in O
particular O
neurological O
/ O
cognitive O
perturbations O
like O
language O
and O
behavioral O
problems O
. O

Effective O
therapies O
are O
available O
. O

Reproductive O
technologies O
allow O
47 O
, O
XXY O
men O
to O
sire O
offspring O
through O
intracytoplasmic O
sperm O
injection O
( O
ICSI O
) O
; O
however O
, O
genetic O
counseling O
is O
complex O
and O
success O
is O
low O
. O

Behavioral O
and O
expressive O
language O
difficulties O
are O
amenable O
to O
treatment O
by O
androgen O
therapy O
and O
psychological O
help O
. O

Early O
treatment O
may O
be O
imperative O
for O
optimal O
outcome O
. O

Fetal O
chromosomal O
analysis O
of O
pregnancies O
following O

injection O

amniotic O
tissue O
culture O
. O

objective O
of O

was O

. O

. O

Both O

The O

( O

) O
was O

The O

. O

The O

confirmed O
the O

findings O
, O

[ O

The O

( O

( O

For O

to O

In O

( O

and O

system O
teratomas O
are O
a O
rare O
subgroup O
of O
extragonadal O
germ O
cell O
tumors O
. O

Previous O
studies O
show O
ovarian O
mature O
teratomas O
to O
be O
karyotypically O
normal O
; O
those O
with O
increasing O
immaturity O
show O
increasing O
cytogenetic O
abnormalities O
. O

Adult O
testicular O
teratomas O
, O
regardless O
of O
maturity O
, O
most O
often O
show O
the O
i O
sochromosome O
12p O
, O
a O
consistent O
chromosomal O
abnormality O
seen O
in O
adult O
testicular O
germ O
cell O
tumors O
. O

This O
study O
investigates O
the O
cytogenetic O
abnormalities O
of O
six O
central O
nervous O
system O
teratomas O
by O
the O
use O
of O
routine O

analysis O
and O
fluorescence O
in O
situ O
hybridization O
. O

Karyotypic O
analysis O
was O
performed O
on O
two O
tumors O
. O

Four O
additional O
tumors O
were O
analyzed O
by O
dual O
- O
labeled O
fluorescence O
in O
situ O
hybridization O
. O

Paraffin O
blocks O
were O
disaggregated O
, O
and O
nuclei O
were O
hybridized O
with O
both O
biotin O
- O
and O

- O
labeled O
probes O
to O
the O
centromeric O
domains O
of O
the O
X O
and O
Y O
chromosomes O
, O
respectively O
. O

Tumor O
cells O
were O
scored O
for O
X O
and O
Y O
copy O
number O
. O

Tumor O
ploidy O
was O
determined O
by O
image O
analysis O
of O
the O
disaggregated O
specimens O
. O

The O
patients O
( O
five O
male O
, O
one O

) O

from O
2 O

. O

. O

Psychosocial O
adaptation O
of O
39 O
adolescents O
with O
sex O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
. O

Children O
with O
sex O

( O
SCA O
) O
are O
known O
to O
be O
at O
increased O
risk O
for O

, O

and O

, O
but O
little O
is O
known O
of O
psychosocial O

of O
SCA O
adolescents O
. O

This O
study O
was O
conducted O
to O
evaluate O
psychologic O
characteristics O
of O
unselected O
SCA O
adolescents O
, O
including O
socialization O
, O

progress O
, O

from O
family O
, O
and O
incidence O
and O
severity O
of O
psychiatric O
disturbance O
. O

Thirty O
- O
nine O
propositi O
identified O
through O
the O
screening O
of O
40 O
, O
000 O
consecutive O
Denver O
newborns O
, O
including O
boys O
with O
47 O
, O

and O

with O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O

, O
or O
SCA O

, O
have O
been O
followed O
longitudinally O
into O
adolescence O
. O

Twenty O
- O
seven O
siblings O
served O
as O
controls O
. O

Between O
12 O
and O
19 O
years O
of O
age O
, O

in O

and O

and O

. O

propositi O
demonstrated O
a O
mean O

score O
21 O
points O
lower O
than O
that O
of O
control O
subjects O
. O

In O

, O

were O
seen O
on O

results O
as O
well O
as O

and O
increased O

of O
psychiatric O

. O

Depression O
was O
the O
most O
frequent O
psychiatric O
diagnosis O
. O

Propositi O
were O
more O
likely O
to O
receive O
special O
education O

in O

and O

. O

Of O

Mosaic O
girls O
were O

from O
control O

. O

Marked O

was O
found O
among O
all O
three O

, O

some O

. O

The O

of O

chromosome O

the O

for O

skills O
, O

, O
and O

in O

. O

The O

that O

for O

in O

. O

The O

for O

in O
unselected O
SCA O
adults O
remains O
uncertain O
. O

Isolating O
fetal O
cells O
in O
maternal O
circulation O
for O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
. O

Fetal O
cells O
unequivocally O
exist O
in O
and O
can O
be O
isolated O
from O
maternal O
blood O
. O

Erythroblasts O
, O
trophoblasts O
, O
granulocytes O
and O
lymphocytes O
have O
all O
been O
isolated O
by O
various O
density O
gradient O
and O
flow O
sorting O
techniques O
. O

Chromosomal O
abnormalities O
detected O
on O
isolated O
fetal O
cells O
include O
trisomy O
21 O
, O
trisomy O
18 O
, O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
. O

Polymerase O
chain O
reaction O
( O
PCR O
) O
technology O
has O
enabled O
the O
detection O
of O
fetal O
sex O
, O
Mendelian O
disorders O
( O
e O
. O
g O
. O
beta O
- O
globin O
mutations O
) O
, O
HLA O
polymorphisms O
, O
and O
fetal O
Rhesus O
( O
D O
) O
blood O
type O
. O

The O
fetal O
cell O
type O
that O
has O
generated O
the O
most O
success O
is O
the O
nucleated O
erythrocyte O
; O
however O
, O
trophoblasts O
, O
lymphocytes O
and O
granulocytes O
are O
also O
considered O
to O
be O
present O
in O
maternal O
blood O
. O

Fetal O
cells O
circulate O
in O
maternal O
blood O
during O
the O
first O
and O
second O
trimesters O
, O
and O
their O
detection O
is O
probably O
not O
affected O
by O
Rh O
or O
ABO O
maternal O
- O
fetal O
incompatibilities O
. O

Emphasis O
is O
now O
directed O
toward O
determining O
the O
most O

and O

for O

. O

Seizures O
in O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
: O
a O
clinical O
and O
EEG O
study O
of O
five O
patients O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
report O
the O
cases O
of O
five O
unrelated O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
and O
seizures O
or O
EEG O
epileptiform O
abnormalities O
; O
the O
karyotype O
was O
47 O
, O
XXY O
in O
four O
, O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
/ O
46 O
, O
XX O
in O
one O
. O

They O
were O
aged O
13 O
- O
25 O
years O
and O

up O
both O

and O
by O
means O
of O

. O

Two O

. O

In O

( O

of O

in O
Klinefelter O
' O

. O

Sex O
chromosome O

and O

. O

Sex O

abnormalities O
occur O
in O
at O
least O
1 O
in O
400 O

and O
include O
the O
well O
- O
described O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
47 O
, O

, O
47 O
, O
XYY O
, O
and O
45 O
, O

karyotypes O
. O

The O
addition O
of O
more O
than O
one O
extra O
X O
or O

chromosome O
occurs O
rarely O
, O
and O
little O
information O
is O
available O
in O
the O
medical O
literature O
. O

Individual O

reports O
make O

most O
of O
this O

of O

, O
and O

of O

and O

; O

information O

of O

and O

. O

A O

between O
the O

of O
additional O
sex O

and O
the O

of O
the O

is O

assumed O
. O

of O

is O
to O

about O
these O

and O
to O

. O

, O
48 O

[ O
Detection O
of O
fetal O
cells O
in O
maternal O
blood O
: O
towards O
a O
noninvasive O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
] O
. O

Fetal O
cells O
exist O
in O
maternal O
blood O
and O
can O
be O
utilized O
for O
prenatal O
genetic O
diagnosis O
. O

These O
cells O
are O
present O
during O
the O
first O
and O
second O
trimesters O
, O
with O
frequency O
increasing O
as O
gestation O
advances O
. O

Enrichment O
of O
erythroblasts O
by O
various O
density O
gradient O
techniques O
and O
either O
magnetic O
activated O
or O
flow O
sorting O
techniques O
can O
be O
followed O
by O
FISH O
with O
chromosome O
- O
specific O
DNA O
probes O
. O

This O
approach O
has O
allowed O
detection O
of O
trisomy O
21 O
, O
trisomy O
18 O
, O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
. O

Polymerase O
chain O
reaction O
( O
PCR O
) O
analysis O
of O
maternal O
blood O
has O
enabled O
the O
detection O
of O
fetal O
sex O
, O
certain O

disorders O
( O
e O
. O
g O
. O

) O
, O

, O
and O
fetal O
Rhesus O
( O
D O
) O
blood O
type O
. O

The O
fetal O
cell O
types O
receiving O
the O
most O
attention O
has O
been O
nucleated O
erythrocyte O
( O
erythroblast O
) O
and O
the O

. O

Lymphocytes O
and O

are O

in O

; O

, O

are O
considered O

most O

to O

after O

. O

is O
now O

in O

U O
. O

. O
that O
will O
allow O
determine O
whether O

to O

of O

. O

. O

The O

( O

) O

in O

( O

. O

Homozygous O
Ala65Pro O
Mutation O
with O
V89L O
Polymorphism O
in O
SRD5A2 O
Deficiency O
. O

Deficiency O
of O
steroid O
5 O
- O
alpha O
reductase O
type O
2 O
( O
5 O
α O
RD2 O
) O
is O
a O
rare O
autosomal O

disorder O
caused O
by O
mutations O
in O
the O
SRD5A2 O
gene O
. O

A O

in O
the O
5 O
- O
alpha O
reductase O
enzyme O
, O
which O
ensures O
conversion O
of O
testosterone O
into O
dihydrotestosterone O
, O
leads O
to O
disorders O
of O
sex O
development O
. O

This O
study O
presents O
the O
clinical O
and O
genetic O
results O
of O
patients O
with O
5 O
α O
RD2 O
deficiency O
. O
5 O
α O
RD2 O
deficiency O
was O
detected O
in O
6 O
different O
patients O
from O
3 O
unrelated O
families O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
reared O
as O
girls O
. O

Two O
of O
the O
patients O
presented O
with O
primary O
amenorrhea O
, O
one O
with O
primary O

and O
rejection O

, O
and O

with O

in O

. O

and O
sex O
- O
determining O
region O

( O

) O

were O

. O

, O

of O

were O

with O

chain O

in O

. O

was O

was O

. O

was O

. O

( O

Sperm O
Retrieval O
in O
Adolescents O
and O
Young O
Adults O
with O
Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
: O
A O
Prospective O
, O
Pilot O
Study O
. O

To O
assess O
sperm O
retrieval O
rates O
in O
adolescents O
and O
young O
adults O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O
with O
the O
ultimate O
goal O
of O
improving O
fertility O
in O
this O
population O
. O

Secondary O
aims O
were O
to O
evaluate O
other O
clinical O
characteristics O
of O
the O
cohort O
and O
identify O
predictors O
of O
sperm O
retrieval O
. O

Patients O
12 O
- O
25 O
years O
of O
age O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
were O
recruited O
at O
the O
Boston O
Children O
' O
s O
Hospital O
. O

Physical O
examination O
, O
biochemical O
evaluation O
, O
scrotal O
ultrasonography O
, O
and O
semen O
analysis O
were O
performed O
. O

Neurocognitive O
data O
were O
collected O
. O

Microdissection O
sperm O
extraction O
( O
unilateral O
micro O
- O
testicular O
sperm O
extraction O
) O
was O
offered O
to O
individuals O
with O
no O
sperm O
in O
their O
ejaculates O
. O

Given O
the O
small O
sample O
size O
, O
analysis O
was O
primarily O
descriptive O
. O

Fifteen O
patients O
were O
enrolled O
. O

None O
had O
sperm O
in O
their O
ejaculates O
. O

Ten O
patients O
underwent O
unilateral O
micro O
- O
testicular O
sperm O
extraction O
. O

Sperm O
retrieval O
rate O
was O
50 O
% O
. O

From O
a O
neurocognitive O
standpoint O
, O
subjects O
reported O
problems O
with O
peers O
, O
conduct O
, O
and O
overall O
difficulties O
. O

Incidentally O
, O
one O
- O
third O
of O
the O
patients O
were O
found O
to O
have O
testicular O
microlithiasis O
and O
17 O
% O
of O
subjects O
with O
renal O
ultrasound O
imaging O
had O
bilateral O
renal O
medullary O
nephrocalcinosis O
. O

This O
pilot O
study O
suggests O
that O
sperm O
retrieval O
rates O
in O
adolescents O
and O
young O
adults O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
are O
comparable O
with O
those O
reported O
in O
older O
men O
. O

However O
, O
larger O
studies O
are O
needed O
to O
confirm O
our O
findings O
. O

The O
clinical O
significance O
of O
the O
scrotal O
and O
renal O
ultrasound O
findings O
merits O
further O
investigation O
. O

. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O

) O

, O

, O

. O

in O

. O

, O

between O

, O

( O

) O

. O

( O

, O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
may O
be O
more O
likely O
to O
develop O
germ O
cell O
tumors O
( O
GCTs O
) O
, O
particularly O
mediastinal O
GCTs O
. O

To O
date O
, O
there O
are O
no O
reports O
characterizing O
the O
prevalence O
of O
KS O
among O
male O
GCT O
cases O
. O

The O
authors O
used O
array O
genotyping O
data O
from O
a O

' O

Oncology O
Group O

study O
to O
estimate O

of O

in O
males O
with O
GCTs O
( O
433 O
males O
aged O
birth O
- O
19 O
years O
) O
. O

Using O
Fisher O
' O
s O
exact O
tests O
, O
the O
authors O
examined O
differences O
in O
age O
at O
diagnosis O

race O
/ O

, O
tumor O
location O
and O

, O
and O

birth O
characteristics O
between O
cases O
of O

- O

and O
GCT O

without O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
. O

Using O
publicly O

data O
, O
the O
authors O
estimated O
the O

- O
year O
risk O
, O
risk O
ratio O
, O
and O
corresponding O

% O
confidence O
interval O
of O
GCTs O
among O
KS O

. O

Based O
on O
analysis O
of O

data O

3 O
% O
of O
male O

cases O
( O

. O

Of O

Compared O

The O

in O

. O

DNA O
methylation O
signature O
in O
peripheral O
blood O
reveals O
distinct O
characteristics O
of O
human O
X O
chromosome O
numerical O
aberrations O
. O

Abnormal O
sex O
chromosome O
numbers O
in O
humans O
are O
observed O
in O
Turner O
( O
45 O
, O
X O
) O
and O
Klinefelter O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
syndromes O
. O

Both O
syndromes O
are O
associated O
with O
several O
clinical O
phenotypes O
, O
whose O
molecular O
mechanisms O
are O
obscure O
, O
and O
show O
a O
range O
of O
inter O
- O
individual O
penetrance O
. O

In O
order O
to O
understand O
the O
effect O
of O
abnormal O
numbers O
of O
X O
chromosome O
on O
the O
methylome O
and O
its O
correlation O
to O
the O
variable O
clinical O
phenotype O
, O
we O
performed O
a O
genome O
- O
wide O
methylation O
analysis O
using O
MeDIP O
and O
Illumina O
' O
s O
Infinium O
assay O
on O
individuals O
with O

, O
X O
, O
46 O
, O
XY O
, O
46 O
, O
XX O
, O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

DNA O
methylation O
changes O
were O
widespread O
on O
all O
autosomal O
chromosomes O
in O
45 O
, O
X O
and O
in O
47 O
, O
XXY O
individuals O
, O
with O
Turner O
individuals O
presenting O
five O
times O
more O
affected O
loci O
. O

Differentially O
methylated O
CpGs O
, O
in O
most O
cases O
, O
have O
intermediate O
methylation O
levels O
and O
tend O
to O
occur O
outside O
CpG O
islands O
, O
especially O
in O
individuals O
with O
Turner O
syndrome O
. O

The O
X O
inactivation O
process O
appears O
to O
be O
less O
effective O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
as O
methylation O
on O
the O
X O
was O
decreased O
compared O
to O
normal O
female O
samples O
. O

In O
a O
large O
number O
of O
individuals O
, O
we O
verified O
several O
loci O
by O
pyrosequencing O
and O
observed O
only O
weak O
inter O

correlations O
between O
the O
verified O
regions O
. O

This O
suggests O
a O
certain O
stochastic O
/ O
random O
contribution O
to O
the O
methylation O
changes O
at O
each O
locus O
. O

Interestingly O
, O
methylation O
patterns O
on O
some O
PAR2 O
loci O
differ O
between O
male O
and O
Turner O
syndrome O
individuals O
and O
between O
female O

possibly O
contributed O
to O
this O
distinguished O
and O
unique O
autosomal O

patterns O
in O

and O

syndrome O

. O

The O
presented O
data O
clearly O
show O
that O
gain O
or O
loss O
of O
an O
X O
chromosome O
results O
in O
different O
epigenetic O
effects O
, O
which O
are O
not O
necessary O
opposite O
. O

of O
skewed O

- O

in O

and O

. O

of O

. O

47 O

. O

. O

[ O
Chromosome O
anomalies O
found O
in O

of O
750 O

. O

Cytogenetic O
studies O
on O
newborn O
infants O
show O
a O
high O
incidence O
in O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
( O
0 O
. O
5 O
- O
1 O
% O
of O
the O
population O
) O
. O

Chromosomal O
study O
is O
carried O
out O
on O
750 O
children O
from O
the O
University O
Hospital O
of O
Valencia O
over O
a O
two O
- O
year O
period O
, O
chosen O
at O
random O
and O
without O
any O
clinical O
pathology O
. O

Five O
gonosomopathies O
and O
three O
autosomopathies O
were O
found O
. O

In O
the O
former O
, O
three O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
one O
triple O
- O
X O
, O
and O
one O
isochromosome O
of O
long O
arms O
of O
chromosome O
X O
, O
were O
detected O
. O

In O
autosomal O
chromosomopathies O
, O
a O

translocation O
was O
seen O
between O
chromosomes O
13 O
and O
14 O

a O

translocation O
between O
chromosomes O
8 O
and O
10 O
, O
and O
an O
inversion O
of O
chromosome O
3 O
. O

Altogether O
eight O
cytogenetic O
anomalies O
appeared O
, O
a O
percentage O
slightly O
over O
one O
percent O
. O

Importance O
of O
early O
diagnosis O
of O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
is O
discussed O
, O
with O
the O
aim O
of O

adequate O
treatment O
when O
possible O
, O
and O
genetic O
counselling O
for O
the O
family O
. O

X O
- O
linked O
mental O
retardation O
. O
I O
. O
Martin O
- O
Bell O
syndrome O
( O
report O
of O
18 O
families O
) O
. O

Eighteen O

( O

) O

Rapid O

Prenatal O
diagnosis O
is O
testing O
for O
diseases O
or O

in O
a O

or O
embryo O

. O

It O

a O

of O
techniques O
to O
determine O
the O
health O
and O
condition O
of O
an O

. O

The O

of O

is O
to O
perform O

at O
the O
earliest O
possible O
stage O
of O

. O

In O

, O

- O
polymerase O
chain O
reaction O
( O
QF O
- O
PCR O
) O
, O
a O

that O
is O

, O
was O

to O

( O

, O

, O
X O
and O
Y O
) O

need O
of O

- O
consuming O

process O
. O

The O
QF O
- O
PCR O
method O
can O
detect O
five O
different O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
with O
98 O
. O
6 O
% O

. O

In O
this O
study O
, O

fluid O
samples O
of O

, O

, O
Adana O
, O
Turkey O
( O

) O

. O

. O

) O

or O

out O

1874 O

. O

The O

of O

was O
32 O
( O

. O

Short O
QTc O
interval O
in O

- O

, O

, O

. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
a O
sex O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
affecting O
1 O
/ O
660 O
males O
. O

Based O
on O
findings O
in O
Turner O
syndrome O
, O
we O
hypothesized O
that O
electrocardiogram O
( O
ECG O
) O
abnormalities O
would O
be O
present O
in O
males O
with O
KS O
. O

To O
investigate O
ECGs O
in O
males O
with O
KS O
and O
compare O
with O
controls O
. O

Case O
control O
study O
of O
62 O
males O
with O
KS O
and O
62 O
healthy O
males O
matched O
on O
age O
. O

The O
primary O
outcome O
parameter O
was O
a O
difference O
in O
the O
ECG O
presentation O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
. O

The O
ECGs O
were O
analyzed O
by O
one O
blinded O
examiner O
( O
intraobserver O
variability O
0 O
. O
2 O
- O
2 O
. O
1 O
% O
) O
. O

The O
QT O
- O
interval O
was O
measured O
using O
" O
teach O
- O
the O
- O
tangent O
" O
method O
excluding O
the O
U O
- O
wave O
. O

QTc O
was O
calculated O
using O
Bazett O
' O
s O
equation O
, O
Hodges O
' O
equation O
, O
and O
a O
linear O
regression O
model O
. O

Body O
mass O
index O
, O
abdominal O
fat O
, O
and O
muscle O
mass O
as O
well O
as O
sex O
hormone O
levels O
were O
secondary O
parameters O
. O

The O
prevalence O
of O
mutations O
in O
genes O
related O
to O
short O
QT O
syndrome O
was O
determined O
in O
participants O
with O
a O
QTc O
< O
330 O
ms O
. O

Compared O
to O
controls O
, O
the O
QTc O
- O
interval O
was O
shorter O
( O
P O
= O
0 O
. O
02 O
- O
0 O
. O
06 O
) O
in O
males O
with O
KS O
depending O
on O
the O
applied O
correction O
method O
. O

QTc O
was O
shortest O
among O
testosterone O
( O
T O
) O
- O
treated O
males O
with O
KS O
, O
while O
untreated O
and O
thus O
hypogonadal O
KS O
had O
QTc O
interval O
comparable O
to O
controls O
. O

No O
mutations O
in O
genes O
related O
to O
short O
QT O
syndrome O
were O
found O
. O

We O
found O
short O
QTc O
interval O
in O
males O
with O
KS O
, O
with O
further O
shortening O
of O
the O
QTc O
interval O
by O
T O
. O

These O
results O
suggest O
that O
genes O
on O
the O
X O
chromosome O
could O
be O
involved O
in O
regulation O
of O
the O
QTc O
interval O
and O
that O
T O
treatment O
may O
aggravate O
this O
mechanism O
. O

Is O
microcephaly O
a O
so O
- O
far O

feature O
of O
XYY O
syndrome O
? O

• O

, O

is O

. O
• O

. O

Gene O
expression O
patterns O
in O

to O
the O

in O
Klinefelter O

. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
the O

in O

( O

) O

. O

The O

between O

and O

remains O
unknown O
. O

To O
elucidate O
whether O

can O
be O

in O

and O

. O

EXAKT O
( O
Epigenetics O
, O
X O
- O

Features O
and O

Applications O
in O
Klinefelter O
Syndrome O

) O
is O
a O

ü O
nster O
- O

involving O
132 O
Klinefelter O

and O

. O

A O
range O
of O

, O

- O

= O

( O

= O

is O

. O

Our O

was O
that O

gene O
expression O

in O

cells O
exist O
in O

vs O

. O

Differential O

of O

and O

genes O
put O
KS O
patients O
into O
a O
unique O

vs O
male O
and O

controls O
. O

The O

cohort O
exhibited O
increased O
insulin O
resistance O
, O
enhanced O
inflammatory O
and O

status O
, O
higher O

, O

( O
all O

< O
. O
001 O
) O

was O

of O

genes O
( O
all O
P O
< O
. O

) O
. O

Parental O

was O
a O

( O

) O

Results O

because O

was O

in O

. O

The O

in O

. O

The O
pattern O
of O

and O

of O

the O
clinical O

. O

Ovotesticular O
disorder O
of O

with O

: O
patient O
report O
. O

Ovotesticular O
disorder O
of O
sex O

( O

- O

) O
( O
true O

) O
is O
an O
anatomopathological O
diagnosis O
based O
on O
the O
findings O
of O
testicular O
and O
ovarian O
tissues O
in O
the O
same O
subject O
, O
in O
the O
same O
gonad O
( O
ovotestis O
) O
, O
or O
in O
separate O
gonads O
. O

OT O
- O
DSD O
is O
a O
rare O
cause O
of O
sex O
ambiguity O
, O
and O
the O
most O
common O
karyotype O
is O
46 O
, O
XX O
; O
mosaics O
and O
chimeras O
are O
found O
only O
in O
10 O
% O
- O
20 O
% O
. O

To O
report O
a O
case O
of O
an O
OT O
- O
DSD O
patient O
with O
a O
rare O
karyotype O
constitution O
. O

A O
2 O
- O
month O
- O
old O
child O
with O
male O
sex O
assignment O
was O
referred O
to O
our O
clinic O
for O
investigation O
of O
sex O

. O

He O
was O
the O
second O
child O
of O
healthy O
unrelated O
parents O
; O
pregnancy O
and O

were O
uneventful O
. O

On O
physical O
examination O
, O
he O
had O
a O
2 O
. O
3 O
- O
cm O
phallus O
and O

( O
Prader O
grade O
III O
) O
; O
the O

was O
in O
the O

fold O
and O
the O

was O
found O
in O
the O

channel O
. O

Karyotype O
was O
46 O
, O
XX O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
/ O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
. O

Anatomopathological O
examination O
of O
gonads O
revealed O
right O
testis O
and O
left O
ovotestis O
. O

The O
male O
sex O
assignment O
was O
maintained O
; O
the O
child O
underwent O
left O
gonadectomy O
, O
removal O
of O

and O
urethroplasty O
. O

A O
thorough O
revision O
of O
literature O
revealed O
a O
single O
case O
of O
OT O
- O
DSD O
with O
the O
same O
chromosome O
constitution O
. O

Gonadal O
biopsy O
is O
necessary O
to O
establish O
diagnosis O
in O
cases O
of O
sex O
chromosome O
mosaicism O
. O

Asymmetry O
of O
cerebral O
gray O
and O
white O
matter O
and O
structural O
volumes O
in O
relation O
to O
sex O
hormones O
and O
chromosomes O
. O

Whilst O
many O
studies O
show O
sex O
differences O
in O
cerebral O
asymmetry O
, O
their O
mechanisms O
are O
still O
unknown O
. O

This O
report O
describes O
the O
potential O
impact O
of O
sex O
hormones O
and O
sex O
chromosomes O
by O
comparing O

data O
from O
39 O

and O
47 O

controls O
and O
33 O
men O
with O
an O
extra O
X O
- O
chromosome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
. O

Regional O
asymmetry O
in O
gray O
and O
white O
matter O
volumes O
( O
GMV O
and O
WMV O
) O
was O
calculated O
using O
voxel O
based O
moprhometry O
( O
SPM5 O
) O
, O
by O
contrasting O
the O
unflipped O
and O

individual O
GMV O
and O
WMV O
images O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
structural O
volumes O
were O
calculated O
for O
the O
thalamus O
, O
caudate O
, O
putamen O
, O
amygdala O
, O
and O
hippocampus O
, O
using O
the O
FreeSurfer O
software O
. O

Effects O
of O
plasma O
testosterone O
and O
estrogen O
on O
the O
GMV O
and O
WMV O
, O
as O
well O
on O
the O
right O
/ O
left O
ratios O
of O
the O
subcortical O
volumes O
were O
tested O
by O
multi O
- O
regression O
analysis O
. O

All O
three O
groups O
showed O
a O
leftward O
asymmetry O
in O
the O
motor O
cortex O
and O
the O
planum O
temporale O
, O
and O
a O
rightward O
asymmetry O
of O
the O
middle O
occipital O
cortex O
. O

Both O
asymmetries O
were O
more O
pronounced O
in O
46 O
, O
XY O
males O
than O
46 O
, O
XX O
females O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
males O
, O
and O
were O
positively O
correlated O
with O
testosterone O
levels O
. O

There O
was O
also O
a O
rightward O
asymmetry O
of O
the O
vermis O
and O
leftward O
GMV O
asymmetry O
in O
the O
cerebellar O
hemispheres O
in O
all O
groups O
. O

Notably O
, O
cerebellar O
asymmetries O
were O
larger O
in O
46 O
, O
XX O
females O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
males O
, O
but O
were O
not O
related O
to O
sex O
hormone O
levels O
. O

No O
asymmetry O
differences O
between O
46 O
, O
XX O
females O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
males O
, O
and O
no O
overall O
effects O
of O
brain O
size O
were O
detected O
. O

The O
asymmetry O
in O
the O
planum O
temporale O
area O
and O
the O
occipital O
cortex O
seem O
related O
to O
processes O
associated O
with O
testosterone O
, O
whereas O
the O
observed O

suggest O
a O
link O
with O
X O
- O
chromosome O
escapee O
genes O
. O

Sex O
differences O
in O
cerebral O
asymmetry O
are O
moderated O
by O
sex O
hormones O
and O
X O
- O
chromosome O
genes O
, O
in O
a O
regionally O
differentiated O
manner O
. O

Preliminary O
results O
of O
a O
prospective O
study O
of O
testicular O
sperm O
extraction O
in O
young O
versus O
adult O
patients O
with O
nonmosaic O
47 O
, O
XXY O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Testicular O
sperm O
extraction O
( O
TESE O
) O
in O
adult O
patients O
with O
nonmosaic O
47 O
, O
XXY O
provides O
a O
sperm O
retrieval O
rate O
( O
SRR O
) O
of O
approximately O
50 O
% O
. O

Age O
is O
the O
only O
significant O
prognostic O
factor O
. O

Whether O
TESE O
should O
be O
performed O
in O
adolescent O
patients O
for O
sperm O
cryopreservation O
remains O
to O
be O
determined O
. O

The O
objective O
of O
the O
study O
was O
to O
compare O
SRR O
between O
young O
( O
15 O
- O
23 O
y O
) O
and O
adult O
( O
> O
23 O
y O
) O
patients O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
and O
to O
determine O
whether O
previous O
androgenic O
treatment O
had O
a O
deleterious O
effect O
. O

We O
designed O
a O
prospective O
comparative O
study O
between O
two O
groups O
enrolled O
in O
parallel O
from O
September O
2010 O
onward O
. O

University O
hospital O
. O

Forty O
one O
patients O
with O
nonmosaic O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
and O
azoospermia O
were O
included O
. O

Twenty O
five O
patients O
from O
15 O
- O
22 O
years O
of O
age O
were O
assigned O
to O
the O
" O
Young O
" O
group O
, O
and O
16 O
patients O
age O
23 O
years O
or O
more O
, O
to O
the O
" O
Adult O
" O
group O
. O

A O
bilateral O
testicular O
open O
biopsy O
was O
performed O
by O
a O
single O
surgeon O
. O

The O
reproductive O
biologist O
who O
performed O
TESE O
was O
blind O
to O
the O
patient O
' O
s O
age O
. O

Principal O
Outcome O
Measure O
: O
The O
main O
outcome O
measure O
was O
the O
SRR O
. O

The O
TESE O
procedure O
was O
considered O
positive O
if O
at O
least O
20 O
sperm O
cells O
could O
be O
cryopreserved O
for O
intracytoplasmic O
sperm O
injection O
. O

SRR O
was O
13 O
/ O
25 O
= O
52 O
% O
in O
the O
Young O
group O
and O
10 O
/ O
16 O
= O

. O

Identification O

Successful O

in O

To O

( O

Most O

3 O

/ O

in O

Testicular O

has O

in O

. O

Their O

. O

X O
- O

inactivation O
patterns O
and O

. O

) O

In O
77 O

with O

of O

. O

Forty O
- O

and O
received O

; O

The O

was O

. O

CAGn O
length O
was O

associated O
with O
body O

. O

of O

. O

was O

. O

There O
was O

with O

to O

diagnosed O

in O

. O

in O

: O

on O

. O

of O

2078 O

Validation O

Microdeletions O
of O
the O

( O

) O
, O

( O

are O

Here O
, O

of O

( O

, O

1 O
, O

In O

This O

in O

patients O
( O
1 O
% O
- O
1 O
. O

) O
, O

are O

linked O
to O

In O

, O
we O
developed O

to O
reliably O

The O

of O

. O

Multicenter O
study O
of O
genetic O
abnormalities O
associated O
with O
severe O
oligospermia O
and O
non O
- O

. O

Objective O
* O
Chong O
Xie O
, O
Xiangfeng O
Chen O
, O
and O
Yulin O
Liu O
contributed O
equally O
to O
this O
work O
. O

Genetic O
defects O
are O
identified O
in O
nearly O
20 O
% O
of O
infertile O
males O
. O

Determining O
the O
frequency O
and O
types O
of O
major O
genetic O
abnormalities O
in O
severe O
male O
infertility O
helps O
inform O
appropriate O
genetic O
counseling O
before O
assisted O
reproductive O
techniques O
. O

Methods O
Cytogenetic O
results O
of O
912 O
patients O
with O
non O
- O
obstructive O
azoospermia O
( O
NOA O
) O
and O
severe O
oligozoospermia O
( O
SOS O
) O
in O
Eastern O
China O
were O
reviewed O
in O
this O
multicenter O
study O
from O
January O
2011 O
to O
December O
2015 O
. O

Controls O
were O
215 O
normozoospermic O
men O
with O
offspring O
. O

Results O
Among O
all O
patients O
, O
22 O
. O
6 O
% O
( O
206 O
/ O
912 O
) O
had O
genetic O
abnormalities O
, O
including O
27 O
. O
3 O
% O
( O
146 O
/ O
534 O
) O
of O
NOA O
patients O
and O
15 O
. O
9 O
% O
( O
60 O
/ O
378 O
) O
of O
SOS O
patients O
. O

Chromosomal O
abnormalities O
( O
all O
autosomal O
) O
were O
detected O
in O
only O
1 O
. O
9 O

Complexities O

MECHANISMS O
IN O

: O
Aberrations O
of O
the O
X O
chromosome O
as O

of O

. O

Male O
infertility O
is O
most O
commonly O
caused O
by O
spermatogenetic O
failure O
, O
clinically O
noted O
as O
oligo O
- O
or O

- O

. O

Today O
, O

approximately O
20 O
% O
of O
azoospermic O
patients O

can O

. O

The O

of O

( O

( O
47 O
, O

) O

. O

Consistent O
with O

' O

, O

is O

Rapid O

. O

have O

that O

and O

are O

. O

The O
largest O
study O
found O
19 O
. O

- O
and O
57 O
. O
8 O
- O
fold O
increases O
in O

and O

, O

% O
lower O

, O

that O

to O

. O

Altered O
hormone O
levels O
( O
especially O
the O
ratio O
of O
oestrogens O
to O
androgens O
) O
, O
administration O
of O
exogenous O
androgens O
, O
gynaecomastia O
and O
genetic O
factors O
have O
been O
offered O
as O
possible O
explanations O
for O
the O
high O
risks O
. O

Additional O
well O
- O
designed O
epidemiologic O
studies O
are O
needed O
to O
clarify O
which O
patients O
with O
KS O
are O
at O
a O
high O
risk O
of O
developing O
MBC O
and O
to O
distinguish O
between O
possible O
predisposing O
factors O
, O
including O
altered O
endogenous O
hormones O
. O

Fertility O
preservation O
in O
adolescents O
with O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
one O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
and O
is O
characterized O
by O
hypergonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
and O
infertility O
. O

Some O
men O
with O
non O
- O
mosaic O
syndrome O
have O
azoospermia O
and O
only O
few O
have O
oligospermia O
. O

In O
adult O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
germ O
cell O
aplasia O
, O
total O
tubular O
atrophy O
or O
hyalinising O
fibrosis O
and O
relative O
hyperplasia O
of O
Leydig O
cells O
are O
found O
. O

Occasionally O
, O
single O
foci O
of O
spermatogenesis O
do O
exist O
in O
the O
testes O
. O

The O
mechanisms O
leading O
to O
degeneration O
of O
seminiferous O
tubules O
are O
unknown O
. O

But O
this O
process O
accelerates O
dramatically O
at O
the O
time O
of O
puberty O
. O

Therefore O
, O
the O
preservation O
of O
reproductive O
potential O
for O
a O
chromosopathy O
that O
for O
years O
has O
been O
synonymous O
of O
sterility O
may O
offer O
to O
KS O
subjects O
the O
ability O
to O
father O
genetically O
own O
their O
child O
and O
may O
have O
significant O
psychological O
consequences O
in O
adulthood O
. O

In O
non O
- O
mosaic O
KS O
, O
pregnancy O
have O
been O
reported O
using O
intracytoplasmic O
sperm O
injection O
( O
ICSI O
) O
with O

. O

In O
azoospermic O
KS O
men O
, O
ICSI O
using O
testicular O
spermatozoa O
retrieved O
with O
micro O
- O
testicular O
extracted O
sperm O
( O
TESE O
) O
is O
the O
sole O
mode O
of O
treatment O
that O
can O
be O
offered O
, O
besides O
sperm O
donation O
. O

These O
issues O
are O
addressed O
here O
with O
the O
aim O
of O
assisting O
physicians O
in O
the O
management O
of O
adolescents O
with O
KS O
. O

The O
spectrum O
of O
the O
behavioral O
phenotype O
in O
boys O
and O
adolescents O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
) O
. O

The O
behavioral O
phenotype O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
) O
includes O
increased O
risks O
for O
developmental O
delays O
, O
language O
- O
based O
learning O
disabilities O
, O
executive O
dysfunction O
/ O
ADHD O
, O
and O
socialemotional O
difficulties O
. O

However O
there O
is O
significant O
variability O
between O
individuals O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
and O
many O
children O
and O
adolescents O
have O
minimal O
or O
no O
behavioral O
features O
while O
others O
have O
quite O
significant O
involvement O
. O

This O
paper O
describes O
behavioral O
features O
in O
a O
cohort O
of O
57 O
children O
and O
adolescents O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
including O
results O
on O
standardized O
measures O
of O
behavior O
( O
BASC O
- O
2 O
) O
, O
attention O
( O
Conner O
' O
s O
Rating O
Scales O
) O
, O
and O
social O
skills O
( O
Social O
Responsiveness O
Scale O
) O
. O

A O
subset O
was O
directly O
assessed O
for O
autism O
spectrum O
disorders O
using O
the O
ADOS O
and O
ADIR O
. O

We O
discuss O
our O
results O
within O
the O
context O
of O
previous O
literature O
, O
including O
implications O
for O
genetic O
counseling O
, O
recommendations O
for O
care O
, O
and O
areas O
for O
future O
research O
. O

[ O
Fertility O
in O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
] O
. O

In O
the O
past O
10 O
years O
, O
our O
knowledge O
about O
fertility O
chances O
of O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
has O
changed O
considerably O
, O
especially O
when O
regarding O
the O
possibility O
of O
IVF O
ICSI O
treatment O
( O
in O
vitro O
fertilisation O
, O
intracytoplasmic O
sperm O
injection O
) O
with O
single O
testicular O
spermatozoa O
. O

Thus O
, O
it O
is O
important O
to O
take O
this O
knowledge O
into O
consideration O
when O
counselling O
Klinefelter O
patients O
. O
Germ O
cell O
degeneration O
in O
the O
testicles O
of O
Klinefelter O
patients O
due O
to O
their O
additional O
X O
chromosome O
is O
an O
important O
phenomenon O
in O
this O
disease O
which O
is O
not O
yet O
fully O
understood O
. O

When O
entering O
puberty O
, O
the O
testicular O
volume O
of O
KS O
patients O
increases O
for O
a O
short O
time O
with O
rising O
testosterone O
and O
inhibin O
B O
levels O
at O
the O
same O
time O
. O

These O
decrease O
, O
however O
, O
and O
FSH O
increases O
during O
puberty O
. O

This O
seems O
to O
indicate O
a O
critical O
point O
in O
time O
when O
spermatogenetic O
function O
of O
the O
testicles O
could O
still O
be O
existent O
. O

Thus O
, O
in O
early O
puberty O
there O
could O
possibly O
be O
a O
time O
slot O
when O
spermatozoa O
could O
be O
detected O
in O
the O
ejaculate O
or O
- O
if O
not O
- O
at O
least O
in O
the O
testicular O
tissue O
. O

These O
could O
be O
extracted O
by O
testicular O
sperm O
extraction O
, O
cryopreserved O
and O
used O
for O
intracytoplasmic O
sperm O
injection O
therapy O
later O
on O
. O

In O
the O
literature O
, O
a O
total O
of O
133 O
births O
of O
children O
from O
Klinefelter O
fathers O
have O
been O
reported O
. O

This O
early O
specific O
procedure O
could O
lead O
to O
a O
better O
acceptance O
of O
their O
diagnosis O
and O
also O
offer O
the O
option O
of O
not O
being O
incurably O
infertile O
. O

Variable O
associations O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
in O
children O
. O

KF O
is O
characterized O
by O
heterogeneity O
in O
the O
degree O
of O
expressed O
phenotypes O
. O
to O
ascertain O
the O
variable O
phenotypes O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
in O
children O
. O

We O
present O
eight O
klinefelter O
patients O
, O
their O
age O
ranged O
from O
2 O
to O
11 O
years O
( O
mean O
6 O
. O
63 O
) O
. O

Subjects O
were O
meticulously O
examined O
for O
evidence O
of O
dysmorphology O
. O

Intelligence O
quotient O
was O
estimated O
. O

Cytogenetic O
analysis O
revealed O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
in O
all O
patients O
. O

The O
following O
was O
detected O
: O
Dysmorphism O
in O
5 O
/ O
8 O
, O
micropenis O
in O
4 O
/ O
8 O
, O
the O
left O
testis O
was O
nonpalpable O
in O
4 O
/ O
8 O
, O
short O
stature O
in O
4 O
/ O
8 O
, O
congenital O
cardiac O
malformations O
in O
4 O
/ O
8 O
, O
seizures O
in O
4 O
/ O
8 O
, O
mental O
retardation O
in O
5 O
/ O
8 O
, O
growth O
hormone O
deficiency O
in O
2 O
/ O
8 O
, O
hypothyroidism O
and O
delayed O
bone O
age O
in O
1 O
/ O
8 O
. O

Our O
study O
demonstrated O
a O
variable O
association O
of O
mental O
retardation O
, O
dysmorphism O
, O
micropenis O
, O
undescended O
testis O
, O
seizures O
, O
congenital O
heart O
defects O
, O
and O
growth O
hormone O
deficiency O
among O
Egyptian O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

This O
merits O
further O
study O
to O
facilitate O
earlier O
diagnosis O
and O
better O
management O
to O
improve O
their O
quality O
of O
life O
. O

Meiotic O
studies O
of O
a O
38 O
, O
XY O
/ O
39 O
, O
XXY O
mosaic O
boar O
. O

Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
chromosome O
abnormality O
identified O
in O
human O
males O
. O

This O
syndrome O
is O
generally O
associated O
with O
infertility O
. O

Men O
with O
KS O
may O
have O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
or O
a O
46 O
, O
XY O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

Studies O
carried O
out O
in O
humans O
and O
mice O
suggest O
that O
only O
XY O
cells O
are O
able O
to O
enter O
and O
complete O
meiosis O
. O

These O
cells O
could O
originate O
from O
the O
XY O
cells O
present O
in O
mosaic O
patients O
or O
from O
XXY O
cells O
that O
have O
lost O
one O
X O
chromosome O
. O

In O
pig O
, O
only O
3 O
cases O
of O
pure O
39 O
, O
XXY O
have O
been O
reported O
until O
now O
, O
and O
no O
meiotic O
analysis O
was O
carried O
out O
. O

For O
the O
first O
time O
in O
pig O
species O
we O
report O
the O
analysis O
of O
a O
38 O
, O
XY O
/ O
39 O
, O
XXY O
boar O
and O
describe O
the O
origin O
of O
the O
supplementary O
X O
chromosome O
and O
the O
chromosomal O
constitutions O
of O
the O
germ O
and O
Sertoli O
cells O
. O

[ O
35 O
- O
year O
old O
patient O
with O
severe O
thromboembolism O
] O
. O

We O
report O
a O
case O
of O
a O
35 O
year O
old O
male O
with O

of O

lower O

on O
both O
sides O
and O
pulmonary O

. O

A O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
mosaic O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
[ O
81 O
% O
] O
/ O
48 O
, O
XXXY O
[ O
19 O
% O
] O
) O
was O
diagnosed O
. O

Because O
no O

cause O
for O
this O

was O

that O
in O

, O

' O

. O

In O

, O

unusual O
habitus O

as O

. O

Testosterone O
substitution O
therapy O
should O
be O
started O
in O
all O

with O
Klinefelter O

s O
syndrome O
to O
prevent O
further O
disease O
. O

Association O
between O
venous O
leg O
ulcers O

. O

We O

) O

. O

were O
performed O
due O
to O

young O
age O
for O

of O

. O

The O

behind O

of O

in O

with O

of O

is O
incompletely O

. O

Involvement O
of O

- O
1 O
levels O
in O

of O

in O

Notably O
, O

patient O
with O
47 O
, O

/ O
48 O
, O

presented O
with O
androgen O
deficiency O
but O
normal O
plasminogen O
activator O

- O
1 O
activity O
. O

A O
case O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O
mosaicism O
( O
46 O
, O
XY O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
, O
associated O
with O
anorexia O
nervosa O
. O

We O
report O
the O
case O
of O
a O
12 O
. O
4 O
- O
yr O
- O
old O
boy O
who O
presented O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
mosaicism O
( O
46 O
, O
XY O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
, O
associated O
with O
mental O
retardation O
and O
anorexia O
nervosa O
( O
AN O
) O
. O

KS O
was O

before O

in O
a O

unit O
. O

The O
patient O
was O
referred O
to O
a O

. O

The O

and O

to O

. O

The O

were O
: O

, O
short O

and O

. O

Cytogenetic O
analysis O
revealed O
a O
mosaicism O
, O
46 O
, O
XY O
[ O
11 O
] O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
[ O
19 O
] O
karyotype O
. O

The O
psychiatric O
assessment O
demonstrated O
the O
presence O
of O
AN O
and O
low O
mood O
. O

No O
specific O

links O
between O
the O

of O

of O

should O
be O

of O

. O

In O

- O

boys O

of O
KS O
should O
be O
considered O
, O

of O

of O

. O

Nevertheless O
, O

shows O
that O

can O
be O
first O

during O

for O

Few O

This O

of O

, O
mosaicism O
( O
46 O
, O
XY O
/ O
47 O
, O

) O

with O

. O

, O

between O

and O

, O
a O

. O

[ O
Fertility O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
] O
. O

In O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
with O
non O
- O
mosaic O
47 O
, O
XXY O
caryotype O
, O
a O
biological O
paternity O
can O
be O
obtained O
by O
TEsticular O
Sperm O
Extraction O
and O
Intra O
- O
Cytoplasmic O
sperm O
injection O
( O
TESE O
- O
ICSI O
) O
. O

TESE O
is O
positive O
in O
about O
50 O
% O
of O
the O
cases O
in O
published O
series O
of O
non O
- O
mosaic O
47 O
, O
XXY O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Age O
is O
the O
main O
prognosis O
factor O
for O
TESE O
. O

Among O
patients O
seeking O
children O
, O
the O
percentage O
of O
positive O
TESE O
is O
higher O
in O
younger O
men O
. O

Sperm O
cells O
are O
extracted O
from O
focal O
spermatogenesis O
. O

They O
differenciate O
from O
spermatogonia O
which O
have O
corrected O
their O
chromosome O
complement O
( O
46 O
, O
XY O
) O
. O

The O
risk O
of O
aneuploidy O
is O
similar O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
and O
in O
non O
- O
obstructive O
azoospermia O
with O
normal O
caryotype O
. O

Among O
more O
than O
100 O
born O
children O
reported O
in O
the O
literature O
, O
all O
have O
a O
normal O
caryotype O
. O

Only O
one O
foetus O
, O
within O
a O
triple O
pregnancy O
, O
had O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
caryotype O
. O

Whether O
the O
percentage O
of O
positive O
TESE O
is O
better O
for O
adolescent O
than O
for O
adult O
Klinefelter O
patients O
should O
be O
addressed O
by O
performing O
a O
TESE O
in O
adolescent O
( O
from O
15 O
years O
old O
) O
similarly O
to O
adult O
Klinefelter O
patients O
. O

TESE O
will O
be O
followed O
by O
cryopreservation O
of O
extracted O
sperms O
. O

They O
will O
be O
used O
latter O
for O
ICSI O
when O
the O
patient O
will O
seek O
children O
. O

This O
early O
TESE O
can O
be O
performed O
before O
the O

of O
the O
androgenic O
treatment O
, O
avoiding O
the O
potential O
deleterious O
feedback O

of O
exogenous O
testosterone O
on O
the O

secretion O
and O
on O
the O
focal O

. O

Any O
androgenic O
treatment O
should O
be O
interrupted O
at O

six O
months O
before O

TESE O
to O
avoid O
the O
feedback O
lowering O
effect O
on O
gonadotropin O
secretion O
. O

Social O
attention O
, O
affective O
arousal O
and O
empathy O
in O
men O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
: O
evidence O
from O
eyetracking O
and O
skin O
conductance O
. O

Individuals O
with O
an O
extra O
X O
chromosome O
( O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
) O
are O
at O
risk O
for O
problems O
in O
social O
functioning O
and O
have O
an O
increased O
vulnerability O
for O
autism O
traits O
. O

In O
the O
search O
for O
underlying O
mechanisms O
driving O
this O
increased O
risk O
, O
this O
study O
focused O
on O
social O
attention O
, O
affective O
arousal O
and O
empathy O
. O

Seventeen O
adults O
with O
XXY O
and O
20 O
non O
- O
clinical O
controls O
participated O
in O
this O
study O
. O

Eyetracking O
was O
used O
to O
investigate O
social O
attention O
, O
as O
expressed O
in O
visual O
scanning O
patterns O
in O
response O
to O
the O
viewing O
of O
empathy O
evoking O
video O
clips O
. O

Skin O
conductance O
levels O
, O
reflecting O
affective O
arousal O
, O
were O
recorded O
continuously O
during O
the O
clips O
as O
well O
. O

Empathic O
skills O
, O
i O
. O
e O
. O
participants O
' O
understanding O
of O
own O
and O
others O
' O
emotions O
in O
response O
to O
the O
clips O
was O
also O
assessed O
. O

Results O
showed O
reduced O
empathic O
understanding O
, O
decreased O
visual O
fixation O
to O
the O
eye O
region O
, O
but O
increased O
affective O
arousal O
in O
individuals O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

We O
conclude O
that O
individuals O
with O
XXY O
tend O
to O
avoid O
the O
eye O
region O
. O

Considering O
the O
increased O
affective O
arousal O
, O
we O
speculate O
that O
this O
attentional O
deployment O
strategy O
may O
not O
be O
sufficient O
to O
successfully O
downregulate O
affective O
hyper O
- O
responsivity O
. O

As O
increased O
affective O
arousal O
was O
related O
to O
reduced O
empathic O
ability O
, O
we O
hypothesize O
that O
own O
affective O
responses O
to O
social O
cues O
play O
an O
important O
role O
in O
difficulties O
in O
understanding O
the O
feelings O
and O
intentions O
of O
others O
. O

This O
knowledge O
may O
help O
in O
the O
identification O
of O
risk O
factors O
for O
psychopathology O
and O
targets O
for O
treatment O
. O

Different O
clinical O
presentation O
of O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
in O
monozygotic O
twins O
. O

There O
is O
a O
wide O
variability O
in O

of O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
. O

We O
report O
the O

of O
a O

a O

/ O

, O

( O

. O

Male O
infertility O
in O
Northeast O
China O
: O
molecular O
detection O
of O

. O

The O
prevalence O
of O

of O

( O

) O
among O
azoospermic O

' O
s O
syndrome O
( O
KFS O
) O
patients O
shows O
conflicting O
data O
. O

We O
aimed O
to O
detect O
this O
frequency O
in O
a O
Northeast O
Chinese O

, O

between O

Eighty O
men O
affected O
with O

and O
a O

. O

were O
detected O
by O
multiplex O

chain O
reaction O
using O
9 O
specific O
sequence O
- O

sites O
. O

Karyotype O
analyses O
were O
performed O
on O
peripheral O
blood O
lymphocytes O
using O
standard O

- O
banding O
. O

Finally O
, O

was O
confirmed O
in O
77 O
men O

with O
KFS O
and O
no O

were O

. O

Karyotype O
analysis O
revealed O
1 O
patient O
with O

47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
inv O
( O
9 O
) O
( O

, O

) O

2 O

( O
46 O
, O

/ O

, O

and O
46 O
, O
XY O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
. O

All O
other O
patients O
had O
karyotype O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

Review O
of O
the O

showed O
that O
these O

were O
similar O
to O

Our O

supported O

that O

. O

The O

patients O

among O

, O
and O

might O

. O

These O

suggest O
that O

for O
classical O

. O

Germ O
cell O
loss O
is O
associated O
with O

Lin28a O
expression O
in O

mouse O

' O

. O

Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
is O
a O
male O

- O

( O
47 O
, O

) O

The O

are O

to O

after O

. O

As O

, O

to O

in O

. O

In O
this O

, O

used O
the O
41 O
, O
XX O
( O

* O
) O

to O

the O

line O

. O

We O
examined O
marker O
expression O
of O

cells O

on O
the O

( O

) O

) O

. O

. O

% O

7 O

on O

. O

The O

in O

- O

* O

) O

. O

The O

of O

( O

) O
, O

We O
suggest O
a O
model O
for O
the O
course O
of O
germ O
cell O
loss O
starting O
during O
the O

. O

Neonatally O
, O

marker O
expression O
by O

of O

. O

Subsequently O
, O

entire O
germ O
line O
is O
then O
generally O
lost O
when O
entering O
meiosis O
. O

Factors O
influencing O
parental O
decision O
making O
in O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
of O
sex O

aneuploidy O
. O

To O

toward O

or O

a O

We O
reviewed O

of O

A O

. O

Forty O
- O

( O

. O
45 O

. O

. O

Can O
pubertal O
boys O
with O

syndrome O

from O
spermatogonial O
stem O
cell O
banking O
? O

Although O
early O
development O
of O
testes O
appears O
normal O
in O
boys O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
, O
spermatogonial O
stem O
cell O
( O
SSC O
) O
depletion O
occurs O
in O
mid O
puberty O
, O
leading O
to O
infertility O
. O

Cryopreservation O
of O
SSCs O
prior O
to O
stem O
cell O
loss O
is O
an O
option O
that O
is O
currently O
offered O
to O
boys O
who O
have O
to O
undergo O

treatments O
. O

This O
study O
aimed O
to O
explore O
the O
possibility O
of O
preserving O
SSCs O
in O
pubertal O
KS O
adolescents O
by O
testicular O
tissue O
banking O
. O

A O
retrospective O
study O
was O
conducted O
in O
seven O
non O
- O
mosaic O
47 O
, O
XXY O
adolescents O
, O
aged O
13 O
- O

years O
, O
who O
were O

for O

during O

- O

at O

of O

Brussel O
between O
2009 O
and O
2011 O
. O

- O
embedded O
testicular O
tissue O
was O

and O
stained O
with O
haematoxylin O
- O

, O
and O

/ O

. O

and O

Effects O

The O

in O

. O

Recently O
, O

have O
been O

, O

are O

in O

. O

One O

reduced O

for O

. O

However O

has O
been O
no O
study O
of O

in O

to O

in O

( O

to O

for O

to O

( O

) O

( O

. O

These O

. O

Morbidity O
and O
mortality O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
chromosome O
disorder O
in O
man O
and O
is O
a O
relatively O
common O
cause O
of O
male O
infertility O
and O
hypogonadism O
. O

The O
syndrome O
has O
been O
known O
since O
1942 O
, O
and O
many O
reports O
of O
different O
diseases O
associated O
with O
KS O
have O
been O
reported O
since O
that O
, O
but O
a O
more O

knowledge O
about O
the O
long O
- O
term O
outcome O
was O
not O
described O
until O
the O
last O
decade O
, O
where O
nation O
- O
wide O
epidemiological O
studies O
were O
reported O
from O
Britain O
and O
Denmark O
. O

We O
here O
review O
the O
epidemiological O
data O
from O
two O
cohorts O
of O
patients O
with O
KS O
in O
Denmark O
and O
Britain O
, O
showing O
a O
significant O
increase O
in O

and O

from O
a O

of O
different O

. O

Mortality O
was O
increased O
by O
50 O
% O
( O
SMR O
1 O
. O
5 O
or O
HR O
1 O
. O
4 O
) O
corresponding O
to O
a O
median O
loss O
of O
approximately O
2 O
years O
. O

The O
risk O
of O
being O
admitted O
to O
hospital O
with O
any O

was O

by O
70 O
% O
. O

The O
underlying O
reason O
for O

poorer O
health O
in O
KS O
may O
be O
caused O
by O
interaction O
of O

, O

and O

- O

. O

Both O

in O

to O

. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O
genetic O
form O
of O
male O
hypogonadism O
, O
but O
overt O
phenotype O
becomes O
evident O
only O
after O
puberty O
. O

During O
childhood O
, O
and O
even O
during O
early O
puberty O
, O
pituitary O
- O
gonadal O
function O
in O
47 O
, O
XXY O
subjects O
is O
relatively O
normal O
, O
but O
from O
midpuberty O
onwards O
, O
FSH O
and O
LH O
levels O
increase O
to O
hypergonadotropic O
levels O
, O
inhibin O
B O
decreases O
to O
undetectable O
levels O
, O
and O
testosterone O
levels O
after O
some O
increase O
plateau O
at O
low O
- O
normal O
levels O
for O
healthy O
adult O
men O
. O

Hence O
, O
most O
adult O
KS O
males O
display O
a O
clear O
hypergonadotropism O
with O
a O
varying O
degree O
of O
androgen O
deficiency O
; O
subsequently O
testosterone O
substitution O
therapy O
is O
widely O
used O
to O
prevent O
symptoms O
and O
sequels O
of O
androgen O
deficiency O
. O

Testicular O
biopsies O
of O
prepubertal O
KS O
boys O
have O
shown O
preservation O
of O

tubules O
with O
reduced O
numbers O
of O

, O

and O

have O
appeared O
normal O
. O

The O

in O

are O

by O

and O

of O

, O

of O

. O

However O
, O
the O
tubules O
may O
show O
residual O
foci O
of O

. O

of O

( O

allowed O

- O

father O

. O

Clinical O

. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
the O
most O
frequent O
sex O
chromosome O
disorder O
in O
males O
, O
but O
the O
phenotype O
varies O

We O

A O

of O

aged O
0 O
. O

. O

. O

Data O
on O

, O

( O

In O

Patients O

All O
patients O

smaller O

( O

. O

was O

in O

, O

in O

. O

Novel O

Unusual O

Noninvasive O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
of O
common O
aneuploidies O
by O
semiconductor O
sequencing O
. O

Massively O
parallel O
sequencing O
( O
MPS O
) O
of O
cell O
- O
free O
fetal O
DNA O
from O
maternal O
plasma O
has O
revolutionized O
our O
ability O
to O
perform O
noninvasive O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
. O

This O
approach O
avoids O
the O
risk O
of O
fetal O
loss O
associated O
with O
more O
invasive O
diagnostic O
procedures O
. O

The O
present O
study O
developed O
an O
effective O
method O
for O
noninvasive O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
of O
common O
chromosomal O
aneuploidies O
using O
a O
benchtop O
semiconductor O
sequencing O
platform O
( O
SSP O
) O
, O
which O
relies O
on O
the O
MPS O
platform O
but O
offers O
advantages O
over O
existing O
noninvasive O
screening O
techniques O
. O

A O
total O
of O
2 O
, O
275 O
pregnant O
subjects O
was O
included O
in O
the O
study O
; O
of O

, O

, O
and O

study O
. O

In O

, O
all O

The O

. O

Furthermore O

New O
approaches O
to O
the O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

The O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
, O
with O
an O
incidence O
of O
1 O
to O
2 O
per O
1000 O
male O
neonates O
, O
is O
one O
of O
the O
most O
frequent O
congenital O
chromosome O
disorders O
. O

The O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
causes O
infertility O
, O
testosterone O
deficiency O
and O
a O
spectrum O
of O
further O
symptoms O
and O
comorbidities O
. O

In O
recent O
years O
, O
significant O
progress O
has O
been O
made O
in O
the O
elucidation O
of O
the O
pathophysiology O
and O
the O
treatment O
of O
the O
KS O
. O

It O
became O
clear O
that O
, O
to O
a O
large O
extent O
, O
the O
clinical O
picture O
is O
determined O
by O
gene O
dosage O
effects O
of O
the O
supernumerary O
X O
- O
chromosome O
. O

of O

- O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
: O
clinical O
and O
molecular O
aspects O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
is O
the O
most O
common O
chromosome O
abnormality O
in O
humans O
. O

The O
estimated O
prevalence O
is O
one O
in O
500 O
to O
one O
in O
1000 O
males O
but O
due O
to O
the O
widely O
variable O
and O
often O
aspecific O
features O
, O
only O
one O
in O
four O
cases O
are O
recognized O
. O

The O
most O
specific O
clinical O
features O
which O
can O
be O
observed O
at O
adult O
age O
are O
small O
testes O
, O
gynecomastia O
, O
female O
distribution O
of O
fat O
and O
body O
hair O
, O
slightly O
increased O
body O
length O
due O
to O
an O
increased O
leg O
length O
and O
azoospermia O
. O

Cognition O
is O
characterized O
by O
verbal O
deficits O
and O
psychosocial O
features O
include O
autistiform O
behavior O
. O

Structural O
brain O
abnormalities O
have O
been O
observed O
by O
MRI O
, O
such O
as O
decreased O
brain O
volumes O
and O
a O
decrease O
of O
asymmetry O
in O
areas O
corresponding O
to O
language O
performance O
. O

In O
the O
vast O
majority O
of O
cases O
a O
non O
- O
mosaic O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
is O
observed O
. O

Parental O
imprinting O
of O
the O
extra O
X O
chromosome O
, O

of O

and O

of O

may O
all O
be O

to O

of O

. O

. O

[ O

. O

. O

Genetics O
of O
azoospermia O
: O
current O
knowledge O
, O
clinical O

, O

. O
Part O
I O
. O

We O
reviewed O
the O
most O
recent O
advances O
in O
the O

of O
male O
infertility O
focusing O
on O

, O
and O

. O

To O
update O
our O
previous O
review O
, O
we O
searched O
the O
literature O
using O
PubMed O
and O
skimmed O
articles O
published O
from O
January O
1998 O
to O
November O
2006 O
. O

There O
were O
52 O
, O
30 O
, O
and O
41 O
relevant O
articles O
to O
our O
subject O
on O
karyotypic O
abnormalities O
, O
obstructive O

, O
and O
idiopathic O
hypogonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
full O
texts O
of O
these O
articles O
and O
their O
bibliographic O
information O
were O
reviewed O
and O
a O
total O
of O
93 O
were O
used O
to O
contribute O
to O
this O
review O
. O

The O
frequency O
of O
sperm O
aneulpoidy O
in O
karyotypic O
abnormalities O
such O
as O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
is O
higher O
than O
that O
in O
the O
healthy O
individuals O
, O
but O
transmission O
of O
the O
abnormalities O
to O
the O
offspring O
is O
rare O
and O
the O
outcomes O
of O
assisted O
reproductive O
techniques O
are O
encouraging O
. O

Mutations O
in O
the O
cystic O
fibrosis O
gene O
are O
detectable O
in O
up O
to O
80 O
% O
of O
men O
with O
congenital O
bilateral O

of O
the O
vas O
deferens O
. O

However O
, O
there O
is O
a O

among O
different O
populations O
and O
the O
role O
of O
other O

is O
not O
ruled O
out O
yet O
. O

Autosomal O
and O
X O
- O
linked O
genetic O

in O

. O

can O
provide O
the O

of O

' O

, O

. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
in O
clinical O
practice O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
is O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
- O
chromosome O
disorder O
; O
it O
affects O
approximately O
one O
in O
every O
660 O
men O
. O

This O
syndrome O
is O
characterized O
by O
the O
presence O
of O
one O
or O
more O
extra O
X O
chromosomes O
, O
and O
the O
karyotype O
47 O
, O
XXY O
is O
the O
most O
prevalent O
type O
. O

The O
' O
prototypic O
' O
man O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
has O
traditionally O
been O
described O
as O
tall O
, O
with O
narrow O
shoulders O
, O
broad O

, O

, O

, O

, O

and O
decreased O

. O

A O
less O
distinct O
phenotype O
has O
, O
however O
, O
been O
described O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
is O
an O
underdiagnosed O
condition O
; O
only O
25 O
% O
of O
the O
expected O
number O
of O
patients O
are O
diagnosed O
, O
and O
of O
these O

a O

. O

Patients O
with O

syndrome O
should O
be O
treated O
with O
lifelong O

supplementation O
that O
begins O
at O

, O
to O
secure O
proper O

of O
sexual O

, O
muscle O

and O
bone O

, O

to O

long O

of O
hypogonadism O
; O
however O
, O
the O
optimal O

for O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
remains O
to O
be O
established O
. O

Chromosomal O

. O

. O

. O

that O

. O

Omphalocele O

Root O
lengths O
in O
the O

of O
Klinefelter O
( O
47 O
, O

) O

. O

Earlier O

The O

seems O
to O

. O

in O

The O

in O
47 O
, O

or O

with O

extra O

show O
increased O

, O

. O

There O

- O

tooth O

. O

45 O

Chromosomal O
anomalies O
in O

. O

The O

represents O
a O

material O

of O

was O
high O

Chromosomal O
analysis O
from O

sampling O
of O
259 O
of O
304 O

, O

is O
presented O
. O

An O

was O

in O
61 O
% O
of O

. O

Rapid O
detection O
of O
chromosomal O
aneuploidies O
in O

amniocytes O
by O

- O
dependent O
probe O

( O

) O
. O

To O
test O
whether O

- O
dependent O
probe O
amplification O
( O
MLPA O
) O
can O
be O
used O
for O

13 O
, O

, O

, O

, O
and O

in O

amniocytes O
. O

We O
performed O
a O

study O
based O
on O
527 O

fluid O
samples O
. O

Chromosome O
copy O
numbers O
were O

by O

the O
relative O
amount O
of O
PCR O
product O
of O

. O

Results O
were O
available O

h O
and O
were O

with O
those O
of O

. O

There O
were O
517 O

tests O
. O

In O
514 O
tests O
, O

were O
concordant O
with O
those O
of O

. O

There O
were O
two O

, O
XXX O

that O

by O

. O

Here O
, O

indicated O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
fetus O
, O

the O

was O
46 O
, O
XY O
. O

We O
correctly O
identified O
all O
23 O
cases O
of O
autosomal O
trisomy O
and O
the O

of O

X O
in O

collected O
from O

of O

. O

In O
10 O

was O

to O
an O

amount O
of O
DNA O
. O

Sensitivity O
, O

, O
and O

of O

were O
comparable O
to O

of O

and O

- O

. O

Aneuploidy O
screening O
in O

amniocytes O
by O

is O
feasible O
in O

diagnostic O
setting O
, O

and O
rapid O
result O
in O
98 O
% O
of O
cases O
. O

Chromosome O
abnormalities O
in O
sperm O
of O
individuals O
with O
constitutional O
sex O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
. O

The O
most O
common O
type O
of O
karyotype O
abnormality O
detected O
in O
infertile O
subjects O
is O
represented O
by O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
, O
and O
the O
most O
frequent O
non O
- O
chromosomal O
alteration O
is O
represented O
by O
Y O
chromosome O
long O
arm O
microdeletions O
. O

Here O
we O
report O
our O
experience O
and O
a O
review O
of O
the O
literature O
on O
sperm O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
in O
these O
two O
conditions O
. O

Non O
mosaic O
47 O
, O
XXY O
Klinefelter O
patients O
( O
12 O
subjects O
) O
show O
a O
significantly O
lower O
percentage O
of O
normal O
Y O
- O
bearing O
sperm O
and O
slightly O
higher O
percentage O
of O
normal O
X O
- O
bearing O
sperm O
. O

Consistent O
with O

that O

cells O
may O
undergo O
and O

disomies O

with O
respect O
to O
controls O
, O

the O

of O

disomies O
is O

. O

Aneuploidy O
rates O
in O

with O
mosaic O
47 O
, O

/ O

, O

( O
11 O

) O

lower O
than O

non O

, O
and O
only O
the O
frequency O
of O
XY O
- O
disomic O
sperm O
is O
significantly O
higher O
with O
respect O
to O
controls O
. O

Although O
the O
great O
majority O
of O
children O
born O
by O

injection O
from O
Klinefelter O
subjects O
are O
chromosomally O
normal O

of O
producing O

with O

is O
significant O
. O

Men O
with O

( O

of O

to O

- O

. O

of O

therefore O
transmit O

to O

the O

47 O

Mechanisms O
of O
nondisjunction O
in O
human O
spermatogenesis O
. O

A O
reduction O
in O
recombination O
in O
the O
pseudoautosomal O
region O
is O
associated O
with O
an O
increased O
frequency O
of O
aneuploid O
24 O
, O
XY O
human O
sperm O
. O

Similarly O
, O
individuals O
with O
paternally O
derived O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
also O
have O
a O
paucity O
of O
recombination O
in O
the O
chromosomes O
that O
have O
undergone O
nondisjunction O
. O

Meiotic O
studies O
using O
newly O
developed O
immunocytogenetic O
techniques O
have O
demonstrated O
errors O
of O
chromosome O
synapsis O
and O
significantly O
reduced O
recombination O
in O
infertile O
men O
with O
nonobstructive O
azoospermia O
. O

These O
men O
have O
an O
increased O
risk O
of O
aneuploidy O
in O
sperm O
that O
have O
been O
surgically O
removed O
from O
the O
testes O
. O

Thus O
, O
evidence O
is O
starting O
to O
accumulate O
that O
reduced O
recombination O
has O
a O
marked O
effect O
on O
the O
generation O
of O
aneuploid O
sperm O
. O

Natural O
history O
of O
seminiferous O
tubule O
degeneration O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
is O
characterized O
by O
small O
, O
firm O
testis O
, O
gynaecomastia O
, O
azoospermia O
and O
hypergonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
. O

Degeneration O
of O
the O
seminiferous O
tubules O
in O
47 O
, O
XXY O
males O
is O
a O
well O
- O
described O
phenomenon O
. O

It O
begins O
in O
the O
fetus O
, O
progresses O
through O
infancy O
and O
accelerates O
dramatically O
at O
the O
time O
of O
puberty O
with O
complete O
hyalinization O
of O
the O
seminiferous O
tubules O
, O
although O
a O
few O
tubules O
with O
spermatogenesis O
may O
be O
present O
in O
adult O
life O
. O

Activation O
of O
the O
pituitary O
- O
gonadal O
axis O
at O
3 O
months O
of O
age O
is O
seen O
in O
Klinefelter O
boys O
similar O
to O
healthy O
boys O
. O

However O
, O
the O
level O
of O
testosterone O
in O
Klinefelter O
boys O
is O
significantly O
lower O
than O
in O
controls O
. O

After O
this O
' O
minipuberty O
' O
, O
the O
hormone O
levels O
decline O
to O
normal O
prepubertal O
levels O
until O
puberty O
. O

In O
puberty O
, O
an O
initial O
rise O
in O
testosterone O
, O
inhibin O
B O
, O
LH O
and O
FSH O
occurs O
in O
Klinefelter O
boys O
. O

However O
, O
the O
rise O
in O
testosterone O
levels O
off O
and O
ends O
at O
a O
low O
- O
normal O
level O
in O
young O
adults O
. O

Likewise O
, O
serum O
concentration O
of O
inhibin O
B O
exhibits O
a O
dramatic O
decline O
to O
a O
low O
, O
often O
undetectable O
level O
, O
concomitantly O
with O
a O
rise O
in O
FSH O
, O
reflecting O
the O
degeneration O
of O
the O
seminiferous O
tubules O
. O

Many O
hypotheses O
about O
the O
underlying O
mechanism O
of O
the O
depletion O
of O
the O
germ O
cells O
in O
Klinefelter O
males O
have O
been O
reported O
and O
include O
insufficient O
supranumerary O
X O
- O
chromosome O
inactivation O
, O
Leydig O
cell O
insufficiency O
and O
disturbed O
regulation O
of O
apoptosis O
of O
Sertoli O
and O
Leydig O
cells O
. O

However O
, O
at O
present O
, O
the O
exact O
mechanism O
remains O
unclear O
. O

In O
this O
article O
, O
we O
summarize O
current O
knowledge O
on O
the O
development O
of O
the O
classical O
endocrinological O
and O
histological O
features O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
males O
from O

to O

and O
review O
the O
literature O
concerning O
the O
degeneration O
of O
the O

in O
this O
