. O

Cancer O
incidence O
and O
mortality O
in O
men O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
: O
a O
cohort O
study O
. O

Men O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
have O
one O
or O
more O
extra O
X O
chromosomes O
and O
have O
endocrine O
abnormalities O
. O

Case O
reports O
have O
led O
to O
suggestions O
that O
men O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
have O
elevated O
risks O
of O
several O
cancers O
, O
but O
published O
cohort O
studies O
have O
been O
relatively O
small O
. O

We O
conducted O
a O
nationwide O
cohort O
study O
to O
examine O
these O
risks O
. O

We O
followed O
a O
cohort O
of O
3518 O
men O
who O
had O
been O

diagnosed O
with O

in O

1959 O

and O

with O
that O
of O
men O
in O
the O
national O
population O
. O

All O
statistical O
tests O
were O
two O
- O
sided O
. O

The O
standardized O
mortality O
ratio O
( O
SMR O
) O
for O
all O
cancers O
was O
1 O
. O

( O

% O

= O

1 O
. O

. O

. O

Early O

Klinefelter O

( O

) O
is O

the O

47 O

. O

. O

. O

and O

. O

was O

. O

Thus O
, O

and O

with O

of O

. O

The O

of O

and O

of O

replacement O
require O
further O
study O
. O

Recombination O
in O
men O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
: O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
, O
occurs O
in O
one O
in O
1000 O
male O
births O
. O

Men O
with O
KS O
are O
infertile O
and O
have O
higher O
rates O
of O
aneuploidies O
in O
sperm O
compared O
with O
normal O
fertile O
men O
. O

In O
the O
course O
of O
analyzing O
recombination O
in O
a O
population O
of O
infertile O
men O
, O
we O
observed O
that O
four O
men O
in O
our O
study O
presented O
with O
KS O
. O

We O
examined O
whether O
these O
men O
differed O
in O
recombination O
parameters O
among O
themselves O
and O
relative O
to O
normal O
men O
. O

Even O
though O
the O
number O
of O
men O
with O
KS O
analyzed O
was O
small O
, O
we O
observed O
remarkable O
variation O
in O
spermatogenesis O
. O

In O
spite O
of O
the O
fact O
that O
the O
men O
had O
the O
same O
genetic O
cause O
for O
infertility O
, O
two O
of O
four O
KS O
patients O
had O
few O
or O
no O
spermatogenic O
cells O
that O
progressed O
through O
meiosis O
to O
the O
pachytene O
stage O
, O
whereas O
the O
other O
two O
men O
produced O
abundant O
pachytene O
cells O
that O
had O
recombination O
frequencies O
comparable O
with O
those O
of O
fertile O
men O
, O
although O
one O
had O
a O
significant O
reduction O
in O
fidelity O
of O
synapsis O
. O

Moreover O
, O
regardless O
of O
histological O
appearance O
, O
examination O
of O
outcomes O
of O
assisted O
reproduction O
indicated O
that O
sperm O
were O
extracted O
from O
testis O
biopsies O
in O
all O
four O
cases O
, O
and O
when O
used O
in O
assisted O
reproductive O
practices O
chromosomally O
normal O
babies O
were O
born O
. O

These O
results O
reinforce O
that O
: O
( O
i O
) O
men O
with O
the O
same O
underlying O
genetic O
cause O
for O
infertility O
do O
not O
present O
with O
uniform O
pathology O
, O
( O
ii O
) O
the O
checkpoint O
machinery O
that O
might O
arrest O
spermatogenesis O
in O
the O
face O
of O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
does O
not O
prevent O
pockets O
of O
complete O
spermatogenesis O
in O
men O
with O
KS O
, O
and O
( O
iii O
) O
aneuploidy O
, O
in O
some O
cases O
, O
is O
compatible O
with O
birth O
of O
a O
chromosomally O
normal O
child O
, O
suggesting O
that O
sperm O
produced O
from O
a O
background O
of O
aneuploidy O
can O
be O
normal O
in O
men O
with O
KS O
. O

Origin O
of O
the O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosome O
in O
a O
patient O
with O
fragile O
X O
and O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

We O
report O
on O
a O
10 O
- O
year O
- O
old O
patient O
with O
the O
fragile O
X O
[ O
fra O
( O
X O
) O
] O
syndrome O
and O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

He O
had O
Martin O
- O
Bell O
syndrome O
, O

Genetic O
concerns O
for O
the O
subfertile O
male O
in O
the O
era O
of O
ICSI O
. O

The O
treatment O
of O
severe O
male O
factor O
infertility O
has O
seen O
remarkable O
advances O
in O
the O
last O
five O
years O

and O

of O

injection O
( O

) O
. O

Although O

represents O
one O
of O
the O
most O

in O
the O
treatment O
of O
the O
subfertile O
male O
, O
significant O

for O

of O

genes O
to O
the O
offspring O
because O

of O

to O

. O

these O

to O

- O

in O

. O

Genetic O
abnormalities O
related O
to O
male O
infertility O
need O
to O
be O
considered O
in O
terms O
of O
being O
( O
1 O
) O

for O
male O
infertility O
and O
( O
2 O
) O

transmissible O
to O
the O
offspring O
. O

Reasons O
for O
pursuing O
a O

include O
( O
1 O
) O

a O
diagnosis O
, O
( O
2 O
) O

a O
possible O

origin O
, O
( O
3 O
) O

the O
pattern O
of O
inheritance O
, O
and O
( O
4 O
) O

information O
on O
natural O
history O
, O

and O
expression O
. O

The O
three O
most O
common O

factors O
related O
to O
male O

are O

gene O

, O

- O

leading O
to O

impairment O
, O
and O

abnormalities O
. O

When O
congenital O
bilateral O
absence O
of O
the O
vas O
deferens O
with O
azoospermia O
is O
encountered O
, O
cystic O
fibrosis O
transmembrane O
conductance O
regulator O
( O
CFTR O
) O
gene O
mutations O
are O
commonly O
the O
underlying O
cause O
. O

When O

failure O
is O
manifest O
by O
azoospermia O
or O
severe O

, O

- O
chromosome O
microdeletions O
may O
be O
present O
in O
approximately O
10 O
- O
15 O
per O
cent O
of O
otherwise O
normal O
appearing O
men O
. O

Karyotyping O
can O
uncover O
potentially O
transmissible O
genetic O
abnormalities O
in O
the O
infertile O
male O
including O
structural O
chromosomal O
disorders O
such O
as O

' O
s O
( O
classic O

, O
XXY O
) O
, O

dysgenesis O
, O

translocations O
and O
XYY O
syndromes O
. O

Finally O
, O
potential O
male O

XXX O
aneuploidy O
: O
heterogeneous O
mechanisms O
and O
role O
of O
aberrant O
recombination O
. O

We O
investigated O
the O
parent O
and O
cell O
division O
of O
origin O
of O
the O
additional O
sex O
chromosome O
in O
142 O
males O
with O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
constitution O
and O
50 O
females O
with O
a O
47 O
, O
XXX O
constitution O
. O

In O
66 O
of O
the O
47 O
, O
XXY O
males O
the O
additional O
chromosome O
was O
paternal O
in O
origin O
and O
in O
76 O
it O
was O
maternal O
in O
origin O
, O
while O
among O
the O
47 O
, O
XXX O
females O
only O
5 O
had O
an O
additional O
paternal O
X O
chromosome O
, O
the O
remaining O
45 O
having O
an O
additional O
maternal O
chromosome O
. O

Among O
the O
107 O
maternally O
derived O
aneuploids O
for O
whom O
it O
was O
possible O
to O
determine O
the O
cell O
division O
of O
origin O
, O
73 O
were O
the O
result O
of O
a O
mat O
MI O
error O
, O
24 O
the O
result O
of O
a O
mat O
MII O
error O
and O
10 O
the O
result O
of O
a O
post O
zygotic O
mitotic O
( O
PZM O
) O
error O
involving O
the O
maternal O
X O
chromosome O
. O

Among O
those O
in O
which O
the O
non O
- O
disjunction O
was O
attributable O
to O
an O
error O
at O
the O
first O
meiotic O
division O
( O
MI O
) O
we O
observed O
three O
different O
mechanisms O
of O
origin O
. O

Approximately O
30 O
% O
were O
associated O
with O
complete O
absence O
of O
recombination O
( O
nullichiasmate O
) O
; O
approximately O
24 O
% O
were O
associated O
with O
a O
normal O
number O
of O
recombinant O
events O
but O
an O
abnormal O
distribution O
of O
exchanges O
( O
perturbed O
recombination O
) O
, O
while O
approximately O
45 O
% O
were O
associated O
with O
a O
normal O
number O
and O
distribution O
of O
recombinant O
events O
( O
normochiasmate O
) O
. O

Nondisjunction O
due O
to O
an O
error O
at O
the O
second O
meiotic O
division O
( O
MII O
) O
was O
associated O
with O
a O
slight O
reduction O
in O
the O
total O
number O
of O
recombinant O
events O
and O
an O
abnormal O
distribution O
of O
exchanges O
. O

Thus O
of O
the O
four O
different O
meiotic O
mechanisms O
of O
origin O
, O
three O
were O
associated O
with O
an O
abnormal O
number O
and O
/ O
or O
distribution O
of O
exchange O
events O
. O

There O
was O
no O
evidence O
of O
an O
increased O
paternal O
age O
in O
the O
aneuploids O
of O
paternal O
origin O
. O

True O
hermaphroditism O
: O
genetic O
variants O
and O
clinical O
management O
. O

The O
diagnosis O
and O
management O
of O
22 O
patients O
with O
true O
hermaphroditism O
are O
described O
. O

Sixteen O
of O
them O
were O
first O
seen O
before O
the O
age O
of O
4 O
months O
. O

The O
initial O
manifestations O
were O
ambiguous O
genitalia O
in O
20 O
cases O
( O

of O
them O
identified O
prenatally O
by O
ultrasound O
examination O
) O
, O
isolated O
clitoromegaly O
in O
one O
, O
and O
penile O
hypospadias O
plus O
unilateral O
cryptorchidism O
in O
one O
. O

All O
patients O
but O
one O
had O
at O
least O
one O
palpable O
gonad O
. O

Eleven O
of O
the O
twelve O
patients O
examined O
before O
the O
age O
of O
6 O
months O
had O
basal O
plasma O
testosterone O
levels O
> O
0 O
. O
4 O
ng O
/ O
ml O
. O

In O
older O
patients O
the O
stimulation O
test O
was O
necessary O
to O
demonstrate O
male O
testosterone O
secretion O
. O

The O
most O
common O
peripheral O
karyotype O
was O
46 O
, O
XX O
( O
17 O
cases O
) O
; O
the O
other O
karyotypes O
were O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
1 O
case O
) O
and O
mosaicism O
46 O
, O
XX O
/ O
46 O
, O
XY O
( O
2 O
cases O
) O
or O
46 O
, O
XX O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
2 O
cases O
) O
. O

One O
of O
the O
patients O
with O
the O
46 O
, O
XX O
karyotype O
had O
46 O
, O
XX O
/ O
46 O
, O
XY O
on O
fibroblast O
culture O
; O
four O
had O
the O
SRY O
gene O
in O
their O
leukocytes O
and O
one O
in O
the O
tissue O
taken O
at O
gonadal O
biopsy O
. O

A O
vagina O
was O
found O
in O
all O
patients O
at O
laparotomy O
, O
and O
a O
uterus O
was O
found O
in O
17 O
cases O
( O
as O
a O
hemiuterus O
in O
9 O
) O
. O

Genitography O
failed O
to O
demonstrate O
a O
uterus O
in O
only O
one O
case O
. O

The O
testicular O
tissue O
was O
dysgenetic O
but O
the O
ovarian O
tissue O
was O
normal O
. O

Sex O
assignment O
was O
male O
in O
8 O
patients O
( O
reoriented O
by O
us O
in O
2 O
) O
and O
female O
in O
14 O
patients O
( O
reoriented O
by O
us O
in O
3 O
) O
. O

Spontaneous O
pubertal O
development O
occurred O
in O
the O
4 O
patients O
( O
2 O
boys O
, O
2 O
girls O
) O
with O
gonadal O
tissue O
who O
reached O
pubertal O
age O
. O

We O
conclude O
that O
true O
hermaphroditism O
is O
a O
heterogeneous O
condition O
in O
terms O
of O
its O
genetic O
background O
, O
with O
a O
prevalence O
of O
the O
46 O
, O
XX O
karyotype O
. O

There O
may O
be O
mosaicism O
with O
a O
Y O
- O
bearing O
cell O
line O
limited O
to O
the O
gonad O
( O
its O
frequency O
is O
probably O
underestimated O
) O
, O
a O
paternal O
meiotic O
exchange O
between O
X O
and O
Y O
occurring O
in O
46 O
, O
XX O
cases O
with O
SRY O
, O
or O
a O
lack O
of O
the O
SRY O
gene O
, O
suggesting O
that O
other O
genes O
working O
independently O
of O
SRY O
may O
also O
determine O
testicular O
differentiation O
. O

[ O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
with O
hypogonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
and O
absence O
of O
Leydig O
cells O
] O
. O

Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
is O
characterized O
by O
hypergonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
, O
gynecomastia O
, O
azoospermia O
and O
testicular O
atrophy O
with O
hyalinization O
of O
seminiferous O
tubules O
and O
hyperplasia O
of O
Leydig O
cells O
. O

Some O
cases O
of O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
with O
unexplainably O
low O
levels O
of O
gonadotropins O
have O
been O
reported O
in O
the O
literature O
. O

Two O
additional O
cases O
of O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
with O
hypogonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
and O
absence O
of O
Leydig O
cells O
are O
described O
. O

Crown O
- O
rump O
length O
in O
chromosomally O
abnormal O
fetuses O
at O
10 O
to O
13 O
weeks O
' O
gestation O
. O

Our O
purpose O
was O
to O
investigate O
whether O
fetuses O
with O
aneuploidies O
demonstrate O
evidence O
of O
growth O
retardation O
during O
the O
first O
trimester O
. O

This O
was O
a O
retrospective O
, O
cross O

sectional O
study O
of O
singleton O
pregnancies O
undergoing O
fetal O
karyotyping O
at O
10 O
to O
13 O
weeks O
' O
gestation O
. O

Measurements O
of O
crown O
- O
rump O
length O
in O
135 O
chromosomally O
abnormal O
fetuses O
were O
compared O
with O
those O
in O
700 O
chromosomally O
normal O
fetuses O
. O

The O
median O
crown O
- O

length O
of O
fetuses O
with O
trisomy O
18 O
( O
n O
= O
32 O
) O
was O
significantly O
reduced O
. O

In O
contrast O
, O
in O
fetuses O
with O
trisomy O
21 O
( O
n O
= O
72 O
) O
, O
trisomy O
13 O
( O
n O
= O
11 O
) O
, O
47 O
, O
XXX O
( O
n O
= O
6 O
) O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
n O
= O
6 O
) O
, O
45 O
, O
X O
( O
n O
= O
5 O
) O
, O
and O
triploidy O
( O

= O
3 O
) O

- O

length O
was O
not O
lower O
than O
normal O
. O

At O
10 O
to O
13 O
weeks O
' O
gestation O

with O

18 O

retarded O
, O
whereas O

, O

. O

. O

of O

( O

describe O

. O

of O

. O

and O

. O

The O
literature O
on O

with O

and O

reported O

underlines O

of O

of O

: O

excess O

( O
and O

The O

. O

The O

for O

. O

California O
' O
s O
experience O
with O
low O
MS O
- O
AFP O
results O
. O

The O
California O
AFP O
Screening O
Program O
was O
developed O
to O
offer O
pregnant O
women O
the O
opportunity O
to O
have O
their O
pregnancies O
screened O
for O
open O
neural O
tube O
defects O
( O
NTD O
) O
. O

Because O
it O
is O
unwise O
to O
withhold O
potentially O
important O
clinical O
information O
about O
low O
MS O
- O
AFP O
results O
from O
the O
screened O
women O
and O
their O
physicians O
, O
follow O
- O
up O
diagnostic O
evaluations O
and O

were O
offered O
to O
women O
with O
low O
MS O
- O
AFP O
results O
in O
addition O
to O
those O
with O
high O
results O
or O
positive O

histories O
of O

. O

Between O
April O
7 O
, O
1986 O
and O
September O
30 O
, O
1987 O
, O

275 O
, O

. O

During O
the O

year O
of O
the O
program O
3 O
, O
939 O

were O
seen O
for O

- O

to O

- O

. O

Alterations O
in O
the O

of O
X O

in O
a O

XXXY O
/ O
47 O
, O

. O

It O
has O
recently O
been O
shown O
that O
5 O
- O
azacytidine O
( O
5 O
- O
azaC O
) O
can O
induce O
altered O
replication O
patterns O
of O
the O
late O
- O

X O
chromosome O
in O
normal O
female O
cells O
. O

This O
has O
been O
demonstrated O
by O
bromodeoxyuridine O
labelling O
of O
cells O
late O
in O
the O
S O
phase O
. O

In O
the O
present O
study O
the O
same O
method O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
lymphocytes O
of O
a O
Klinefelter O
patient O
( O
48 O
, O
XXXY O
/ O
47 O
, O

. O

- O

- O

in O

of O

entire O

X O

, O

late O
to O
early O
, O
were O

in O

of O
this O
patient O
. O

These O
results O
indicate O
that O

agents O
can O
not O

of O
individual O

, O
but O
also O
change O
the O
gross O
replication O

of O
multiple O
inactive O
X O

in O

of O

. O

Isolated O
choroid O
plexus O
separation O
on O
second O
- O
trimester O
sonography O
: O
natural O
history O
and O
postnatal O
importance O
. O

This O
study O
was O
undertaken O
to O
investigate O
the O
natural O
history O
and O
clinical O
importance O
of O
choroid O
plexus O
separation O
( O
a O
> O
or O
= O
3 O
mm O
distance O
between O
the O
choroid O
plexus O
and O
medial O
wall O
of O
the O
lateral O
ventricle O
) O
as O
an O
isolated O
finding O
in O
the O
second O
trimester O
. O

This O
was O
a O
5 O
- O
year O
retrospective O
review O
of O
an O
ultrasound O
database O
, O
looking O
for O
singleton O
fetuses O
with O
a O

age O
of O
16 O
to O
26 O
weeks O
and O
a O
finding O
of O
isolated O
choroid O
plexus O
separation O
. O

There O
were O
78 O
cases O
available O
for O
study O
. O

The O
finding O
of O
choroid O
plexus O
separation O
was O
usually O
transient O
. O

Resolution O
was O
noted O
in O
37 O
% O
of O
the O
cases O
that O
were O
rescanned O
within O
2 O
weeks O
and O
71 O
% O
of O
the O
cases O
that O
were O
rescanned O
more O
than O
2 O
weeks O
after O
the O
initial O
diagnosis O
. O

Two O
abnormal O
karyotypes O
( O
trisomy O
21 O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
and O
3 O
cases O
with O
abnormal O
development O
not O
associated O
with O

abnormal O
karyotype O
were O
noted O
on O
neonatal O
follow O
- O
up O
. O

Cases O
with O
abnormal O
development O
were O
quite O
varied O
in O
their O
presentation O
. O

The O
finding O
of O
isolated O
choroid O
plexus O
separation O
is O
usually O
temporary O
, O
resolving O
in O
most O
cases O
within O
4 O
weeks O
of O
the O
initial O
diagnosis O
. O

Most O
infants O
with O
this O

have O
no O

. O

The O

implication O
of O
the O
lone O

of O

21 O
was O
limited O
by O
a O
major O
preexisting O
risk O
in O
this O
patient O
. O

The O
3 O
cases O
of O
abnormal O
development O
had O
varying O
presentations O
; O
the O
causal O
nature O
of O
this O
association O
is O
not O
yet O
clear O
. O

No O
trends O
were O
noted O
between O
the O
changing O
choroid O
plexus O
appearance O
with O
time O
and O
abnormal O
neonatal O
outcome O
, O
but O
the O
number O
of O
abnormal O
cases O
was O
quite O
limited O
. O

Detecting O
sex O
chromosome O
anomalies O
and O
common O
triploidies O
in O
products O
of O
conception O
by O
array O
- O
based O
comparative O
genomic O
hybridization O
. O

In O
recent O
years O
, O
array O
- O
based O
comparative O
genomic O
hybridization O
( O
array O
CGH O
) O
has O
moved O
to O
the O
forefront O
of O
molecular O
cytogenetics O
with O
its O
ability O
to O
rapidly O
characterize O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
at O
resolutions O
much O
higher O
than O
routine O
chromosome O
banding O
. O

However O
, O
array O
CGH O
, O
like O
all O
CGH O
procedures O
, O
has O
heretofore O
been O
deemed O
unable O
to O
detect O
ploidy O
, O
a O
major O
cause O
of O
fetal O
demise O
and O
spontaneous O
miscarriage O
. O

We O
recently O
developed O
a O
CGH O
microarray O
that O
is O
designed O
for O
detecting O
aneuploidy O
and O
unbalanced O
chromosome O
rearrangements O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
introduce O
the O
use O
of O
a O
Klinefelter O
male O
cell O
line O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
as O
a O
control O
for O
array O
CGH O
analyses O
on O
products O
of O
conception O
( O
POCs O
) O
. O

This O
approach O
facilitates O
the O
detection O
of O
common O
trisomies O
and O
monosomies O
of O
the O
sex O
chromosomes O
by O
reducing O
the O
analysis O
to O
the O
identification O
of O
single O
copy O
gains O
or O
losses O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
in O
a O
blinded O
study O
, O
careful O
interpretation O
of O
the O
microarray O
results O
with O
particular O
attention O
to O
the O
sex O
chromosome O
ratios O
between O
the O
patient O
sample O
and O
the O
control O
allowed O
for O
the O
detection O
of O
some O
common O
triploidies O
. O

These O
results O
suggest O
that O
using O
a O
chromosomally O
abnormal O
cell O
line O
in O
array O
CGH O
analysis O
can O
be O
applied O
to O
other O
CGH O
platforms O
and O
that O
array O
CGH O
, O
when O
properly O
performed O
and O
analyzed O
, O
is O
a O
powerful O
tool O
that O
can O
detect O
most O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
observed O
in O
a O
clinical O
setting O
including O
some O
polyploidies O
. O

Cytogenetic O
analyses O
in O

. O

. O

Seven O

of O

, O

( O

, O

) O

Whole O

from O
15 O

gestational O
weeks O
and O
harvested O
without O
using O
fetal O
cell O

. O

in O

and O

. O

All O
slides O
were O

scanned O
to O

. O

have O

4 O
- O

/ O

We O

of O

Effects O
of O
sex O

from O

Variation O

, O

/ O

The O

( O

) O

. O

of O

, O

of O

in O

, O

, O

) O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O

) O

of O

( O

( O

, O
47 O
, O
XYY O
) O
is O
less O
common O
, O
but O
it O
is O
important O
to O
understand O
their O
social O
functioning O
as O
it O
provides O
insight O
into O
treatment O
implications O
. O

[ O
Diagnosis O
differential O
of O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
in O
a O
24 O
- O
year O
old O
male O
hospitalized O
with O
with O
sudden O
dyspnoea O
- O
- O
case O
report O
] O
. O

Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
is O
the O
most O
common O
genetically O
determined O
cause O
of O
male O
infertility O
. O

It O
is O
also O
connected O
with O
higher O
risk O
of O
many O
diseases O
such O
as O
cardiovascular O
disorders O
and O
malignant O
tumors O
as O
breast O
cancer O
and O
germinal O
tumors O
. O

As O
a O
consequence O
of O
phenotypic O
variability O
, O
still O
the O
majority O
of O
cases O
remains O
undiagnosed O
. O
24 O
years O
old O
male O
who O
was O
admitted O
to O
the O
department O
because O
of O
an O
episode O
of O
sudden O
resting O
dyspnoea O
with O
the O
coexisting O
pain O
in O
the O
retrosternal O
region O
and O
a O
state O
of O
anxiety O
. O

Performed O
examinations O
did O
not O
confirm O
the O
diagnosis O
of O
heart O
muscle O
dysfunction O
and O
pulmonary O
embolism O
either O
. O

However O
, O
we O
noticed O
the O
constellation O
of O
the O
specific O
phenotype O
features O
of O
this O
patient O
: O
high O
stature O
, O
gynecomastia O
, O
abdominal O
obesity O
, O
poor O
hair O
growth O
in O
genital O
regions O
. O

The O
hormonal O
tests O
were O
performed O
that O
allowed O
to O
diagnose O
the O
hypergonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
. O

Cytogenetic O
examination O
revealed O
the O
abnormal O
karyotype O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

There O
are O
no O
clear O
references O
as O
to O
diagnosing O
the O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
. O

Probably O
, O
like O
in O
this O
case O
report O
, O
in O
the O
majority O
of O
cases O
the O
diagnosis O
is O
accidental O
. O

Severe O
XIST O
hypomethylation O
clearly O
distinguishes O
( O
SRY O
+ O
) O
46 O
, O
XX O
- O
maleness O
from O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

46 O
, O
XX O
- O
maleness O
affects O
1 O
in O
20 O
000 O
live O
male O
newborns O
resulting O
in O
infertility O
and O
hypergonadotrophic O
hypogonadism O
. O

Although O
the O
phenotypes O
of O
XX O
- O
males O
have O
been O
well O
described O
, O
the O
molecular O
nature O
of O
the O
X O
chromosomes O
remains O
elusive O
. O

We O
assessed O
the O
X O
inactivation O
status O
by O
DNA O
methylation O
analysis O
of O
four O
informative O
loci O
and O
compared O
those O
to O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
and O
Turner O
syndrome O
. O

Patient O
cohort O
consisted O
of O
ten O
sex O
- O
determining O
region O
of O
the O
Y O
( O
SRY O
+ O
) O
XX O
- O
males O
, O
two O
( O
SRY O
- O
) O
XX O
- O
males O
, O
ten O
47 O
, O
XXY O
Klinefelter O
men O
, O
six O
45 O
, O
X O
Turner O
females O
and O
ten O
male O
and O
female O
control O
individuals O
each O
. O

Methylation O
analysis O
was O
carried O
out O
by O
bisulphite O
sequencing O
of O
DNA O
from O
peripheral O
blood O
lymphocytes O
analysing O

- O

- O
specific O
transcript O
( O

) O
, O

kinase O
1 O
( O

) O
, O

, O
heavy O
peptide O
- O

( O

) O
and O
short O
stature O
homeobox O
( O

) O
. O

XIST O
methylation O
was O
18 O
% O
in O
( O
SRY O
+ O
) O
XX O
- O
males O
, O
and O
thus O
they O
were O
severely O
hypomethylated O
compared O
to O
( O
SRY O
- O
) O
XX O
- O
males O
( O
48 O
% O
; O
P O
< O
0 O
. O
01 O
) O
, O
Klinefelter O
men O
( O
44 O
% O
; O
P O
< O
0 O
. O
01 O
) O
and O
female O
controls O
( O
47 O
% O
; O
P O
< O
0 O
. O
01 O
) O
. O

Turner O
females O
and O
male O
controls O
displayed O
a O
high O
degree O
of O
XIST O
methylation O
of O
98 O
and O
94 O
% O
respectively O
. O

Methylation O
of O

, O
undergoing O
X O

, O
was O
not O
significantly O
reduced O
in O
( O
SRY O
+ O
) O

- O
males O
compared O
to O
female O
controls O
in O
spite O
of O
severe O
XIST O
hypomethylation O
( O
51 O
vs O
69 O
% O
; O
P O
> O
0 O
. O
05 O
) O
. O

FTHL17 O
, O
escaping O
X O
inactivation O
, O
but O
undergoing O
cell O
- O
type O
- O
specific O
inactivation O
was O
similarly O
methylated O
in O
XX O
- O
males O
( O
89 O
% O
) O
, O
KS O
patients O
( O
87 O
% O
) O
and O
female O
controls O
( O
90 O
% O
) O
. O

SHOX O
, O
an O

escapee O
located O
in O
the O
pseudoautosomal O
region O
, O
displays O
similarly O
low O
degrees O
of O

for O
XX O
- O
males O
( O
7 O
% O
) O
, O
KS O
patients O
( O
7 O
% O
) O
and O
female O
controls O
( O
9 O
% O
) O
. O

XIST O
hypomethylation O
clearly O
distinguishes O
( O
SRY O
+ O
) O
XX O
- O
males O
from O
Klinefelter O
men O
. O

It O
does O
not O
, O
however O
, O
impair O
appropriate O
epigenetic O
regulation O
of O
representative O
X O
- O
linked O
loci O
. O

Androgen O
treatment O
effects O
on O
hippocampus O
structure O
in O
boys O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
in O
males O
. O

A O
variety O
of O
complex O
clinical O
needs O
is O
associated O
with O
KS O
, O
including O
physical O
, O
cognitive O
and O
psychosocial O
impairments O
. O

Standard O
treatment O
for O
KS O
consists O
of O
androgen O
replacement O
therapy O
in O
adolescence O
to O
offset O
testosterone O
deficiency O
. O

Such O
treatment O
has O
a O
beneficial O
effect O
on O
the O
physical O
and O
behavioral O
manifestations O
of O
this O
syndrome O
. O

Whether O
androgen O
supplementation O
has O
a O
significant O
influence O
on O
the O
brain O
, O
however O
, O
is O
unknown O
. O

In O
the O
current O
study O
, O
we O
examined O
regional O
gray O
matter O
volume O
in O
boys O
with O
KS O
to O
assess O
whether O
treatment O
with O
oxandrolone O
, O
a O
synthetic O
hormone O
analog O
of O
testosterone O
, O
was O
associated O
with O
structural O
changes O
in O
the O
brain O
. O

Specifically O
, O
we O
focused O
our O
investigation O
on O
the O
hippocampus O
, O
given O
( O
1 O
) O
its O
involvement O
in O
KS O
, O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
the O
high O
concentration O
of O
androgen O
receptors O
found O
in O
this O
region O
. O

Structural O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
data O
was O
acquired O
from O
a O
subsample O
of O
boys O
who O
completed O
a O
2 O
- O
year O
double O
- O
blind O
clinical O
trial O
in O
which O
patients O
were O
randomized O
to O
treatment O
with O
oxandrolone O
or O
to O
placebo O
, O
as O
well O
as O
from O
a O
sample O
of O
typically O
developing O
( O
TD O
) O
boys O
. O

Group O
differences O
in O
hippocampal O
volume O
were O
examined O
. O

A O
significant O
main O
effect O
of O
group O
was O
observed O
. O

Pairwise O
comparisons O
indicated O
smaller O
hippocampal O
volume O
in O
the O
placebo O
group O
relative O
to O
the O
oxandrolone O
group O
, O
as O
well O
as O
smaller O
volume O
in O
the O
placebo O
group O
relative O
to O
the O
TD O
control O
group O
. O

No O
difference O
in O
volume O
was O
observed O
between O
the O
treatment O
and O
TD O
groups O
. O

Moreover O
, O
across O
KS O
subgroups O
, O
a O
significant O
positive O
association O
was O
observed O
between O
hippocampus O
volume O
and O
performance O
on O
a O
spatial O
memory O
task O
, O
indicating O
treatment O
- O
based O
changes O
in O
brain O
structure O
may O
underlie O
cognitive O
change O
. O

These O
findings O
confirm O
prior O
reports O
implicating O
a O
role O
of O
the O
hippocampus O
in O
KS O
and O
are O
important O
in O
extending O
previous O
research O
by O
demonstrating O
a O
significant O
effect O
of O
androgens O
on O
brain O
structure O
. O

PCDH19 O
- O
related O
epilepsy O
in O
a O
male O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
: O
Additional O
evidence O
supporting O
PCDH19 O
cellular O
interference O
disease O
mechanism O
. O

Heterozygous O
de O
novo O
or O
inherited O
pathogenic O
variants O
in O
the O
PCDH19 O
gene O
cause O
a O
spectrum O
of O
neurodevelopmental O
features O
including O
developmental O
delay O
and O
seizures O
. O

PCDH19 O
epilepsy O
was O
previously O
known O
as O
" O
epilepsy O
and O
mental O
retardation O
limited O
to O
females O
" O
, O
since O
the O
condition O
almost O
exclusively O
affects O
females O
. O

It O
is O
hypothesized O
that O
the O
co O
- O
existence O
of O
two O
populations O
of O
neurons O
, O
some O
with O
and O
some O
without O
PCDH19 O
protein O
expression O
, O
results O
in O
pathologically O
abnormal O
interactions O
between O
these O
neurons O
, O
a O
mechanism O
also O
referred O
to O
as O
cellular O
interference O
. O

Consequently O
, O
PCDH19 O
- O
related O
epilepsies O
are O
inherited O
in O
an O
atypical O
X O
- O
linked O
pattern O
, O
such O
that O
hemizygous O
, O
non O
- O
mosaic O
, O
46 O
, O
XY O
males O
are O
typically O
unaffected O
, O
while O
individuals O
with O
a O
disease O
- O
causing O
PCDH19 O
variant O
, O
mainly O
heterozygous O
females O
and O
mosaic O
males O
, O
are O
affected O
. O

As O
a O
corollary O
to O
this O
hypothesis O
, O
an O
individual O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
who O
has O
a O
heterozygous O
disease O
- O
causing O
PCDH19 O
variant O
should O
develop O
PCDH19 O
- O
related O
epilepsy O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
report O
such O
evidence O
: O
- O
a O
male O
child O
with O
KS O
and O
PCDH19 O
- O
related O
epilepsy O
- O
supporting O
the O
PCDH19 O
cellular O
interference O
disease O
hypothesis O
. O

Genomics O
- O
based O
non O
- O
invasive O
prenatal O
testing O
for O
detection O
of O
fetal O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
in O
pregnant O
women O
. O

Common O
fetal O
aneuploidies O
include O
Down O
syndrome O
( O
trisomy O
21 O
or O
T21 O
) O
, O
Edward O
syndrome O
( O
trisomy O
18 O
or O
T18 O
) O
, O
Patau O
syndrome O
( O
trisomy O
13 O
or O
T13 O
) O
, O
Turner O
syndrome O
( O
45 O
, O
X O
) O
, O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
, O
Triple O
X O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXX O
) O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XYY O
) O
. O

Prenatal O
screening O
for O
fetal O
aneuploidies O
is O
standard O
care O
in O
many O
countries O
, O
but O
current O
biochemical O
and O
ultrasound O
tests O
have O
high O
false O
negative O
and O
false O
positive O
rates O
. O

The O
discovery O
of O
fetal O
circulating O
cell O
- O
free O
DNA O
( O
ccfDNA O
) O
in O
maternal O
blood O
offers O
the O
potential O
for O
genomics O
- O
based O
non O
- O
invasive O
prenatal O
testing O
( O
gNIPT O
) O
as O
a O
more O
accurate O
screening O
method O
. O

Two O
approaches O
used O
for O
gNIPT O
are O
massively O
parallel O
shotgun O
sequencing O
( O
MPSS O
) O
and O
targeted O
massively O
parallel O
sequencing O
( O
TMPS O
) O
. O

To O
evaluate O
and O
compare O
the O
diagnostic O
accuracy O
of O
MPSS O
and O
TMPS O
for O
gNIPT O
as O
a O
first O
- O
tier O
test O
in O
unselected O
populations O
of O
pregnant O
women O
undergoing O
aneuploidy O
screening O
or O
as O
a O
second O
- O
tier O
test O
in O
pregnant O
women O
considered O
to O
be O
high O
risk O
after O
first O
- O
tier O
screening O
for O
common O
fetal O
aneuploidies O
. O

The O
gNIPT O
results O
were O
confirmed O
by O
a O
reference O
standard O
such O
as O
fetal O
karyotype O
or O
neonatal O
clinical O
examination O
. O

We O
searched O
13 O
databases O
( O
including O
MEDLINE O
, O
Embase O
and O
Web O
of O
Science O
) O
from O
1 O
January O
2007 O
to O
12 O
July O
2016 O
without O
any O
language O
, O
search O
filter O
or O
publication O
type O
restrictions O
. O

We O
also O
screened O
reference O
lists O
of O
relevant O
full O
- O
text O
articles O
, O
websites O
of O
private O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
companies O
and O
conference O
abstracts O
. O

Studies O
could O
include O
pregnant O
women O
of O
any O
age O
, O
ethnicity O
and O
gestational O
age O
with O
singleton O
or O
multifetal O
pregnancy O
. O

The O
women O
must O
have O
had O
a O
screening O
test O
for O
fetal O
aneuploidy O
by O
MPSS O
or O
TMPS O
and O
a O
reference O
standard O
such O
as O
fetal O
karyotype O
or O
medical O
records O
from O
birth O
. O

Two O
review O
authors O
independently O
carried O
out O
study O
selection O
, O
data O
extraction O
and O
quality O
assessment O
( O
using O
the O
QUADAS O
- O
2 O
tool O
) O
. O

Where O
possible O
, O
hierarchical O
models O
or O
simpler O
alternatives O
were O
used O
for O
meta O
- O
analysis O
. O

Sixty O
- O
five O
studies O
of O
86 O
, O
139 O
pregnant O
women O
( O
3141 O
aneuploids O
and O
82 O
, O
998 O
euploids O
) O
were O
included O
. O

No O
study O
was O
judged O
to O
be O
at O
low O
risk O
of O
bias O
across O
the O
four O
domains O
of O
the O
QUADAS O
- O
2 O
tool O
but O
applicability O
concerns O
were O
generally O
low O
. O

Of O
the O
65 O
studies O
, O
42 O
enrolled O
pregnant O
women O
at O
high O
risk O
, O
five O
recruited O
an O
unselected O
population O
and O
18 O
recruited O
cohorts O
with O
a O
mix O
of O
prior O
risk O
of O
fetal O
aneuploidy O
. O

Among O
the O
65 O
studies O
, O
44 O
evaluated O
MPSS O
and O
21 O
evaluated O
TMPS O
; O
of O
these O
, O
five O
studies O
also O
compared O
gNIPT O
with O
a O
traditional O
screening O
test O
( O
biochemical O
, O
ultrasound O
or O
both O
) O
. O

Forty O
- O
six O
out O
of O
65 O
studies O
( O
71 O
% O
) O
reported O
gNIPT O
assay O
failure O
rate O
, O
which O
ranged O
between O
0 O
% O
and O
25 O
% O
for O
MPSS O
, O
and O
between O
0 O
. O
8 O
% O
and O
7 O
. O
5 O
% O
for O
TMPS O
. O
In O
the O
population O
of O
unselected O
pregnant O
women O
, O
MPSS O
was O
evaluated O
by O
only O
one O
study O
; O
the O
study O
assessed O
T21 O
, O
T18 O
and O
T13 O
. O

TMPS O
was O
assessed O
for O
T21 O
in O
four O
studies O
involving O
unselected O
cohorts O
; O
three O
of O
the O
studies O
also O
assessed O
T18 O
and O
13 O
. O

In O
pooled O
analyses O
( O
88 O
T21 O
cases O
, O
22 O
T18 O
cases O
, O
eight O
T13 O
cases O
and O
20 O
, O
649 O
unaffected O
pregnancies O
( O
non O
T21 O
, O
T18 O
and O
T13 O
) O
) O
, O
the O
clinical O
sensitivity O
( O
95 O

. O

. O

In O

( O

) O

( O
95 O
% O

) O
of O
TMPS O
was O
99 O
. O
2 O
% O
( O

. O

. O

, O

. O

( O

for O

. O

The O

were O
above O
100 O

for O
T21 O

and O
T13 O
and O
99 O
. O

% O
( O
98 O
. O
3 O

to O
100 O
% O
) O
for O

, O
X O
. O

Indirect O
comparisons O
of O
MPSS O
and O
TMPS O
for O
T21 O
, O
T18 O
and O
45 O
, O
X O
showed O
no O
statistical O
difference O
in O
clinical O
sensitivity O
, O
clinical O
specificity O
or O
both O
. O

Due O
to O
limited O
data O
, O
comparative O
meta O
- O
analysis O
of O
MPSS O
and O
TMPS O
was O
not O
possible O
for O
T13 O
. O
We O
were O
unable O
to O
perform O
meta O
- O
analyses O
of O
gNIPT O
for O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
because O
there O
were O
very O
few O
or O
no O
studies O
in O
one O
or O
more O
risk O
groups O
. O

These O
results O
show O
that O
MPSS O
and O
TMPS O
perform O
similarly O
in O
terms O
of O
clinical O
sensitivity O
and O
specificity O
for O
the O
detection O
of O
fetal O
T31 O
, O
T18 O
, O
T13 O
and O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
( O
SCA O
) O
. O

However O
, O
no O
study O
compared O
the O
two O
approaches O
head O
- O
to O
- O
head O
in O
the O
same O
cohort O
of O
patients O
. O

The O
accuracy O
of O
gNIPT O
as O
a O
prenatal O
screening O
test O
has O
been O
mainly O
evaluated O
as O
a O
second O
- O
tier O
screening O
test O
to O
identify O
pregnancies O
at O
very O
low O
risk O
of O
fetal O
aneuploidies O
( O
T21 O
, O
T18 O
and O
T13 O
) O
, O
thus O
avoiding O
invasive O
procedures O
. O

Genomics O
- O
based O
non O
- O
invasive O
prenatal O
testing O
methods O
appear O
to O
be O
sensitive O
and O
highly O
specific O
for O
detection O
of O
fetal O
trisomies O
21 O
, O
18 O
and O
13 O
in O
high O
- O
risk O
populations O
. O

There O
is O
paucity O
of O
data O
on O
the O
accuracy O
of O
gNIPT O
as O
a O
first O
- O
tier O
aneuploidy O
screening O
test O
in O
a O
population O
of O
unselected O
pregnant O
women O
. O

With O
respect O
to O
the O
replacement O
of O
invasive O
tests O
, O
the O
performance O
of O
gNIPT O
observed O
in O
this O
review O
is O
not O
sufficient O
to O
replace O
current O
invasive O
diagnostic O
tests O
. O
We O
conclude O
that O
given O
the O
current O
data O
on O
the O
performance O
of O
gNIPT O
, O
invasive O
fetal O
karyotyping O
is O
still O
the O
required O
diagnostic O
approach O
to O
confirm O
the O
presence O
of O
a O
chromosomal O
abnormality O
prior O
to O
making O
irreversible O
decisions O
relative O
to O
the O
pregnancy O
outcome O
. O

However O
, O
most O
of O
the O
gNIPT O
studies O
were O
prone O
to O
bias O
, O
especially O
in O
terms O
of O
the O
selection O
of O
participants O
. O

The O
application O
of O
NIPT O
using O
combinatorial O
probe O
- O
anchor O
synthesis O
to O
identify O
sex O
chromosomal O
aneuploidies O
( O
SCAs O
) O
in O
a O
cohort O
of O
570 O
pregnancies O
. O

Non O
- O
invasive O
prenatal O
testing O
( O
NIPT O
) O
as O
alternative O
screening O
method O
had O
been O
proven O
to O
have O
very O
high O
sensitivity O
and O
specificity O
for O
detecting O
common O
aneuploidies O
such O
as O
T21 O
, O
T18 O
, O
and O
T13 O
, O
with O
low O
false O
positive O
and O
false O
negative O
rates O
. O

Unfortunately O
, O
recent O
studies O
suggested O
that O
the O
NIPT O
achieved O
lower O
accuracy O
in O
sex O
chromosomal O
aneuploidies O
( O
SCAs O
) O
detection O
than O
autosomal O
aneuploidies O
detection O
. O

BGISEQ O
- O
500 O
powered O
by O
Combinatorial O
Probe O
- O
Anchor O
Synthesis O
( O
CPAS O
) O
and O
DNA O
Nanoballs O
( O
DNBs O
) O
technology O
that O
combined O
linear O
amplification O
and O
rolling O
circle O
replication O
to O
reduce O
the O
error O
rate O
while O
enhancing O
the O
signal O
. O

Therefore O
, O
NIPT O
based O
on O
CPAS O
might O
be O
a O
good O
method O
for O
SCAs O
screening O
in O
routine O
clinical O
practice O
. O

In O
the O
study O
, O
we O
intended O
to O
evaluate O
the O
clinical O
utility O
of O
NIPT O
based O
on O
CPAS O
on O
screening O
for O
fetal O
SCAs O
. O

A O
total O
of O
570 O
pregnant O
women O
were O
included O
in O
the O
retrospective O
study O
. O

Maternal O
blood O
samples O
were O
collected O
for O
NIPT O
; O
amniocentesis O
was O
performed O
on O
all O
pregnant O
women O
. O

NIPT O
was O
carried O
out O
by O
BGISEQ O
- O
500 O
sequencing O
platform O
based O
on O
CPAS O
. O

Karyotype O
analysis O
of O
amniotic O
cells O
was O
performed O
by O
standard O
G O
- O
banding O
techniques O
. O
43 O
out O
of O
the O
total O
570 O
pregnant O
women O
tested O
by O
NIPT O
showed O
fetal O
SCAs O
( O
19 O
of O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
12 O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
10 O
of O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
and O
2 O
of O
47 O
, O
XYY O
) O
. O

The O
following O
amniocentesis O
confirmed O
that O
26 O
cases O
were O
true O
positive O
( O
7 O
of O
true O
positive O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
9 O
of O
true O
positive O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
9 O
of O
true O
positive O
47 O
, O
XXX O
as O
well O
as O
1 O
of O
47 O
, O
XYY O
) O
and O
the O
positive O
predictive O
value O
( O
PPV O
) O
for O
fetal O
SCAs O
was O
60 O
. O
47 O
% O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
the O
PPV O
of O
advanced O
maternal O
age O
group O
( O
67 O
. O
74 O
% O
) O
was O
higher O
than O
the O
other O
indications O
group O
( O
45 O
. O
45 O
% O
) O
or O
serological O
screening O
high O
- O
risk O
/ O
critical O
- O
risk O
group O
( O
0 O
% O
) O
. O

NIPT O
based O
on O
CPAS O
could O
be O
a O
potential O
method O
for O
SCAs O
screening O
. O

However O
, O
it O
still O
had O
high O
false O
positive O
rates O
, O
especially O
for O
45 O
, O
X O
. O

The O
pregnant O
women O
with O
fetal O
SCAs O
detected O
by O
NIPT O
, O
especially O
those O
with O
non O
- O
age O
- O
related O
prenatal O
diagnostic O
indications O
, O
should O
be O
advised O
to O
accept O
invasive O
prenatal O
karyotype O
analysis O
. O

[ O
Preimplantation O
genetic O
diagnosis O
( O
PGD O
) O
: O
the O
Erasme O
Hospital O
experience O
] O
. O

The O
clinical O
activity O
of O
the O
preimplantation O
genetic O
diagnosis O
( O
PGD O
) O
at O
Erasme O
Hospital O
was O
carried O
out O
since O
September O
1999 O
for O
a O
47 O
, O
XYY O
patient O
. O

Up O
to O
31 O
December O
2007 O
, O
79 O
PGD O
cycles O
were O
carried O
out O
( O
45 O
couples O
) O
for O
either O
chromosomal O
structural O
abnormalities O
( O
robertsonian O
and O
reciprocal O
translocations O
, O
pericentric O
inversion O
, O
deletion O
) O
( O
n O
= O
41 O
) O
, O
chromosomal O
numerical O
abnormalities O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
47 O
, O
XYY O
, O
45 O
, O
X O
/ O
46 O
, O
XX O
) O
( O
n O
= O
10 O
) O
, O
aneuploidy O
screening O
for O
recurrent O
miscarriages O
or O
multiple O
in O
vitro O
fertilization O
failures O
( O
n O
= O
10 O
) O
, O
autosomal O

recessive O
diseases O
( O
cystic O
fibrosis O
and O
sickle O
cell O
anaemia O
) O
( O
n O
= O
12 O
) O
or O
X O
- O
linked O
disorders O
( O
n O
= O
6 O
) O
. O

A O
total O
of O
475 O
embryos O
were O
biopsied O
for O
genetic O
analysis O
. O

Unaffected O
embryos O
were O
transferred O
in O
58 O
cycles O
, O
resulting O
in O
22 O
pregnancies O
, O
including O
fifteen O
clinical O
pregnancies O
. O

Up O
to O
now O
, O
9 O
babies O
were O
born O
and O
3 O
pregnancies O
are O
still O
ongoing O
. O

After O
a O
learning O
curve O
, O
our O
current O
PGD O
efficiency O
shows O
a O
total O
pregnancy O
rate O
per O
transfer O
of O
60 O
. O
0 O
% O
and O
an O
implantation O
rate O
of O
28 O
. O
6 O
% O
. O

Each O
PGD O
result O
was O
confirmed O
by O
prenatal O
or O
postnatal O
diagnosis O
. O

Our O
data O
demonstrate O
that O
PGD O
is O
a O
valid O
technique O
to O
allow O
couples O
at O
high O
risk O
of O
transmitting O
a O
genetic O
abnormality O
to O
increase O
their O
chances O
of O
a O
healthy O
pregnancy O
, O
but O
considering O
its O
complexity O
, O
patients O
must O
be O
counselled O
and O
selected O
rigorously O
. O

Cytogenetic O
abnormalities O
in O
179 O
cases O
with O
male O
infertility O
in O
Western O
Region O
of O
Turkey O
: O
report O
and O
review O
. O

In O
this O
study O
we O
aimed O
to O
evaluate O
the O
postnatally O
screened O
karyotype O
results O
in O
couples O
who O
were O
referred O
because O
of O
primary O
infertility O
between O
2000 O
and O
2006 O
in O
Izmir O
. O

The O
records O
of O
a O
total O
of O
179 O
cases O
were O
evaluated O
retrospectively O
. O

A O
total O
of O
21 O
cases O
( O
11 O
. O
74 O
% O
) O
showed O
chromosomal O
alteration O
. O

Thirteen O
( O
7 O
. O
26 O
% O
) O
were O
47 O
, O
XXY O
; O
three O
( O
1 O
. O
68 O
% O
) O
were O
pericentric O
inversion O
of O
chromosome O
9 O
; O
one O
( O
0 O
. O
56 O
% O
) O
46 O
, O
XY O
/ O
45 O
, O
XO O
; O
one O
( O
0 O
. O
56 O
% O
) O
46 O
, O
XY O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
/ O
48 O
, O
XXXY O
; O
one O
( O
0 O
. O
56 O
% O
) O
46 O
, O
XY O
, O
t O
( O
X O
; O
1 O
) O
; O
one O
( O
0 O
. O
56 O
% O
) O
46 O
, O
XY O
/ O
46 O
, O
XY O
, O
del O
( O
Y O
) O
( O
q11 O
. O
2 O
) O
and O
one O
( O
0 O
. O
56 O

% O
) O
46 O
, O
XX O
. O

The O
rate O
of O
gonosomal O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
was O
nearly O
three O
times O
higher O
in O
our O
region O
than O
the O
rate O
in O
the O
literature O
. O

Chromosomal O
analysis O
is O
strongly O
suggested O
particularly O
in O
those O
who O
suffer O
fertility O
problems O
. O

A O
male O
phenotype O
with O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
. O

Aicardi O
syndrome O
is O
a O
rare O
neurodevelopmental O
condition O
that O
occurs O
almost O
exclusively O
in O
women O
. O

We O
report O
a O
second O
male O
phenotype O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
with O
a O
typical O
presentation O
of O
the O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
including O
a O
midline O
arachnoid O
cyst O
. O

A O
novel O
CDKL5 O
mutation O
in O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
boy O
with O
the O
early O
- O
onset O
seizure O
variant O
of O
Rett O
syndrome O
. O

Mutations O
of O
the O
cyclin O
- O
dependent O
kinase O
- O
like O
5 O
gene O
( O
CDKL5 O
) O
, O
reported O
almost O
exclusively O
in O
female O
subjects O
, O
have O
been O
recently O
found O
to O
be O
the O
cause O
of O
a O
phenotype O
overlapping O
Rett O
syndrome O
with O
early O
- O
onset O
epileptic O
encephalopathy O
. O

We O
describe O
the O
first O
CDKL5 O
mutation O
detected O
in O
a O
male O
individual O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

This O
previously O
unreported O
, O
de O
novo O
, O
mutation O
truncates O
the O
large O
CDKL5 O
COOH O
- O
terminal O
region O
, O
thought O
to O
be O
crucial O
for O
the O
proper O
sub O
- O
cellular O
localization O
of O
the O
CDKL5 O
protein O
. O

The O
resulting O
phenotype O
is O
characterized O
by O
a O
severe O
early O
- O
onset O
epileptic O
encephalopathy O
, O
global O
developmental O
delay O
, O
and O
profound O
intellectual O
and O
motor O
impairment O
with O
features O
reminiscent O
of O
Rett O
syndrome O
. O

In O
light O

Concepts O
in O
diagnosis O
and O
therapy O
for O
male O
reproductive O
impairment O
. O

An O
accurate O
medical O
history O
and O
directed O
physical O
examination O
are O
essential O
in O
diagnosis O
of O
male O
infertility O
. O

We O
review O
the O
hormonal O
assessments O
and O
specific O
genetic O
analyses O
that O
are O
useful O
additional O
tests O
, O
and O
detail O
other O
evidence O
- O
based O
examinations O
that O
are O
available O
to O
help O
guide O
therapeutic O
strategies O
. O

By O
contrast O
with O
female O
infertility O
treatments O
- O
especially O
hormonal O
manipulations O
to O
stimulate O
or O
enhance O
oocyte O
production O
- O
spermatogenesis O
and O
sperm O
quality O
abnormalities O
are O
much O
more O
difficult O
to O
affect O
positively O
. O

In O
general O
, O
a O
healthy O
lifestyle O
can O
improve O
sperm O
quality O
. O

A O
few O
men O
have O
conditions O
in O
which O
evidence O
- O
based O
therapies O
can O
increase O
their O
chances O
for O
natural O
conception O
. O

In O
this O
second O
of O
two O
papers O
in O
The O
Lancet O
Diabetes O
and O
Endocrinology O
Series O
on O
male O
reproductive O
impairment O
, O
we O
examine O
the O
agreements O
and O
controversies O
that O
surround O
several O
of O
these O
conditions O
. O

When O
we O
are O
not O
able O
to O
cure O
, O
correct O
, O
or O
mitigate O
the O
cause O
of O
conditions O
such O
as O
severe O
oligozoospermia O
, O
non O
- O
remedial O
ductal O
obstruction O
, O
and O
absence O
of O
sperm O
fertilising O
ability O
, O
assisted O
reproductive O
technologies O
, O
such O
as O
in O
- O
vitro O
fertilisation O
( O

) O
with O
intracytoplasmic O
sperm O
injection O
( O
ICSI O
) O
, O
can O
be O
used O
as O
an O
adjunctive O
measure O
to O
allow O
for O
biological O
paternity O
. O

Not O
considered O
possible O
just O
two O
decades O
ago O
, O
azoospermia O
due O
to O
testicular O
failure O
, O
including O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
) O
, O
is O
now O
treatable O
in O
approximately O
50 O
% O
of O
cases O
when O

surgical O
harvesting O
of O
testicular O
sperm O
and O
ICSI O
. O

Although O
genetic O
fatherhood O
is O
now O
possible O
for O
many O
men O
previously O
considered O
sterile O
, O
it O
is O
crucial O
to O
discover O
and O
abrogate O
causes O
as O
best O
possible O
, O
provide O
reliable O
and O
evidenced O
- O
based O
therapy O
, O
consider O
seriously O
the O
health O
and O
wellness O
of O
any O
offspring O
conceived O
, O
and O
always O
view O
infertility O
as O
a O
possible O
symptom O
of O
a O
more O
general O
or O
constitutional O
disease O
. O

Cytogenetic O
studies O
in O

. O

The O

Caries O

in O

( O

) O

Men O

The O

was O

of O

. O

The O
parental O
origin O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
males O
. O

We O
report O
the O
results O
of O
our O
investigation O
using O
DNA O
markers O
, O
of O
the O
parental O
origin O
of O

males O
ascertained O
during O

of O

and O

with O

from O

of O

males O

or O

. O

In O
the O

group O

of O

in O

latter O
" O
referral O
" O
group O
the O

X O
chromosome O
was O
paternally O
derived O
in O
54 O
% O
and O

derived O
in O
46 O
% O
of O
the O
cases O
. O

The O
precise O
maternal O

division O
at O
which O

occurred O
was O
determined O
in O
39 O

. O

Twenty O
eight O
( O

There O
was O
no O

origin O

to O

. O

There O
was O

. O

of O

. O

This O

for O

in O

of O

. O

A O

survey O
of O
14 O
, O
835 O

. O

of O

Heterogeneity O
of O
clinical O
severity O
and O
molecular O
lesions O
in O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
. O

All O
patients O
with O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
are O
female O
or O
have O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

This O
finding O
, O
along O
with O
a O
report O
of O
an O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
patient O
with O
an O
Xp22 O
/ O
autosome O
translocation O
, O
led O
to O
the O
hypothesis O
that O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
might O
be O
caused O
by O
an O
X O
- O
linked O
dominant O
, O
male O
- O
lethal O
mutation O
on O
the O
short O
arm O
of O
the O
X O
chromosome O
. O

To O
study O
this O
hypothesis O
, O
we O
investigated O
X O
chromosome O
inactivation O
patterns O
in O
peripheral O
lymphocytes O
from O
seven O
patients O
. O

We O
used O
two O
methods O
: O
methylation O
- O
sensitive O
restriction O
enzyme O
analysis O
and O
segregation O
of O
the O
active O
X O
chromosome O
in O
somatic O
cell O
hybrids O
. O

We O
found O
that O
three O
of O
seven O
cytogenetically O
normal O
girls O
with O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
had O
profoundly O
skewed O
X O
- O
inactivation O
in O
their O
lymphocytes O
, O
supporting O
the O
concept O
that O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
is O
X O
linked O
. O

Three O
of O
the O
five O
girls O
with O
the O
greatest O
degree O
of O
psychomotor O
retardation O
and O
the O
poorest O
seizure O
control O
had O
skewed O
X O
- O
inactivation O
. O

In O
contrast O
, O
the O
two O
highest O
- O
functioning O
children O
had O
random O
X O
- O
inactivation O
. O

We O
screened O
DNA O
using O
eight O
polymorphic O
probes O
from O
the O
Xp22 O
region O
but O
were O
unable O
to O
identify O
a O
deletion O
in O
any O
of O
the O
seven O
patients O
. O

Nonrandom O
X O
- O
inactivation O
in O
lymphocytes O
and O
possibly O
other O
tissues O
in O
some O
, O
but O
not O
all O
, O
patients O
with O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
may O
reflect O
heterogeneity O
of O
their O
molecular O
lesions O
. O

[ O

of O

. O

Normal O
cytogenetic O
values O
for O
bone O
marrow O
based O
on O
studies O
of O
bone O
marrow O
transplant O
donors O
. O

For O
individuals O
suspected O
of O
having O
hematologic O
neoplasms O
, O
interpretation O
of O
the O
clinical O
significance O
of O
sporadic O
cells O
with O
chromosome O
breakage O
, O

, O

, O
or O

is O
often O
difficult O
. O

To O
help O
resolve O
this O
problem O
, O
we O
established O
normal O
cytogenetic O
values O
for O
bone O
marrow O
( O

) O
by O
investigating O
219 O
BM O
transplant O
( O

) O

using O

for O

. O

The O

ranged O
in O

from O
2 O
to O

and O
were O

for O
7 O

. O

The O
constitutional O
karyotype O
for O
two O
individuals O
was O
47 O
, O
XXY O
; O
one O
was O
mos45 O
, O
X O
/ O

, O

was O
mos46 O
, O
XX O
/ O
47 O
, O
XX O
, O
+ O

, O

were O

. O

Among O
other O

, O

and O

( O

) O
were O
determined O
for O
any O

of O
chromosome O
abnormality O
, O

loss O
, O

gain O
, O
sex O
chromosome O
loss O
, O
sex O

, O
chromosome O
breaks O
or O

, O

, O

. O

The O
results O
suggest O
that O
random O
loss O
of O
chromosomes O
is O
common O
in O
cytogenetic O
preparations O
of O
BM O
, O
appears O
to O
be O
largely O
technical O
and O
is O
inversely O
proportional O
to O
chromosome O
size O
. O

Cells O
with O
extra O
chromosomes O
or O
with O
structural O
abnormalities O
are O
rare O
in O
normal O
BM O
. O

No O
specific O

structural O
abnormalities O
of O
chromosomes O
are O
associated O
with O
normal O
BM O
. O

The O
widely O

cytogenetic O
definition O
for O
an O
abnormal O
clone O
appears O
to O
be O
valid O
, O
with O

loss O
of O
smaller O

. O

There O
may O
be O
a O
correlation O
between O
loss O
of O
the O
Y O
chromosome O
and O
age O
of O
the O
patient O
. O

Cyclosporine O
A O
( O

) O
- O

decrease O
of O

levels O
in O
a O

' O

We O
report O
a O

of O

' O

who O
developed O
a O
decrease O
of O

after O

for O

( O

. O

A O

- O

suffering O
from O

and O

was O

in O

, O

was O

to O

for O

for O

, O

revealed O
that O

had O

from O

. O

, O

. O

) O

( O

, O

. O

, O

, O

cells O
and O

The O

47 O
, O

, O

of O

. O

( O

) O

[ O
Developmental O
abnormalities O
in O
humans O
] O
. O

Recently O
, O
tremendous O
advances O
have O
been O
made O
in O
our O
understanding O
of O
pre O
- O
and O
perinatal O
death O
and O
congenital O
anomaly O
, O
but O
many O
aspects O
of O
the O
field O
remain O
unknown O
and O
require O
the O
continued O
collaboration O
of O
workers O
in O
many O
clinical O
and O
basic O
science O
disciplines O
. O

Most O
of O
mankind O
dies O
before O
, O
not O
after O
birth O
, O
mostly O
due O
to O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
arising O
during O
pregenesis O
. O

A O
few O
trisomy O
13 O
and O
18 O
cases O
survive O
till O
birth O
by O
virtue O
of O
placental O
mosaicism O
; O
even O
trisomy O
21 O
is O
an O
80 O
% O
prenatally O
lethal O
and O
a O
postnatally O
sublethal O
syndrome O
. O

Most O
aneuploid O
individuals O
surviving O

- O

affective O
disorder O
with O
influence O
syndrome O
, O

, O

. O

- O

( O

to O

One O

We O

, O

. O

heterozygous O
for O
the O
MAOA O
promoter O
polymorphism O
. O

Since O
MAOA O
is O
X O
- O
linked O
, O
the O
heterozygotes O
are O
probable O
cases O
of O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
suggesting O
that O
X O
- O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
may O
increase O
the O
risk O
for O
developing O
type O
2 O
alcoholism O
. O

Morphometric O
and O
cytogenetic O
characteristics O
of O
testicular O
germ O
cells O
and O
Sertoli O
cell O
secretory O
function O
in O
men O
with O
non O
- O
mosaic O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
is O
the O
most O
frequent O
chromosomal O
abnormality O
in O
infertile O
men O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
the O
chromosomes O
of O
round O
spermatids O
and O
spermatogonia O
/ O
primary O
spermatocytes O
from O
men O
with O
non O
- O
mosaic O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
were O
examined O
, O
together O
with O
the O
Sertoli O
cell O
secretory O
function O
and O
sperm O
morphometry O
. O

Twenty O
- O
four O
men O
with O
non O
- O
mosaic O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
and O
nine O
men O
with O
obstructive O
azoospermia O
underwent O
therapeutic O
testicular O
biopsy O
. O

When O
spermatozoa O
in O
the O
final O
filtrate O
were O
present O
, O
they O
were O
processed O
for O
sperm O
morphometry O
or O
ICSI O
. O

Sperm O
morphometry O
was O
evaluated O
by O
the O
maximal O
length O
and O
width O
of O
the O
sperm O
head O
, O
the O
length O
of O
the O
midpiece O
and O
the O
ratio O
of O
the O
acrosomal O
region O
to O
the O
total O
surface O
area O
of O
the O
head O
. O

When O
round O
spermatids O
were O
present O
, O
they O
were O
processed O
for O
fluorescent O
in O
- O
situ O
hybridization O
( O
FISH O
) O
. O

FISH O
was O
also O
applied O
to O
fragments O
of O
seminiferous O
tubules O
. O

Sertoli O
cell O
secretory O
function O
was O
measured O
by O
the O
amount O
of O
androgen O
binding O
protein O
( O
ABP O
) O
secreted O
in O
vitro O
. O

More O
than O
93 O
% O
of O
the O
evaluated O
round O
spermatids O
were O
normal O
. O

The O
proportions O
of O
24 O
, O
XY O
and O
of O
24 O
, O
XX O
round O
spermatids O
to O
the O
total O
number O
were O
significantly O
larger O
in O
men O
with O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
than O
in O
obstructed O
azoospermic O
men O
. O

Men O
with O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
who O
had O
spermatozoa O
in O
their O
testicular O
tissue O
( O
n O
= O
12 O
) O
were O
positive O
for O
both O
46 O
, O
XY O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
spermatogonia O
in O
their O
seminiferous O
tubules O
. O

In O
contrast O
, O
men O
with O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
without O
spermatozoa O
in O
their O
testicular O
tissue O
( O
n O
= O
12 O
) O
were O
positive O
for O
47 O
, O
XXY O
spermatogonia O
but O
negative O
for O
46 O
, O
XY O
spermatogonia O
in O
their O
seminiferous O
tubules O
. O

ABP O
profiles O
were O
significantly O
smaller O
in O
men O
with O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
who O
were O
negative O
for O
spermatozoa O
compared O
with O
men O
who O
were O
positive O
. O

Four O
pregnancies O
were O
achieved O
and O
five O
healthy O
babies O
were O
born O
. O

This O
study O
suggests O
that O
few O
46 O
, O
XXY O
spermatogonia O
undergo O
meiosis O
with O
an O
XX O
pairing O
and O
a O
Y O
univalent O
type O
of O
pairing O
. O

Hyperhaploid O
round O
spermatids O
( O
24 O
, O
XY O
and O
24 O
, O
XX O
) O
may O
be O
produced O
by O
meiosis O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
spermatogonia O
. O

Men O
with O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
who O
are O
negative O
for O
testicular O
spermatozoa O
have O
a O
greater O
degree O
of O
Sertoli O
cell O
secretory O
dysfunction O
compared O
with O
men O
with O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
who O
are O
positive O
for O
spermatozoa O
. O

There O
are O
several O
defects O
in O
sperm O
morphometry O
with O
functional O
significance O
in O
men O
with O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
. O

The O
clinical O
application O
of O
array O
CGH O
for O
the O
detection O
of O
chromosomal O
defects O
in O
20 O
, O
126 O
unselected O
newborns O
. O

Array O
comparative O
genomic O
hybridization O
( O
CGH O
) O
is O
a O
powerful O
tool O
for O
detecting O
unbalanced O
chromosomal O
alterations O
. O

To O
validate O
the O
usefulness O
of O
array O
CGH O
in O
newborn O
screening O
, O
we O
examined O
20 O
, O
126 O
unselected O
infants O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
the O
number O
of O
newborns O
analyzed O
with O
array O
CGH O
is O
the O
largest O
one O
ever O
reported O
. O

A O
total O
of O
20 O
, O
126 O
unselected O
newborns O
were O
investigated O
with O
array O
CGH O
and O
cytogenetic O
analyses O
. O

The O
analyses O
revealed O
87 O
cases O
with O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
. O

Of O
these O
, O
53 O
cases O
had O
significant O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
, O
including O
trisomy O
13 O
, O
trisomy O
21 O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
or O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
and O
the O
other O
34 O
cases O
presented O
partial O
chromosomal O
deletions O
or O
duplications O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
show O
that O
array O
CGH O
is O
an O
appropriate O
tool O
for O
the O
screening O
of O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
in O
newborns O
, O
especially O
for O
the O
infants O
without O
distinct O
clinical O
features O
. O

SNP O
- O
based O
non O
- O
invasive O
prenatal O
testing O
detects O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
with O
high O
accuracy O
. O

This O
study O
aimed O
to O
develop O
a O
single O
- O
nucleotide O
polymorphism O
- O
based O
and O
informatics O
- O
based O
non O
- O
invasive O
prenatal O
test O
that O
detects O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
early O
in O
pregnancy O
. O

Sixteen O
aneuploid O
samples O
, O
including O
thirteen O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
two O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
and O
one O
47 O
, O
XYY O
, O
along O
with O
185 O
euploid O
controls O
, O
were O
analyzed O
. O

Cell O
- O
free O
DNA O
was O
isolated O
from O
maternal O
plasma O
, O
amplified O
in O
a O
single O
multiplex O
polymerase O
chain O
reaction O
assay O
that O
targeted O
19 O
, O
488 O
polymorphic O
loci O
covering O
chromosomes O
13 O
, O
18 O
, O
21 O
, O
X O
, O
and O
Y O
, O
and O
sequenced O
. O

Sequencing O
results O
were O
analyzed O
using O
a O
Bayesian O
- O
based O
maximum O
likelihood O
statistical O
method O
to O
determine O
copy O
number O
of O
interrogated O
chromosomes O
, O
calculating O
sample O
- O
specific O
accuracies O
. O

Of O
the O
samples O
that O
passed O
a O
stringent O
quality O
control O
metric O
( O
93 O
% O
) O
, O
the O
algorithm O
correctly O
identified O
copy O
number O
at O
all O
five O
chromosomes O
in O
all O
but O
one O
of O
the O
187 O
samples O
, O
for O
934 O
/ O
935 O
correct O
calls O
as O
early O
as O
9 O
. O
4 O
weeks O
of O
gestation O
. O

We O
detected O
45 O
, O
X O
with O
91 O
. O
7 O
% O
sensitivity O
( O
CI O
: O
61 O
. O
5 O
- O
99 O
. O
8 O
% O
) O
and O
100 O
% O
specificity O
( O
CI O
: O
97 O
. O
9 O
- O
100 O
% O
) O
, O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
. O

The O
average O
calculated O
accuracy O
was O
99 O
. O
78 O
% O
. O

This O
method O
non O
- O
invasively O
detected O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
fetuses O
from O
cell O
- O
free O
DNA O
isolated O
from O
maternal O
plasma O
with O
high O
calculated O
accuracies O
and O
thus O
offers O
a O
non O
- O
invasive O
method O
with O
the O
potential O
to O
function O
as O
a O
routine O
screen O
allowing O
for O
early O
prenatal O
detection O
of O
rarely O
diagnosed O
yet O
commonly O
occurring O
sex O
aneuploidies O
. O

Cognitive O
and O
medical O
features O
of O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
. O

This O
chapter O
describes O
the O
physical O
characteristics O
, O
medical O
complications O
, O
and O
cognitive O
and O
psychological O
profiles O
that O
are O
associated O
with O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
conditions O
, O
a O
group O
of O
conditions O
in O
which O
individuals O
are O
born O
with O
one O
or O
more O
additional O
chromosome O
. O

Overall O
, O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
conditions O
occur O
in O
approximately O
1 O
in O
250 O
children O
. O

Information O
regarding O
autosomal O
disorders O
including O
trisomy O
21 O
( O
Down O
syndrome O
) O
, O
trisomy O
13 O
( O
Patau O
syndrome O
) O
, O
and O
trisomy O
18 O
( O
Edward O
syndrome O
) O
are O
presented O
. O

Sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
conditions O
such O
as O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
, O
XYY O
, O
trisomy O
X O
, O
and O
Turner O
syndrome O
( O
45 O
, O
X O
) O
, O
in O
addition O
to O
less O
frequently O
occurring O
tetrasomy O
and O
pentasomy O
conditions O
are O
also O
covered O
. O

Treatment O
recommendations O
and O
suggestions O
for O
future O
research O
directions O
are O
discussed O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
diagnosed O
by O
prenatal O
screening O
tests O
in O
high O
- O
risk O
groups O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
is O
a O
chromosomal O
disorder O
present O
in O
1 O
out O
of O
400 O
to O
1 O
, O
000 O
male O
newborns O
in O
Western O
populations O
. O

Two O
- O
thirds O
of O
affected O
newborns O
show O
a O
karyotype O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

Few O
studies O
have O
examined O
the O
incidence O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
in O
Korea O
. O

The O
aim O
of O
this O
study O
was O
to O
investigate O
the O
incidence O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
by O
use O
of O
prenatal O
screening O
tests O
. O

From O
January O
2001 O
to O
December O
2010 O
, O
18 O
, O
049 O
pregnant O
women O
who O
had O
undergone O
a O
chromosomal O
study O
for O
fetal O
anomalies O
were O
included O
. O

For O
fetuses O
that O
were O
diagnosed O
as O
having O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O
the O
patients O
' O
medical O
records O
were O
retrospectively O
reviewed O
. O

Both O
parents O
' O
ages O
, O
the O
reason O
for O
the O
chromosomal O
studies O
, O
and O
karyotypes O
were O
investigated O
. O

We O
found O
that O
22 O
of O
18 O
, O
049 O
( O
0 O
. O
12 O
% O
) O
fetuses O
were O
diagnosed O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

The O
incidence O
of O
this O
disorder O
in O
male O
fetuses O
was O
22 O
of O
9 O
, O
387 O
( O
0 O
. O
23 O
% O
) O
. O

Also O
, O
19 O
of O
the O
newborns O
( O
86 O
. O
4 O
% O
) O
showed O
a O
karyotype O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
; O
the O
other O
newborns O
showed O
karyotypes O
of O
48 O
, O
XXY O
, O
+ O
21 O
; O
48 O
, O
XXY O
, O
+ O
12 O
[ O
12 O
] O
/ O
46 O
, O
XY O
[ O
54 O
] O
; O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
[ O
6 O
] O
/ O
45 O
, O
X O
[ O
1 O
] O
/ O
46 O
, O
XY O
[ O
95 O
] O
. O

The O
mean O
age O
of O
the O
mothers O
was O
36 O
. O
1 O
years O
, O
and O
2 O
women O
had O
a O
past O
history O
of O
a O
Down O
syndrome O
pregnancy O
. O

Nine O
mothers O
had O
a O
normal O
spontaneous O
delivery O
, O
9 O
mothers O
underwent O
artificial O
abortion O
, O
and O
2 O
fetuses O
were O
spontaneously O
aborted O
. O

The O
incidence O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
as O
reported O
in O
this O
study O
is O
higher O
than O
in O
previous O
studies O
. O

Further O
studies O
with O
a O
broader O
population O
should O
be O
considered O
to O
confirm O
these O
results O
. O

Ovotesticular O
disorder O
of O
sexual O
development O
and O
a O
rare O
46 O
, O
XX O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

Ovotesticular O
disorder O
of O
sexual O
development O
( O
DSD O
) O
is O
characterized O
by O
the O
presence O
of O
both O
ovarian O
and O
testicular O
tissues O
in O
the O
same O
individual O
. O

The O
most O
common O
karyotype O
is O
46 O
, O
XX O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
report O
the O
case O
of O
a O
boy O
with O
a O
46 O
, O
XX O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
diagnosed O
as O
ovotesticular O
DSD O
by O
gonadal O
biopsy O
. O

A O
5 O
- O
month O
- O
old O
boy O
presented O
with O
hypospadias O
, O
unilateral O
cryptorchidism O
, O
and O
a O
micropenis O
. O

Pelvic O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
revealed O
a O
suspicious O
gonad O
tissue O
that O
is O
solid O
in O
structure O
in O
the O
right O
scrotum O
and O
a O
suspicious O
gonad O
that O
is O
cystic O
in O
structure O
in O
the O
left O
inguinal O
canal O
. O

He O
underwent O
a O
diagnostic O
laparoscopy O
. O

Cytogenetic O
analysis O
of O
peripheral O
blood O
revealed O
a O
46 O
, O
XX O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

Histopathologic O
examination O
of O
the O
left O
gonad O
showed O
ovarian O
tissue O
containing O
primordial O
follicles O
with O
ipsilateral O
undifferentiated O
tuba O
uterina O
. O

The O
right O
gonad O
showed O
immature O
testis O
tissue O
. O

He O
underwent O
left O
gonadectomy O
and O
hypospadias O
repair O
, O
and O
was O
raised O
as O
a O
male O
. O

Through O
this O
rare O
case O
, O
we O
highlight O
the O
importance O
of O
histological O
and O
cytogenetic O
investigation O
in O
DSD O
. O

Noninvasive O
prenatal O
detection O
of O
sex O
chromosomal O
aneuploidies O
by O
sequencing O
circulating O
cell O
- O
free O
DNA O
from O
maternal O
plasma O
. O

Whole O
- O
genome O
sequencing O
of O
circulating O
cell O
free O
( O
ccf O
) O
DNA O
from O
maternal O
plasma O
has O
enabled O
noninvasive O
prenatal O
testing O
for O
common O
autosomal O
aneuploidies O
. O

The O
purpose O
of O
this O
study O
was O
to O
extend O
the O
detection O
to O
include O
common O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
( O
SCAs O
) O
: O
[ O
47 O
, O
XXX O
] O
, O
[ O
45 O
, O
X O
] O
, O
[ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
] O
, O
and O
[ O
47 O
, O
XYY O
] O
syndromes O
. O

Massively O
parallel O
sequencing O
was O
performed O
on O
ccf O
DNA O
isolated O
from O
the O
plasma O
of O
1564 O
pregnant O
women O
with O
known O
fetal O
karyotype O
. O

A O
classification O
algorithm O
for O
SCA O
detection O
was O
constructed O
and O
trained O
on O
this O
cohort O
. O

Another O
study O
of O
411 O
maternal O
samples O
from O
women O
with O
blinded O
- O
to O
- O
laboratory O
fetal O
karyotypes O
was O
then O
performed O
to O
determine O
the O
accuracy O
of O
the O
classification O
algorithm O
. O

In O
the O
training O
cohort O
, O
the O
new O
algorithm O
had O
a O
detection O
rate O
( O
DR O
) O
of O
100 O
% O
( O
95 O
% O
CI O
: O
82 O
. O
3 O
% O
, O
100 O
% O
) O
, O
a O
false O
positive O
rate O
( O
FPR O
) O
of O
0 O
. O

of O

using O

a O
low O

. O

Testicular O
function O
and O
fertility O
in O
men O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
: O
a O
review O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
KS O
) O
, O
is O
the O
most O
frequent O
sex O
chromosome O
aberration O
in O
males O
, O
affecting O
1 O
in O
660 O
newborn O
boys O
. O

The O
syndrome O
is O
characterized O
by O
testicular O
destruction O
with O
extensive O
fibrosis O
and O
hyalinization O
of O
the O
seminiferous O
tubules O
resulting O
in O
small O
testes O
, O
hypergonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
, O
and O
azoospermia O
in O
the O
majority O
of O
cases O
. O

Until O
recently O
, O
infertility O
was O
considered O
an O
untreatable O
condition O
in O
KS O
. O

However O
, O
with O
the O
development O
of O
new O
advanced O
assisted O
reproductive O
techniques O
such O
as O
testicular O
sperm O
extraction O
( O
TESE O
) O
combined O
with O
ICSI O
it O
seems O
that O
KS O
patients O
should O
no O
longer O
be O
labelled O
as O
infertile O
. O

Especially O
, O
microdissection O
( O
micro O
) O
- O
TESE O
has O
proved O
to O
be O
an O
advantageous O
procedure O
for O
the O
identification O
of O
testicular O
spermatozoa O
in O
KS O
. O

The O
aim O
of O
this O
review O
was O
to O
describe O
current O
knowledge O
on O
the O
testicular O
changes O
occurring O
in O
KS O
, O
the O
associated O
changes O
in O
reproductive O
hormones O
and O
spermatogenesis O
, O
and O
the O
existing O
possibilities O
of O
biological O
fatherhood O
in O
47 O
, O
XXY O
patients O
. O

A O
history O
of O
undescended O
testes O
in O
young O
men O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
does O
not O
reduce O
the O
chances O
for O
successful O
microsurgical O
testicular O
sperm O
extraction O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
and O
undescended O
testes O
( O
UDT O
) O
are O
known O
etiologies O
for O
non O
- O
obstructive O
azoospermia O
( O
NOA O
) O
, O
and O
coexistence O
of O
both O
etiologies O
is O
not O
uncommon O
. O

Patients O
with O
both O
KS O
and O
a O
history O
of O
UDT O
are O
therefore O
considered O
to O
have O
extremely O
reduced O
chances O
for O
paternity O
. O

We O
aimed O
to O
analyze O
the O
impact O
of O
previous O
surgically O
corrected O
unilateral O
or O
bilateral O
UDT O
on O
sperm O
retrieval O
rates O
( O
SRRs O
) O
by O
microsurgical O
testicular O
sperm O
extraction O
( O
mTESE O
) O
in O
azoospermic O
men O
with O
KS O
. O

Age O
, O
testicular O
volumes O
, O
and O
hypothalamo O
- O
pituitary O
- O
gonadal O
axis O
function O
were O
investigated O
in O
relation O
to O
SRRs O
in O
29 O

- O
mosaic O

( O

, O

( O

and O

to O
the O
data O
of O
age O

and O

- O
matched O
non O

KS O
controls O
with O
eutopic O

at O

Screening O
for O
Sex O
Chromosome O
Aneuploidy O
by O
Cell O
- O
Free O

Testing O
: O
Patient O
Choice O
and O
Performance O
. O

To O
study O
patient O
choice O
regarding O
testing O
for O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
( O
SCA O
) O
and O
the O

of O
cell O
- O

DNA O
( O

) O
screening O
for O
SCA O
. O

Patient O
choice O
regarding O
screening O
for O
SCA O
and O
factors O
influencing O
this O
choice O
were O
evaluated O
in O
a O
single O
center O
. O

In O
a O
subsequent O
two O
- O
center O
study O
, O
cases O
that O
screened O
positive O
for O
SCA O
were O
analyzed O
to O
determine O
the O
positive O

value O
( O

) O
for O
each O

. O

In O
all O
, O
1 O
, O
957 O
( O
61 O
. O
9 O
% O
) O
of O
the O
3 O
, O
162 O
patients O
undergoing O
cfDNA O
testing O
opted O
for O
SCA O
screening O
. O

Regression O
analysis O
demonstrated O
that O
independent O
predictors O
of O
a O
patient O
' O

decision O
for O
SCA O
were O
earlier O
gestational O
age O
, O

conception O
, O
and O
cfDNA O
chosen O
as O
a O

method O
of O
screening O
. O

A O
total O
of O
161 O
cases O
screened O
positive O
for O
SCA O
and O
follow O
- O
up O
data O
were O
available O
for O
118 O
( O
73 O
. O
3 O
% O
) O
. O

Forty O
- O

of O
the O
61 O
cases O
of O
45 O
, O

were O
false O
- O
positive O
results O
and O

with O

( O

= O
24 O
. O

) O
. O

Seventeen O
of O

47 O
, O

were O

and O

( O

% O
) O
. O

Eleven O
of O

of O
47 O
, O

were O
false O

and O
19 O
concordant O
( O

. O

% O
) O
. O

All O

, O

were O

, O

. O

More O

for O

, O
but O

were O
less O

to O
do O
so O
in O
the O
presence O
of O
an O
increased O
risk O
of O
trisomy O
. O

SCAs O
involving O
the O
X O
chromosome O
had O
a O
lower O
PPV O
than O
those O
involving O
the O
Y O
chromosome O
. O

Ovotestis O
in O
Adolescence O
: O
2 O
Case O
Reports O
. O

We O
present O
2 O
patients O
found O
to O
have O

disorder O
of O
sexual O
development O
( O

) O
in O

. O

Two O
15 O
- O

male O
patients O
presented O
to O

with O

: O

with O
concern O
for O

after O
a O

injury O
; O
1 O
with O

. O

Further O
workup O
, O
including O

and O

tests O
, O
was O
performed O
before O
surgical O
exploration O
. O

The O

had O

, O

, O
and O

- O
negative O
46 O
, O

karyotype O
. O

The O

patient O
with O

had O
unilateral O
ovotestis O
with O
hemi O
- O
uterus O
and O
fallopian O
tube O
, O
contralateral O
ovarian O
tissue O
, O
and O
46 O
, O
XX O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O

mosaic O

. O

Although O
rare O
, O
phenotypically O
normal O
male O
patients O
may O
present O
later O
with O
ovotesticular O
disorder O
of O
sexual O
development O
. O

Detection O
of O
low O
- O
grade O
mosaicism O
in O
fetal O
cells O
isolated O
from O
maternal O
blood O
. O

Recovering O
and O
analysing O
fetal O
erythrocytes O
from O
maternal O
blood O
is O
being O
pursued O
for O
non O
- O
invasive O
prenatal O
genetic O
diagnosis O
. O

We O
report O
the O
observation O
of O
46 O
, O
XY O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
mosaicism O
in O

from O
a O
woman O
whose O
first O
- O

( O

) O

, O

. O

( O

cells O
found O
in O

. O

Molecular O
analysis O
in O
true O
hermaphrodites O
with O
different O
karyotypes O
and O
similar O
phenotypes O
. O

True O
hermaphroditism O
is O
characterized O
by O
the O
development O
of O
ovarian O
and O
testicular O
tissue O
in O
the O
same O
individual O
. O

M O
ü O
llerian O
and O
Wolffian O
structures O
are O
usually O
present O
, O
and O
external O
genitalia O
are O
often O
ambiguous O
. O

The O
most O
frequent O
karyotype O
in O
these O
patients O
is O
46 O
, O
XX O
or O
various O
forms O
of O
mosaicism O
, O
whereas O
46 O
, O
XX O
is O
very O
rarely O
found O
. O

The O
phenotype O
in O
all O
these O
subjects O
is O
similar O
. O

We O
studied O
10 O
true O
hermaphrodites O
. O

Six O
of O
them O
had O
a O
46 O
, O
XX O
chromosomal O
complement O
: O
3 O
had O
been O
reared O
as O
males O
and O
3 O
as O
females O
. O

The O
other O
4 O
patients O
were O
mosaics O
: O
3 O
were O
46 O
, O
XX O
/ O
46 O
, O
XY O
and O
one O
had O
a O
46 O
, O
XX O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

One O
of O
the O
46 O
, O
XX O
/ O
46 O
, O
XY O
mosaics O
was O
reared O
as O
a O
female O
, O
whereas O
the O
other O
3 O
mosaics O
were O
reared O
as O
males O
. O

The O
sex O
of O
assignment O
in O
the O
10 O
patients O
depended O
only O
on O
labio O
- O
scrotal O
differentiation O
. O

Molecular O
studies O
in O
46 O
, O
XX O
subjects O
documented O
the O
absence O
of O
Y O
centromeric O
sequences O
in O
all O
cases O
, O
arguing O
against O
hidden O
mosaicism O
. O

One O
patient O
presented O
Yp O
sequences O
( O
ZFY O
+ O
, O
SRY O
+ O
) O
, O
which O
contrast O
with O
South O

black O
46 O
, O
XX O
true O
hermaphrodites O
in O
whom O
no O
Y O
sequences O
were O
found O
. O

Molecular O
analysis O
in O
the O
subjects O
with O
mosaicism O
demonstrated O
the O
presence O
of O
Y O
centromeric O
and O

sequences O
confirming O
the O
presence O
of O
a O
Y O
chromosome O
. O

Gonadal O
development O
, O

function O
, O
and O
phenotype O
in O

did O
not O

of O

or O

sequences O
in O

genome O
, O
confirming O
that O
true O
hermaphroditism O
is O
a O
heterogeneous O
condition O
. O

Serpentine O
fibula O
syndrome O
: O
expansion O
of O
the O
phenotype O
with O
three O
affected O

. O

We O
describe O
three O
siblings O
, O
one O
of O
whom O

( O

. O

The O

of O

. O

These O
are O
the O

and O

. O

They O

have O
not O
previously O
been O

as O

of O

disease O
, O

( O

( O

There O
are O
also O
features O
in O
common O
with O
Hadju O
- O

syndrome O
. O

and O

studies O
of O

Intrauterine O
diagnosis O
of O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
. O

To O
provide O
current O
information O
on O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
to O
obstetricians O
who O
encounter O
such O
diagnoses O
and O
who O
counsel O
prospective O
parents O
faced O
with O
the O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
of O
a O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
. O

Unbiased O
information O
about O
the O
natural O
course O
of O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
has O
become O
available O
only O
in O
the O
last O
few O
years O
. O

Current O
knowledge O
is O
based O
on O
seven O
prospective O
studies O
on O
unselected O
individuals O
with O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
identified O
20 O
- O
30 O
years O
ago O
. O

All O
literature O
on O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
was O
reviewed O
. O

Karyotypes O
specifically O
addressed O
included O
the O
following O
: O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
47 O
, O
XYY O
, O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
45 O
, O
X O
/ O
46 O
, O
XX O
, O
46 O
, O
XX O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
and O
46 O
, O
XY O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

The O
international O
studies O
followed O
the O
affected O
subjects O
from O
birth O
to O
young O
adulthood O
. O

All O
published O
reports O
, O
case O
studies O
, O
and O
articles O
were O
reviewed O
. O

All O
prospective O
studies O
were O
included O
in O
the O
course O
of O
determining O
necessary O
information O
for O
obstetricians O
and O
prospective O
parents O
. O

Points O
addressed O
for O
each O
of O
the O
aneuploid O
karyotypes O
included O
expected O
phenotype O
, O
reproductive O
competence O
, O
developmental O
risks O
, O
and O
intervention O
therapies O
. O

Information O
about O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
can O
assist O
obstetricians O
in O
providing O
accurate O
and O
comprehensive O
genetic O
counseling O
to O
parents O
of O
affected O
fetuses O
, O
and O
thereby O
facilitate O
the O
process O
of O
making O
an O
informed O
decision O
about O
pregnancy O
management O
. O

Gonadal O
mosaicism O
for O
incontinentia O
pigmenti O
in O
a O
healthy O
male O
. O

Incontinentia O
pigmenti O
( O

) O
is O
a O
genodermatosis O
that O
segregates O
as O
an O
X O
linked O
dominant O
trait O
with O
male O

. O

The O
disease O
has O
been O
linked O
to O
Xq28 O
in O
a O
number O
of O
studies O
. O

A O
few O
affected O
males O
have O
been O
documented O
, O
most O
of O
whom O
have O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

We O
report O
a O
family O
with O
two O
paternally O
related O
half O
sisters O
, O
each O
affected O
with O
IP O
. O

The O
father O
is O
healthy O
, O
clinically O
normal O
, O
and O
has O
a O
46 O
, O
XY O
normal O
male O
karyotype O
. O

Linkage O
analysis O
of O
12 O

markers O
( O
two O
X O
linked O
and O
10 O
autosomal O
) O
confirms O
paternity O
. O

with O
the O

receptor O
( O

) O

that O

, O
and O
that O

is O
a O

for O

. O

- O

( O

) O

Meiotic O

of O

This O

( O

Learning O
disabilities O
in O
children O
with O
sex O
chromosome O
anomalies O
. O

Studies O
of O
clinical O
populations O
have O
suggested O
that O
genetic O
factors O
may O
be O
involved O
in O
the O
etiology O
of O
learning O
disabilities O
. O

The O
present O
study O
included O
44 O
children O
( O
ages O
7 O
- O
16 O
) O
with O
sex O
chromosome O
anomalies O
( O
SCA O
) O
who O
were O

in O

of O

. O

. O

A O
characteristic O

and O
behavioral O
pattern O
as O
a O

to O
suspect O
Klinefelter O

. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
with O
the O
classic O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
is O
the O
most O
frequent O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
, O
with O
a O
prevalence O
of O
1 O
in O
700 O
men O
; O
although O
the O
classic O
clinical O
picture O
is O
well O
- O
known O
and O
easily O
recognizable O
, O
most O
patients O
remain O
undiagnosed O
. O

The O
rate O
of O
diagnosis O
during O
childhood O
is O
extremely O
low O
, O
and O
only O
10 O
% O
of O
cases O
are O
identified O
before O
puberty O
, O
with O
a O
subsequent O
rate O
of O
ascertainment O
during O
lifetime O
of O
25 O
% O
. O

The O
low O
rate O
of O
timely O
diagnosis O
is O
because O
most O
of O
the O
classical O
signs O
and O
symptoms O
of O
androgen O
deficiency O
appear O
in O
mid O
- O
to O
late O
adolescence O
but O
it O
is O
important O
to O
recognize O
that O
adult O
men O
with O
KS O
may O
show O
a O
great O
variability O
in O
clinical O
and O
physical O
features O
. O

A O
common O
, O
often O
underappreciated O
, O
element O
in O
young O
boys O
and O
children O
with O
KS O

. O

. O

. O

Klinefelter O
group O
( O

= O

) O

) O

) O

. O

Vulnerability O
for O
autism O
traits O
in O

and O

( O
