: O
the O
mediating O
role O
of O
cognitive O
flexibility O
. O

The O
XXY O
chromosomal O
pattern O
( O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O
KS O
) O
has O
been O
associated O
with O
specific O
effects O
on O
physical O
, O
neurobiological O
, O
endocrinological O
and O
psychological O
development O
. O

This O
study O
was O
focused O
on O
the O
described O
risk O
for O
autism O
in O
KS O
, O
and O
the O
cognitive O
mechanisms O
that O
mediate O
this O
risk O
. O

Our O
aim O
was O
to O
assess O
whether O
autistic O
features O
in O
KS O
result O
from O
impairments O
in O
executive O
functioning O
, O
more O
specifically O
difficulties O
in O
cognitive O
flexibility O
. O

In O
total O
, O
71 O
boys O
and O
men O
with O
KS O
and O
61 O
non O
- O
clinical O
controls O
participated O
in O
the O
study O
. O

Autistic O
features O
were O
assessed O
using O
the O
Autism O
- O
spectrum O
Quotient O
( O
AQ O
) O
. O

Mental O
flexibility O
was O
measured O
using O
the O
Wisconsin O
Card O
Sorting O
Test O
( O
WCST O
) O
. O

The O
level O
of O
autism O
traits O
was O
significantly O
increased O
in O
the O
KS O
group O
, O
the O
effect O
size O
for O
total O
AQ O
score O
was O
1 O
. O
6 O
. O

The O
KS O
group O
also O
showed O
significantly O
more O
difficulties O
in O
cognitive O
flexibility O
, O
as O
indicated O
by O
and O
increased O
number O
of O
perseverative O
( O
but O
not O
non O
- O
perseverative O
) O
errors O
in O
the O
WCST O
. O

This O
effect O
was O
independent O
of O
intellectual O
functioning O
, O
age O
or O
testosterone O
supplements O
. O

Within O
the O
KS O
group O
, O
the O
number O
of O
perseverative O
errors O
was O
significantly O
( O
positively O
) O
correlated O
with O
total O
AQ O
score O
. O

Our O
findings O
suggest O
that O
KS O
can O
be O
associated O
with O
dysfunctions O
in O
mental O
flexibility O
, O
and O
that O
individuals O
with O
more O
mental O
flexibility O
problems O
also O
have O
more O
autism O
traits O
. O

This O
insight O
is O
relevant O
for O
diagnosis O
, O
prevention O
and O
treatment O
of O
severe O
problems O
in O
individuals O
with O
KS O
. O

Implications O
also O
extend O
beyond O
this O
specific O
syndrome O
. O

As O
executive O
dysfunctions O
in O
KS O
have O
also O
been O
linked O
to O

and O
thought O

, O

to O

in O
symptoms O
and O

between O
different O

conditions O
. O

Eruption O
delay O
in O
a O

: O
a O
case O
report O
. O

The O
47 O
, O
XXY O
syndrome O
, O
or O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O
though O
it O
is O
a O
rare O
occurrence O
, O
it O
is O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
choromosome O
disorder O
affecting O
male O
subjects O
. O

This O
syndrome O
is O
underdiagnosed O
and O
seldomly O
before O
puberty O
. O

In O
this O
case O
, O
diagnosis O
was O
made O
before O
birth O
, O
through O
chorion O
villus O
sampling O
. O

A O
16 O
month O
- O
old O
Italian O
male O
with O
47 O
XXY O
syndrome O
showed O
the O
absence O
of O
primary O
teeth O
, O
with O
a O
delay O
of O
about O
8 O
- O
10 O
months O
, O
whereas O
during O
the O
first O
15 O
months O
of O
life O
the O
auxological O
development O
has O
been O
normal O
both O
in O
weight O
and O
height O
( O
about O
50th O
percentile O
) O
. O

We O
assumed O
that O
this O
delay O
may O
be O
linked O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O
as O
sexual O
chromosomes O
play O
an O
important O
role O
in O
the O
dental O
development O
. O

The O
size O
of O
permanent O
teeth O
in O
Klinefelter O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
syndrome O
in O
man O
. O

The O
permanent O

tended O
to O
be O
larger O
than O
normal O
in O
a O
group O
of O
77 O
males O
with O
the O
syndrome O
, O
indicating O
that O
the O
presence O
of O
an O
extra O
X O
- O
chromosome O
has O
a O
growth O
- O
promoting O
effect O
which O
operates O
from O
early O
in O
development O
. O

Sex O
chromosome O
variations O
in O
school O
- O
age O
children O
. O

Current O
evidence O
suggests O
that O
some O
school O
- O

children O
are O
born O
with O
a O

. O

Large O

of O

indicate O
that O
0 O
. O
5 O
% O
to O
0 O
. O

errors O
, O
with O

[ O

Genetic O

To O

Sixty O

( O

. O

Neuroimaging O
aspects O
of O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
. O

Aicardi O
syndrome O
is O
a O
rare O
neurodevelopmental O
disorder O
characterized O
by O
congenital O
chorioretinal O
lacunae O
, O
corpus O
callosum O
dysgenesis O
, O
seizures O
, O
polymicrogyria O
, O
cerebral O
heterotopias O
, O
intracranial O
cysts O
, O
and O
costovertebral O
defects O
. O

Cerebellar O
abnormalities O
have O
been O
described O
occasionally O
. O

Aicardi O
syndrome O
is O
sporadic O
and O
has O
been O
observed O
only O
in O
females O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
males O
. O

Therefore O
, O
it O
is O
thought O
to O
result O
from O
a O
mutation O
in O
an O
X O
- O
linked O
gene O
. O

Improved O
definition O
of O
the O
clinical O
phenotype O
should O
focus O
the O
selection O
of O
functional O
candidate O
genes O
for O
mutation O
analysis O
. O

Because O
central O
nervous O
system O
abnormalities O
are O
the O
most O
prominent O
component O
of O
the O
phenotype O
, O
we O
performed O
a O
detailed O
characterization O
of O
abnormalities O
identified O
on O
magnetic O
resonance O
neuroimaging O
studies O
from O
23 O
girls O
with O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
, O
the O
largest O
cohort O
to O
undergo O
such O
review O
by O
a O
single O
group O
of O
investigators O
. O

All O
patients O
had O
polymicrogyria O
that O
was O
predominantly O
frontal O
and O
perisylvian O
and O
often O
associated O
with O
underopercularizatio O
. O

Periventricular O
nodular O
heterotopias O
, O
present O
in O
all O
patients O
, O
were O
more O
frequent O
than O
previously O
reported O
; O
10 O
had O
single O
and O
11 O
had O
multiple O
intracranial O
cysts O
. O

Posterior O
fossa O
abnormalities O
were O
also O
more O
frequent O
than O
previously O
described O
. O

Cerebellar O
abnormalities O
were O
noted O
in O
95 O
% O
of O
studies O
where O
they O
could O
be O
evaluated O
. O

As O
a O
novel O
finding O
, O
we O
noted O
tectal O
enlargement O
in O
10 O
patients O
. O

Since O
mildly O
affected O
girls O
with O
variable O
callosal O
dysgenesis O
have O
now O
been O
reported O
, O
the O
constellation O
of O
frontal O
- O
dominant O
and O
perisylvian O
polymicrogyria O
, O
periventricular O
nodular O
heterotopias O
, O
intracranial O
cysts O
, O
and O
posterior O
fossa O
abnormalities O
, O
including O
tectal O
enlargement O
, O
should O
prompt O
consideration O
of O
the O
diagnosis O
of O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
. O

We O
further O
propose O
that O
improved O
characterization O
of O
the O
neurological O
phenotype O
will O
benefit O
the O
selection O
of O
candidate O
genes O
for O
mutation O
analysis O
. O

New O
concepts O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
its O
variants O
, O
is O
the O
most O
common O
chromosomal O
aberration O
among O
men O
, O
with O
estimated O
frequency O
of O
1 O
: O
500 O
among O
newborns O
. O

Men O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
present O
with O
sequels O
of O
hormonal O
and O
spermatogenic O
testicular O
failure O
like O
infertility O
, O
low O
testosterone O
, O
erectile O
dysfunction O
, O
and O
low O
bone O
mineral O
density O
. O

This O
review O
is O
aimed O
to O
provide O
the O
practicing O
urologist O
with O
an O
important O
source O
of O
clinically O
relevant O
information O
about O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Sperm O
can O
be O
found O
in O
over O
50 O
% O
of O
men O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O
thus O
men O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
are O
not O
sterile O
. O

Recent O
evidence O
suggests O
that O
children O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
are O
born O
with O
spermatogonia O
and O
lose O
large O
numbers O
of O
germ O
cells O
during O
puberty O
. O

Early O
diagnosis O
and O
treatment O
can O
improve O
the O
quality O
of O
life O
and O
the O
overall O
health O
of O
men O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Growing O
interest O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
among O
translational O
scientists O
and O
clinicians O
will O
result O
in O
better O
understanding O
of O
the O
pathophysiology O
of O
testicular O
failure O
. O

In O
some O
states O
, O
screening O
programs O
for O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
are O
already O
in O
place O
, O
which O
will O
increase O
the O
number O
of O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
seen O
by O
practicing O
urologists O
in O
the O
near O
future O
. O

Diagnosis O
and O
management O
of O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
is O
within O
the O
scope O
and O
training O
of O
urologists O
. O

Development O
of O
randomized O
clinical O
trials O
comparing O
different O
forms O
of O
interventions O
in O
men O
and O
children O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
will O
allow O
us O
to O
standardize O
the O
care O
of O
these O
patients O
. O

Palatal O
and O
alveolar O
arch O
dimensions O
in O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
) O
men O
. O

Men O
with O
one O
extra O
X O
chromosome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
; O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
) O
show O

to O
have O
a O
shallower O
but O

palate O
than O
normal O
( O
46 O
, O
XY O
) O
men O
. O

The O

is O
also O
narrower O
than O
in O
46 O
, O
XY O
men O
. O

The O
mandible O
is O
clearly O
narrower O
but O
sagittally O
longer O
compared O
with O
the O
mandibles O
of O
46 O
, O
XY O
men O
. O

The O
present O

indicate O
that O
the O

of O

extra O
X O
chromosome O
in O

, O
XXY O

is O
reflected O
in O
decreased O
growth O
of O
the O
maxilla O
transversely O
and O
vertically O
and O
of O
the O
mandible O
transversely O
. O

Increased O
length O
of O
the O
alveolar O
arches O
might O
be O
partly O
a O
compensation O
for O
the O
decreased O
width O
of O
the O
alveolar O
arch O
. O

This O
change O
might O
be O
associated O
with O
larger O
tooth O
sizes O
in O
47 O
, O
XXY O
men O
. O

Unbalanced O
appositional O
growth O
rather O
than O
disturbances O
in O
other O
orofacial O
growth O
mechanisms O
might O
be O
associated O
with O
the O
XXY O
sex O
chromosome O
pattern O
. O

Probable O
de O
novo O
17q O
duplication O
( O
q11 O
. O
2 O
- O
- O
> O
q21 O
. O
1 O
) O
: O
a O
newly O
recognised O
chromosomal O
syndrome O
in O
a O
child O
with O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
. O

A O
child O
is O
described O
with O
a O
previously O
unreported O

for O
a O

of O

. O

These O
include O

, O

to O
thrive O
, O

of O

, O

, O

- O

reflux O
, O

delay O
, O

disturbance O
, O
and O

. O

The O
coexistence O
of O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
is O
of O
minor O

in O
relation O
to O
this O

' O
s O
phenotype O
. O

Cytogenetic O
diagnoses O
after O
chorionic O
villus O
sampling O
are O
less O
reliable O
in O
very O
- O
high O
- O
or O
very O
- O
low O
- O
risk O
pregnancies O
. O

An O
increasing O
number O
of O
cytogenetic O
prenatal O
diagnoses O
are O
performed O
on O
chorionic O
villus O
samplings O
. O

The O
accuracy O
of O
this O
method O
is O
influenced O
by O
chromosomal O
mosaicism O
, O
mostly O
confined O
to O
direct O
preparation O
methods O
. O

Especially O
those O
investigators O
who O
have O
experienced O
false O
- O
negative O
and O
false O
- O
positive O
findings O
propagate O
the O
combined O
use O
of O
direct O
and O
culture O
methods O
. O

Yet O
large O

shown O
that O

of O

. O

' O
. O

Adrenal O
Insufficiency O
, O

, O
and O

Disomy O

. O

Cholesterol O

- O

( O

Herein O

. O

Comprehensive O

, O

. O

In O

of O

was O

. O

The O

, O

In O

that O

of O

of O
2 O

, O

, O

. O

. O

. O

. O

International O

. O

47 O

( O

) O

1 O
: O
650 O

Forty O

was O

for O

. O

. O

On O

This O

The O
nature O
of O
social O

deficits O
in O

and O

with O

syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
. O

About O
1 O
in O
650 O
boys O
are O
born O
with O
an O
extra O
X O
chromosome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
or O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
) O
. O
47 O
, O

is O
associated O
with O
vulnerabilities O
in O
socio O
- O
emotional O
development O
. O

This O
study O
was O
designed O
to O
assess O

of O

in O

with O

, O

that O
may O
contribute O
to O

, O
and O
to O
evaluate O
the O

of O
such O

at O

: O
ranging O
from O
basic O

, O

in O

( O

) O
, O
to O

expression O

. O

A O
total O
of O
70 O
boys O
and O
men O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
aged O
8 O
to O
60 O
O O
years O
old O
, O
participated O
in O
the O

The O
subtests O
feature O
identification O
, O
FR O
and O
identification O
of O
facial O
emotions O
of O
the O
Amsterdam O
Neuropsychological O
Tasks O
were O
used O
. O

Level O
of O
intellectual O
functioning O
was O
assessed O
with O
the O
child O
and O
adult O
versions O
of O
the O
Wechsler O
Intelligence O
Scales O
. O

Reaction O
time O
data O
showed O
that O
in O

47 O
, O

group O
, O
17 O
% O
had O
difficulties O
in O

processing O
( O
no O
social O
load O
) O
, O
26 O
% O
had O
difficulties O
with O
FR O
( O
medium O
social O
load O
) O
and O
an O
even O
higher O
number O
of O
33 O
% O
had O
difficulties O
with O
facial O
expressions O
of O
emotions O
( O
high O
- O
social O
load O
) O
. O

Information O
processing O
impairments O
increased O
as O
a O
function O
of O
" O
social O
load O
" O
of O
the O
stimuli O
, O
independent O
of O

functioning O
. O

Taken O
together O
, O
our O
data O
suggest O
that O
on O
average O
individuals O
with O

may O
have O
more O

in O

" O

" O
increases O
, O

in O

order O

and O

of O

, O
which O
cannot O
be O

by O
more O

. O

Considering O
the O
increased O
risk O
for O
social O
cognitive O
impairments O
, O
routine O
assessment O
of O
social O
cognitive O
functioning O
as O
part O
of O
neuropsychological O
screening O
is O
warranted O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
: O
more O
than O
hypogonadism O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
the O
most O
frequent O
chromosome O
disorder O
in O
males O
( O
1 O
: O
650 O
newborn O
males O
) O
, O
defined O
by O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

The O
classical O
phenotype O
is O
that O
of O
a O
tall O
male O
with O
relatively O
long O
legs O
, O
small O
, O
firm O
testes O
and O
gynecomastia O
. O

Azoospermia O
and O
infertility O
are O
almost O
inevitably O
present O
, O
but O
may O
be O
overcome O
by O
TESE O
and O
ICSI O
. O

Nevertheless O
, O
a O
broad O
spectrum O
of O
phenotypes O
has O
been O
described O
and O
more O
than O
70 O
% O
of O
the O
actually O
existing O
KS O
men O
may O
remain O
undiagnosed O
throughout O
their O
lifespan O
. O

Accordingly O
, O
hypogonadism O
is O
usually O
not O
evident O
until O
early O
adulthood O
and O
progresses O
with O
ageing O
. O

KS O
patients O
present O
a O
series O
of O
comorbidities O
that O
increase O
morbidity O
and O
mortality O
by O
40 O
% O
. O

Such O
disturbances O
are O
the O
impaired O
metabolic O
profile O
( O
obesity O
, O
dyslipidemia O
, O
insulin O
resistance O
) O
and O
a O
tendency O
to O
thrombosis O
, O
which O
all O
favor O
cardiovascular O
disease O
. O

They O
also O
present O
susceptibility O
for O
specific O
neoplasias O
( O
breast O
cancer O
, O
extragonadal O
germ O
cell O
tumors O
) O
, O
autoimmune O
diseases O
as O
well O
as O
osteoporosis O
and O
bone O
fractures O
. O

Moreover O
, O
KS O
has O
been O
associated O
with O
verbal O
processing O
and O
attention O
deficits O
as O
well O
as O
social O
skill O
impairments O
, O
leading O
KS O
individuals O
to O
academic O
and O
professional O
achievements O
inferior O
to O
those O
of O
their O
peers O
of O
comparable O
socio O
- O
economic O
status O
. O

Nevertheless O
, O
the O
majority O
fall O
within O
the O
average O
range O
regarding O
their O
intellectual O
abilities O
and O
adaptive O
functioning O
. O

Testosterone O
replacement O
therapy O
( O
TRT O
) O
is O
the O
mainstay O
of O
treatment O
in O
hypogonadal O
KS O
patients O
; O
however O
, O
randomized O
trials O
are O
needed O
to O
determine O
optimal O
therapeutic O
regimens O
and O
follow O
- O
up O
schedules O
. O

Electroconvulsive O
therapy O
and O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
is O
a O
common O
sex O
chromosome O
disorder O
characterized O
by O
the O
presence O
of O
1 O
or O
more O
extra O
X O
chromosomes O
, O
and O
the O
most O
prevalent O
karyotype O
is O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

Epidemiological O
studies O
have O
showed O
that O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
had O
a O
significantly O
increased O
risk O
of O
psychosis O
. O

We O
presented O
a O
case O
of O
a O
patient O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
who O
was O
characterized O
by O
psychiatric O
symptoms O
. O

The O
patients O
had O
been O
refractory O
to O
clozapine O
and O
sodium O
valproate O
, O
but O
a O
remarkable O
improvement O
occurred O
after O
a O
cycle O
of O
11 O
sessions O
of O
modified O
electroconvulsive O
therapy O
. O

Chromosomal O
aberrations O
and O
aneuploidies O
of O
spermatozoa O
. O

Chromosomal O
abnormalities O
are O
relevant O
causes O
of O
human O
infertility O
, O
affecting O
2 O
- O
14 O
% O
of O
infertile O
males O
. O

Patients O
with O
seminal O
anomalies O
could O
be O
affected O
by O
improper O
meiotic O
recombination O
and O
increased O
sperm O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
. O

Since O
the O
transmission O
of O
a O
haploid O
chromosomal O
asset O
is O
fundamental O
for O
embryo O
vitality O
and O
development O
, O
the O
study O
of O
sperm O
chromosomes O
has O
become O
fundamental O
because O
intracytoplasmic O
sperm O
injection O
allows O
fertilization O
in O
cases O
of O
severe O
male O
infertility O
. O
In O
this O
chapter O
we O
summarize O
the O
data O
on O
the O
incidence O
of O
sperm O
aneuploidy O
, O
detected O
by O
fluorescence O
in O
situ O
hybridization O
( O
FISH O
) O
, O
in O
infertile O
men O
with O
normal O
or O
abnormal O
karyotype O
. O

The O
possibility O
of O
reducing O
sperm O
chromosomal O
imbalance O
is O
also O
reported O
. O
Among O
control O
males O
, O
the O
lowest O
aneuploidy O
rate O
was O
detected O
( O
range O
: O
0 O
. O
09 O
- O
0 O
. O
14 O
% O
for O
autosomes O
; O
0 O
. O
04 O
- O
0 O
. O
10 O
% O
for O
gonosomes O
) O
. O

In O
infertile O
patients O
with O
normal O
karyotype O
, O
the O
severity O
of O
semen O
alteration O
is O
correlated O
with O
the O
frequency O
of O
aneuploidy O
, O
particularly O
for O
X O
and O
Y O
chromosomes O
. O

Among O
patients O
with O
abnormal O
karyotype O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
carriers O
showed O
a O
high O
variability O
of O
sperm O
aneuploidy O
both O
for O
gonosomes O
and O
autosomes O
. O

In O
Robertsonian O
translocation O
carriers O
, O
the O
increase O
in O
aneuploidy O
rate O
was O
particularly O
evident O
for O
total O
sex O
disomy O
, O
and O
resulted O
mainly O
from O
interchromosomal O
effect O
( O
ICE O
) O
. O

In O
reciprocal O
translocation O
carriers O
, O
a O
high O
percentage O
of O
unbalanced O
sperm O
( O
approximately O
50 O
% O
) O
was O
detected O
, O
perhaps O
mostly O
related O
to O
ICE O
. O
Sperm O
chromosomal O
constitution O
could O
be O
analyzed O
to O
obtain O
more O
accurate O
information O
about O
the O
causes O
of O
male O
infertility O
. O

It O
would O
be O
worthwhile O
to O
evaluate O
the O
benefits O
of O
a O
therapy O
with O
recombinant O
Follicle O
Stimulating O
Hormone O
( O
rFSH O
) O
on O
sperm O
chromosome O
segregation O
in O
selected O
infertile O
males O
. O

[ O
Gonosomal O
trisomy O
syndrome O
. O
Five O
case O
reports O
and O
review O
of O
literature O
] O
. O

Gonosomal O
trisomies O
( O
GT O
) O
or O
so O
called O
sex O
chromosome O
trisomies O
( O
SCTs O
) O
are O
the O
most O
common O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
in O
humans O
. O

The O
addition O
of O
extra O
X O
and O
/ O
or O
Y O
chromosomes O
leads O
to O
neurodevelopmental O
differences O
, O
with O
increased O
risk O
for O
developmental O
delays O
, O
cognitive O
impairments O
, O
executive O
dysfunction O
, O
and O
behavioural O
and O
psychological O
disorders O
. O

Attentional O
problems O
, O
hyperactivity O
, O
autistic O
spectrum O
disorders O
and O
impulsivity O
are O
commonly O
described O
. O

Rates O
of O
language O
and O
communication O
problems O
are O
high O
in O
all O
3 O
trisomies O
. O

Especially O
in O
cases O
of O
language O
impairment O
ENT O
specialists O
may O
be O
the O
main O
contact O
to O
rule O
out O
hearing O
loss O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
present O
5 O
patients O
with O
SCT O
. O

In O
2 O
boys O
and O
a O
young O
man O
, O
SCT O
was O
already O
known O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
; O
47 O

; O
47 O

) O
, O
in O
2 O
cases O
we O
initiated O
genetic O
investigation O
( O
47 O
, O
XXX O
; O
47 O
, O

) O
. O

Main O
symptom O
of O
the O
4 O
children O
was O
a O
language O
delay O
; O
the O
young O
man O
reported O
had O

of O
mild O

and O

delay O
, O
too O
. O

Main O

of O

were O

with O

- O
in O
- O
noise O

. O

Furthermore O

of O

mild O

features O
. O

The O

of O

in O

, O

on O

of O

. O

Furthermore O
, O
in O

with O

/ O

a O

may O
be O
initiated O
at O
least O
at O
the O

of O
the O

to O
clarify O
the O

of O

abnormalities O
. O

If O
the O
suspicion O
of O
hearing O

as O
the O
cause O

in O
a O

, O
ENT O
specialists O
should O
also O
consider O
SCA O
as O
a O
possible O
cause O
in O
the O
differential O
diagnosis O
. O

Chromosomal O
abnormalities O
in O
infertile O
men O
referred O
to O
iran O
blood O
transfusion O
organization O
research O
center O
. O

The O
prevalence O
of O
somatic O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
in O
infertile O
male O
individuals O
has O
been O
reported O
to O
vary O
in O
different O
literatures O
. O

The O
aim O
of O
this O
study O
was O
to O
investigate O
the O
frequency O
of O
chromosomal O
aberrations O
among O
infertile O
men O
referred O
to O
the O
Cytogenetic O
Laboratory O
of O
Iran O
Blood O
Transfusion O
Organization O
Research O
Centre O
( O
IBTO O
) O
. O

Chromosomal O
analysis O
was O
performed O
on O
phytohemag O
- O
glutinin O
( O
PHA O
) O
- O
stimulated O
peripheral O
lymphocyte O
cultures O
of O
1052 O
infertile O
men O
using O
standard O
cytogenetic O
methods O
. O

The O
study O
took O
place O
during O
1997 O
to O
2007 O
. O

Total O
chromosome O
alterations O
were O
revealed O
in O
161 O
( O
15 O
. O
30 O
% O
) O
infertile O
men O
. O

The O
most O
prevalent O
chromosomal O
abnormality O
in O
the O
infertile O
men O
was O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
that O
was O
seen O
in O
94 O
( O
58 O
. O
38 O
% O
) O
men O
while O
one O
of O

had O
a O
mosaic O
karyotype O
: O
mos O
47 O
, O

[ O
54 O
] O
/ O
47 O
, O

[ O
18 O
] O
/ O
46 O
, O

[ O
9 O
] O
. O

In O
37 O
( O
22 O
. O
98 O
% O
) O

were O

. O

There O
were O

( O

. O

. O

Cytogenetic O

of O

of O

for O

of O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
: O
are O
we O
missing O
opportunities O
for O
early O
detection O
? O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
is O
a O
common O
condition O
that O
remains O
underdiagnosed O
, O
particularly O
prior O
to O
adulthood O
. O

Early O
detection O
could O
prevent O
morbidity O
and O
mortality O
, O
but O
the O
classic O
phenotype O
of O
small O
testes O
and O
tall O
stature O
may O
not O
be O
apparent O
until O
adolescence O
, O
and O
there O
is O
minimal O
guidance O
regarding O
whom O
to O
screen O
. O

We O
performed O
a O
retrospective O
study O
at O
Boston O
Children O
' O
s O
Hospital O
in O
patients O
with O
the O
ICD O
- O
9 O
code O
for O
" O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
" O
diagnosed O
prior O
to O
age O
20 O
years O
, O
and O
determined O
age O
and O
reason O
for O
diagnosis O
, O
karyotype O
, O
heights O
, O
and O
comorbid O
conditions O
. O

Eighty O
percent O
had O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
, O
of O
whom O
half O
were O
diagnosed O
at O
age O
11 O
to O
19 O
years O
. O

The O
most O
common O
comorbidities O
were O
neurocognitive O
, O
including O
learning O
disabilities O
( O
67 O
% O
) O
, O
psychosocial O
problems O
( O
33 O
% O
) O
, O
and O
attention O
deficit O
disorder O
( O
27 O
% O
) O
. O

Subjects O
were O
only O
slightly O
taller O
than O
average O
in O
childhood O
( O
height O
standard O
deviation O
score O
= O
0 O
. O
64 O
) O
. O

These O
data O
show O
that O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
is O
associated O
with O
long O
- O
standing O
comorbidities O
that O
frequently O
remain O
under O
- O
recognized O
; O
a O
karyotype O
should O
be O
considered O
in O
boys O
with O
neurocognitive O
problems O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
: O
the O
commonest O
form O
of O
hypogonadism O
, O
but O
often O
overlooked O
or O
untreated O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
with O
the O
karyotype O
47 O
, O
XXY O
is O
one O
of O
the O
commonest O
types O
of O
congenital O
chromosomal O
disorder O
in O
males O
, O
with O
an O
incidence O
of O
0 O
. O
1 O
% O
to O
0 O
. O
2 O
% O
of O
newborn O
male O
infants O
. O

It O
causes O
hypogonadism O
and O
infertility O
. O

Until O
now O
, O
however O
, O
only O
about O
one O
- O
quarter O
of O
all O
persons O
with O
KS O
received O
the O
diagnosis O
during O
their O
lifetimes O
. O

Selective O
review O
of O
the O
literature O
. O

KS O
is O
caused O
by O
aneuploidy O
of O
the O
sex O
chromosomes O
. O

Small O
, O
firm O
testes O
, O
the O
manifestations O
of O
androgen O
deficiency O
( O
sparse O
development O
of O
male O
- O
pattern O
body O
hair O
, O
greater O
than O
average O
height O
, O
lack O
of O
libido O
, O
erectile O
dysfunction O
) O
and O
, O
in O
more O
than O
90 O
% O
of O
affected O
men O
, O
azoospermia O
are O
its O
main O
features O
in O
adults O
. O

Affected O
boys O
may O
have O
verbalization O
difficulties O
and O
problems O
with O
learning O
and O
socialization O
. O

KS O
is O
often O
accompanied O
by O
other O
disturbances O
such O
as O
gynecomastia O
, O
varicose O
veins O
, O
thrombosis O
, O
osteoporosis O
, O
the O
metabolic O
syndrome O
, O
type O
2 O
diabetes O
, O
and O
epilepsy O
. O

The O
most O
important O
therapeutic O
measure O
is O
testosterone O
supplementation O
, O
which O
should O
be O
initiated O
if O
the O
testosterone O
concentration O
drops O
below O
12 O
nmol O
/ O
L O
and O
should O
be O
given O
as O
directed O
in O
the O
guidelines O
for O
the O
treatment O
of O
hypogonadism O
. O

This O
recommendation O
is O
made O
even O
though O
there O
have O
not O
been O
any O
randomized O
controlled O
trials O
documenting O
the O
efficacy O
of O
testosterone O
therapy O
in O
adolescents O
or O
young O
adults O
. O

In O
some O
cases O
, O
viable O
sperm O
can O
be O
obtained O
from O
individual O
testicular O
tubules O
by O
biopsy O
, O
so O
that O
these O
patients O
are O
able O
to O
become O
fathers O
. O

The O
diagnosis O
of O
KS O
would O
be O
less O
frequently O
missed O
if O
doctors O
were O
more O
aware O
of O
, O
and O
attentive O
to O
, O
its O
key O
manifestations O
, O
particularly O
the O
small O
, O
firm O
testes O
, O
erectile O
dysfunction O
, O
and O
the O
comorbidities O
mentioned O
above O
. O

If O
the O
diagnosis O
were O
made O
more O
often O
, O
patients O
would O
more O
often O
be O
able O
to O
receive O
early O
treatment O
, O
which O
would O
improve O
their O
quality O
of O
life O
. O

Twenty O
years O
of O
endocrinologic O
treatment O
in O
transsexualism O
: O
analyzing O
the O
role O
of O
chromosomal O
analysis O
and O
hormonal O
profiling O
in O
the O
diagnostic O
work O
- O
up O
. O

To O
demonstrate O
that O
adequate O
pubertal O
history O
, O
physical O
examination O
, O
and O
a O
basal O
hormone O
profile O
is O
sufficient O
to O
exclude O
disorders O
of O

( O

) O

and O

be O

in O
cases O
of O
unremarkable O
hormonal O

and O

. O

Retrospective O
chart O
analysis O
. O

Endocrine O
outpatient O
clinic O
of O
a O

research O
institute O
. O

A O
total O
of O
475 O

( O
302 O

- O

[ O

] O
, O
173 O

- O

] O
) O
. O

Data O
from O
323 O
( O

/ O

) O
were O
collected O
for O
hormonal O
and O

. O

Information O
regarding O
chromosomal O
analysis O
was O
available O
for O
270 O

( O

/ O
105 O

) O
. O

None O
. O

Pubertal O
abnormalities O
, O

cycle O
, O
and O

in O
relation O
to O
chromosomal O

or O

. O

In O

, O

. O

and O
5 O
. O

. O
8 O
% O

19 O
. O
1 O
% O
, O
respectively O
. O

Overall O
chromosomal O

in O

1 O
. O

( O

. O

0 O
. O

) O
. O

The O

found O

one O

( O
45 O
, O
X O
[ O
10 O
] O
/ O

[ O

] O
/ O
46 O
, O
XX O
[ O
98 O
] O
) O
, O

( O
45 O
, O

( O
14 O
; O
22 O
) O
( O
q10 O
; O
q10 O
) O
) O
, O

syndrome O
( O

, O

) O

in O

. O

Our O
data O
show O
a O
low O
incidence O
of O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
and O
thus O
question O
routine O
chromosomal O
analysis O
at O
the O

of O

, O
and O
suggest O
that O
it O
be O
considered O
only O
in O
cases O
of O
abnormal O
history O
or O
hormonal O
examination O
. O

Salivary O
testosterone O
in O
relation O
to O
social O
cognition O
and O
social O
anxiety O
in O
children O
and O
adolescents O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
) O
. O

Approximately O
1 O
in O
650 O
boys O
are O
born O
with O
an O
extra O
X O
chromosome O
. O

Boys O
and O
men O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
) O
are O
at O
risk O
for O
neurodevelopmental O
disorders O
and O
specific O
cognitive O
impairments O
. O

This O
study O
was O
focused O
on O
social O
anxiety O
and O
social O
cognition O
. O

The O
aim O
was O
to O
assess O
if O
these O
aspects O
of O
the O
phenotype O
are O
related O
to O
testosterone O
deficiency O
, O
which O
is O
typically O
seen O
in O
47 O
, O
XXY O
from O
puberty O
onwards O
. O

In O
the O
study O
20 O
boys O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
25 O
non O
- O
clinical O
controls O
between O
8 O
and O
19 O
years O
participated O
. O

None O
had O
ever O
used O
testosterone O
supplements O
. O

Cognitive O
tests O
measuring O
the O
labeling O
of O
facial O
expressions O
and O
perspective O
taking O
( O
Theory O
of O
Mind O
) O
were O
administered O
. O

Self O
- O
report O
questionnaires O
were O
used O
to O
assess O
social O
anxiety O
. O

Testosterone O
was O
measured O
in O
saliva O
. O

Within O
the O
47 O
, O
XXY O
group O
lower O
levels O
of O
salivary O
testosterone O
were O
significantly O
associated O
with O
higher O
levels O
of O
social O
anxiety O
. O

The O
correlation O
was O
strong O
, O
andindependent O
of O
age O
and O
pubertal O
development O
. O

However O
, O
salivary O
levels O
of O
testosterone O
were O
uncorrelated O
to O
social O
cognitive O
skills O
. O

These O
findings O
point O
out O
that O
lower O
testosterone O
levels O
might O
contribute O
to O
high O
social O
anxiety O
in O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
suggesting O
that O
anxiety O
should O
be O
monitored O
in O
pubertal O
boys O
with O
XXY O
presenting O
with O
testosterone O
deficiency O
. O

This O
should O
be O
done O
in O
addition O
to O
exploring O
cognitive O
behavioral O
therapy O
or O
psychopharmacologic O
treatments O
targeting O
anxiety O
, O
which O
are O
more O
evidence O
based O
. O

In O
contrast O
, O
testosterone O
levels O
were O
not O
associated O
with O
social O
cognitive O
functioning O
, O
suggesting O
that O
other O
mechanisms O
are O
driving O
vulnerabilities O
in O
this O
domain O
. O

Neuropsychiatric O
Aspects O
in O
Men O
with O
Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
and O
cause O
of O
male O
hypergonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
. O

It O
is O
characterized O
by O
an O
extreme O
clinical O
heterogeneity O
in O
presentation O
, O
including O
infertility O
, O
hypogonadism O
, O
language O
delay O
, O
metabolic O
comorbidities O
, O
and O
neurocognitive O
and O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O

Since O
testosterone O
is O
known O
to O
have O
organizational O
, O
neurotrophic O
and O
neuroprotective O
effects O
on O
brain O
, O
the O
condition O
of O
primary O
hypogonadism O
could O
play O
a O
role O
. O

Moreover O
, O
given O
that O
KS O
subjects O
have O
an O
additional O
X O
, O
genes O
on O
the O
extra O
- O
chromosome O
could O
also O
exert O
a O
significant O
impact O
. O

The O
aim O
of O
this O
narrative O
review O
is O
to O
analyze O
the O
available O
literature O
on O
the O
relationship O
between O
KS O
and O
neuropsychiatric O
disorders O
. O

To O
extent O
to O
the O
best O
of O
published O
literature O
on O
the O
topic O
, O
it O
was O
identified O
the O
appropriate O
keywords O
and O
MeSH O
terms O
and O
searched O
them O
in O
Pubmed O
. O

Finally O
, O
references O
of O
original O
articles O
and O
reviews O
were O
examined O
. O

Both O
morphological O
and O
functional O
studies O
focusing O
on O
the O
brain O
showed O
that O
there O
were O
important O
differences O
in O
brain O
structure O
of O
KS O
subjects O
. O

Different O
psychiatric O
disorders O
such O
as O
Schizophrenia O
, O
autism O
, O
attention O
deficit O
hyperactivity O
disorder O
, O
depression O
, O
anxiety O
, O
were O
frequently O
reported O
in O
KS O
patients O
according O
to O
a O
broad O
spectrum O
of O
phenotypes O
. O

T O
supplentation O
( O
TRT O
) O
was O
not O
able O
to O
improve O
the O
psychotic O
disorders O
in O
KS O
men O
with O
or O
without O
overt O
hypogonadism O
. O

Although O
the O
risk O
of O
psychosis O
, O
depression O
and O
autism O
is O
increased O
in O
subjects O
with O
KS O
, O
no O
definitive O
evidence O
has O
been O
found O
in O
studies O
aiming O
at O
identify O
the O
relationship O
between O
aneuploidy O
, O
T O
deficit O
and O
the O
risk O
of O
psychiatric O
and O
cognitive O
disorders O
in O
subjects O
affected O
by O
KS O
. O

Evidence O
of O
increased O
humoral O
endocrine O
organ O
- O
specific O
autoimmunity O
in O
severe O
and O
classic O
X O
- O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
in O
comparison O
with O
46 O
, O
XY O
control O
subjects O
. O

In O
literature O
, O

of O
X O
- O
linked O
gene O
dosage O
as O
a O
contributing O
factor O
for O
autoimmune O
diseases O
is O
generally O
assumed O
. O

However O
, O
little O
information O
is O
available O
on O
the O
frequency O
of O
humoral O
endocrine O
organ O
- O
specific O

in O

- O

. O

In O

, O

relative O
to O

( O

. O

( O

. O

from O

( O

These O

. O

The O

for O

, O

should O

considered O
in O

for O

rare O

- O

of O

- O

. O

Sex O
chromosome O
trisomies O
are O
not O
associated O
with O
atypical O
lateralization O
for O
language O
. O

To O
test O
the O

that O
sex O
chromosome O
trisomies O
( O

) O
are O
associated O
with O
reduced O
left O
lateralization O
for O
language O
. O

Using O
a O
cross O
- O
sectional O
design O
, O
language O
laterality O
was O
measured O
during O
an O
animation O
description O
task O
using O
functional O
transcranial O
Doppler O

. O

Data O
were O
available O
for O
75 O
children O
with O
an O
SCT O
( O
47 O
, O
XXX O
females O
[ O
n O
= O
26 O
] O
, O
47 O
, O

males O
[ O
n O
= O
25 O
] O
, O
47 O
, O
XYY O
males O
[ O
n O
= O
24 O
] O
; O
mean O
age O
11y O
4mo O
[ O
SD O
3y O
10mo O
] O
) O
and O
132 O
comparison O

with O

( O
69 O
males O
, O

; O
mean O
age O
9y O
1mo O
[ O
SD O
1y O
7mo O
] O
) O
. O

Lateralization O
for O

did O
not O

between O

comparison O

, O
either O
in O

. O

There O
were O
no O

when O

the O
group O
with O
an O

by O
trisomy O
. O

Handedness O
showed O
no O
group O
effects O
. O

Our O
data O
provide O
no O
evidence O
for O
disrupted O
lateralization O
for O
language O
in O

. O

The O
brain O
basis O
of O

in O

is O
unlikely O
to O
be O
a O
failure O
of O

to O

for O

, O

. O

Children O
with O
a O
sex O
chromosome O
trisomy O
( O
SCT O
) O
have O
typically O
lateralized O
language O
. O

This O
disproves O
theories O
linking O
language O
problems O
to O
hemispheric O

in O
SCTs O
. O

analysis O
of O
1572 O

, O

. O

. O

, O

[ O

The O

. O

. O

He O

. O

( O

) O
. O

Puberty O

was O

. O

Because O

. O

The O

' O
s O

, O

. O

In O

of O

was O

high O

Increased O

a O

Noninvasive O
prenatal O
screening O
for O
fetal O
common O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
from O
maternal O
blood O
. O

Objective O
To O
explore O
the O
feasibility O
of O
high O
- O
throughput O
massively O
parallel O
genomic O
DNA O
sequencing O
technology O
for O
the O
noninvasive O
prenatal O
detection O
of O
fetal O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
( O
SCAs O
) O
. O

Methods O
The O
study O
enrolled O
pregnant O
women O
who O
were O
prepared O
to O
undergo O
noninvasive O
prenatal O
testing O
( O
NIPT O
) O
in O
the O
second O
trimester O
. O

Cell O
- O
free O
fetal O
DNA O
( O
cffDNA O
) O
was O
extracted O
from O
the O
mother O
' O
s O
peripheral O
venous O
blood O
and O
a O
high O
- O
throughput O
sequencing O
procedure O
was O
undertaken O
. O

Patients O
identified O
as O
having O
pregnancies O
associated O
with O
SCAs O
were O
offered O
prenatal O
fetal O
chromosomal O
karyotyping O
. O

Results O
The O
study O
enrolled O
10 O
275 O
pregnant O
women O
who O
were O
prepared O
to O
undergo O
NIPT O
. O

Of O
these O
, O
57 O
pregnant O
women O
( O
0 O
. O
55 O
% O
) O
showed O
fetal O
SCA O
, O
including O
27 O
with O
Turner O
syndrome O
( O
45 O
, O
X O
) O
, O
eight O
with O
Triple O
X O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXX O
) O
, O

with O

syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
and O
three O
with O
47 O
, O
XYY O
. O

Thirty O
- O

women O
agreed O
to O
undergo O
fetal O
karyotyping O
and O
18 O
had O
results O
consistent O
with O

, O
while O
15 O
patients O

a O
normal O
karyotype O
result O
. O

The O
overall O
positive O
predictive O
value O
of O
NIPT O
for O
detecting O
SCAs O
was O
54 O
. O
54 O
% O
( O
18 O
/ O
33 O
) O
and O
for O
detecting O
Turner O
syndrome O
( O
45 O
, O
X O
) O
was O
29 O
. O
41 O
% O
( O
5 O
/ O
17 O
) O
. O

Conclusion O
NIPT O
can O
be O
used O
to O
identify O
fetal O

by O
analysing O

using O
massively O
parallel O
genomic O
sequencing O
, O
although O
the O
accuracy O
needs O
to O
be O
improved O
particularly O
for O
Turner O
syndrome O
( O
45 O
, O
X O
) O
. O

Chromosomal O
anomalies O
and O
sperm O
retrieval O
outcomes O
of O
patients O
with O
non O
- O
obstructive O
azoospermia O
: O
a O
case O

. O

Some O
preoperative O
factors O
affecting O

of O

( O

- O

) O

been O

. O

However O
, O
other O
than O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O

) O
, O
no O
other O
chromosomal O
anomalies O
have O

in O
the O

of O

. O

The O

of O

was O
to O

. O

[ O
Analysis O
of O
genetic O
etiology O
of O
a O
female O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
syndrome O
] O
. O

To O
explore O
the O
genetic O
cause O
of O
a O
female O
case O
with O
intellectual O
development O
disorder O
. O

G O
banding O
karyotyping O
was O
performed O
for O
the O
patient O
. O

Following O
DNA O
extraction O
, O
the O
coding O
sequence O
of O
SRY O
gene O
was O
amplified O
with O
PCR O
and O
subjected O
to O
Sanger O
sequencing O
. O
qPCR O
was O
used O
to O
detect O
the O
copy O
numbers O
of O
the O
SRY O
gene O
. O

The O
karyotype O
of O
the O
patient O
was O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

PCR O
and O
qPCR O
analyses O
of O
the O

gene O
showed O
a O
large O
deletion O
with O
null O
copy O
number O
. O

The O
female O
phenotype O
of O
the O
patient O
is O
probably O
due O
to O
deletion O
of O
the O
SRY O
gene O
on O
the O
Y O
chromosome O
. O

This O
is O
the O
first O
report O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
female O
case O
with O
deletion O
of O
the O
SRY O
gene O
in O
China O
. O

Autism O
spectrum O
disorder O
associated O
with O
49 O
, O
XYYYY O
: O
case O
report O
and O
review O
of O
the O
literature O
. O

Sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
occur O
in O
approximately O
one O
in O
420 O
live O
births O
. O

The O
most O
frequent O
abnormalities O
are O
45 O
, O
X O
( O
Turner O
syndrome O
) O
, O
47 O
, O
XXX O
( O
triple O
X O
) O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
) O
, O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
. O

The O
prevalence O
of O
males O
with O
more O
than O
one O
extra O
sex O
chromosome O
( O
e O
. O
g O
. O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
or O
48 O
, O
XXXY O
) O
is O
less O
common O
. O

However O
, O
the O
literature O
provides O
little O
information O
about O
the O
cognitive O
and O
behavioural O
phenotype O
and O
the O
natural O
history O
of O
the O
disease O
. O

We O
report O
the O
clinical O
, O
neurocognitive O
, O
social O
cognitive O
and O
psychiatric O
characterization O
of O
a O
patient O
with O
49 O
, O
XYYYY O
syndrome O
. O

The O
patient O
presented O
with O
a O
complex O

including O
a O
particular O
cognitive O
profile O
with O
intellectual O
deficiency O
and O

spectrum O
disorder O
( O

) O
with O
limited O
interests O
. O

Moreover O
, O
social O

disorder O
with O

and O

anxiety O
disorder O
were O
observed O
( O

- O
5 O
criteria O
, O
MINI O
Assessment O
) O
. O

It O
is O
now O
admitted O
that O
49 O
, O
XYYYY O
has O
unique O
medical O
, O
neurodevelopmental O
and O
behavioural O
characteristics O
. O

Interestingly O
, O
ASD O
is O
more O
common O
in O
groups O
with O

chromosome O
aneuploidy O
. O

This O
clinical O
report O
suggests O
that O

the O

and O

of O
these O
patients O
may O
provide O
new O
insights O
into O
possible O
therapeutic O
strategies O
, O
as O
cognitive O
remediation O
or O
social O
cognitive O
training O
. O

A O
case O
of O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
with O
bilateral O
absence O
of O
the O
vas O
deferens O
. O

A O
33 O
- O
year O
- O
old O
male O
presented O
to O

with O
the O

of O

. O

were O
not O

. O

revealed O
hypergonadotropic O

and O

studies O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O

. O

The O
significance O
of O
the O

of O
this O

with O
the O

of O
vas O
deferens O
is O
discussed O
. O

Maternal O
meiosis O
II O
nondisjunction O
in O
a O
case O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
testicular O
feminization O
. O

An O
11 O
- O
year O
- O
old O
patient O
with O
incomplete O
testicular O

and O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
is O
described O
. O

The O
patient O
had O
female O
external O
genitalia O
, O
clitoromegaly O
, O
and O
some O
features O
of O
Klinefelter O
' O

syndrome O
, O
including O

and O

. O

DNA O
analysis O
using O
X O
chromosomal O
DNA O
sequences O
suggest O
that O
the O

X O
chromosome O
in O
the O
patient O
resulted O
from O
maternal O

during O
meiosis O
II O
. O

The O
M O
II O
error O
thereby O
provides O
the O
basis O
for O
homozygosity O
of O
a O
mutation O
in O
the O
androgen O
receptor O
locus O
. O

Interpretation O
of O
chromosome O
mosaicism O
and O
discrepancies O
in O
chorionic O
villi O
studies O
. O

In O
3 O
, O
000 O
chorionic O
villi O
studies O
( O
CVS O
) O
33 O
cases O
of O
mosaicism O
and O
7 O
false O
- O

cell O
lines O
in O
all O
cells O
were O
seen O
. O

The O
mosaic O
cell O
lines O
were O
caused O
by O

of O
autosomes O
( O
13x O
) O
, O

chromosomes O
( O
9x O
) O

( O
11x O
) O
. O

Mosaics O
of O

origin O
were O
only O
4 O
cases O
of O
trisomy O
21 O
and O
one O
47 O
, O
XXY O
mosaic O
. O

In O
7 O
cases O
abnormal O
karyotype O
of O
non O
- O
fetal O
origin O
was O
seen O
in O
all O
cells O
in O
direct O
studies O
, O
including O
trisomy O
16 O
( O
3x O
) O
and O
trisomy O
18 O
( O
2x O
) O
. O

The O
combined O
use O
of O
direct O
CVS O
and O
cell O
cultures O
always O
uncovered O
the O
non O
- O
fetal O
origin O
of O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
and O
the O
study O
of O
cultured O
cells O
in O
all O
cases O
could O
have O

5 O

. O

Complete O
follow O
- O
up O
studies O
demonstrated O

, O

Rare O

Klinefelter O

represents O

True O
hermaphroditism O
with O
characteristics O
of O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
: O
a O
rare O
presentation O
. O

True O
hermaphroditism O
, O
a O
very O
rare O
cause O
of O
intersex O
, O
is O
usually O
diagnosed O
during O
the O
newborn O
period O
in O
the O
course O
of O
evaluating O
ambiguous O
genitalia O
. O

As O
an O
exception O
we O
report O
an O
unusual O
case O
of O
a O
14 O
. O
5 O
year O
- O
old O
boy O
with O

and O

, O
who O
was O
seen O
for O

of O

and O

. O

' O

. O

He O
had O

( O

. O

/ O

) O

/ O

The O
patient O
was O
diagnosed O
as O

46 O
, O

/ O
47 O
, O

. O

Male O
- O
to O
- O
male O
transmission O
of O
X O
- O
linked O
Alport O
syndrome O
in O
a O
boy O
with O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

Alport O
syndrome O
( O
AS O
) O
is O
a O
genetically O
heterogeneous O
renal O
hereditary O
disease O
. O

Male O
- O
to O
- O
male O
transmission O
has O
been O
considered O
fully O
indicative O
of O
autosomal O
dominant O
AS O
. O

We O
report O
a O
family O
with O
male O
- O
to O
- O
male O
transmission O
of O
X O
- O
linked O
AS O
due O
to O
an O
extra O

chromosome O
of O

origin O
in O
the O
proband O
. O

analysis O
excluded O

loci O
and O
demonstrated O
segregation O
with O
the O
COL4A5 O
locus O
( O
Xq22 O
. O
3 O
) O
. O

from O

. O

of O

, O

. O

. O

grandmother O
showed O
random O
X O
chromosome O
inactivation O
. O

However O

of O

. O

This O

of O

of O

. O

Androgen O
receptor O
CAGn O
repeat O
length O
influences O
phenotype O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
Klinefelter O
) O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
; O
47 O
, O
XXY O

and O

) O
is O
characterized O

and O

failure O
, O

marked O

in O

. O

Previous O

have O
proposed O
that O

of O

( O

) O

The O

. O

The O

. O

. O

Isolation O
of O

- O

) O

, O

with O

. O

XXY O
male O
mice O
: O
an O
experimental O
model O
for O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
in O
men O
. O

Thus O
, O
it O
is O
important O
to O
establish O
an O
experimental O
animal O
model O
to O
explore O
its O
underlying O
molecular O
mechanisms O
. O

Mice O
with O
a O
41 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
were O
produced O
by O
mating O
wild O
- O
type O
male O
mice O
with O
chimeric O
female O
mice O
carrying O
male O

stem O
cells O
. O

The O
objectives O
of O
the O
present O
study O
were O
to O
characterize O
the O

phenotype O
of O
adult O
XXY O
mice O
and O
to O

the O

of O

of O

in O

mice O
. O

In O
the O
first O
experiment O

of O

mice O
and O

controls O
( O

, O

. O

XXY O

identified O
by O

Southern O

and O
were O

showed O
that O

of O

( O
0 O
. O

+ O
/ O

of O

( O

. O

+ O
/ O
- O
0 O
. O
01 O
g O
) O
. O

Although O

in O

compared O
with O

. O

The O

of O

small O

with O

of O

. O

Hypertrophy O
and O

of O

cells O
were O
observed O
in O

interstitium O
. O

Electron O

showed O

cells O

of O

. O

The O

between O

appeared O
normal O
. O

In O
some O

of O

were O
found O
. O

In O
the O
second O
experiment O
the O

of O
germ O

loss O
in O
juvenile O
XXY O
mice O
and O
their O

controls O
was O

. O

Spermatogonia O
were O
found O
and O
appeared O
to O
be O

normal O
in O

XXY O
mice O
. O

Progressive O
loss O
of O
germ O
cells O
occurred O
within O
10 O
days O
after O
birth O
. O

This O
resulted O
in O
the O

of O

in O

mice O
. O

We O
conclude O
that O
a O

of O

in O
early O

life O
results O
in O

absence O
of O
germ O
cells O
in O
adult O
XXY O
mice O
. O

The O
XXY O
mouse O
provides O
an O
experimental O
model O
for O
its O

counterpart O
, O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

An O
SRY O
- O
negative O
47 O
, O
XXY O
mother O
and O
daughter O
. O

Females O

are O

of O

. O

We O
now O
describe O
an O

- O

47 O

XXY O
female O
who O

. O

Maternal O

Human O
trisomy O
is O
attributable O
to O
many O
different O
mechanisms O
and O
the O
relative O
importance O
of O
each O
mechanism O
is O
highly O

specific O
. O

The O
association O
between O

and O
maternal O
non O
- O

is O
well O
documented O
: O
reductions O
in O

have O
been O
reported O
for O
maternal O

( O

) O

involving O
chromosomes O
15 O
, O
16 O
, O

and O

recombination O
has O
been O
reported O
for O

( O

) O

involving O
chromosome O

. O

of O

. O

We O

XXX O
females O

of O

. O

Our O

demonstrate O
that O
49 O
% O
arose O
during O

, O

were O

. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
is O
the O
most O
common O

( O
SCA O
) O

and O

, O

and O
/ O
or O

were O

. O

In O
this O

, O

present O

. O

( O

) O

( O

) O
. O

, O

and O

measured O

between O

and O

. O

Systemic O

revealed O

and O

of O

in O
the O
patient O
. O

The O
couple O
was O
referred O
to O
microtesticular O
sperm O

( O
micro O
- O
TESE O
) O
/ O
intracytoplasmic O
sperm O
injection O
( O

) O
cycles O
and O
preimplantation O

diagnosis O
( O
PGD O
) O
. O

To O
the O
best O
of O
our O
knowledge O
, O
this O
is O
the O
first O
report O
of O
combination O
of O
XYY O
and O

with O

Rapid O
and O
simultaneous O
screening O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
AZF O
microdeletions O
by O
quadruplex O
real O
- O
time O
polymerase O
chain O
reaction O
. O

We O
developed O
a O
quadruplex O
real O
- O
time O
PCR O
assay O
that O
allows O
rapid O
and O
simultaneous O
detection O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
azoospermia O
factor O
( O
AZF O
) O
microdeletions O
on O
Y O
chromosome O
. O

The O
quadruplex O
assay O
consisted O
of O
four O
hydrolysis O
probes O
and O
primer O
sets O
. O

Three O
probes O
and O
the O
corresponding O
primers O
were O
used O
to O
qualitatively O
detect O
AZFa O
, O
AZFb O
, O
and O
AZFc O
deletions O
. O

For O
the O
detection O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
the O
hydrolysis O
probe O
- O
mediated O
melting O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
to O
analyze O
the O
relative O
amounts O
of O
X O
and O
Y O
chromosomes O
. O

The O
quadruplex O
assay O
for O
detecting O
47 O
, O
XXY O
was O
characterized O
by O
very O
high O
analytical O
specificity O
( O
100 O
% O
) O
in O
a O
wide O
template O
DNA O
range O
( O
2 O
- O
100 O
ng O
) O
. O

The O
detection O
limit O
of O
the O
assay O
was O
2 O
ng O
of O
genomic O
DNA O
, O
and O
the O
optimal O
template O
DNA O
amount O
for O
the O
detection O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
was O
25 O
ng O
. O

The O
quadruplex O
assay O
for O
detecting O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
AZF O
microdeletions O
has O
also O
demonstrated O
very O
high O
diagnostic O
sensitivity O
and O
specificity O
( O
100 O
% O
) O
. O

The O
assay O
was O
found O
to O
be O
rapid O
, O
sensitive O
, O
reliable O
, O
and O
inexpensive O
. O

This O
method O

to O

as O
a O

of O

and O

. O

Bilateral O
congenital O
cataracts O
in O
an O

with O
Klinefelter O

. O

Congenital O

is O
one O
of O
the O
most O
treatable O
causes O
of O
visual O
impairment O
and O
blindness O
during O
infancy O
, O
with O
an O
estimated O
prevalence O
of O
approximately O
2 O
. O
5 O
: O
10 O
, O
000 O
infants O
under O
the O
age O
of O
1 O
year O
. O

Congenital O
cataract O
can O
be O
observed O
with O
certain O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
, O
such O
as O

, O

, O

In O

and O

In O

present O
a O

of O

very O

. O

patient O

only O
the O

- O

Screening O

Genotyping O
of O
AR O
and O
PSA O
polymorphisms O
in O
a O
patient O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O

- O
Hodgkin O
lymphoma O
, O
and O
adenocarcinoma O
of O
the O
prostate O
. O

It O
has O
been O
hypothesized O
that O
the O
AR O
( O
androgen O
receptor O
) O
gene O
binds O
the O
two O
PSA O
( O
prostate O
- O
specific O
antigen O
) O

with O
differing O

and O
may O
differentially O
influence O
prostate O
cancer O
risk O
. O

In O
this O
article O
, O
we O
report O
a O
case O
of O
adenocarcinoma O
of O
the O
prostate O
in O
a O
56 O
- O
year O
- O
old O
man O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
and O
non O
- O
Hodgkin O

, O
as O
well O
as O
the O
AR O
and O
PSA O
genotype O
. O

AR O
and O
PSA O
gene O
polymorphisms O
were O
analyzed O
by O
polymerase O
chain O
reaction O
- O
based O
methods O
using O
DNA O
from O
peripheral O
white O
blood O
cells O
and O
the O
prostate O
cancer O
. O

We O
determined O
the O
methylation O
status O
of O
the O
AR O
gene O
on O
the O
X O
chromosome O
. O

The O
patient O
presents O
with O
the O
AG O
genotype O
for O
the O
ARE O
- O
1 O
( O
androgen O
response O
element O
) O
region O
of O
the O
PSA O
gene O
. O

We O
detect O
the O
presence O
of O
two O
short O
AR O
alleles O
with O
19 O
and O
11 O
CAG O
repeats O
each O
. O

Unmethylated O

were O
demonstrated O
for O
both O
. O

The O

was O
inactive O
in O
more O
than O
60 O
% O
of O
total O
DNA O
in O
both O
control O
blood O
and O
prostate O
cancer O
cells O
. O

The O
presence O
of O
short O
AR O
alleles O
and O

of O

gene O
may O

of O

in O

47 O
, O
XXY O
patient O
. O

of O

iris O

Genetic O
counseling O
disclosed O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

A O
genome O
- O
wide O
screen O
for O
copy O
number O
alterations O
in O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
. O

Aicardi O
syndrome O
is O
a O
severe O
neurodevelopmental O
disorder O
that O
affects O
females O
or O
rarely O
males O
with O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

Therefore O
, O
it O
is O
thought O
to O
be O
caused O
by O

in O
an O
essential O

- O
linked O
gene O
or O
by O

in O

gene O
with O
sex O
- O
limited O
expression O
. O

Because O
all O
reported O
cases O
are O
sporadic O
with O
one O
exception O
, O
traditional O
linkage O
analysis O
to O
identify O
the O

gene O
is O
not O
possible O
, O
and O
the O
de O
novo O
mutation O
rate O
must O
be O
high O
. O

As O
an O

approach O
to O
localize O
the O
mutant O
gene O
, O
we O
screened O
the O
DNA O
of O
38 O
girls O
with O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
by O
high O
- O
resolution O
, O
genome O
- O
wide O
array O
comparative O
genomic O
hybridization O
for O
copy O
number O
gains O
and O
losses O
. O

We O
found O
110 O
copy O
number O
variants O
( O
CNVs O
) O
, O
97 O
of O
which O
are O
known O

, O

; O
8 O
have O
been O
seen O
before O
in O
unrelated O
studies O
in O
unaffected O
individuals O
. O

Four O
previously O
unseen O
CNVs O
on O
autosomes O
were O
each O
inherited O
from O
a O
healthy O
parent O
. O

One O
subject O
with O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
had O
a O
de O
novo O
loss O
of O
X O
- O
linked O
copy O
number O
in O
a O
region O
without O
known O
genes O
. O

Detailed O
analysis O
of O
this O
and O

regions O
did O
not O
reveal O

or O
mutations O

annotated O

in O

. O

We O
conclude O
that O
, O
in O
this O
study O

of O
38 O
subjects O
, O

is O
not O

by O

detectable O

array O

was O
used O
. O

of O

Tremor O
in O

. O

Three O

. O

48 O
, O

of O

. O

a O

. O

PGD O
in O
47 O
, O
XXY O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O

. O

The O

ICSI O

a O

in O

of O
male O

. O

Even O

in O
the O

may O

from O

in O

to O

a O

. O

As O

have O

for O

. O

To O

, O

in O
56 O
. O
0 O

- O
22 O
. O
4 O
% O

. O

. O

. O

Eight O

A O

+ O

or O

. O

Aberrant O
recombination O
and O
the O
origin O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Trisomy O
is O
the O
most O
commonly O
identified O
chromosome O
abnormality O
in O
humans O
, O
occurring O
in O
at O
least O
4 O
% O
of O
all O
clinically O
recognized O
pregnancies O
; O
it O
is O
the O
leading O
known O
cause O
of O
pregnancy O
loss O
and O
of O
mental O
retardation O
. O

Over O
the O
past O
decade O
, O
molecular O
studies O
have O
demonstrated O
that O
most O
human O
trisomies O
originate O
from O
errors O
at O
maternal O
meiosis O
I O
. O

However O
, O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
is O
a O
notable O
exception O
, O
as O
nearly O
one O
- O
half O
of O
all O
cases O
derive O
from O
paternal O
non O
- O
disjunction O
. O

In O
this O
review O
, O
the O
data O
on O
the O
origin O
of O
sex O
chromosome O
trisomies O
are O
summarized O
, O
focusing O
on O
the O
47 O
, O
XXY O
condition O
. O

Additionally O

results O
of O
recent O

mapping O
studies O

reviewed O
that O
have O
led O
to O
the O

of O
the O
first O

correlate O
of O
autosomal O
and O
sex O

- O

; O

. O

. O

Spermatogenesis O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
chromosomal O
disorder O
, O
and O
it O
is O
a O
frequent O
form O
of O
male O
hypogonadism O
and O
infertility O
. O

Although O
the O
majority O
of O
these O
patients O
are O
azoospermic O
, O
they O
might O
have O
severe O
oligozoospermia O
or O
residual O
single O
- O
residual O
foci O
with O
spermatogenesis O
in O
the O
testis O
. O

We O
report O
our O
experience O
on O
sperm O
retrieval O
in O
the O
ejaculate O
and O
testis O
, O
and O
evaluate O
the O
frequency O
of O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
in O
sperm O
of O
KS O
. O

Eighty O
- O
four O
47 O
, O
XXY O
KS O
were O
evaluated O
with O
seminal O
analysis O
, O
body O
hair O
distribution O
, O
reproductive O
hormones O
, O
ultrasonographic O
scanning O
of O
the O
testis O
and O
prostate O
, O
bilateral O
testicular O
sperm O
extraction O
( O
TESE O
) O
, O
sperm O
or O
testicular O
cells O
sex O
chromosomes O
aneuploidies O
. O

Out O
of O
84 O
patients O
, O
7 O
( O
7 O
/ O
84 O
; O
8 O
. O
3 O
% O
) O
had O
sperm O
in O
the O
ejaculate O
. O

Out O
of O
the O
77 O
azoospermic O
patients O
, O
24 O
underwent O
TESE O
and O
9 O
( O
9 O
/ O
24 O
; O
37 O
. O
5 O
% O
) O
had O
successful O
sperm O
recovery O
. O

The O
comparison O
of O
reproductive O
hormones O
, O
age O
and O
testicular O
volume O
did O
not O
show O
significant O
differences O
between O
patients O
with O
and O
without O
successful O
sperm O
recovery O
in O
semen O
or O
TESE O
. O

Patients O
without O
successful O
sperm O
recovery O
in O

analysis O
or O
TESE O
had O
signs O
of O
hypoandrogenism O
more O
evident O
than O
patients O
with O

sperm O

Patients O
with O
KS O
produced O
a O
higher O
number O
of O
sperm O

with O
respect O
to O
normozoospermic O
fertile O
controls O
and O
non O
- O
genetic O
severely O
oligozoospermic O
men O
. O

Men O
with O
KS O
are O
not O
always O
sterile O
. O

In O
some O
of O
these O
patients O
sperm O
can O
be O
found O
in O
semen O
or O
in O
the O
testis O

but O
the O
proportion O
of O
sperm O
aneuploidy O
is O
high O
. O

Signs O
of O
hypoandrogenism O
seem O
to O
be O
associated O
with O
low O
sperm O
recovery O
rate O
. O

Endothelial O
progenitor O
cells O
as O
a O
new O
cardiovascular O
risk O
factor O
in O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
associated O
with O
a O
significant O
reduced O
life O
expectancy O
( O
2 O
. O
1 O
years O
) O
including O
greater O
mortality O
from O
cardiovascular O
diseases O
. O

Underlying O
causes O
that O
may O
involve O
low O
levels O
of O
testosterone O
as O
well O
as O
the O
extra O
X O
chromosome O
are O
not O
fully O
understood O
. O

Low O
testosterone O
may O
have O
a O
direct O
affect O
on O
vascular O
tissue O
or O
act O
indirectly O
via O
metabolic O
effects O
. O

Testosterone O
levels O
may O
act O
genomically O
on O
cardiac O
function O
via O
the O
androgen O
receptor O
( O
AR O
) O
or O
non O
- O
genomically O
. O

Recently O
, O
it O
has O
been O
demonstrated O
that O
a O
reduced O
number O
of O
circulating O
endothelial O
progenitor O
cells O
( O
EPCs O
) O
is O
an O
independent O
predictor O
of O
morbidity O
and O
mortality O
from O
cardiovascular O
diseases O
. O

Because O
EPCs O
have O
never O
been O
studied O
in O
KS O
, O
we O
evaluated O
the O
number O
of O
circulating O
EPCs O
in O
68 O
adult O
47 O
, O
XXY O
Klinefelter O
men O
and O
46 O
healthy O
males O
. O

Patients O
and O
controls O
were O
divided O
into O
two O
groups O
, O
according O
to O
the O
absence O
or O
presence O
of O
cardiovascular O
risk O
factors O
( O
CRFs O
) O
. O

Controls O
without O
CRFs O
had O
significantly O
higher O
levels O
of O
EPCs O
than O
controls O
with O
CRFs O
; O
on O
the O
contrary O
, O
KS O
patients O
without O
CRFs O
had O
EPCs O
levels O
similar O
to O
KS O
men O
with O
risk O
factors O
and O
significantly O
lower O
with O
respect O
to O
controls O
without O
CRFs O
. O

The O
number O
of O
EPCs O
in O
patients O
with O
hypogonadism O
was O
not O
different O
from O
that O
of O
those O
with O
normal O
testosterone O
levels O
. O

Twenty O
- O
two O
hypogonadal O
patients O
were O
re O
- O
evaluated O
after O
6 O
months O
of O
androgen O
therapy O
, O
but O
we O
did O
not O
observe O
any O
modification O
in O
the O
number O
of O
EPCs O
. O

These O
primary O
hypothesis O
- O
generating O
data O
suggest O
that O
factors O
involved O
in O
KS O
, O
whether O
hypogonadism O
, O
CRFs O
or O
other O
genetically O
determined O
factors O
related O
to O
the O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosome O
might O
contribute O
to O
a O
reduction O
in O
EPCs O
number O
and O
that O
this O
could O
be O
considered O
another O
CRF O
contributing O
to O
the O
increased O
mortality O
of O
these O
subjects O
. O

Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
and O
psychoneurologic O
function O
. O

Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
due O
to O
the O
presence O
of O
one O
or O
more O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosomes O
. O

Aneuploidy O
47 O
, O
XXY O
is O
the O
most O
common O
abnormality O
of O
sex O
chromosomes O
in O
humans O
, O
with O
an O
incidence O
of O
1 O
/ O
500 O
male O
live O
births O
. O

Only O
one O
- O
third O
of O
subjects O
with O
KS O
is O
, O
however O
, O
diagnosed O
. O

The O
aim O
of O
this O
work O
is O
to O
present O
a O
review O
of O
current O
literature O
about O
neurogenetic O
functions O
in O
KS O
, O
referring O
to O
both O
clinical O
and O
therapeutics O
aspects O
. O

If O
it O
is O
well O
known O
that O
the O
majority O
of O
subjects O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
have O
a O
normal O
intellectual O
level O
, O
the O
identification O
of O
strengths O
and O
weaknesses O
of O
their O
intellectual O
functioning O
is O
important O
for O
the O
purpose O
of O
planning O
early O
psycho O
- O
educational O
interventions O
. O

Language O
difficulties O
are O
one O
of O
the O
more O
distinctive O
traits O
in O
cognitive O
functioning O
of O
people O
with O
KS O
. O

It O
has O
also O
been O
suggested O
that O
the O
limitations O
in O
communication O
markedly O
affect O
social O
adaptation O
and O
behavioral O
aspects O
, O
as O
well O
as O
the O
development O
of O
personality O
. O

Moreover O
, O
difficulties O
in O
learning O
language O
appear O
to O
be O
related O
to O
an O
altered O
functional O
lateralization O
; O
therefore O
, O
KS O
subjects O
are O
a O
suitable O
model O
for O
studying O
genetic O
abnormalities O
of O
lateralization O
. O

In O
this O
, O
perspective O
psychopathological O
risk O
is O
analyzed O
. O

Early O
recognition O
of O
this O
aspect O
is O
needed O
to O
address O
the O
educational O
and O
therapeutic O
perspectives O
for O
KS O
subjects O
. O

Comprehensive O
5 O
- O
year O
study O
of O
cytogenetic O
aberrations O
in O
668 O
infertile O
men O
. O

The O
causes O
of O

are O
heterogeneous O
but O
more O
than O
50 O
% O
of O
cases O
have O
a O

. O

Specific O

have O

of O

males O

to O

. O

The O

Clinical O

profile O
of O

of O

- O
48 O
, O
XXXY O
. O

Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
is O
a O
sex O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
caused O
by O
an O
addition O
of O
X O
chromosome O
in O
males O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
. O
Variants O
of O
this O
syndrome O
with O
X O
and O
Y O
polygamy O
are O
of O
rare O
occurrence O
. O

Here O
we O
describe O
a O
rare O
case O
of O
48 O
, O
XXXY O

' O

variant O
from O

India O
with O

of O
1 O
per O
17 O
, O
000 O
to O
1 O
per O
50 O
, O
000 O
male O

. O

The O

of O
an O
extra O
X O
chromosome O
/ O

in O

, O

could O
be O

to O
gene O

effects O
and O
genes O
involved O
in O

development O
. O

Reproductive O
outcome O
of O
male O
carriers O
of O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
: O
multidisciplinary O
approach O
for O
genetic O
counseling O
and O
its O
implications O
. O

Chromosomal O
abnormality O
is O
the O
most O
common O
genetic O
cause O
of O
infertility O
. O

Infertility O
, O
as O
a O
psychological O
problem O
, O
has O
received O
an O
increasing O
amount O
of O
attention O
. O

Psychological O
interventions O
have O
been O
shown O
to O
have O
beneficial O
effects O
on O
infertile O
patients O
with O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
. O

The O
present O
study O
explored O
reproductive O
outcome O
of O
male O
carriers O
of O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
, O
who O
accepted O
genetic O
counseling O
and O
psychological O
support O
. O

Cytogenetic O
analysis O
was O
performed O
using O
cultured O
peripheral O
blood O
lymphocytes O
and O
G O
- O
banding O
. O

The O
detection O
rate O
of O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
was O
10 O
. O
3 O
% O
in O
pre O
- O
pregnancy O
counseled O
males O
, O
with O
polymorphisms O
being O
most O
common O
, O
followed O
by O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
balanced O
translocation O
. O

Follow O
- O
up O
of O
170 O
carriers O
with O
normozoospermia O
, O
after O
3 O
years O
, O
showed O
that O
94 O
. O
7 O
% O
of O
the O
cases O
resulted O
in O
live O
births O
. O

In O
the O
carriers O
of O
polymorphisms O
, O
balanced O
translocation O
, O
inv O
( O
9 O
) O
, O

translocation O
, O
inversion O
, O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
, O
live O
birth O
rates O
were O
96 O
. O
8 O
, O
85 O
. O
7 O
, O
100 O
, O
83 O
. O
3 O
, O
75 O
, O
and O
100 O
% O
, O
respectively O
. O

Follow O
- O
up O
of O
54 O
carriers O
with O
oligozoospermia O
or O
azoospermia O
, O
after O
3 O
years O
, O
showed O
that O
14 O
. O
8 O
% O
of O
the O
cases O
resulted O
in O
live O

. O

In O
the O
carriers O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
with O
severe O
oligozoospermia O
or O
azoospermia O
, O
80 O
or O
5 O
. O

% O
of O
the O

resulted O
in O
live O
births O
, O
respectively O
. O

Therefore O
, O
timely O

support O
would O
be O
beneficial O
and O

approach O
should O
be O
preferentially O
considered O
for O

of O
individuals O
with O

. O

Cytogenetic O
analysis O
of O
the O

products O
of O
conception O
after O
missed O
abortion O
following O

: O

, O

- O
scale O

. O

Cytogenetic O
analysis O
of O
the O
retained O
products O
of O
conception O
( O
POC O
) O
is O
the O
most O
effective O
test O
for O
identifying O
miscarriage O
causes O
. O

However O
, O
there O
has O
been O
no O
large O
- O
scale O
study O
limited O
to O
blastocyst O
transfer O
. O

This O
study O
retrospectively O
reports O
the O
findings O
of O
1030 O
cases O
in O
which O
POC O
analysis O
was O
performed O
after O
missed O
abortion O
following O
single O
blastocyst O
transfer O
performed O
at O
the O
Shinbashi O
Yume O
Clinic O
. O

We O
identified O
19 O
. O
4 O
% O
as O
normal O
karyotypes O
and O
80 O
. O
6 O
% O
as O
aneuploid O
. O

These O
cases O
broke O
down O
into O
: O
62 O
. O
3 O
% O
trisomy O
; O
7 O
. O
8 O
% O
double O
trisomy O
; O
0 O
. O
5 O
% O
triple O
or O
quadruple O
trisomy O
; O
1 O
. O
3 O
% O
monosomy O
21 O
; O
3 O
. O
2 O
% O
monosomy O
X O
; O
0 O
. O
1 O
% O
47 O
, O
XXY O
; O
1 O
. O
0 O
% O
polyploidy O
; O
1 O
. O
0 O
% O
mixed O
; O
1 O
. O
1 O
% O
embryonic O
mosaicism O
; O
and O
2 O
. O
4 O
% O
structural O
anomalies O
. O

In O
samples O
with O
normal O
karyotypes O
, O
49 O
. O
5 O
% O
were O
female O
while O
50 O
. O
5 O
% O
were O
male O
. O

The O
occurrence O
of O
trisomy O
and O
double O
trisomy O
were O
both O
significantly O
more O
frequent O
in O
the O
≥ O
38 O
years O
group O
than O
in O
the O
≤ O
37 O
years O
group O
( O
P O
< O
0 O
. O
01 O
) O
. O

Trisomy O
was O
significantly O
more O
frequently O
associated O
with O
fetal O
heartbeat O
( O
P O
< O
0 O
. O
01 O
) O
; O
double O
trisomy O
, O
polyploidy O
and O
normal O
karyotype O
were O
significantly O
more O
frequent O
with O
no O
fetal O
heartbeat O
( O
P O
< O
0 O
. O
01 O
) O
. O

There O
was O
no O
significant O
difference O
in O
the O
frequency O
of O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
between O
the O
number O
of O
miscarriages O
or O
blastocyst O
quality O
. O

Thus O
, O
POC O
cytogenetic O
testing O
is O
highly O
valuable O
for O
ascertaining O
the O
cause O
of O
miscarriage O
. O

XCI O
- O
escaping O
gene O
KDM5C O
contributes O
to O
ovarian O
development O
via O
downregulating O
miR O
- O
320a O
. O

Mechanisms O
underlying O
female O
gonadal O
dysgenesis O
remain O
unclarified O
and O
relatively O
unstudied O
. O

Whether O
X O
- O
chromosome O
inactivation O
( O
XCI O
) O
- O
escaping O
genes O
and O
microRNAs O
( O
miRNAs O
) O
contribute O
to O
this O
condition O
is O
currently O
unknown O
. O

We O
compared O
45 O
, O
X O
Turner O
Syndrome O
women O
with O

to O
include O
additional O
genetic O
tests O
, O
such O
as O
CFTR O
gene O
mutations O
, O
sperm O

DNA O
mutations O
, O
and O
androgen O
receptor O
gene O

, O
besides O
the O
conventional O
chromosomal O
analyses O
, O

chromosome O
microdeletion O
detection O
, O
and O
sperm O
- O
FISH O
analyses O
. O

Testicular O
function O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O
genetic O
form O
of O
male O
hypogonadism O
, O
but O
the O
phenotype O
becomes O
evident O
only O
after O
puberty O
. O

During O
childhood O
, O
and O
even O
during O
early O
puberty O
, O
pituitary O
- O
gonadal O
function O
in O
47 O
, O
XXY O
subjects O
is O
relatively O
normal O
, O
but O
from O
midpuberty O
onwards O
, O
FSH O
and O
LH O
levels O
increase O
to O
hypergonadotropic O
levels O
, O
inhibin O
B O
decreases O
to O
undetectable O
levels O
, O
and O
testosterone O
after O
an O
initial O
increase O
levels O
off O
at O
a O
low O
or O
low O
- O
normal O
level O
. O

Hence O
, O
most O
adult O
KS O
males O
display O
a O
clear O
hypergonadotropism O
with O
a O
varying O
degree O
of O
androgen O
deficiency O
; O
subsequently O
, O
testosterone O
substitution O
therapy O
is O
widely O
used O
to O
prevent O
symptoms O
and O
sequels O
of O
androgen O
deficiency O
. O

Testicular O
biopsies O
of O
prepubertal O
KS O
boys O
have O
shown O
preservation O
of O
seminiferous O
tubules O
with O
reduced O
numbers O
of O
germ O
cells O
, O
but O
Sertoli O
and O
Leydig O
cells O
have O
appeared O
normal O
. O

The O
testes O
in O
the O
adult O
KS O
male O
are O
, O
however O
, O
characterized O
by O
extensive O
fibrosis O
and O
hyalinization O
of O
the O
seminiferous O
tubules O
, O
and O
hyperplasia O
of O
the O
interstitium O
, O
but O
the O
tubules O
may O
show O
residual O
foci O
of O
spermatogenesis O
. O

Introduction O
of O
testicular O
sperm O
extraction O
in O
combination O
with O
intracytoplasmic O
sperm O
injection O
techniques O
has O
allowed O
non O
- O
mosaic O
KS O
males O
to O
father O
children O
. O

Brain O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
findings O
in O
49 O
, O
XXXXY O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
is O
a O

characterized O
by O
one O
or O

, O

Whereas O

( O

) O

in O
1 O
: O
400 O
births O
, O
the O
most O

( O
49 O
, O
XXXXY O
) O
occurs O
in O
only O
1 O
: O
85 O
, O

births O
. O

The O
degree O
of O

, O

, O
and O

with O

of O

- O

present O
. O

Magnetic O

in O

, O

We O

reports O
and O

of O

, O

. O

Neural O
systems O
for O
social O
cognition O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
: O

from O

. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
a O
chromosomal O
condition O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
that O
may O
help O

to O
unravel O
gene O
- O

to O

. O

The O
phenotype O
includes O
social O
cognitive O
impairments O
and O
increased O
risk O
for O

traits O
. O

We O
used O
functional O
MRI O
to O
study O
neural O
mechanisms O
underlying O
social O
information O
processing O
. O

Eighteen O
nonclinical O
controls O
and O
thirteen O
men O
with O
XXY O
were O
scanned O
during O
judgments O
of O
faces O
with O

to O

and O

. O

While O

as O
untrustworthy O

to O
trustworthy O

with O

displayed O

( O
i O
) O

, O
which O
plays O

in O

information O
for O

- O

, O
( O
ii O
) O

, O

experience O
, O

( O

and O
( O

, O

of O

and O

. O

This O

can O

as O

and O

. O

Pregnancy O
outcomes O
in O
188 O
French O
cases O
of O
prenatally O
diagnosed O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
, O
a O
common O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
is O
diagnosed O
prenatally O
with O
an O

of O
0 O
. O
15 O
% O
. O

The O

is O
generally O

, O
since O
there O
are O
no O
typical O
malformations O
on O

( O
US O
) O
. O

Once O
detected O

is O
often O

and O

' O

to O
continue O

. O

We O
sought O
to O
assess O

outcomes O
( O

. O

. O
continuation O
versus O

in O

From O

, O

of O

In O

, O

, O

of O

, O

procedure O
, O

, O

were O
recorded O
. O

The O
pregnancy O

rate O
declined O

over O

, O

46 O
. O
9 O

11 O
. O

% O
thereafter O
, O

, O

in O

. O

. O

of O

used O
to O

of O

and O

- O

. O

A O

( O

) O

Second O

. O

Diagnosis O
and O
treatment O
difficulties O
of O
psychiatric O
symptoms O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
: O
a O
case O
report O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
can O
involve O
various O
psychiatric O
symptoms O
that O
are O
often O
heterogeneous O
and O
atypical O
. O

To O
illustrate O
the O
diagnosis O
and O
treatment O
difficulties O
of O
psychiatric O
non O
- O
specific O
symptoms O
occurring O
in O
KS O
, O
we O
report O
a O
17 O
- O
year O
- O
old O
man O
presenting O
with O
gynaecomastia O
and O
marfanoid O
features O
. O

Investigations O
showed O
high O
concentrations O
of O
gonadotrophins O
and O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

Although O

was O
normal O
, O

patient O
had O

and O
suffered O
from O

. O

revealed O
pituitary O
non O
- O

. O

Treatment O
with O

resulted O
in O
a O

of O

levels O
and O
a O

in O

size O
. O

During O

- O
up O
, O

and O

to O

. O

depression O
, O
schizotypical O
personality O
and O
patterns O
of O

. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
is O
one O
of O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
chromosomal O
aneuploidies O
( O
1 O
in O
650 O
male O

) O
and O
associated O
with O
increased O

for O
psychopathology O
, O
including O
psychotic O
symptoms O
. O

Yet O
, O

remains O
unknown O
whether O
this O
increased O
risk O
is O
associated O
with O
underlying O
psychophysiological O
mechanisms O
that O
are O
typically O
deficient O
in O
individuals O
with O
psychotic O
disorders O
. O

The O
present O
study O
assessed O
three O
" O
classic O
" O
psychophysiological O
markers O
of O
psychosis O
in O

syndrome O
( O

) O
: O

( O

) O
, O

( O

) O
and O

. O

Fourteen O
adults O
with O

and O
15 O
non O
- O
clinical O
adults O
participated O
in O
the O
study O
. O

Data O
on O
SPEM O
( O
reflecting O
visuo O
- O
motor O
control O
) O
as O
well O
as O
PPI O
and O
P50 O
suppression O
( O

) O
were O
collected O
. O

Dysfunctions O
in O

were O
observed O
in O
individuals O
with O

, O
with O
less O
smooth O
pursuit O
as O
expressed O
in O
lower O
position O
gain O
. O

Also O

gating O
in O

was O
suggested O
by O
significantly O
reduced O

of O
the O

response O
( O

) O
( O
effect O
size O
1 O
. O
6 O
) O
. O

No O
abnormalities O
were O
found O
in O
suppression O
of O
the O
P50 O
( O
effect O
size O
0 O
. O
6 O
) O
. O

We O
speculate O
that O

in O

may O

deficit O

. O

to O

of O

for O

Chromosomal O

in O

. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
describes O
the O
phenotype O
of O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
chromosome O
abnormality O
in O
humans O
and O
occurs O
in O
one O
of O
every O
600 O
newborn O
males O
. O

The O
typical O
symptoms O
are O
a O
tall O
stature O
, O

shoulders O
, O

hips O
, O

, O

, O

, O

to O

function O
, O

of O

, O

, O

normal O
to O

. O

Apart O
from O
that O
, O
amongst O
others O
, O
osteoporosis O
, O

, O

disease O
, O

. O

Some O
of O

features O
can O

that O

often O

the O

. O

of O
4 O

Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O

of O
sex O
chromosomes O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
and O
represents O
the O

of O

. O

Mechanisms O

to O

are O
still O

to O

of O

of O

on O

3 O

. O

The O

found O
that O
, O

to O
controls O
, O

showed O
the O

up O

and O
down O
- O

of O
656 O
and O

. O

( O

. O

Taken O

of O

of O

Effects O

Supernumerary O

( O

1 O

. O

Although O

is O

, O

has O

of O

and O

. O

) O
between O

( O

) O

( O

= O

) O

: O

numbers O

Amniocytes O
from O
aneuploidy O
embryos O
have O
enhanced O
random O
aneuploidy O
and O
signs O
of O
senescence O
- O
can O
these O
findings O
be O
related O
to O
medical O
problems O
? O

Genomic O
aneuploidy O
is O
a O
common O
cause O
of O
human O
genetic O
disorders O
. O

Individuals O
with O
aneuploidy O
tend O
to O
develop O
malignancies O
. O

Recent O
studies O
correlated O
aneuploidy O
with O
early O
aging O
, O
senescence O
and O
organ O
dysfunction O
. O

This O
study O
investigated O
potential O
explanations O
for O
these O
increased O
risks O
by O
evaluating O
random O
aneuploidy O
and O
senescence O
rates O
in O
amniocytes O
from O
fetuses O
with O
aneuploidy O
. O

The O
rates O
of O
random O
aneuploidy O
in O
amniocytes O
from O
normal O
pregnancies O
were O
evaluated O
and O
compared O
to O
amniocytes O
from O
fetuses O
with O
trisomies O
21 O
, O

and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
using O
a O
FISH O
technique O
with O
X O
+ O
Y O
, O
9 O
and O
18 O
probes O
. O

Senescence O
was O
evaluated O
by O
calculating O
the O
percentage O
of O
amniocytes O
with O
fragmented O
nuclei O
: O
senescence O
associated O

foci O
( O

) O
, O
using O

staining O
. O

Significantly O

of O

with O

were O

18 O

, O
and O
47 O
, O

( O
p O
< O
0 O
. O
001 O
) O

control O

for O

. O

Increased O

of O

with O

were O
observed O
among O

samples O
compared O
to O

. O

Higher O

of O

and O

were O

in O

from O

with O

. O

might O

to O

. O

dysfunction O
and O

with O

47 O
, O

47 O
, O

. O

Neuroimaging O

have O
shown O
that O

with O

and O

, O

is O

in O

. O

However O
, O

is O
little O
of O
knowledge O
of O

and O

of O

. O

The O
present O
study O
aims O
to O
provide O
in O
this O
. O

In O
total O
, O
40 O
children O
( O
23 O
boys O
with O
47 O

XXY O
and O
17 O
girls O
with O
47 O
, O
XXX O
) O

100 O

- O

controls O
( O
47 O

and O
53 O

) O
participated O
in O
the O
study O
. O

The O
participants O
were O
9 O
- O
18 O
years O
old O
. O

Processing O
speed O
and O
executive O
functioning O
were O
assessed O
using O
the O
Amsterdam O
Neuropsychological O
Testbattery O
( O

) O
and O

Questionnaire O
( O

) O
. O

Problems O
in O

and O

functioning O
were O
assessed O
with O
the O
Childhood O
Behavior O
Checklist O
( O
CBCL O
) O
. O

Children O
with O
an O
extra O
X O
chromosome O
showed O
deficits O
in O
inhibition O
, O
mental O
flexibility O
, O
sustained O
attention O
and O
visual O
working O
memory O
. O

Parental O
report O
showed O
high O
levels O
of O
everyday O
manifestations O
of O
executive O
dysfunction O
. O

More O
severe O
inhibition O
difficulties O
were O
associated O
with O
higher O
levels O
of O
thought O
problems O
, O
aggression O
and O
