breaking O
behavior O
. O

Boys O
and O
girls O
with O
an O
extra O
X O
chromosome O
could O
not O
be O
differentiated O
based O
on O
severity O
of O
executive O
dysfunction O
, O
however O
, O
girls O
had O
lower O
information O
processing O
speed O
than O
boys O
. O

These O
findings O
suggest O
that O
executive O
dysfunction O
may O
be O
part O
of O
the O
phenotype O
of O
children O
with O
an O
extra O
X O
chromosome O
, O
impacting O
the O
ability O
to O
function O
adequately O
in O
everyday O
life O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
children O
with O
impairments O
in O
inhibition O
may O
have O
more O
problems O
in O
regulating O
their O
thinking O
, O
emotions O
and O
behavior O
. O

47 O
, O
XXY O
/ O
48 O
, O
XXXY O
/ O
49 O
, O
XXXXY O
mosaic O
with O
hydrocephaly O
: O
a O
case O
report O
and O
review O
of O
the O
literature O
. O

Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
is O
a O
frequent O
genetic O
sexual O
alteration O
in O
males O
, O
associated O
with O
the O
47 O
, O
XXY O
aneuploidy O
. O

Several O
syndrome O
variants O
are O
caused O
by O
different O
X O
and O
Y O
polysomy O
and O
mosaicisms O
, O
including O
the O
49 O
, O
XXXXY O
condition O
described O
by O
some O
authors O
as O
Fraccaro O
' O
s O
syndrome O
. O

Mosaics O
with O
three O
or O
more O
different O
chromosomal O
lines O
are O
very O
rare O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
describe O
a O
case O
with O
XXY O
/ O
XXXY O
/ O
XXXXY O
mosaic O
in O
a O
newborn O
with O
clinical O
features O
of O
Fraccaro O
' O
s O
syndrome O
, O
but O
also O
with O
obstructive O
hydrocephaly O
which O
has O
not O
been O
reported O
previously O
. O

A O
simple O
screening O
method O
for O
detection O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
and O
other O
X O
- O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
based O
on O
copy O
number O
of O
the O
androgen O
receptor O
gene O
. O

Due O
to O
the O
high O
prevalence O
and O
variable O
phenotype O
of O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O
there O
is O
a O
need O
for O
a O
robust O
and O
rapid O
screening O
method O
allowing O
early O
diagnosis O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
report O
on O
the O
development O
and O
detailed O
clinical O
validation O
of O
a O
quantitative O
real O
- O
time O
PCR O
( O
qPCR O
) O
- O
based O
method O
of O
the O
copy O
number O
assessment O
of O
the O
androgen O
receptor O
( O
AR O
) O
gene O
, O
located O
to O
Xq11 O
. O
2 O
- O
q12 O
. O

We O
analysed O
samples O
from O
50 O
individuals O
, O
including O
a O
healthy O
male O
and O
female O
controls O
and O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
; O
48 O
, O
XXXY O
) O
( O
n O
= O
28 O
) O
, O
mosaicisms O
( O
46 O
, O
XX O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
/ O
48XXYY O
; O
45 O
, O
X O
/ O
46 O
, O
XY O
) O
( O
n O
= O
3 O
) O
, O
other O
sex O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
( O
46 O
, O
XX O
males O
; O
47 O
, O
XYY O
) O
( O
n O
= O
4 O
) O
and O
normal O
karyotypes O
( O
46 O
, O
XY O
) O
( O
n O
= O
13 O
) O
. O

The O
reference O
range O
for O
the O
AR O
- O
copy O
number O
was O
established O
as O
0 O
. O
8 O
- O
1 O
. O
2 O
for O
one O
copy O
and O
1 O
. O
7 O
- O
2 O
. O
3 O
for O
two O
copies O
. O

The O
qPCR O
results O
were O
within O
the O
reference O
range O
in O
17 O
/ O
18 O
samples O
( O
94 O
% O
) O
or O
30 O
/ O
31 O
( O
97 O
% O
) O
samples O
with O
one O
or O
two O
copies O
of O
the O
AR O
gene O
, O
respectively O
. O

None O
of O
the O
Klinefelter O
patients O
were O
misdiagnosed O
as O
having O
a O
karyotype O
with O
only O
one O
X O
- O
chromosome O
, O
and O
in O
none O
of O
the O
46 O
, O
XY O
males O
were O
two O
copies O
demonstrated O
. O

We O
systematically O
compared O
qPCR O
results O
with O
those O
obtained O
with O
another O
PCR O
- O
based O
method O
, O
the O
XIST O
- O
gene O
expression O
. O

The O
XIST O
- O
expression O
based O
assay O
was O
correct O
in O
only O
29 O
/ O
36 O
samples O
( O
81 O
% O
) O
. O

Our O
findings O
demonstrated O
that O
the O
AR O
- O
qPCR O
technique O
is O
a O
simple O
and O
reliable O
screening O
method O
for O
diagnosis O
of O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
or O
other O
chromosomal O
disorders O
involving O
an O
aberrant O
number O
of O
X O
- O
chromosomes O
. O

Genital O
anomalies O
in O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
is O
characterized O
by O
progressive O
testicular O
failure O
causing O
aspermatogenesis O
and O
androgen O
deficiency O
. O

Klinefelter O
patients O
classically O
have O
complete O
male O
sex O
differentiation O
, O
and O
genital O
anomalies O
are O
generally O
not O
recognized O
as O
associated O
features O
of O
the O
syndrome O
. O

We O
reviewed O
the O
cases O
of O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
with O
genitalia O
abnormalities O
from O
the O
Cambridge O
Disorders O
of O
Sex O
Development O
Database O
, O
and O
also O
reviewed O
previous O
case O
reports O
of O
genital O
anomalies O
associated O
with O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
and O
its O
variants O
. O

We O
present O
seven O
Klinefelter O
patients O
with O
abnormalities O
of O
the O
genitalia O
, O
ranging O
from O
mild O
anomalies O
( O
chordee O
) O
to O
moderate O
undervirilisation O
( O
bifid O
scrotum O
and O
perineal O
hypospadias O
) O
. O

Two O
cases O
were O
true O
hermaphrodites O
with O
karyotypes O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
/ O
46 O
, O
XX O
respectively O
. O

Though O
androgen O
insensitivity O
has O
been O
postulated O
previously O
as O
a O
possible O
pathogenic O
mechanism O
, O
we O
demonstrated O
normal O
androgen O
binding O
in O
3 O
cases O
in O
which O
this O
was O
studied O
. O

Review O
of O
other O
case O
reports O
revealed O
a O
range O
of O
mild O
- O
to O
- O
severe O
abnormalities O
as O
well O
as O
cases O
reported O
as O
sex O
reversal O
, O
testicular O
feminization O
, O
and O
true O
hermaphroditism O
. O

Genital O
anomalies O
are O
not O
commonly O
observed O
in O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
. O

However O
, O
it O
is O
important O
to O
acknowledge O
the O
association O
, O
and O
recognize O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
as O
one O
of O
the O
causes O
of O
abnormal O
genitalia O
at O
birth O
. O

Phenotype O
and O
management O
of O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
: O
new O
findings O
from O
a O
survey O
of O
69 O
children O
. O

Aicardi O
syndrome O
is O
a O
rare O
neurodevelopmental O
disorder O
characterized O
by O
agenesis O
of O
the O
corpus O
callosum O
, O
other O
developmental O
brain O
abnormalities O
, O
chorioretinal O
lacunae O
, O
and O
severe O
seizures O
. O

Current O
clinical O
knowledge O
is O
derived O
from O
small O
series O
that O
focus O
on O
these O
major O
defects O
. O

The O
authors O
performed O
a O
health O
survey O
on O
a O
large O
number O
of O
affected O
children O
to O
expand O
this O
knowledge O
and O
to O
uncover O
previously O
unrecognized O
features O
of O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
. O

Responses O
received O
from O
caregivers O
of O
69 O
children O
with O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
met O
inclusion O
criteria O
for O
data O
analysis O
. O

Ages O
ranged O
from O
5 O
months O
to O
32 O
years O
( O
mean O
, O
88 O
months O
) O
. O

All O
subjects O
were O
girls O
, O
except O
for O
1 O
boy O
with O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

The O
authors O
found O
that O
the O
growth O
rate O
in O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
slows O
at O
age O
10 O
years O
to O
below O
the O
5th O
percentile O
and O
that O
weight O
gain O
slows O
at O
age O
7 O
years O
to O
below O
the O
25th O
percentile O
. O

The O
median O
age O
of O
survival O
was O
estimated O
at O
18 O
. O
5 O
( O
+ O
/ O
- O
4 O
) O
years O
, O
more O
favorable O
than O
previously O
reported O
. O

The O
most O
common O
complication O
aside O
from O
seizures O
was O
gastrointestinal O
dysfunction O
, O
present O
in O
> O
90 O
% O
. O

The O
results O
from O
this O
survey O
contribute O
new O
information O
on O
Aicardi O
syndrome O
that O
will O
benefit O
clinical O
management O
, O
and O
collected O
data O
will O
benefit O
phenotype O
- O
driven O
research O
toward O
its O
underlying O
cause O
. O

Atypical O
Association O
of O
Angelman O
Syndrome O
and O
Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
in O
a O
Boy O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
Karyotype O
and O
Deletion O
15q11 O
. O
2 O
- O
q13 O
. O

Angelman O
syndrome O
( O
AS O
, O
OMIM O
105830 O
) O
is O
a O
neurogenetic O
disorder O
with O
firm O
clinical O
diagnostic O
guidelines O
, O
characterized O
by O
severe O
developmental O
delay O
and O
speech O
impairment O
, O
balanced O
and O
behavioral O
disturbance O
as O
well O
as O
microcephaly O
, O
seizures O
, O
and O
a O
characteristic O
electroencephalogram O
( O
EEG O
) O
. O

The O
majority O
of O
AS O
cases O
( O
70 O
% O
) O
are O
caused O
by O
a O
15q11 O
. O
2 O
- O
q13 O
deletion O
on O
the O
maternally O
derived O
chromosome O
. O

The O
frequency O
of O
AS O
has O
been O
estimated O
to O
be O
between O
1 O
/ O
10000 O
and O
1 O
/ O
20000 O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
occurs O
due O
to O
the O
presence O
of O
an O
extra O
X O
chromosome O
( O
karyotype O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
. O

The O
main O
features O
in O
KS O
are O
small O
testes O
, O
hypergonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
, O
gynecomastia O
, O
learning O
difficulties O
, O
and O
infertility O
. O

We O
present O
what O
is O
, O
to O
our O
knowledge O
, O
the O
first O
case O
of O
a O
patient O
with O
both O
KS O
and O
AS O
due O
to O
a O
15q11 O
. O
2 O
- O
q13 O
deletion O
on O
the O
maternally O
derived O
chromosome O
and O
an O
extra O
X O
chromosome O
of O
paternal O
origin O
. O

He O
showed O
dysmorphic O
features O
, O
axial O
hypotonia O
, O
and O
delayed O
acquisition O
of O
motor O
skills O
. O

Early O
diagnosis O
is O
essential O
for O
optimal O
treatment O
of O
AS O
children O
; O
this O
is O
one O
of O
the O
earliest O
diagnosed O
cases O
of O
AS O
probably O
due O
to O
the O
presence O
of O
two O
syndromes O
. O

Clinical O
findings O
in O
this O
patient O
here O
described O
may O
be O
helpful O
to O
identify O
any O
other O
cases O
and O
to O
evaluate O
recurrence O
risks O
in O
these O
families O
. O

[ O
Retardation O
of O
psychomotor O
development O
and O
tremor O
in O
a O
boy O
with O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
karyotype O
] O
. O

We O
report O
a O
seven O
- O
year O
- O
old O
boy O
with O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
karyotype O
, O
presenting O
with O
tremor O
and O
a O
slight O
retardation O
of O
psychomotor O
development O
. O

Although O
the O
physical O
phenotype O
is O
similar O
to O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
is O
associated O
with O
additional O
medical O
problems O
and O
more O
significant O
neurodevelopmental O
and O
psychological O
features O
. O

Increased O
awareness O
of O
such O
features O
is O
important O
to O
facilitate O
timely O
diagnosis O
and O
initiation O
of O
appropriate O
screenings O
and O
treatments O
. O

Karyotyping O
should O
be O
considered O
in O
individuals O
presenting O
with O
tremor O
and O
a O
history O
of O
develop O
- O
mental O
delay O
, O
learning O
disabilities O
, O
tall O
stature O
or O
micro O
- O
orchidism O
. O

Discordant O
sex O
in O
monozygotic O
XXY O
/ O
XX O
twins O
: O
a O
case O
report O
. O

We O
report O
a O
case O
of O
discordant O
phenotypic O
sex O
in O
monozygotic O
twins O
mosaic O
47 O
, O
XXY O
/ O
46 O
, O
XX O
: O
monozygotic O
heterokaryotypic O
twins O
. O

The O
twins O
presented O
with O
cognitive O
and O
comprehension O
delay O
, O
behavioural O
and O
language O
disorders O
, O
all O
symptoms O
frequently O
reported O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Molecular O
zygosity O
analysis O
with O
several O
markers O
confirmed O
that O
the O
twins O
are O
in O
effect O
monozygotic O
( O
MZ O
) O
. O

Array O
comparative O
genomic O
hybridization O
found O
no O
evidence O
for O
the O
implication O
of O
copy O
number O
variation O
in O
the O
phenotypes O
. O

Ultrasound O
scans O
of O
the O
reproductive O
organs O
revealed O
no O
abnormalities O
. O

Endocrine O
tests O
showed O
a O
low O
testosterone O
level O
in O
Twin O
1 O
( O
male O
phenotype O
) O
and O
a O
low O
gonadotrophin O
level O
in O
Twin O
2 O
( O
female O
phenotype O
) O
which O
, O
combined O
with O
the O
results O
from O
ultrasound O
examination O
, O
provided O
useful O
information O
for O
potentially O
predicting O
the O
future O
fertility O
potential O
of O
the O
twins O
. O

Blood O
karyotypes O
revealed O
the O
presence O
of O
a O
normal O
46 O
, O
XX O
cell O
line O
and O
an O
aneuplo O
ï O
d O
47 O
, O
XXY O
cell O
line O
in O
both O
patients O
. O

Examination O
of O
the O
chromosome O
constitutions O
of O
various O
tissues O
such O
as O
blood O
, O
buccal O
smear O
and O
urinary O
sediment O
not O
surprisingly O
showed O
different O
proportions O
for O
the O
46 O
, O
XX O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
cell O
lines O
, O
which O
most O
likely O
explains O
the O
discordant O
phenotypic O
sex O
and O
mild O
Klinefelter O
features O
. O

The O
most O
plausible O
underlying O
biological O
mechanism O
is O
a O
post O
- O
zygotic O
loss O
of O
the O
Y O
chromosome O
in O
an O
initially O
47 O
, O
XXY O
zygote O
. O

This O
would O
result O
in O
an O
embryo O
with O
both O
46 O
, O
XX O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
cells O
lines O
which O
could O
subsequently O
divide O
into O
two O
monozygotic O
embryos O
through O
a O
twinning O
process O
. O

The O
two O
cell O
lines O
would O
then O
be O
distributed O
differently O
between O
tissues O
which O
could O
result O
in O
phenotypic O
discordances O
in O
the O
twins O
. O

These O
observations O
emphasize O
the O
importance O
of O
regular O
paediatric O
evaluations O
to O
determine O
the O
optimal O
timing O
for O
fertility O
preservation O
measures O
and O
to O
detect O
new O
Klinefelter O
features O
which O
could O
appear O
throughout O
childhood O
in O
the O
two O
subjects O
. O

Retrospective O
analysis O
of O
fetal O
anterior O
abdominal O
wall O
defects O
. O

To O
analyze O
fetal O
abdominal O
defects O
diagnosed O
during O
the O
prenatal O
period O
in O
the O
perinatology O
department O
in O
a O
tertiary O
center O
in O
Turkey O
. O

This O
retrospective O
study O
consisted O
of O
27 O
cases O
diagnosed O
with O
fetal O
abdominal O
wall O
defects O
between O
January O
2011 O
and O
February O
2014 O
in O
the O
perinatology O
outpatient O
clinic O
of O
Celal O
Bayar O
University O
, O
Manisa O
, O
Turkey O
. O

Eighteen O
( O
66 O
. O
7 O
% O
) O
cases O
were O
diagnosed O
with O
omphalocele O
, O
6 O
( O
22 O
. O
2 O
% O
) O
had O
gastroschisis O
, O
and O
3 O
( O
11 O

102 O

. O

The O
aim O
of O
this O

follow O
- O

of O

of O

In O

( O
5 O
. O

% O

This O

already O

of O

. O

/ O

Lost O
for O

- O

. O

. O

These O

not O

These O

are O
still O

in O

and O
should O
be O
further O

and O

. O

In O

patients O
should O
be O

about O

data O

treatment O
: O

appears O

of O

, O
of O
de O
- O
novo O
, O
mainly O
sex O
- O
chromosomal O
aberrations O
and O
of O
transmitting O
fertility O
problems O
to O
the O
offspring O
. O

Patients O
should O
also O
be O
reassured O
that O
until O
now O
there O
seems O
to O
be O
no O
higher O
incidence O
of O
congenital O
malformations O
in O
children O
born O
after O
ICSI O
with O
epididymal O
or O
testicular O
spermatozoa O
or O
after O
replacement O
of O
ICSI O
embryos O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
is O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
chromosome O
disorder O
. O

Affected O
males O
carry O
an O
additional O
X O
chromosome O
, O
which O
results O
in O
male O
hypogonadism O
, O
androgen O
deficiency O
, O
and O
impaired O
spermatogenesis O
. O

Some O
patients O
may O
exhibit O
all O
of O
the O
classic O
signs O
of O
this O
disorder O
, O
including O
gynecomastia O
, O
small O
testes O
, O
sparse O
body O
hair O
, O
tallness O
, O
and O
infertility O
, O
whereas O
others O
, O
because O
of O
the O
wide O
variability O
in O
clinical O
expression O
, O
lack O
many O
of O
these O
features O
. O

Treatment O
consists O
of O
testosterone O
replacement O
therapy O
to O
correct O
the O
androgen O
deficiency O
and O
to O
provide O
patients O
with O
appropriate O
virilization O
. O

This O
therapy O
also O
has O
positive O
effects O
on O
mood O
and O
self O
- O
esteem O
and O
has O
been O
shown O
to O
protect O
against O
osteoporosis O
, O
although O
it O
will O
not O
reverse O
infertility O
. O

Although O
the O
diagnosis O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
is O
now O
made O
definitively O
using O
chromosomal O
karyotyping O
, O
revealing O
in O
most O
instances O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
genotype O
, O
the O
diagnosis O
also O
can O
be O
made O
using O
a O
careful O
history O
and O
results O
of O
a O
physical O
examination O
, O
with O
the O
hallmark O
being O
small O
, O
firm O
testes O
. O

As O
it O
affects O
1 O
in O
500 O
male O
patients O
and O
presents O
with O
a O
variety O
of O
clinical O
features O
, O
primary O
care O
physicians O
should O
be O
familiar O
with O
this O
condition O
. O

Age O
- O
specific O
incidences O
of O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
at O
the O
second O
trimester O
amniocentesis O
for O
Japanese O
mothers O
aged O
35 O
and O
older O
: O
collaborative O
study O
of O
5484 O
cases O
. O

The O
aim O
of O
this O
study O
was O
to O
calculate O
the O
expected O
incidences O
of O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
found O
at O
amniocentesis O
in O
Japanese O
women O
aged O
35 O
and O
older O
. O

From O
four O
clinics O
in O
Japan O
, O
we O
gathered O
genetic O
amniocentesis O
data O
on O
5484 O
pregnant O
women O
at O
risk O
only O
due O
to O
their O
advanced O
age O
, O
35 O
years O
and O
older O
. O

We O
analyzed O
the O
data O
using O
the O
logistic O
regression O
model O
. O

Of O
the O
5484 O
fetuses O
, O
117 O
( O
2 O
. O
1 O
% O
) O
were O
diagnosed O
with O
a O
chromosome O
abnormality O
. O

The O
abnormal O
karyotypes O
included O
42 O
cases O
of O
trisomy O
21 O
; O
13 O
of O

18 O
; O

of O

13 O
; O
10 O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
; O
4 O
of O
47 O
, O
XXX O
; O
1 O
of O

27 O
with O
various O
structural O

; O
and O
13 O
with O

types O
of O

. O

The O
incidences O
of O
trisomy O
21 O
, O
lethal O
autosomal O
aneuploidies O
( O
trisomy O
18 O
and O

13 O

and O

- O

abnormalities O
( O
XXY O
, O
XXX O
, O
XYY O
) O
increased O
with O
maternal O
age O
. O

Parameters O
of O
the O
regression O
equations O
with O
their O
standard O
errors O
were O
calculated O
and O
the O
expected O
incidences O
of O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
at O
each O
maternal O
age O
were O
derived O
. O

The O
expected O
incidences O
of O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
obtained O
in O
this O
study O
are O
the O
first O
data O
published O
for O
Japan O
and O
will O
be O
useful O
for O
the O
counseling O
of O
pregnant O
women O
. O

The O
incidence O
of O
trisomy O
21 O
is O
not O
different O
from O
the O
rates O
published O
previously O
for O
Western O
countries O
. O

The O
incidences O
of O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
are O
not O
affected O
by O
race O
or O
by O
geographic O
factors O
. O

, O

: O
a O

. O

cases O

review O
. O

Over O
100 O
cases O
of O
49 O
, O

syndrome O
have O
been O
published O
to O

Classic O

include O

, O

, O

. O

47 O

This O

The O

. O

( O

) O
. O

Most O

Biopsy O

" O

. O

The O

considered O

. O

This O

Eosinophilia O
was O
not O
a O

. O

Overall O

up O

Klinefelter O

( O

) O

sex O

occurring O
in O
1 O
in O
1 O
, O
000 O
males O
. O

An O

with O

, O

cell O

, O

in O

. O

is O
frequently O

. O

We O
report O
on O
a O

cell O
carcinoma O
( O
RCC O
) O
in O
a O

The O
advantages O
of O

- O
marker O
screening O
for O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
. O

Our O

of O

for O

. O

Our O

received O
10 O
, O

. O

. O

. O

In O

and O

of O

Combination O
of O
Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
and O
Acromegaly O
: O
A O
Rare O
Case O
Report O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
in O
male O
population O
, O
which O
demonstrates O
an O
unusual O
association O
with O
acromegaly O
. O

We O
herein O
present O
a O
rare O
case O
involving O
the O
confirmation O
of O
KS O
2 O
years O
after O
surgical O
treatment O
for O
acromegaly O
. O
A O
27 O
- O
year O
- O
old O
man O
presented O
with O
an O
acromegalic O
appearance O
. O

Endocrinological O
examination O
revealed O
a O
high O
growth O
hormone O
( O
GH O
) O
concentration O
, O
low O
testosterone O
concentration O
, O
and O
high O
follicle O
- O
stimulating O
hormone O
and O
luteinizing O
hormone O
concentration O
. O

Brain O
imaging O
revealed O
a O
9 O
O O
× O
O O
6 O
O O
× O
O O
7 O
- O
O O
mm O
sellar O
low O
- O
density O
nodule O

Trans O
- O
sphenoidal O
surgery O
was O
undertaken O
, O
and O
immunohistochemistry O
revealed O
GH O
positivity O
. O

Two O
years O
after O
surgery O
, O
the O
patient O
underwent O
examination O
for O
infertility O
. O

He O
presented O
with O
diminished O
pubic O
hair O
, O
and O
small O
and O
firm O
testes O
. O

Hormonal O
assay O
revealed O
hypergonadotrophic O

on O
the O

of O
decreased O

total O
testosterone O
( O
< O
0 O
. O
2 O
O O
ng O
/ O
mL O
) O
, O
and O
elevated O
luteinizing O
hormone O
( O
14 O
. O
71 O
O O
mIU O
/ O
mL O
) O
and O
follicle O
- O
stimulating O
hormone O
( O
21 O
. O
8 O
O O
mIU O
/ O

A O
chromosomal O

examination O
showed O
47 O
, O

the O

of O
KS O
. O

Replacement O

with O
oral O

was O
begun O
. O

Brain O

showed O
no O

in O

of O

, O
but O

of O

. O

The O

was O

by O

. O

In O

, O

was O

for O

to O
control O

hypersecretion O
. O
The O
misdiagnosis O

of O
KS O
is O
mainly O
because O
of O
substantial O
variations O
in O
clinical O
presentation O
and O
insufficient O
professional O
awareness O
of O
the O
syndrome O
itself O
. O

As O
the O
simultaneous O
occurrence O
of O
KS O
and O
acromegaly O
is O
rare O
, O
and O
the O
association O
between O
them O
remains O
unclear O
, O

suggest O
that O
complete O

and O
conventional O

should O
be O
essential O
for O
patients O
with O
KS O
to O
screen O
for O
pituitary O
tumor O
. O

Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
is O
in O
excess O
among O
men O
with O
Sj O
ö O
gren O
' O
s O
syndrome O
. O

Primary O
Sj O
ö O
gren O
' O
s O
syndrome O
( O
pSS O
) O
has O
a O
strong O

. O

We O
evaluated O
an O
X O
chromosome O
dose O
effect O
by O
analyzing O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O

' O
s O
syndrome O
, O
1 O
in O
500 O
live O
male O

) O
among O
subjects O
with O

. O
47 O
, O
XXY O
was O
determined O
by O
examination O
of O
fluorescence O
intensity O
of O
single O
nucleotide O
polymorphisms O
from O
the O
X O
and O

chromosomes O
. O

Among O
136 O

men O
there O
were O

47 O

. O

This O
was O

different O
from O

( O

of O
1254 O
had O

= O
0 O
. O

by O

' O

( O

These O

. O

Positive O
predictive O
value O
estimates O
for O
cell O
- O
free O
noninvasive O
prenatal O
screening O
from O
data O
of O
a O
large O
referral O
genetic O
diagnostic O
laboratory O
. O

Since O
its O
debut O
in O
2011 O
, O
cell O
- O
free O
fetal O
DNA O
screening O
has O
undergone O
rapid O
expansion O
with O
respect O
to O
both O
utilization O
and O
coverage O
. O

However O
, O
conclusive O
data O
regarding O
the O
clinical O
validity O
and O
utility O
of O
this O
screening O
tool O
, O
both O
for O
the O
originally O
included O
common O
autosomal O
and O
sex O
- O
chromosomal O
aneuploidies O
as O
well O
as O
the O
more O
recently O
added O
chromosomal O
microdeletion O
syndromes O
, O
have O
lagged O
behind O
. O

Thus O
, O
there O
is O
a O
continued O
need O
to O
educate O
clinicians O
and O
patients O
about O
the O
current O
benefits O
and O
limitations O
of O
this O
screening O
tool O
to O
inform O
pre O
- O
and O
posttest O
counseling O
, O
pre O
/ O
perinatal O
decision O
making O
, O
and O
medical O
risk O
assessment O
/ O
management O
. O

The O
objective O
of O
this O
study O
was O
to O
determine O
the O
positive O
predictive O
value O
and O
false O
- O
positive O
rates O
for O
different O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
identified O
by O
cell O
- O
free O
fetal O
DNA O
screening O
using O
a O
large O
data O
set O
of O
diagnostic O
testing O
results O
on O
invasive O
samples O
submitted O
to O
the O
laboratory O
for O
confirmatory O
studies O
. O

We O
tested O
712 O
patient O
samples O
sent O
to O
our O
laboratory O
to O
confirm O
a O
cell O
- O
free O
fetal O
DNA O
screening O
result O
, O
indicating O
high O
risk O
for O
a O
chromosome O
abnormality O
. O

We O
compiled O
data O
from O
all O
cases O
in O
which O
the O
indication O
for O
confirmatory O
testing O
was O
a O
positive O
cell O
- O
free O
fetal O
DNA O
screen O
, O
including O
the O
common O
trisomies O
, O
sex O
chromosomal O
aneuploidies O
, O
microdeletion O
syndromes O
, O
and O
other O
large O
genome O
- O
wide O
copy O
number O
abnormalities O
. O

Testing O
modalities O
included O
fluorescence O
in O
situ O
hybridization O
, O
G O
- O
banded O
karyotype O
, O
and O
/ O
or O
chromosomal O
microarray O
analysis O
performed O
on O
chorionic O
villus O
samples O
, O
amniotic O
fluid O
, O
or O
postnatally O
obtained O
blood O
samples O
. O

Positive O
predictive O
values O
and O
false O
- O
positive O
rates O
were O
calculated O
from O
tabulated O
data O
. O

The O
positive O
predictive O
values O
for O
trisomy O
13 O
, O
18 O
, O
and O
21 O
were O
consistent O
with O
previous O
reports O
at O
45 O
% O
, O
76 O
% O
, O
and O
84 O
% O
, O
respectively O
. O

For O
the O
microdeletion O
syndrome O
regions O
, O
positive O
predictive O
values O
ranged O
from O
0 O
% O
for O
detection O
of O
Cri O
- O
du O
- O
Chat O
syndrome O
and O
Prader O
- O
Willi O
/ O
Angelman O
syndrome O
to O
14 O
% O
for O
1p36 O
deletion O
syndrome O
and O
21 O
% O
for O
22q11 O
. O
2 O
deletion O
syndrome O
. O

Detection O
of O
sex O
chromosomal O
aneuploidies O
had O
positive O
predictive O
values O
of O
26 O
% O
for O
monosomy O
X O
, O
50 O
% O
for O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
and O
86 O
% O
for O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

The O
positive O
predictive O
values O
for O
detection O
of O
common O
autosomal O
and O
sex O
chromosomal O
aneuploidies O
by O
cell O
- O
free O
fetal O
DNA O
screening O
were O
comparable O
with O
other O
studies O
. O

Identification O
of O
microdeletions O
was O
associated O
with O
lower O
positive O
predictive O
values O
and O
higher O
false O
- O
positive O
rates O
, O
likely O
because O
of O
the O
low O
prevalence O
of O
the O
individual O
targeted O
microdeletion O
syndromes O
in O
the O
general O
population O
. O

Although O
the O
obtained O
positive O
predictive O
values O
compare O
favorably O
with O
those O
seen O
in O
traditional O
screening O
approaches O
for O
common O
aneuploidies O
, O
they O
highlight O
the O
importance O
of O
educating O
clinicians O
and O
patients O
on O
the O
limitations O
of O
cell O
- O
free O
fetal O
DNA O
screening O
tests O
. O

Improvement O
of O
the O
cell O
- O
free O
fetal O
DNA O
screening O
technology O
and O
continued O
monitoring O
of O
its O
performance O
after O
introduction O
into O
clinical O
practice O
will O
be O
important O
to O
fully O
establish O
its O
clinical O
utility O
. O

Nonetheless O
, O
our O
data O
provide O
valuable O
information O
that O
may O
aid O
result O
interpretation O
, O
patient O
counseling O
, O
and O
clinical O
decision O
making O
/ O
management O
. O

Aberrant O
ocular O
architecture O
and O
function O
in O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
, O
the O
most O
common O
chromosomal O
disorder O
in O
men O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
, O
is O
associated O
with O
numerous O
comorbidities O
. O

Based O
on O
a O
number O
of O
isolated O
case O
reports O
, O
we O
performed O
the O
first O
systematic O
and O
comprehensive O
evaluation O
of O
eye O
health O
in O
KS O
patients O
with O
a O
focus O
on O
ocular O
structure O
and O
vascularization O
. O

Twenty O
- O
one O
KS O
patients O
and O
26 O
male O
and O
38 O
female O
controls O
underwent O
a O
variety O
of O
non O
- O
invasive O
examinations O
investigating O
ocular O
morphology O
( O
examination O
of O
retinal O
thickness O
, O
optic O
nerve O
head O
, O
and O
cornea O
) O
and O
function O
( O
visual O
field O
testing O
and O
quantification O
of O
ocular O
vessel O
density O
by O
optical O
coherence O
tomography O
angiography O
) O
. O

In O
comparison O
to O
healthy O
controls O
, O
KS O
patients O
exhibited O
a O
smaller O
foveal O
avascular O
zone O
and O
a O
decreased O
retinal O
thickness O
due O
to O
a O
drastically O
thinner O
outer O
nuclear O
layer O
. O

The O
cornea O
of O
KS O
patients O
showed O
a O
decreased O
peripheral O
thickness O
and O
volume O
. O

In O
perimetry O
evaluation O
, O
KS O
patients O
required O
brighter O
stimuli O
and O
gave O
more O
irregular O
values O
. O

KS O
patients O
show O
an O
ocular O
phenotype O
including O
morphological O
and O
functional O
features O
, O
which O
is O
very O
likely O
caused O
by O
the O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosome O
. O

Thus O
, O
KS O
should O
not O
be O
limited O
to O
infertility O
, O
endocrine O
dysfunction O
, O
neurocognitive O
and O
psychosocial O
comorbidities O
. O

Defining O
an O
aberrant O
ocular O
morphology O
and O
function O
, O
awareness O
for O
possible O
eye O
problems O
should O
be O
raised O
. O

Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
in O
Childhood O
: O
Variability O
in O
Clinical O
and O
Molecular O
Findings O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O
( O
1 O
/ O
500 O
– O
1 O
/ O
1000 O
) O
chromosomal O
disorder O
in O
males O
, O
but O
only O
10 O
% O
of O
cases O
are O
identified O
in O
childhood O
. O

This O
study O
aimed O
to O
review O
the O
data O
of O
children O
with O
KS O
to O
assess O
the O
age O
and O
presenting O
symptoms O
for O
diagnosis O
, O
clinical O
and O
laboratory O
findings O
, O
together O
with O
the O
presence O
of O
comorbidities O
. O

Twenty O
- O
three O
KS O
patients O
were O
analyzed O
retrospectively O
. O

Age O
at O
admission O
, O
presenting O
symptoms O
, O
comorbid O
problems O
, O
height O
, O
weight O
, O
pubertal O
status O
, O
biochemical O
findings O
, O
hormone O
profiles O
, O
bone O
mineral O
density O
and O
karyotype O
were O
evaluated O
. O

Molecular O
analysis O
was O
also O
conducted O
in O
patients O
with O
ambiguous O
genitalia O
. O

The O
median O
age O
of O
patients O
at O
presentation O
was O
3 O
. O
0 O
( O
0 O
. O
04 O
- O
16 O
. O
3 O
) O
years O
. O

Most O
of O
the O
cases O
were O
diagnosed O
prenatally O
( O
n O
= O
15 O
, O
65 O
. O
2 O
% O
) O
. O

Other O
reasons O
for O
admission O
were O
scrotal O
hypospadias O
( O
n O
= O
3 O
, O
14 O
. O
3 O
% O
) O
, O
undescended O
testis O
( O
n O
= O
2 O
, O
9 O
. O
5 O
% O
) O
, O
short O
stature O
( O
n O
= O
1 O
, O
4 O
. O
8 O
% O
) O
, O
isolated O
micropenis O
( O
n O
= O
1 O
, O
4 O
. O
8 O
% O
) O
and O
a O
speech O

( O

= O

Parental O

. O

According O

, O

to O

of O

A O
case O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
with O
hypersexual O
desire O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
a O
chromosomal O
disorder O
affecting O
males O
, O
with O
the O
typical O
karyotype O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
due O
to O
a O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosome O
, O
which O
causes O
progressive O
testicular O
failure O
resulting O
in O
androgen O
deficiency O
and O
infertility O
. O

Despite O
it O
being O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
chromosomal O
disorder O
, O
its O
diagnosis O
is O
easily O
missed O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
its O
classical O
clinical O
features O
of O
tall O
stature O
, O
gynaecomastia O
, O
small O
testes O
, O
and O
symptoms O
and O
signs O
of O
hypogonadism O
including O
infertility O
, O
KS O
is O
also O
often O
associated O
with O
neurocognitive O
, O
behavioural O
and O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O

We O
present O
a O
44 O
- O
year O
- O
old O
man O
with O
KS O
who O
, O
despite O
having O
erectile O
dysfunction O
, O
paradoxically O
had O
increased O
libido O
. O

He O
used O
sildenafil O
to O
overcome O
his O
erectile O
dysfunction O
. O

Hypersexuality O
was O
manifested O
by O
very O
frequent O
masturbation O
, O
multiple O
sexual O
partners O
most O
of O
whom O
were O
casual O
, O
and O
a O
sexual O
offence O
conviction O
at O
the O
age O
of O
17 O
years O
. O

Discussion O
focuses O
on O
the O
frequent O
failure O
of O
clinicians O
to O
diagnose O
KS O
, O
the O
neurocognitive O
, O
behavioural O
and O
psychiatric O
aspects O
of O
KS O
, O
this O
unusual O
presentation O
of O
hypersexuality O
in O
a O
man O
with O
KS O
, O
and O
the O
challenges O
of O
medical O
management O
of O
hypogonadism O
in O
a O
man O
with O
a O
history O
of O
a O
sexual O
offence O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
common O
in O
men O
( O
about O
1 O
in O
600 O
males O
) O
, O
but O
the O
diagnosis O
is O
very O
often O
missed O
. O
In O
addition O
to O
classic O
features O
of O
hypogonadism O
, O
patients O
with O
KS O
can O
often O
have O
associated O
neurocognitive O
, O
behavioural O
and O
/ O
or O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O
More O
awareness O
of O
the O
association O
between O
KS O
and O
difficulties O
related O
to O
verbal O
skills O
in O
boys O
could O
improve O
rates O
of O
early O
diagnosis O
and O
prevent O
longer O
- O
term O
psychosocial O
disability O
. O
Hypersexuality O
in O
the O
context O
of O
hypogonadism O
raises O
the O
possibility O
of O
sex O
steroid O
independent O
mechanistic O
pathways O
for O

libido O
. O
Testosterone O
replacement O
therapy O
in O
KS O
with O
hypersexuality O
should O
be O
undertaken O
with O
caution O
using O

a O
multidisciplinary O
team O
approach O
. O

Achondroplasia O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
: O
a O
case O
report O
of O
the O

of O
an O
extremely O
unusual O
association O
. O

The O
association O
of O

and O

syndrome O
is O
extremely O
rare O
. O

To O
date O
, O
five O

have O
been O
previously O
reported O
, O
all O

diagnosed O
beyond O
the O

, O

. O

We O
describe O
the O
first O

of O
this O

in O

and O

undertaken O
. O

The O
boy O
was O
born O
at O

with O

of O

( O

) O
. O

Neonatal O

showed O
that O

was O

for O
the O

. O

that O

from O

in O

, O

. O

Specific O

analysis O
is O

to O
confirm O
the O

of O

for O
appropriate O

, O

, O

, O

does O
not O

. O

In O

, O

region O
, O

in O

. O

Schizotypy O
: O
key O
feature O
of O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
? O

Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
; O
karyotype O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
is O
associated O
with O
specific O
neurocognitive O
impairments O
, O
especially O
delayed O
language O
development O
and O
impaired O
socioemotional O
evolution O
. O

There O
is O
an O
increased O
risk O
for O
psychiatric O
disturbances O
, O
particularly O
schizophrenia O
and O
affective O
spectrum O
disorders O
. O

A O
51 O
- O

- O
old O

male O

with O
KS O
is O
described O
of O
whom O
one O
was O
referred O
for O
long O
- O

paranoid O
psychotic O
symptoms O
. O

Both O
were O
treated O
with O
testosterone O
and O
had O
an O
average O
level O
of O
intelligence O
. O

Detailed O
psychiatric O
and O

assessment O
in O
the O

patient O
demonstrated O
quasi O
- O

, O

- O

, O

, O

, O

and O
thinking O

. O

In O

, O

and O

could O
be O
demonstrated O
. O

A O
diagnosis O
of O
schizotypal O
personality O
disorder O
was O
made O
. O

A O
less O
pronounced O
identical O
clinical O
picture O
was O
found O
in O
his O
brother O
. O

The O
psychopathological O
phenotype O
of O
KS O
is O
characterised O
by O
a O
schizotypal O
personality O
which O
originates O
from O
its O
specific O
cognitive O

and O
that O
, O

increasing O

, O
may O
develop O
into O
a O

. O

Detailed O
analysis O
of O
an O
idic O
( O

) O
( O
q11 O
. O
21 O
) O
in O
a O
mosaic O

. O

Abnormalities O
involving O
sex O
chromosomes O
account O
for O
approximately O
0 O
. O
5 O
% O

. O

The O

a O

, O
+ O

. O

( O

We O
present O
a O

of O

to O

. O

, O
XX O
, O
+ O
idic O
( O
Y O
) O
( O
q11 O
. O
21 O
) O
detected O
only O
once O
in O
1 O
% O
of O
the O
peripheral O
blood O
cells O
. O

This O
finding O
may O
prove O

in O

of O

, O

of O

47 O
, O
XXY O
in O
peripheral O
blood O
. O

F8 O
gene O
dosage O
defects O
in O
atypical O
patients O
with O
severe O
haemophilia O
A O
. O

We O
performed O
molecular O
analysis O
of O
the O
factor O
8 O
gene O
( O
F8 O
) O
in O
272 O
unrelated O
Spanish O
patients O
with O
haemophilia O
A O
( O
HA O
) O
and O
detected O
a O
mutation O
by O
routine O
analysis O
in O
267 O
of O
them O
( O
98 O
. O
1 O
% O
) O
. O

No O
mutation O
was O
detected O
in O
the O
remaining O
five O
patients O
despite O
clinical O
and O
laboratory O
confirmation O
of O
HA O
. O

The O
aim O
is O
to O
describe O
the O
molecular O
alterations O
in O
F8 O
discovered O
by O
gene O
dosage O
methodologies O
in O
three O
of O
these O
patients O
. O

For O
methodology O
, O
F8 O
sequencing O
, O
intragenic O
marker O
analysis O
, O
multiplex O
ligation O
- O
dependent O
probe O
amplification O
and O
quantitative O
real O
time O
- O
PCR O
were O
followed O
. O

One O
patient O
had O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
and O
a O
large O
deletion O
spanning O
exons O
1 O
- O
12 O
masked O
by O
the O
other O
F8 O
allele O
; O
the O
second O
patient O
showed O
a O
large O
duplication O
spanning O
exons O
2 O
- O
10 O
and O
the O
third O
patient O
revealed O
a O
non O
- O
contiguous O
double O
duplication O
of O
exons O
14 O
and O
23 O
- O
25 O
. O

The O
remaining O
two O
patients O
had O
mild O
HA O
and O
dosage O
results O
were O
normal O
. O

The O
application O
of O
gene O
dosage O
methods O
is O
useful O
to O
define O
haemophilic O
patients O
in O
whom O
mutations O
are O
not O
detected O
using O
other O
routine O
methods O
. O

Nevertheless O
, O
in O
a O
small O
percentage O
of O
patients O
( O
< O
1 O
% O
) O
, O
no O
molecular O
pathology O
can O
be O
identified O
after O
testing O
several O
genetic O
methodologies O
. O

Molecular O
diagnostic O
testing O
for O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
and O
other O
male O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
. O

Male O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
are O
underdiagnosed O
despite O
concomitant O
physical O
and O
behavioral O
manifestations O
. O

To O
develop O
a O
non O
- O
invasive O
, O
rapid O
and O
high O
- O
throughput O
molecular O
diagnostic O
assay O
for O
detection O
of O
male O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
, O
including O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
Klinefelter O
) O
, O
47 O
, O
XYY O
, O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
and O
48 O
, O
XXXY O
syndromes O
. O

The O
assay O
utilizes O
three O
XYM O
and O
four O
XA O
markers O
to O
interrogate O
Y O
: O
X O
and O
X O
: O
autosome O
ratios O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
seven O
markers O
were O
PCR O
amplified O
using O
genomic O
DNA O
isolated O
from O
a O
cohort O
of O
323 O
males O
with O
aneuploid O
( O
n O
O O
= O
O O
117 O
) O
and O
46 O
, O
XY O
( O
n O
O O
= O
O O

The O
resulting O
PCR O
products O
were O
subjected O
to O
Pyrosequencing O
, O
a O
quantitative O
DNA O
sequencing O
method O
. O

Receiver O
operator O
characteristic O
( O
ROC O
) O
curves O
were O
used O
to O
establish O
thresholds O
for O
the O
discrimination O
of O
aneuploid O
from O
normal O
samples O
. O

The O
XYM O
markers O
permitted O
the O
identification O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
48 O
, O
XXXY O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
syndromes O
with O
100 O
% O
sensitivity O
and O
specificity O
in O
both O
purified O
DNA O
and O
buccal O
swab O
samples O
. O

The O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
karyotype O
was O
delineated O
by O
XA O
marker O
data O
from O
46 O
, O
XY O
; O
an O
X O
allele O
threshold O
of O
43 O
% O
also O
permitted O
detection O
of O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
with O
100 O
% O
sensitivity O
and O
specificity O
. O

Analysis O
of O
X O
chromosome O
- O
specific O
biallelic O
SNPs O
demonstrated O
that O
43 O
of O
45 O
individuals O
( O
96 O
% O
) O
with O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
karyotype O
had O
two O
distinct O
X O
chromosomes O
, O
while O
2 O
( O
4 O
% O
) O
had O
a O
duplicate O
X O
, O
providing O
evidence O
that O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
may O
result O
from O
nondisjunction O
during O
early O
mitotic O
divisions O
of O
a O
46 O
, O
XY O
embryo O
. O

Quantitative O
Pyrosequencing O
, O
with O
high O
- O
throughput O
potential O
, O
can O
detect O
male O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
with O
100 O
% O
sensitivity O
. O

A O
unique O
patient O
presenting O
with O
concomitant O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O
Alport O
syndrome O
, O
and O
craniopharyngioma O
. O

A O
31 O
- O
year O
- O
old O
Caucasian O
male O
was O
referred O
for O
panhypopituitarism O
resulting O
from O
a O
surgically O
removed O
craniopharyngioma O
. O

The O
patient O
had O
been O
previously O
submitted O
to O
kidney O
transplantation O
for O
end O
- O
stage O
renal O
disease O
from O
X O
- O
linked O
Alport O
syndrome O
( O
ATS O
) O
. O

Subsequent O
quantitative O
fluorescent O
polymerase O
chain O
reaction O
analysis O
indicated O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
consistent O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
. O

The O
relevance O
of O
this O
unique O
case O
stems O
from O
several O
issues O
: O
1 O
) O
KS O
was O
an O
unexpected O
finding O
because O
of O
a O
previous O
diagnosis O
of O
hypogonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
resulting O
from O
craniopharyngioma O
; O
2 O
) O
the O
discovery O
of O
a O
de O
novo O
p O
. O
G406S O
substitution O
causing O
ATS O
; O
and O
3 O
) O
the O
multifactor O
origin O
of O
severe O
sexual O
dysfunction O
. O

This O
is O
the O
first O
description O
of O
the O
co O
- O
occurrence O
of O
KS O
, O
ATS O
, O
and O
craniopharyngioma O
. O

The O
high O
frequency O
of O
sperm O
aneuploidy O
in O
klinefelter O
patients O
and O
in O
nonobstructive O
azoospermia O
is O
due O
to O
meiotic O
errors O
in O
euploid O
spermatocytes O
. O

For O
nonobstructive O
azoospermic O
( O
NOA O
) O
patients O
with O
a O
normal O
karyotype O
or O
for O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
patients O
, O
intracytoplasmic O
sperm O
injection O
is O
associated O
with O
an O
increased O
aneuploidy O
risk O
in O
offspring O
. O

We O
examined O
testicular O
cells O
from O
patients O
with O
different O
azoospermia O
etiologies O
to O
determine O
the O
origin O
of O
the O
aneuploid O
spermatozoa O
. O

The O
incidence O
of O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
was O
investigated O
in O
all O
types O
of O
azoospermia O
. O

Four O
study O
subgroups O
were O
constituted O
: O
Klinefelter O
patients O
( O
group O
1 O
) O
, O
NOA O
patients O
with O
spermatogenesis O
failure O
but O
a O
normal O
karyotype O
( O
group O
2 O
) O
, O
obstructive O
azoospermic O
patients O
with O
normal O
spermatogenesis O
( O
group O
3 O
) O
, O
and O
control O
patients O
with O
normal O
sperm O
( O
group O
4 O
) O
. O

The O
pachytene O
stage O
( O
in O
the O
three O
azoospermic O
groups O
) O
and O
postmeiotic O
cells O
( O
in O
all O
groups O
) O
were O
analyzed O
with O
fluorescence O
in O
situ O
hybridization O
. O

No O
aneuploid O
pachytene O
spermatocytes O
were O
observed O
. O

Postmeiotic O
aneuploidy O
rates O
were O
higher O
in O
the O
two O
groups O
with O
spermatogenesis O
failure O
( O
5 O
. O
3 O
% O
and O
4 O
. O
0 O
% O
for O
groups O
1 O
and O
2 O
, O
respectively O
) O
than O
in O
patients O
with O
normal O
spermatogenesis O
( O
0 O
. O
6 O
% O
for O
group O
3 O
and O
group O
4 O
) O
. O
Whatever O
the O
etiology O
of O
the O
azoospermia O
, O
the O
spermatozoa O
originated O
from O
euploid O
pachytene O
spermatocytes O
. O

These O
results O
strengthen O
the O
hypothesis O
whereby O
sperm O
aneuploidy O
in O
both O
Klinefelter O
patients O
and O
NOA O
patients O
with O
a O
normal O
karyotype O
results O
from O
meiotic O
abnormalities O
and O
not O
from O
aneuploid O
spermatocytes O
. O

The O
fact O
that O
sperm O
aneuploidy O
was O
more O
frequent O
when O
spermatogenesis O
was O
altered O
suggests O
a O
deleterious O
testicular O
environment O
. O

The O
study O
results O
also O
provide O
arguments O
for O
offering O
preimplantation O
genetic O
diagnosis O
or O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
when O
a O
pregnancy O
occurs O
for O
fathers O
with O
NOA O
( O
whatever O
the O
karyotype O
) O
. O

Reduced O
size O
of O
the O
amygdala O
in O
individuals O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
47 O
, O
XXX O
karyotypes O
. O

The O
excess O
of O
47 O
, O
XXX O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotypes O
found O
in O
cytogenetic O
screening O
studies O
of O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
has O
given O
support O
for O
an O
increased O
risk O
of O
psychiatric O
illness O
among O
men O
and O
women O
with O
sex O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
( O
SCA O
) O
. O

Mesial O
temporal O
lobe O
structures O
, O
including O
the O
amygdala O
and O
hippocampus O
, O
are O
thought O
to O
be O
associated O
with O
abnormalities O
of O
mood O
and O
behavior O
in O
humans O
and O
in O
the O
neurobiology O
of O

. O

This O
study O
focuses O
on O
variations O
in O
volumes O
of O
mesial O
temporal O
lobe O
structures O
in O
men O
and O
women O
with O
SCA O
. O

Utilizing O
an O
unselected O
birth O
cohort O
of O
subjects O
with O
SCA O
and O
high O
- O
resolution O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O

) O
, O
we O
investigated O
the O

of O
a O
supernumerary O

on O
the O

of O

and O

. O

Regional O
and O
total O
brain O
volumes O
were O
measured O
in O
10 O
subjects O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
10 O
subjects O
with O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
and O
20 O
euploid O
controls O
. O

Amygdala O
volumes O
were O
significantly O
reduced O
in O

47 O

compared O
to O

men O
, O
while O

in O

was O
not O
as O

. O

Hippocampus O
volumes O
were O
preserved O
in O
both O
groups O
, O
compared O
to O
same O
- O
gender O
controls O
. O

Longitudinal O
studies O
of O
SCA O
individuals O
have O
shown O
an O
increased O
incidence O
of O
mild O
psychopathology O
and O
behavioral O

in O

with O
47 O
, O

and O

in O

with O
47 O

XXX O
, O
compared O
to O
control O
populations O
. O

The O
alteration O
in O
amygdala O
volumes O
in O
individuals O
with O
a O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosome O
may O
provide O
a O
neuroanatomic O
basis O
for O
these O
findings O
. O

Assessment O
of O
new O
markers O
for O
the O
rapid O
detection O
of O
aneuploidies O
by O
quantitative O
fluorescent O
PCR O
( O
QF O
- O
PCR O
) O
. O

Rapid O
prenatal O
diagnoses O
of O
major O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
have O
been O
achieved O
successfully O
using O
quantitative O
fluoresent O
PCR O
( O
QF O
- O
PCR O
) O
assays O
and O
small O
tandem O
repeat O
( O
STR O
) O
markers O
. O

Here O
we O
report O
the O
results O
of O
evaluating O
the O
use O
of O
previously O
untested O
X O
- O
linked O
STRs O
, O
( O
DXS6803 O
) O
and O
( O

) O
, O
together O
with O
modified O
amelogenin O
( O

) O
sequences O
and O
the O

marker O
that O
maps O
in O
the O

region O

on O

of O

and O

. O

These O
markers O
will O
allow O

diagnoses O
of O
sex O

such O
as O

, O

( O

, O

and O

of O

. O

Data O
are O
also O
presented O
concerning O
the O

associated O
with O
the O

of O

of O

of O

of O

in O

collected O
from O

. O

The O
results O
of O
evaluating O
the O
use O
of O
new O
markers O
for O
the O
rapid O
diagnosis O
of O
aneuploidies O
affecting O
chromosomes O
21 O
, O

and O

are O
also O
presented O
. O

Three O
chromosome O
21 O
specific O
STRs O
have O
been O
found O
to O
produce O
trisomic O
triallelic O
or O
diallelic O
patterns O
from O
all O
amniotic O
samples O
retrieved O
from O
fetuses O
with O

. O

Since O
all O
samples O
tested O
were O
amplified O
and O
no O
false O
positive O
or O

results O
were O
observed O
, O

results O
confirm O
the O

of O

- O

for O
the O
prenatal O
detection O
of O
major O

chromosome O
disorders O
. O

Biopsied O
testis O
cells O
of O
four O
47 O
, O
XXY O
patients O
: O
fluorescence O
in O
- O
situ O
hybridization O
and O
ICSI O
results O
. O

A O
testis O
biopsy O
was O
performed O
for O
four O
non O
- O
mosaic O
47 O
, O
XXY O
azoospermic O
patients O
. O

Spermatozoa O
were O
found O
in O
three O
cases O
and O
frozen O
before O

. O

We O
analysed O
the O
various O
cells O
found O
in O
the O
four O
samples O
by O
multicolour O
fluorescence O
in O
- O
situ O
hybridization O
( O

) O
, O
to O
evaluate O

and O

of O

, O

and O
46 O
, O

testis O
cell O
lines O
, O
and O
to O

rate O
in O
the O

spermatids O
and O

. O

Testis O
diploid O
cells O
( O
either O
somatic O
or O
premeiotic O
) O
, O
meiotic O
, O
and O
post O
- O

haploid O
germ O
cells O
were O
hybridized O
with O
probes O
for O

X O
, O

and O

. O

The O
only O
patient O
with O

had O
a O

XXY O
constitution O
in O
the O

; O

( O

and O

, O

) O

. O

All O
the O
observed O

figures O
were O
XY O
; O
no O

pachytene O
figure O
was O
found O
. O

The O
aneuploidy O
rate O
among O
post O
- O

cells O
for O
chromosomes O
X O
, O

and O
18 O
was O
6 O
. O
75 O
% O
( O
5 O
/ O
74 O
) O
. O

This O
rate O
was O
1 O
. O
5 O
% O
( O
2 O
/ O
133 O
) O
for O
control O
. O

Three O
couples O
underwent O
ICSI O
; O

Genetic O
effects O
of O
intracytoplasmic O
sperm O
injection O
. O

Intracytoplasmic O
sperm O
injection O
( O
ICSI O
) O
must O
be O
proved O
safe O
as O
well O
as O
efficacious O
. O

In O
this O
communication O
we O
first O
review O
available O
data O
following O
ICSI O
pregnancies O
concerning O
frequency O
of O
spontaneous O
abortion O
, O
malformations O
, O
and O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
. O

In O
ICSI O
the O
spontaneous O
abortion O
rate O
is O
slightly O
increased O
, O
just O
as O
it O
is O
in O
in O
vitro O
fertilization O
( O
IVF O
) O
without O
ICSI O
. O

Among O
6077 O
ICSI O
cycles O
begun O
in O
1997 O
in O
the O
United O
States O
, O
there O
were O
17 O
. O
5 O
% O
pregnancy O
losses O
. O

The O
same O
cohort O
showed O
a O
malformation O
rate O
of O
1 O
. O
7 O
% O
in O
live O
- O
born O
infants O
. O

Malformations O
in O
live O
- O
born O
infants O
are O
not O
increased O
: O
1 O
. O
7 O
% O
in O
the O
United O
States O
and O
2 O
. O
3 O
% O
in O
Brussels O
. O

However O
, O
the O
Swedish O
IVF O
Registry O
encompassing O
1139 O
ICSI O
infants O
found O
hypospadias O
to O
be O
increased O
( O
relative O
risk O
2 O
. O
9 O
, O
95 O
% O
C O
. O
I O
. O
1 O
. O
4 O
to O
5 O
. O
4 O
) O
. O

Birth O
weight O
and O
prematurity O
rate O
in O
ICSI O
pregnancies O
seem O
similar O
to O
that O
following O
conventional O
IVF O
without O
ICSI O
. O

The O
category O
of O
genetic O
defects O
for O
which O
concerns O
have O
most O
often O
been O
raised O
is O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
. O

A O
cohort O
of O
1987 O
pregnancies O
in O
Brussels O
yielded O
a O
frequency O
of O
de O
novo O
autosomal O
rearrangements O
of O
0 O
. O
36 O
% O
and O
a O
de O
novo O
sex O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
of O
0 O
. O
83 O
% O
. O

Both O
rates O
are O
higher O
than O
expected O
in O
the O
general O
population O
. O

Various O
explanations O
for O
these O
increased O
cytogenetic O
autosomal O
abnormalities O
are O
explored O
in O
this O
communication O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
arising O
from O
the O
procedure O
per O
se O
, O
a O
genetic O
or O
cytogenetic O
abnormality O
in O
offspring O
of O
an O
ICSI O
pregnancy O
could O
arise O
as O
result O
of O
offspring O
inheriting O
the O
mutant O
gene O
or O
chromosomal O
abnormality O
conferring O
paternal O
infertility O
: O
Y O
deletions O
( O
DAZ O
) O
in O
oligospermia O
males O
, O
cystic O
fibrosis O
in O
offspring O
of O
males O
with O
congenital O
bilateral O
absence O
vas O
deferens O
( O
CBAVD O
) O
, O
and O
sex O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
in O
offspring O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
males O
. O

Pregnancy O
achieved O
following O
ICSI O
from O
a O
man O
with O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
and O
spinal O
cord O
injury O
. O

Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
and O
spinal O
cord O
injury O
are O
major O
causes O
of O
male O
infertility O
. O

Intracytoplasmic O
sperm O
injection O
( O
ICSI O
) O
is O
a O
relatively O
new O
method O
of O
assisted O
reproduction O
. O

A O
testicular O
biopsy O
was O
obtained O
from O
a O
patient O
with O
the O
double O
complications O
of O
non O
- O
mosaic O
47 O
, O
XXY O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
and O
spinal O
cord O
damage O
, O
and O
motile O
spermatozoa O
were O
collected O
. O

ICSI O
was O
then O
performed O
. O

Of O
the O
four O
sperm O
- O
injected O
oocytes O
, O
three O
became O
fertilized O
and O
cleaved O
. O

Two O
embryos O
were O
implanted O
, O
resulting O
in O
a O
single O
pregnancy O
with O
visible O
evidence O
of O
a O
heartbeat O
appearing O
at O
6 O
weeks O
gestation O
. O

The O
pregnancy O
is O
now O
entering O
its O
20th O
week O
. O

To O
the O
best O
of O
our O
knowledge O
, O
this O
is O
the O
first O
case O
of O
a O
pregnancy O
resulting O
from O
the O
sperm O
of O
a O
patient O
with O
double O
complications O
. O

[ O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
: O
diagnosis O
and O
treatment O
. O
Case O
report O
] O
. O

Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
affects O
1 O
in O
500 O
men O
across O
all O
ethnic O
groups O
but O
the O
diagnosis O
is O
often O
delayed O
because O
of O
substantial O
variations O
in O
clinical O
presentation O
. O

A O
26 O
year O
- O
old O
male O
came O
to O
observation O
for O
chronic O
fatigue O
. O

His O
laboratory O
data O
and O
radiological O
examination O
were O
negative O
. O

Examination O
showed O
eunuchoidal O
body O
habitus O
with O
sparse O
facial O
hair O
, O
small O
and O
firm O
testes O
and O
no O
gynecomastia O
. O

The O
patient O
had O
heterosexual O
orientation O
with O
regular O
sexual O
intercourses O
but O
diminished O
libido O
. O

Serum O
gonadotropin O
concentrations O
were O
raised O
while O
serum O
testosterone O
concentration O
was O
low O
- O
normal O
level O
. O

Serum O
PRL O
concentration O
and O
thyroid O
function O
were O
normal O
. O

Seminal O
analysis O
revealed O
azoospermia O
and O
peripheral O
lymphocyte O
karyotyping O
showed O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
, O
confirming O
diagnostic O
suspicion O
. O

Patient O
was O
given O
testosterone O
enanthate O
200 O
mg O
intramuscularly O
every O
2 O
weeks O
. O

He O
noted O
improvements O
in O
fatigue O
and O
libido O
and O
increase O
of O
muscle O
mass O
. O

Since O
the O
true O
prevalence O
of O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
is O
very O
high O
, O
the O
diagnosis O
of O
this O
disease O
should O
be O
considered O
in O
every O
men O
with O
complaints O
related O
to O
hypogonadism O
( O
fatigue O
, O
weakness O
, O
gynecomastia O
, O
infertility O
, O
erectile O
dysfunction O
, O
small O
testis O
and O
osteoporosis O
) O
. O

Testosterone O
replacement O
therapy O
should O
be O
started O
early O
to O
minimize O
the O
physical O
and O
psychological O
effects O
of O
androgen O
deficiency O
. O

There O
have O
been O
recent O
advances O
in O
the O
options O
for O
the O
treatment O
of O
infertility O
in O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
: O
however O
findings O
that O
this O
syndrome O
may O
be O
transmitted O
by O
the O
new O
assisted O
reproductive O
techniques O
is O
cause O
for O
concern O
. O

Survival O
of O
male O
patients O
with O
incontinentia O
pigmenti O
carrying O
a O
lethal O
mutation O
can O
be O
explained O
by O
somatic O
mosaicism O
or O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Incontinentia O
pigmenti O
( O
IP O
) O
, O
or O
" O
Bloch O
- O
Sulzberger O
syndrome O
, O
" O
is O
an O
X O
- O
linked O
dominant O
disorder O
characterized O
by O
abnormalities O
of O
skin O
, O
teeth O
, O
hair O
, O
and O
eyes O
; O
skewed O
X O
- O
inactivation O
; O
and O
recurrent O
miscarriages O
of O
male O
fetuses O
. O

IP O
results O
from O
mutations O
in O
the O
gene O
for O
NF O
- O
kappaB O
essential O
modulator O
( O
NEMO O
) O
, O
with O
deletion O
of O
exons O
4 O
- O
10 O
of O
NEMO O
accounting O
for O
> O
80 O
% O
of O
new O
mutations O
. O

Male O
fetuses O
inheriting O
this O
mutation O
and O
other O
" O
null O
" O
mutations O
of O
NEMO O
usually O
die O
in O
utero O
. O

Less O
deleterious O
mutations O
can O
result O
in O
survival O
of O
males O
subjects O
, O
but O
with O
ectodermal O
dysplasia O
and O
immunodeficiency O
. O

Male O
patients O
with O
skin O
, O
dental O
, O
and O
ocular O
abnormalities O
typical O
of O
those O
seen O
in O
female O
patients O
with O
IP O
( O
without O
immunodeficiency O
) O
are O
rare O
. O

We O
investigated O
four O
male O
patients O
with O
clinical O
hallmarks O
of O
IP O
. O

All O
four O
were O
found O
to O
carry O
the O
deletion O
normally O
associated O
with O
male O

in O
utero O
. O

Survival O
in O
one O
patient O
is O
explained O
by O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
and O
skewed O
X O
inactivation O
. O

Three O
other O
patients O
possess O
a O
normal O
46 O
, O
XY O
karyotype O
. O

We O
demonstrate O
that O
these O
patients O
have O
both O
wild O
- O
type O
and O
deleted O
copies O
of O
the O
NEMO O
gene O
and O
are O
therefore O
mosaic O
for O
the O
common O
mutation O
. O

Therefore O
, O
the O
repeat O
- O
mediated O
rearrangement O
leading O
to O
the O
common O
deletion O
does O
not O
require O
meiotic O
division O
. O

Hypomorphic O
alleles O
, O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
, O
and O
somatic O
mosaicism O
therefore O
represent O
three O
mechanisms O
for O
survival O
of O
males O
carrying O
a O
NEMO O
mutation O
. O

Oculo O
- O
auriculo O
- O
vertebral O
spectrum O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

We O
report O
a O

with O

( O

) O

- O

( O

. O

Two O

reported O

. O

of O

and O

The O

with O

Analysis O
of O

in O

Klinefelter O
' O

. O

of O
47 O

of O

of O
sperm O
from O

reproductive O
techniques O
. O

Ellis O
- O
van O
Creveld O
syndrome O
: O
examination O
at O
15 O
weeks O
' O
gestation O
. O

In O
1940 O
, O
Ellis O
and O
van O
Creveld O
defined O
a O
syndrome O
they O
referred O
to O
as O
chondro O
- O
ectodermal O
dysplasia O
. O

This O
autosomal O
recessive O
condition O
, O
now O
usually O
referred O
to O
as O
Ellis O
- O
van O
Creveld O
syndrome O
( O

) O
, O
comprises O
bilateral O
postaxial O
polydactyly O
, O
a O
chondrodysplasia O
, O
characterized O
by O
shortness O
of O
limbs O
, O
and O
ectodermal O
dysplasia O
. O

Congenital O
heart O
defects O
are O
also O
common O
. O

There O
are O
many O
reports O
in O
medical O
literature O
describing O
affected O
newborns O
and O
even O
, O
older O
children O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
report O
the O

, O

and O

in O
a O

- O

fetus O
. O

The O

of O

- O

in O

is O
based O
on O
a O
positive O

( O

of O
long O
bones O

as O

. O

On O
post O
- O

examination O
, O

postaxial O

of O
the O

. O

, O

was O

of O

of O

. O

This O

is O

. O

Other O

. O

[ O
Molecular O

diagnosis O
of O
Klinefelter O

in O

more O

. O

was O

by O

. O

Complete O

in O
a O

. O

The O

. O

of O

. O

Since O

The O
most O
common O
human O
sex O

disorder O
is O

syndrome O
( O
KS O
; O
47 O
, O

) O
. O

Adult O

with O

display O
a O
diverse O
phenotype O
but O
are O
nearly O
always O
infertile O
, O
due O
to O

at O

. O

To O
identify O

causing O
the O
selective O
destruction O
of O
the O

epithelium O
, O
we O
performed O

- O

of O
24 O

- O
embedded O
testicular O
tissue O
samples O
. O

Analysis O
of O

transcriptomes O
revealed O
235 O
differentially O
expressed O
transcripts O
( O

) O
in O
the O
adult O
KS O
testis O

of O
long O
non O
- O
coding O
RNAs O
, O
but O
surprisingly O
not O
of O
X O
- O
chromosomal O
transcripts O
. O

Comparison O
to O
46 O
, O
XY O
samples O
with O
complete O
spermatogenesis O
and O
Sertoli O
cell O
- O
only O
- O
syndrome O
allowed O
prediction O
of O
the O
cellular O
origin O
of O
71 O
of O
the O
DETs O
. O

DACH2 O
and O
FAM9A O
were O
validated O
by O
immunohistochemistry O
and O
found O
to O
mark O
apparently O
undifferentiated O
somatic O
cell O
populations O
in O
the O
KS O
testes O
. O

Moreover O
, O

from O
fetal O
, O
pre O
- O
pubertal O
, O
and O
adult O
KS O
testes O
showed O
a O
limited O
overlap O
, O
indicating O
that O
different O
mechanisms O
are O
likely O
to O
operate O
at O
each O

stage O
. O

Based O
on O
our O
data O
, O
we O
propose O
that O
testicular O
degeneration O
in O
men O
with O
KS O
is O
a O
consequence O
of O
germ O
cells O
loss O
initiated O
during O
early O
development O
in O
combination O
with O
disturbed O
maturation O
of O
Sertoli O
- O
and O
Leydig O
cells O
. O

Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
. O
The O
Effects O
of O
Early O
Androgen O
Therapy O
on O
Competence O
and O
Behavioral O
Phenotype O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
the O
result O
of O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
most O
often O
characterized O
as O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

The O
typical O
features O
of O
KS O
include O
tall O
stature O
, O
gynecomastia O
, O
small O
firm O
testicles O
, O
hypergonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
, O
and O
infertility O
. O

However O
, O
abnormalities O
in O
neurodevelopment O
, O
cognition O
, O
and O
social O
and O
behavioral O
functioning O
also O
can O
be O
present O
. O

The O
abnormalities O
in O
neurodevelopment O
are O
believed O
to O
be O
due O
in O
part O
to O
androgen O
deficiency O
during O
early O
development O
and O
puberty O
. O

To O
discuss O
the O
role O
of O
androgens O
in O
normal O
adolescent O
development O
; O
discuss O
the O
cognitive O
, O
behavioral O
, O
and O
social O
functioning O
of O
children O
with O
KS O
; O
evaluate O
the O
evidence O
for O
early O
androgen O
therapy O
in O
men O
with O
KS O
; O
and O
discuss O
management O
strategies O
in O
the O
development O
of O
boys O
with O
KS O
. O

A O
systematic O
review O
of O
early O
androgen O
therapy O
and O
KS O
was O
performed O
using O
PubMed O
- O
Medline O
and O
Scopus O
databases O
. O

Relevant O
articles O
commenting O
on O
social O
, O
behavioral O
, O
cognitive O
, O
and O
physical O
outcomes O
among O
infants O
, O
children O
, O
and O
adolescents O
were O
included O
for O
reporting O
and O
discussion O
. O

Social O
and O
behavior O
functioning O
; O
cognitive O
outcomes O
; O
adverse O
effects O
associated O
with O
androgen O
therapy O
. O
3 O
retrospective O
articles O
and O
2 O
randomized O
controlled O
trials O
addressing O
early O
androgen O
therapy O
in O
boys O
with O
KS O
were O
reviewed O
. O

These O
studies O
showed O
an O
improvement O
in O
several O
aspects O
of O
social O
and O
cognitive O
functioning O
based O
on O
validated O
questionnaires O
. O

Treatment O
strategies O
, O
potential O
negative O
effects O
, O
and O
limitations O
of O
the O
literature O
on O
early O
androgen O
therapy O
in O
boys O
with O
KS O
are O
discussed O
. O

Our O
findings O
indicate O
that O
early O
androgen O
supplementation O
in O
children O
with O
KS O
combined O
with O
specific O
educational O
, O
family O
, O
and O
social O
support O
improves O
behavioral O
functioning O
. O

The O
optimal O
timing O
of O
hormonal O
therapy O
might O
require O
prospective O
studies O
, O
but O
based O
on O
our O
data O
and O
review O
of O
the O
literature O
, O
the O
O O
benefit O
of O
early O
hormonal O
and O
therapeutic O
intervention O
in O
KS O
is O
very O
encouraging O

R O
, O
Patel O
P O
, O

DA O

Information O
on O
the O
psychosexual O
outcome O
of O
individuals O
with O
disorders O
of O
sex O
development O
( O
DSDs O
) O
and O
intersex O
conditions O
is O
of O
great O
importance O
for O
sex O
assignment O
at O
birth O
of O
newborns O
with O
DSD O
. O

To O
assess O
gender O
change O
and O
gender O
dysphoria O
in O
a O
large O
sample O
of O
individuals O
with O
different O
DSDs O
. O

A O
cross O
- O

study O
was O
conducted O
in O
14 O
European O
centers O
with O
1 O
, O
040 O
participants O
( O
717 O
female O
- O
identifying O
and O

male O

identifying O
persons O
and O
12 O

identifying O
with O
another O

) O
with O
different O
forms O
of O
DSD O
. O

The O
cohort O
( O
mean O
age O
O O
= O
32 O
. O
36 O
years O
, O

O O
= O
13 O
. O
57 O
) O
was O
divided O
into O
6 O

subgroups O
: O

( O

( O

( O

Data O
on O
psychosexual O
outcome O
were O
gathered O
by O

interviews O
and O

. O

Gender O
change O
and O
gender O
dysphoria O
. O

Although O
gender O
changes O
were O
reported O
by O
5 O
% O
of O
participants O
, O
only O
in O
1 O
% O
( O
3 O
% O
if O
those O
with O
Klinefelter O
and O
Turner O
syndromes O
- O
conditions O
in O
which O
gender O
issues O
are O
not O
prominent O
- O
are O
excluded O
) O
did O
the O
gender O
change O
take O
place O
after O
puberty O
and O
was O
likely O
initiated O
by O
the O
patient O
. O
39 O
participants O
( O
4 O
% O
) O
reported O
gender O
variance O
: O
between O
male O
and O
female O
, O
a O
gender O
other O
than O
male O
or O
female O
, O
or O
gender O
queer O
, O
alternating O
gender O
roles O
, O
or O
a O
gender O
expression O
that O
differed O
from O
the O
reported O
gender O
. O

This O
group O
had O
lower O
self O
- O
esteem O
and O
more O
anxiety O
and O
depression O
than O
the O
other O
participants O
. O

Clinicians O
should O
be O
aware O
of O
and O
sensitive O
to O
the O
possibility O
that O
their O
patients O
with O
DSD O
not O
only O
might O
have O
transgender O
feelings O
and O
a O
desire O
to O
change O
gender O
, O
but O
also O
identify O
as O
different O
from O
male O
or O
female O
. O

The O
complexity O
of O
their O
feelings O
might O
require O
counseling O
for O
some O
patients O
. O

The O
study O
is O
unique O
in O
the O
large O
number O
of O
participants O
from O
many O
different O
clinics O
, O
with O
sizable O
numbers O
in O
most O
subgroups O
, O
and O
in O
the O
large O
number O
of O
aspects O
that O
were O
measured O
. O

However O
, O
the O
very O
broadness O
of O
the O
study O
made O
it O
impossible O
to O
focus O
in O
detail O
on O
gender O
issues O
. O

Also O
, O
there O
is O
a O
need O
for O
instruments O
specifically O
measuring O
gender O
dysphoria O
in O
individuals O
with O
DSD O
that O
take O
non O
- O
binary O
genders O
into O
account O
. O

To O
make O
appropriate O

possible O
for O
people O
with O

, O

gender O
- O

and O
gender O
- O
variant O
development O
of O
children O
with O
DSD O
should O
be O
studied O
in O
longitudinal O
studies O
. O

Intratesticular O
testosterone O
is O
increased O
in O
men O
with O

syndrome O
and O
may O
not O
be O
released O
into O
the O
bloodstream O
owing O
to O
altered O
testicular O
vascularization O
– O
a O
preliminary O
report O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
is O
associated O
with O
low O
serum O
testosterone O
( O
T O
) O
, O
long O
thought O
to O
arise O
from O
disturbed O
steroidogenesis O
in O
Leydig O
cells O
. O

However O
, O
intratesticular O
testosterone O
( O
ITT O
) O
concentrations O
were O
recently O
found O
to O
be O
normal O
in O
a O
KS O
mouse O
model O
( O
41 O
, O
XXY O
* O
) O
. O

So O
far O
, O
nothing O
was O
known O
about O
ITT O
concentrations O
in O
human O
patients O
with O
KS O
. O

Therefore O
, O
ITT O
, O
sex O
hormone O
- O
binding O
globulin O
( O

) O
and O
histological O
parameters O
were O
measured O
in O
human O

biopsies O
of O
11 O

patients O
, O
30 O
azoospermic O
patients O
with O
Sertoli O
- O
cell O
- O
only O
syndrome O
and O
nine O
men O
with O
normal O
spermatogenesis O
as O
controls O
. O

ITT O
concentrations O
showed O
an O
overall O
pronounced O
excess O
over O
intratesticular O
SHBG O
in O
molar O
terms O
and O
were O
significantly O
increased O
in O
men O
with O
KS O
despite O
of O
reduced O
serum O
T O
levels O
. O

While O
the O
ratio O
of O
ITT O
/ O

was O
markedly O
increased O
in O

, O
the O
ITT O
/ O

was O

between O
all O
groups O
. O

After O
finding O
significantly O
increased O
ITT O
levels O
in O
men O

a O
finding O
even O
more O
striking O
than O
in O
the O
41 O
, O
XXY O
* O
KS O
mouse O
model O
, O
we O
set O
out O
to O
find O
a O
possible O
' O
vascular O
' O
explanation O
for O
the O

of O

release O
into O
the O
testicular O

. O

In O
testis O

from O
patients O
, O

analysis O
of O
the O
vessels O
is O
, O
however O
, O

because O
of O

from O
the O

of O

to O

. O

Consequently O
, O

was O

in O
whole O
testis O

from O
adult O
male O
41 O

* O
and O
40 O
, O

* O
mice O
( O
n O
= O
5 O
, O
each O
) O
. O

Indeed O
, O
the O
blood O
vessel O
/ O
testes O

ratio O
correcting O
for O
the O

testes O
of O
XXY O
* O

controls O
. O

In O

that O

might O

. O

Epigenomic O
and O
transcriptomic O
signatures O
of O
a O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
karyotype O
in O
the O
brain O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
- O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
in O
humans O
. O

Most O
affected O
individuals O
carry O
one O
extra O
X O
- O
chromosome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
) O
and O
the O
condition O
presents O
with O
a O
heterogeneous O
mix O
of O
reproductive O
, O
physical O
and O
psychiatric O
phenotypes O
. O

Although O
the O
mechanism O
( O
s O
) O
by O
which O
the O
supernumerary O
X O
- O
chromosome O
determines O
these O
features O
of O
KS O
are O
poorly O
understood O
, O
skewed O
X O
- O
chromosome O
inactivation O
( O
XCI O
) O
, O
gene O
- O
dosage O
dysregulation O
, O
and O
the O
parental O
origin O
of O
the O
extra O
X O
- O
chromosome O
have O
all O
been O
implicated O
, O
suggesting O
an O
important O
role O
for O
epigenetic O
processes O
. O

We O
assessed O
genomic O
, O
methylomic O
and O
transcriptomic O
variation O
in O
matched O
prefrontal O
cortex O
and O
cerebellum O
samples O
identifying O
an O
individual O
with O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
who O
was O
comorbid O
for O
schizophrenia O
and O
had O
a O
notably O
reduced O
cerebellum O
mass O
compared O
with O
other O
individuals O
in O
the O
study O
( O
n O
= O
49 O
) O
. O

We O
examined O
methylomic O
and O
transcriptomic O
differences O
in O
this O
individual O
relative O
to O
female O
and O
male O
samples O
with O
46 O
, O
XX O
or O
46 O
, O
XY O
karyotypes O
, O
respectively O
, O
and O
identified O
numerous O
locus O
- O
specific O
differences O
in O
DNA O
methylation O
and O
gene O
expression O
, O
with O
many O
differences O
being O
autosomal O
and O
tissue O
- O
specific O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
global O
DNA O

patient O
had O
a O
healthy O
baby O
with O
a O
normal O
karyotype O
. O

Some O
non O
- O
mosaic O
Klinefelter O
patients O
have O
ejaculated O
sperm O
that O
can O
result O
in O
a O
successful O
birth O
following O
ICSI O
. O

However O
, O
the O
birth O
rate O
is O
very O
low O
compared O
with O
the O
fertilization O
rate O
, O
suggesting O
increased O
risk O
of O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
. O

Parental O
decisions O
following O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
of O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
: O
a O
trend O
over O
time O
. O

Research O
over O
the O
last O
20 O
years O
has O
considerably O
changed O
the O
understanding O
of O
the O
natural O
history O
and O
prognosis O
for O
individuals O
with O
a O
diagnosis O
of O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
( O
SCA O
) O
. O

A O
cross O
- O
sectional O
retrospective O
analysis O
of O
factors O
influencing O
parental O
decisions O
following O
a O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
of O
SCA O
during O
the O
time O
period O
of O
1971 O
- O
97 O
was O
performed O
. O

The O
records O
of O
169 O
fetuses O
with O
a O
prenatal O
karyotype O
of O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
were O
reviewed O
. O

Mosaic O
karyotypes O
for O
SCA O
were O
also O
included O
. O

Information O
reviewed O
involved O
: O
parental O
decision O
, O
the O
type O
of O
SCA O
, O
the O
presence O
or O
absence O
of O
mosaicism O
, O
the O
presence O
or O
absence O
of O
a O
fetal O

diagnosed O
by O
ultrasound O
examination O
, O
indication O
for O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
, O
prenatal O
procedure O
performed O
, O
parental O
age O
, O
marital O
status O
, O
previous O
pregnancy O
history O
, O
family O
history O
, O
ethnicity O
, O
religion O
, O
education O
, O
and O
profession O
. O

A O
significant O
correlation O
was O
found O
between O
the O
decision O
to O
continue O
a O
pregnancy O
and O
the O
type O
of O
SCA O
and O
the O

of O

on O

. O

In O

this O
study O
examined O
differences O
in O

over O
time O
for O
the O
years O
in O
question O
. O

A O
statistically O
significant O
trend O
was O
observed O
with O
a O
higher O
rate O
of O
pregnancy O
continuation O
in O
the O

. O

Assessment O
of O

in O

47 O

/ O

, O

: O

males O

. O

from O
a O
47 O

- O

( O

) O

. O

The O

in O

may O

of O

- O

. O

Patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
with O

have O

of O

in O

Fluorescence O
in O
- O
situ O

of O
sex O
chromosomes O
in O
spermatozoa O
and O

of O
a O

46 O

/ O

. O

It O
has O

recently O
that O
47 O
, O

are O

to O
progress O

We O

of O

( O

, O

. O

The O

are O

to O
complete O

and O

. O

However O
, O

, O
and O

of O

, O

. O

Instead O
, O

produced O
a O
high O
percentage O
of O
mosaic O
embryos O
with O
chaotic O

arrangements O
. O

Rapid O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
of O
aneuploidy O
by O
quantitative O
fluorescent O
PCR O
on O
fetal O
samples O
from O
mothers O
at O
high O
risk O
for O
chromosome O
disorders O
. O

We O
report O
the O
results O
of O
a O
prospective O
study O
using O
quantitative O
fluorescent O
polymerase O
chain O
reaction O
( O
QF O
- O
PCR O
) O
and O
small O
tandem O
repeat O
markers O
( O
STR O
) O
for O
the O
rapid O
prenatal O
detection O
of O
aneuploidies O
in O
a O
group O
of O
pregnant O
women O
at O
increased O
risk O
of O
having O
fetuses O
with O
numerical O
chromosome O
disorders O
. O

Amniotic O
fluid O
samples O
( O
n O
= O
52 O
) O
were O
collected O
from O
mothers O
undergoing O
prenatal O
invasive O
testing O
for O
fetal O
abnormalities O
on O
ultrasonographic O
examination O
or O
abnormal O
maternal O
serum O
aneuploidy O
screening O
results O
. O

All O
samples O
were O
tested O
by O
cytogenetic O
analysis O
, O
but O
rapid O
diagnoses O
of O
aneuploidies O
were O
offered O
and O
performed O
using O
QF O
- O
PCR O
analysis O
with O
several O
STRs O
specific O
for O
chromosomes O
21 O
, O
18 O
, O
13 O
and O
X O
. O

All O
cases O
with O
numerical O
chromosome O
aberrations O
involving O
chromosomes O
21 O
, O
18 O
and O
13 O
( O
n O
= O
8 O
) O
were O
correctly O
diagnosed O
. O

Three O
gonosomal O
aneuplodies O
( O
one O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
two O
45 O
, O
X O
) O
were O
not O
detected O
because O
they O
were O
uninformative O
for O
the O
X O
markers O
. O

Another O
sample O
with O
a O
deletion O
( O
46 O
, O
XX O
, O
7q O
- O
) O
, O
that O
the O
present O
assay O
was O
not O
designed O
to O
detect O
, O
was O
not O
identified O
. O

One O
sample O
was O
heavily O
contaminated O
with O
maternal O
blood O
and O
the O
results O
of O
the O
QF O
- O
PCR O
assays O
were O
uninformative O
. O

The O
remaining O
samples O
from O
normal O
fetuses O
provided O
QF O
- O
PCR O
patterns O
disomic O
for O
chromosomes O
21 O
, O
18 O
, O
13 O
and O
X O
. O

Our O
study O
demonstrates O
that O
QF O
- O
PCR O
is O
a O
rapid O
method O
for O
the O
detection O
of O
common O
numerical O
chromosome O
disorders O
and O
it O
may O
play O
an O
important O
role O
in O

for O
women O
at O
high O

for O
fetal O

. O

Birth O
of O
16 O
healthy O
children O
after O
ICSI O
in O
cases O
of O
nonmosaic O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Does O
the O
health O
status O
of O
infants O
fathered O
by O
nonmosaic O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
patients O
whose O
partners O
underwent O
ICSI O
with O
sperm O
obtained O
from O
testicular O
dissection O
reveal O
any O
genetic O
risk O
for O
the O
offspring O
? O

. O

KS O
patients O
undergoing O
testicular O
sperm O
extraction O
( O
TESE O
) O
are O
capable O
of O
conceiving O
healthy O
children O
. O

Paternity O
has O
been O
successfully O
achieved O
in O
nonmosaic O
KS O
patients O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
) O
by O
ICSI O
using O
either O
ejaculated O
or O
testicular O
spermatozoa O
. O

A O
crucial O
concern O
is O
the O
potential O
transmission O
of O
genetic O
abnormalities O
to O
the O
offspring O
. O

Some O
studies O
reported O
that O
47 O
, O
XXY O
spermatogonia O
are O
capable O
of O
completing O
spermatogenesis O
leading O
to O
the O
production O
of O
mature O
spermatozoa O
with O
increased O
aneuploidies O
. O

Other O
authors O
showed O
that O
where O
focal O
spermatogenesis O
is O
present O
in O
nonmosaic O
KS O
males O
, O
it O
originates O
from O
euploid O
germ O
cells O
and O
, O
therefore O
, O
produces O
normal O
mature O
gametes O
. O

In O
support O
of O
this O
finding O
, O
at O
present O
, O
the O
great O
majority O
of O
children O
born O
from O
nonmosaic O
KS O
patients O
are O
chromosomally O
normal O
. O

From O
April O
2004 O
to O
June O
2010 O
, O
38 O
azoospermic O
patients O
with O
nonmosaic O
KS O
were O
examined O
for O
the O
presence O
of O
testicular O
spermatozoa O
. O

Spermatozoa O
were O
retrieved O
from O
15 O
patients O
and O
26 O
ICSI O
cycles O
were O
done O
( O
16 O
with O
cryopreserved O
sperm O
) O
. O

There O
were O
15 O
pregnancies O
leading O
to O
the O
birth O
of O
16 O
babies O
who O
were O
karyotyped O
at O
amniocentesis O
and O
after O
birth O
. O

Participants O
were O
recruited O
from O
couples O
attending O
the O
European O
Hospital O
, O
Rome O
, O
and O
Clinica O
MAR O
& O
Gen O
, O
Granada O
, O
for O
infertility O
treatment O
. O

Both O
the O
European O
Hospital O
and O
Clinica O
MAR O
& O
Gen O
are O
private O
clinics O
. O

Testicular O
tissue O
was O
extracted O
with O
TESE O
or O
micro O
- O
TESE O
. O

After O
retrieval O
, O
fresh O
sperm O
was O
used O
for O
ICSI O
or O
it O
was O
cryopreserved O
for O
future O
use O
. O

Spermatozoa O
were O

from O
15 O
patients O
( O
14 O
TESE O
and O
1 O
micro O
- O
TESE O
) O
out O
of O
38 O
( O
39 O
. O
5 O
% O
) O
. O

A O
total O
of O
26 O

cycles O
were O

: O

and O
16 O

- O

. O

Mean O
ages O
( O

) O

, O

, O

. O

± O

. O

. O

± O
4 O
. O

( O

, O

) O
. O

Comparing O

( O

. O

. O

Sixteen O
babies O
were O
born O
, O

of O
them O
are O
healthy O

a O

, O

and O

- O

sperm O
group O
. O

The O
small O
numbers O
available O
for O
study O
mean O
that O
only O
common O
problems O
can O
be O
excluded O
. O

This O
study O
provides O
further O
reassurance O
that O
KS O
men O
can O
father O
healthy O
children O
and O
that O
pre O
- O
implantation O
genetic O
diagnosis O
on O
embryos O
conceived O
with O
their O
sperm O
is O
not O
strongly O
indicated O
. O

However O
, O
until O
conclusive O
information O
is O
available O
, O
such O
couples O
should O
be O
offered O
extensive O
genetic O
counseling O
. O

No O

. O

47 O
, O
XXY O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
: O
clinical O

and O

for O

. O

47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
) O
is O
the O
most O
frequent O
sex O
chromosomal O
disorder O
and O
affects O
approximately O
one O
in O
660 O
newborn O
boys O
. O

The O
syndrome O
is O
characterized O
by O
varying O
degrees O
of O
cognitive O
, O
social O
, O
behavioral O
, O
and O
learning O
difficulties O
and O
in O
adulthood O
additionally O
primary O
testicular O
failure O
with O
small O
testes O
, O
hypergonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
, O
tall O
stature O
, O
and O
eunuchoid O
body O
proportions O
. O

The O
phenotype O
is O
variable O
ranging O
from O
" O
near O
- O
normal O
" O
to O
a O
significantly O
affected O
individual O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
newborns O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
generally O
present O
with O
a O
normal O
male O
phenotype O
and O

consistent O
clinical O
finding O
in O
KS O
is O
small O
testes O
, O
that O
are O
most O
often O
not O
identified O
until O
after O
puberty O
. O

Decreased O
awareness O
of O
this O
syndrome O
among O
health O
professionals O
and O

general O
perception O
that O
all O
patients O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
exhibit O

textbook O

results O
in O
a O
highly O
under O
- O
diagnosed O
condition O
with O
up O
to O
75 O
% O
of O
the O
patients O
left O
undetected O
. O

Typically O
, O

is O
delayed O
with O
the O

of O
patients O
identified O
during O
fertility O
workup O
in O
adulthood O
, O
and O
only O
10 O

of O
patients O

prior O
to O

. O

Early O

of O
this O
syndrome O
is O
recommended O
in O
order O
to O
offer O
treatment O
and O

at O
the O

ages O
and O

of O
development O

/ O

group O
, O

Reproductive O
genetic O
counselling O
in O

- O

With O

. O

It O

Some O

Hematologic O
malignancies O
and O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O
a O
chance O
association O
? O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
was O
first O
described O
in O
1942 O
as O
an O

characterized O
by O

, O

An O
extra O

( O
i O
. O

. O
, O
47 O

We O

The O
