also O
reviewed O
. O

Case O
of O
XXXXY O
syndrome O
. O

. O

) O

Taurodontism O
in O

, O

: O

of O

X O

. O

Effects O
of O
an O
extra O
X O

on O
root O

were O

in O

. O

of O

from O

of O

Nine O
, O

, O

, O

, O

, O

of O

. O

A O

of O

, O

- O
/ O

, O

- O

was O

. O

A O
case O
of O
pure O
gonadal O
dysgenesis O
was O
investigated O
. O

The O
patient O
was O
an O
18 O
- O

- O

with O
a O

of O

. O

She O
had O

, O

, O

and O

. O

The O
patient O
' O
s O

was O
46 O
, O

- O
/ O
47 O
, O

- O
. O

that O

of O

( O

) O
. O

She O
underwent O

with O

consistent O
with O

. O

Laparoscopic O
surgery O
is O
recommended O
as O
it O
is O
much O
less O
invasive O
and O
associated O
with O
rapid O
postoperative O
recovery O
. O

Detection O
of O
aneuploidy O
in O
chromosomes O
X O
, O
Y O
, O
13 O
, O
18 O
and O
21 O
by O

- O
PCR O
in O
662 O
selected O
pregnancies O
at O
risk O
. O

A O
quantitative O
fluorescent O
- O
polymerase O
chain O
reaction O
( O
QF O
- O
PCR O
) O
test O
system O
with O
different O
short O

repeat O
( O

) O
markers O
of O
the O
X O
chromosome O
( O

, O

and O

) O

( O

) O

for O

of O

( O

= O

Analysis O
of O

The O

Brain O
morphology O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
: O
extra O
X O

and O

. O

This O
study O
focuses O
on O

in O

with O

and O

of O

were O

Comparative O
genomic O
hybridization O
: O
a O
new O
approach O
to O
screening O
for O
intrauterine O
complete O
or O
mosaic O
aneuploidy O
. O

In O
the O
practice O
of O
clinical O
genetics O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
in O
both O
mosaic O
and O
nonmosaic O
forms O
has O
long O
been O
recognized O
as O
a O
cause O
of O
abnormal O
prenatal O
and O
postnatal O
development O
. O

Traditionally O
, O
cytogenetic O
analysis O
of O
cultured O
lymphocytes O
has O
been O
used O
as O
a O
standard O
test O
for O
detection O
of O
constitutional O
aneuploidies O
. O

As O
lymphocytes O
represent O
only O
one O
lineage O
, O
chromosomal O
mosaicism O
expressed O
in O
other O
tissues O
often O
remains O
undetected O
. O

The O
purpose O
of O
this O
study O
was O
to O
assess O
the O
utilization O
of O
molecular O
cytogenetic O
analysis O
for O
detection O
of O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
in O
placental O
tissues O
. O

Using O
placentas O
from O
100 O
pregnancies O
with O
viable O
nonmalformed O
livebirths O
, O
both O
trophoblast O
and O
chorionic O
stroma O
were O
analyzed O
using O
comparative O
genomic O
hybridization O
( O
CGH O
) O
. O

In O
all O
cases O
with O
an O
indication O
of O
chromosomal O
imbalance O
by O
CGH O
, O
fluorescence O
in O
situ O
hybridization O
( O
FISH O
) O
analysis O
was O
performed O
to O
confirm O
the O
presence O
of O
aneuploidy O
. O

To O
differentiate O
between O
constitutional O
aneuploidy O
and O
confined O
placental O
mosaicism O
( O
CPM O
) O
, O
amniotic O
membrane O
was O
analyzed O
by O
CGH O
and O
FISH O
techniques O
. O

Our O
results O
demonstrated O
five O
placentas O
with O
CPM O
for O
chromosomes O
2 O
, O
4 O
, O
12 O
, O
13 O
, O
and O
18 O
, O
respectively O
, O
and O
two O
constitutional O
nonmosaic O
aneuploidies O
( O
47 O
, O
XXX O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
. O

Molecular O
cytogenetic O
studies O
of O
human O
placental O
tissues O
enables O
easy O
analysis O
of O
both O
embryonic O
( O
amnion O
) O
and O
extraembryonic O
( O
chorion O
) O
cell O
lineages O
. O

Detection O
at O
birth O
of O
chromosomal O
defects O
affecting O
intrauterine O
placental O
and O
fetal O
development O
is O
important O
because O
these O
chromosomal O
defects O
may O
continue O
to O
have O
an O
influence O
on O
postnatal O
development O
. O

Segregation O
of O
sex O
chromosomes O
in O
spermatozoa O
of O
46 O
, O
XY O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
men O
by O
multicolour O
fluorescence O
in O
- O
situ O
hybridization O
. O

The O
sex O
chromosome O
disomy O
and O
diploidy O
rates O
on O
ejaculated O
spermatozoa O
from O
two O
patients O
with O
mosaic O
Klinefelter O
' O
s O
syndrome O
were O
estimated O
, O
using O
X O
/ O
Y O
/ O
15 O
multicolour O
fluorescence O
in O
- O
situ O
hybridization O
( O
FISH O
) O
. O

A O
8 O
/ O
18 O
dual O
fluorescence O
in O
- O
situ O
hybridization O
analysis O
was O
also O
carried O
out O
. O

In O
triple O
FISH O
, O
a O
total O
of O
1691 O

. O

Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
in O

children O
: O
the O
importance O
of O

early O

for O

and O

. O

The O
aim O
of O
this O

is O

: O

( O

Fifteen O

( O

2 O

and O

) O

, O

to O

( O

High O

. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
a O
genetic O
anomaly O
involving O
the O
presence O
of O
one O
or O
more O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosomes O
in O
male O
individuals O
. O

In O
the O
cognitive O
profile O
of O
these O
individuals O
, O
strengths O
are O
found O
in O
nonverbal O
abilities O
, O
whereas O
weaknesses O
are O
observed O
in O
executive O
function O
, O
language O
, O
and O
academic O
performance O
. O

Our O
study O
is O
based O
on O
a O
comparison O
between O
eight O
children O
diagnosed O
with O
KS O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
( O
age O
range O
: O
9 O
- O
13 O
years O
; O
IQ O
range O
: O
80 O
- O
123 O
) O
, O
with O
no O
delay O
in O

, O
and O
eight O
typically O
developing O
( O
TD O
) O
controls O
. O

We O
explored O
a O
range O
of O
high O
- O
level O
language O

and O
Theory O
of O
Mind O
( O

) O

to O

. O

High O
- O

were O

by O

that O
measures O

and O
a O

test O
( O

) O
. O

To O

, O

administered O
the O
corresponding O

of O
the O
NEPSY O
II O
. O

Basic O
language O
competence O
was O
assessed O
by O
the O
NEPSY O
II O
Comprehension O
of O
Instructions O
subtest O
. O

Although O
basic O
language O
performance O
did O
not O
differentiate O
the O

with O

from O
the O
TD O
controls O
, O

in O

All O

which O

with O

performed O
less O

by O
complex O

. O

Some O
possible O

and O

are O
discussed O
. O

incidence O
of O

47 O

47 O
, O

( O

) O
is O
the O
most O

( O
1 O
: O
660 O

) O

The O

and O

of O

( O

. O

and O

for O

Related O

. O

( O

( O

Within O

, O

of O

( O

This O

on O

47 O

appear O
to O

of O

. O

and O

A O
review O
of O
neurocognitive O
functioning O
and O
risk O
for O
psychopathology O
in O
sex O
chromosome O
trisomy O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
47 O
, O
XYY O
) O
. O

About O
one O
in O
650 O
- O
1000 O
children O
is O
born O
with O
an O
extra O
X O
or O
Y O
chromosome O
, O
referred O
to O
as O
sex O
chromosome O
trisomies O
( O
SCTs O
) O
. O

Studying O
SCTs O
may O
uncover O
unique O
insights O
in O
neurodevelopmental O
pathways O
underlying O
the O
risk O
for O
neurobehavioral O
problems O
and O
psychopathology O
. O

There O
is O
also O
a O
clinical O
need O
for O
more O
knowledge O
about O
the O
phenotype O
of O
SCT O
with O
the O
recent O
introduction O
of O
noninvasive O
prenatal O
screening O
. O

The O
reviewed O
studies O
illustrate O
an O
increased O
vulnerability O
for O
psychopathology O
such O
as O
( O
symptoms O
of O
) O
autism O
spectrum O
disorder O
, O
attention O
- O
deficit O
/ O
hyperactivity O
disorder O
, O
anxiety O
, O
depression O
and O
, O
to O
a O
lesser O
degree O
, O
psychotic O
disorders O
. O

Although O
traditionally O
the O
primary O
focus O
has O
been O
on O
language O
and O
learning O
problems O
, O
recent O
research O
suggests O
that O
impairments O
in O
executive O
functioning O
, O
social O
cognition O
and O
emotion O
regulation O
may O
also O
be O
key O
factors O
underlying O
the O
risk O
for O
neurobehavioral O
problems O
. O

The O
research O
field O
of O
SCT O
is O
in O
need O
of O
a O
more O
longitudinal O
perspective O
to O
identify O
early O
markers O
of O
' O
at O
risk O
' O
development O
, O
and O
to O
assess O
the O
effectiveness O
of O
early O
interventions O
. O

Neurocognitive O
markers O
that O
signal O
compromised O
neurodevelopment O
may O
prove O
to O
be O
helpful O
in O
this O
. O

Variability O
in O
the O
SCT O
phenotype O
provides O
a O
unique O
opportunity O
to O
identify O
not O
only O
genetic O
but O
also O
environmental O
factors O
that O
shape O
neurodevelopmental O
outcome O
, O
calling O
for O
studies O
focused O
on O
understanding O
individual O
differences O
. O

A O
47 O
, O
XXY O
Pregnant O
Woman O
without O
the O
SRY O
Gene O
. O

Individuals O
with O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
usually O
present O
with O
a O
male O
phenotype O
due O
to O
the O
additional O
Y O
chromosome O
. O

In O
this O
paper O
, O
we O
describe O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
female O
who O
was O
pregnant O
with O
a O
fetus O
of O
the O
same O
karyotype O
based O
on O
chromosome O
analysis O
of O
amniotic O
fluid O
cells O
. O

Further O
analysis O
of O
her O
Y O
chromosome O
indicated O
that O
the O
additional O
Y O
chromosome O
contains O
no O
SRY O
gene O
on O
the O
short O
arm O
but O
carries O
the O
azoospermia O
factor O
region O
on O
the O
long O
arm O
, O
including O
azoospermia O
factor O
a O
, O
b O
and O
c O
( O
AZFa O
, O
AZFb O
, O
AZFc O
) O
. O

This O
region O
may O
influence O
her O
female O
phenotype O
. O

Fertile O
females O
with O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
and O
loss O
of O
SRY O
are O
extremely O
rare O
. O

This O
paper O
is O
the O
first O
report O
of O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
pregnant O
woman O
with O
a O
normal O
phenotype O
and O
may O
enrich O
our O
knowledge O
on O
47 O
, O
XXY O
individuals O
. O

A O
strategic O
research O
alliance O
: O
Turner O
syndrome O
and O
sex O
differences O
. O

Sex O
chromosome O
constitution O
varies O
in O
the O
human O
population O
, O
both O
between O
the O
sexes O
( O
46 O
, O
XX O
females O
and O
46 O
, O
XY O
males O
) O
, O
and O
within O
the O
sexes O
( O
e O
. O
g O
. O
, O
45 O
, O
X O
and O
46 O
, O
XX O
females O
, O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
46 O
, O
XY O
males O
) O
. O

Coincident O
with O
this O
genetic O
variation O
are O
numerous O
phenotypic O
differences O
between O
males O
and O
females O
, O
and O
individuals O
with O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
. O

However O
, O
the O
molecular O
mechanisms O
by O
which O
sex O
chromosome O
constitution O
impacts O
phenotypes O
at O
the O
cellular O
, O
tissue O
, O
and O
organismal O
levels O
remain O
largely O
unexplored O
. O

Thus O
, O
emerges O
a O
fundamental O
question O
connecting O
the O
study O
of O
sex O
differences O
and O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
syndromes O
: O
How O
does O
sex O
chromosome O
constitution O
influence O
phenotype O
? O

Here O
, O
we O
focus O
on O
Turner O
syndrome O
( O
TS O
) O
, O
associated O
with O
the O
45 O
, O
X O
karyotype O
, O
and O
its O
synergies O
with O
the O
study O
of O
sex O
differences O
. O

We O
review O
findings O
from O
evolutionary O
studies O
of O
the O
sex O
chromosomes O
, O
which O
identified O
genes O
that O
are O
most O
likely O
to O
contribute O
to O
phenotypes O
as O
a O
result O
of O
variation O
in O
sex O
chromosome O
constitution O
. O

We O
then O
explore O
strategies O
for O
investigating O
the O
direct O
effects O
of O
the O
sex O
chromosomes O
, O
and O
the O
evidence O
for O
specific O
sex O
chromosome O
genes O
impacting O
phenotypes O
. O

In O
sum O
, O
we O
argue O
that O
integrating O
the O
study O
of O
TS O
with O
sex O
differences O
offers O
a O
mutually O
beneficial O
alliance O
to O
identify O
contributions O
of O
the O
sex O
chromosomes O
to O
human O
development O
, O
health O
, O
and O
disease O
. O

Comorbidity O
landscape O
of O
the O
Danish O
patient O
population O
affected O
by O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
. O

Most O
chromosome O
abnormality O
patients O
require O
long O
- O
term O
clinical O
care O
. O

Awareness O
of O
mosaicism O
and O
comorbidities O
can O
potentially O
guide O
such O
health O
care O
. O

Here O
we O
present O
a O
population O
- O
wide O
analysis O
of O
direct O
and O
inverse O
comorbidities O
affecting O
patients O
with O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
. O

We O
extracted O
direct O
and O
inverse O
comorbidities O
for O
the O
11 O
most O
prevalent O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
from O
the O
Danish O
National O
Patient O
Registry O
( O
covering O
6 O
. O
9 O
million O
patients O
hospitalized O
between O
1994 O
and O
2015 O
) O
: O
trisomy O
13 O
, O
18 O
, O
and O
21 O
, O
Klinefelter O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
, O
triple O
X O
, O
XYY O
, O
Turner O
( O
45 O
, O
X O
) O
, O
Wolf O
- O
Hirschhorn O
, O
Cri O
- O
du O
- O
chat O
, O
Angelman O
, O
and O
Fragile O
X O
syndromes O
( O
FXS O
) O
. O

We O
also O
performed O
four O
sub O
- O
analyses O
for O
male O
/ O
female O
Down O
syndrome O
( O
DS O
) O
and O
FXS O
and O
non O
- O
mosaic O
/ O
mosaic O
DS O
and O
Turner O
syndrome O
. O

Our O
data O
cover O
9 O
, O
003 O
patients O
diagnosed O
with O
at O
least O
one O
chromosome O
abnormality O
. O

Each O
abnormality O
showed O
a O
unique O
comorbidity O
signature O
, O
but O
clustering O
of O
their O
profiles O
underlined O
common O
risk O
profiles O
for O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
with O
similar O
genetic O
backgrounds O
. O

We O
found O
that O
DS O
had O
a O
decreased O
risk O
for O
three O
inverse O
cancer O
comorbidities O
( O
lung O
, O
breast O
, O
and O
skin O
) O
and O
that O
male O
FXS O
and O
non O
- O
mosaic O
patients O
have O
a O
much O
more O
severe O
phenotype O
than O
female O
FXS O
and O
mosaic O
patients O
, O
respectively O
. O

Our O
study O
underlines O
the O
importance O
of O
considering O
mosaicism O
, O
sex O
, O
and O
the O
associated O
comorbidity O
profiles O
of O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
to O
guide O
long O
- O
term O
health O
care O
of O
affected O
patients O
. O

Screening O
, O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
, O
and O
prenatal O
decision O
for O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
. O

Objective O
: O
To O
assess O
the O
performance O
of O
non O
- O
invasive O
prenatal O
testing O
( O
NIPT O
) O
in O
screening O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
( O
SCA O
) O
, O
and O
explore O
prenatal O
decision O
- O
making O
in O
NIPT O
positive O
cases O
. O

Methods O
: O
The O
study O
retrospectively O
analyses O
singleton O
pregnancies O
who O
underwent O
NIPT O
screening O
. O

Clinical O
data O
, O
diagnostic O
results O
, O
and O
pregnancy O
outcomes O
were O
also O
collected O
. O

Results O
: O
There O
were O
140 O
positive O
screens O
for O
SCA O
, O
including O
62 O
cases O
of O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
29 O
cases O
with O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
28 O
cases O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
20 O
cases O
of O
47 O
, O
XYY O
, O
and O
one O
case O
of O
lower O
X O
chromosome O
. O

Karyotypic O
information O
was O
available O
in O
103 O
cases O
. O

The O
positive O
predictive O
value O
was O
26 O
. O
09 O
% O
for O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
85 O
. O
00 O
% O
for O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
85 O
. O
00 O
% O
for O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
and O
68 O
. O
75 O
% O
for O
47 O
, O
XYY O
. O

The O
termination O
rates O
of O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
47 O
, O
XYY O
were O
83 O
. O
33 O
% O
, O
26 O
. O
67 O
% O
, O
82 O
. O
35 O
% O
, O
and O
54 O
. O
54 O
% O
, O
respectively O
( O
not O
including O
mosaic O
cases O
) O
. O

Conclusion O
: O
Our O
findings O
demonstrated O
that O
the O
NIPT O
performed O
better O
in O
predicting O
sex O
chromosome O
trisomies O
than O
monosomy O
X O
even O
though O
false O
- O
positive O
cases O
do O
exist O
in O
NIPT O
. O

For O
prenatal O
decisions O
, O
pregnancies O
with O
diagnoses O
of O
fetal O
45 O
, O
X O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
were O
terminated O
more O
often O
than O
those O
with O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
47 O
, O
XYY O
. O

To O
better O
guide O
positive O
screening O
pregnancies O
, O
pre O
- O
and O
post O
- O
test O
counseling O
are O
essential O
in O
telling O
patients O
the O
benefits O
and O
limitations O
of O
the O
test O
, O
comforting O
their O
anxiety O
and O
giving O
them O
the O
choice O
for O
further O
diagnosis O
and O
pregnancy O
decision O
. O

Clinical O
application O
of O
noninvasive O
prenatal O
screening O
for O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
in O
50 O
, O
301 O
pregnancies O
: O
initial O
experience O
in O
a O
Chinese O
hospital O
. O

To O
evaluate O
the O
clinical O
performance O
of O
noninvasive O
prenatal O
screening O
( O
NIPS O
) O
for O
fetal O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
( O
SCAs O
) O
, O
pregnant O
women O
were O
recruited O
in O
this O
retrospective O
observational O
study O
. O

The O
NIPS O
test O
was O
undertaken O
using O
high O
- O
throughput O
gene O
sequencing O
. O

In O
total O
, O
50 O
, O
301 O
pregnant O
women O
were O
analysed O
for O
demographic O
characteristics O
and O
medical O
history O
. O

Of O
them O
, O
308 O
women O
( O
0 O
. O
61 O
% O
) O
had O
high O
risk O
for O
fetal O
SCAs O
, O
including O
138 O
for O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
111 O
for O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
42 O
for O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
and O
17 O
for O
47 O
, O
XYY O
. O

After O
the O
pre O
- O
test O
counselling O
, O
182 O
participants O
chose O
to O
undergo O
invasive O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
, O
confirming O
59 O
positive O
cases O
. O

The O
combined O
positive O
predictive O
value O
of O
NIPS O
was O
32 O
. O
42 O
% O
( O
59 O
/ O
182 O
) O
, O
18 O
. O
39 O
% O
( O
16 O
/ O
87 O
) O
, O
44 O
. O
4 O
% O
( O
12 O
/ O
27 O
) O
, O
39 O
. O
29 O
% O
( O
22 O
/ O
56 O
) O
, O
and O
75 O
% O
( O
9 O
/ O
12 O
) O
for O
detecting O
SCAs O
, O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
, O
respectively O
. O

NIPS O
can O
be O
a O
useful O
method O
to O
detect O
the O
fetal O
SCAs O
using O
high O
- O
throughput O
gene O
sequencing O
, O
though O
accuracy O
can O
still O
be O
improved O
, O
especially O
for O
45 O
, O
X O
. O

Although O
the O
value O
of O
NIPS O
compare O
favorably O
with O
those O
seen O
in O
traditional O
screening O
approaches O
for O
SCAs O
, O
it O
is O
important O
to O
highlight O
the O
limitations O
of O
NIPS O
while O
educating O
clinicians O
and O
patients O
. O

Autism O
and O
social O
anxiety O
in O
children O
with O
sex O
chromosome O
trisomies O
: O
an O
observational O
study O
. O

Background O
: O
Recent O
studies O
suggest O
that O
an O
extra O
sex O
chromosome O
increases O
the O
risk O
of O
both O
autism O
and O
social O
anxiety O
, O
but O
it O
unclear O
whether O
these O
risks O
are O
specific O
to O
particular O
karyotypes O
. O

Methods O
: O
We O
considered O
diagnostic O
data O
from O
an O
online O
psychiatric O
assessment O
( O
DAWBA O
- O
The O
Development O
and O
Well O
- O
Being O
Assessment O
) O
and O
questionnaire O
responses O
completed O
by O
parents O
of O
children O
with O
47 O
, O
XXX O
( O
N O
= O
29 O
) O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
N O
= O
28 O
) O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
( O
N O
= O
32 O
) O
karyotypes O
. O

Analysis O
focused O
mainly O
on O
54 O
children O
who O
were O
diagnosed O
prenatally O
or O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
other O
medical O
concerns O
in O
childhood O
( O
Low O
Bias O
subgroup O
) O
, O
to O
minimise O
ascertainment O
bias O
. O

Results O
: O
Children O
with O
symptoms O
of O
autism O
who O
fell O
short O
of O
meeting O
the O
Diagnostic O
and O
Statistical O
Manual O
of O
Mental O
Disorders O
( O
DSM O
) O
- O
IV O
criteria O
were O
coded O
as O
cases O
of O
Pervasive O
Developmental O
Disorder O
Not O
Otherwise O
Specified O
( O
PDDNOS O
) O
. O

The O
odds O
ratio O
of O
autism O
or O
PDDNOS O
in O
the O
Low O
Bias O
group O
was O
computed O
relative O
to O
gender O
- O
specific O
population O
norms O
. O

This O
gave O
log O
odds O
ratio O
( O
95 O
% O
confidence O
interval O
) O
of O
5 O
. O
56 O
( O
4 O
. O
25 O
- O
6 O
. O
88 O
) O
for O
XXX O
girls O
; O
4 O
. O
00 O
( O
2 O
. O
66 O
- O
5 O
. O
33 O
) O
for O
XXY O
boys O
; O
and O
4 O
. O
60 O
( O
3 O
. O
46 O
- O
5 O
. O
74 O
) O
for O
XYY O
boys O
. O

Despite O
this O
elevated O
risk O
, O
most O
children O
had O
no O
autistic O
features O
. O

A O
diagnosis O
of O
DSM O
- O
IV O
Social O
Phobia O
was O
rare O
, O
though O
, O
in O
line O
with O
prediction O
, O
all O
three O
Low O
Bias O
cases O
with O
this O
diagnosis O
had O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

All O
three O
trisomy O
groups O
showed O
increased O
risk O
of O
milder O
symptoms O
of O
social O
anxiety O
. O

Conclusions O
: O
An O
increased O
risk O
of O
autism O
was O
found O
in O
girls O
with O
47 O
, O
XXX O
karyotype O
, O
as O
well O
as O
in O
boys O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
or O
47 O
, O
XYY O
. O

Symptoms O
of O
social O
anxiety O
were O
increased O
in O
all O
three O
karyotypes O
. O

There O
was O
wide O
variation O
in O
psychiatric O
status O
of O
children O
with O
the O
same O
karyotype O
, O
suggesting O
that O
an O
extra O
sex O
chromosome O
affects O
developmental O
stability O
in O
a O
non O
- O
specific O
way O
, O
with O
a O
diverse O
range O
of O
possible O
phenotypes O
. O

Non O
- O
invasive O
prenatal O
testing O
of O
fetal O
chromosomal O
aneuploidies O
: O
validation O
and O
clinical O
performance O
of O
the O
veracity O
test O
. O

Non O
- O
Invasive O
Prenatal O
Testing O
( O
NIPT O
) O
for O
fetal O
aneuploidies O
using O
cell O
- O
free O
DNA O
( O
cfDNA O
) O
has O
been O
widely O
adopted O
in O
clinical O
practice O
due O
to O
its O
improved O
accuracy O
. O

A O
number O
of O
NIPT O
tests O
have O
been O
developed O
and O
validated O
. O

The O
purpose O
of O
this O
study O
is O
to O
evaluate O
the O
performance O
of O
the O
Veracity O
NIPT O
test O
for O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
( O
SCA O
) O
detection O
in O
singleton O
pregnancies O
, O
autosomal O
aneuploidy O
detection O
in O
twin O
pregnancies O
and O
evaluation O
of O
Veracity O
clinical O
performance O
under O
routine O
NIPT O
conditions O
in O
a O
diverse O
cohort O
. O

Blinded O
retrospective O
study O
in O
singleton O
pregnancies O
( O
n O
= O
305 O
) O
; O
blinded O
retrospective O
and O
prospective O
study O
in O
twin O
pregnancies O
( O
n O
= O
306 O
) O
and O
prospective O
evaluation O
of O
clinical O
performance O
in O
singleton O
and O
twin O
pregnancies O
( O
n O
= O
10564 O
) O
. O

Validation O
study O
results O
for O
the O
detection O
of O
SCAs O
in O
singleton O
pregnancies O
exhibited O
100 O
% O
sensitivity O
and O
specificity O
and O
correctly O
classified O
7 O
( O
45 O
, O
X O
) O
, O
4 O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
, O
2 O
( O
47 O
, O
XXX O
) O
and O
1 O
( O
47 O
, O
XYY O
) O
cases O
. O

Validation O
study O
results O
for O
autosomal O
aneuploidy O
detection O
in O
twin O
pregnancies O
exhibited O
100 O
% O
sensitivity O
and O
specificity O
and O
correctly O
classified O
3 O
trisomy O
21 O
, O
1 O
trisomy O
18 O
and O
1 O
trisomy O
13 O
samples O
. O

Clinical O
performance O
evaluation O
of O
Veracity O
was O
performed O
in O
10564 O
pregnancies O
with O
median O
gestational O
age O
of O
13 O
weeks O
, O
median O
maternal O
age O
35 O
years O
and O
median O
gestational O
weight O
of O
64 O
kg O
. O

Based O
on O
confirmation O
feedback O
the O
PPV O
for O
trisomies O
21 O
, O
18 O
and O
13 O
was O
estimated O
at O
100 O
% O
( O
95 O
% O
CI O
, O
92 O
- O
100 O
% O
) O
, O
100 O
% O
( O
95 O
% O
CI O
, O
69 O
- O
100 O
% O
) O
and O
71 O
% O
( O
95 O
% O
CI O
, O
29 O
- O
96 O
% O
) O
, O
respectively O
. O

Estimated O
PPV O
for O
Monosomy O
X O
was O
57 O
% O
( O
95 O
% O
CI O
, O
18 O
- O
90 O
% O
) O
, O
while O
the O
NPV O
for O
SCA O
detection O
was O
estimated O
at O
100 O
% O
( O
95 O
% O
CI O
, O
99 O
. O
94 O
- O
100 O
% O
) O
. O

Veracity O
NIPT O
test O
is O
based O
on O
a O
very O
powerful O
, O
highly O
accurate O
methodology O
that O
can O
be O
safely O
applied O
in O
the O
clinical O
setting O
. O

Polygenic O
risk O
scores O
in O
schizophrenia O
with O
clinically O
significant O
copy O
number O
variants O
. O

Recent O
studies O
have O
revealed O
that O
the O
interplay O
between O
polygenic O
risk O
scores O
( O
PRS O
) O
and O
large O
copy O
number O
variants O
( O
CNV O
; O
> O
500kb O
) O
is O
essential O
for O
the O
etiology O
of O
schizophrenia O
( O
SCZ O
) O
. O

To O
replicate O
previous O
findings O
, O
including O
those O
for O
smaller O
CNV O
( O
> O
10kb O
) O
, O
the O
PRS O
between O
SCZ O
patients O
with O
and O
without O
CNV O
were O
compared O
. O

The O
PRS O
were O
calculated O
for O
724 O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
and O
1178 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
, O
genotyped O
using O
array O
- O
based O
comparative O
genomic O
hybridization O
and O
single O
nucleotide O
polymorphisms O
chips O
, O
and O
comparisons O
were O
made O
between O
cases O
and O
HC O
, O
or O
between O
subjects O
with O
and O
without O
' O
clinically O
significant O
' O
CNV O
. O

First O
, O
we O
replicated O
the O
higher O
PRS O
in O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
compared O
to O
that O
in O
HC O
( O
without O
taking O
into O
account O
the O
CNV O
) O
. O

For O

significant O
CNV O
, O
as O
defined O
by O
the O
American O
College O
of O
Medical O
Genetics O
( O
' O
pathogenic O
' O
and O
' O
uncertain O
clinical O
significance O
, O
likely O
pathogenic O
' O
CNV O
) O
, O
66 O
patients O

carried O

significant O
CNV O
, O
whereas O
658 O

patients O
had O
no O
such O
CNV O
. O

In O

of O
PRS O
between O
cases O
with O
/ O
without O
the O
CNV O
, O
despite O
no O
significant O
difference O
in O

, O

of O
the O

- O
established O
risk O

( O

. O
2 O
deletion O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXX O
) O
was O
observed O
in O
the O
lowest O

of O

in O

. O

Although O

failed O
to O

- O

. O

Therefore O

may O

' O

because O

of O

association O
analysis O
is O
limited O
due O
to O
their O
rarity O
. O

Mosaicism O
of O
XX O
and O
XXY O
cells O
accounts O
for O
high O
copy O
number O
of O
Toll O
like O
Receptor O
7 O
and O
8 O
genes O
in O
peripheral O
blood O
of O
men O
with O
Rheumatoid O
Arthritis O
. O

The O
X O
chromosome O
, O
hemizygous O
in O
males O
, O
contains O
numerous O
genes O
important O
to O
immunological O
and O

function O
. O

Alterations O
in O
X O
- O
linked O
gene O
dosage O
are O
suspected O
to O
contribute O
to O
female O
predominance O
in O
autoimmunity O
. O

A O

of O

- O

comes O
from O
the O

murine O
lupus O
model O
, O
where O

of O

- O

Toll O
- O

( O

) O

in O

. O

Such O

are O
possible O
in O

with O
autoimmune O
diseases O
. O

Here O
we O
showed O
that O
a O
quarter O
to O

of O

with O

( O

. O

upregulated O

- O

/ O

. O

By O
fluorescence O
in O
situ O
hybridization O
, O

that O

in O

- O

genes O

to O

extra O

in O

. O

of O
female O

. O

Our O

Cytogenetic O
investigation O
of O
couples O
with O
recurrent O
spontaneous O
miscarriages O
. O

Spontaneous O
pregnancy O
loss O
has O
always O
been O
the O
frustrating O
experience O
for O
the O
couples O
and O
concern O
clinician O
. O

Chromosomal O
abnormality O
in O
either O
of O
the O
parent O
is O
considered O
to O
be O
the O
one O
of O
the O
leading O
cause O
of O
recurrent O
spontaneous O
miscarriages O
. O

This O
study O
was O
designed O
to O
evaluate O
the O
possible O
chromosomal O
etiology O
of O
miscarriage O
and O
the O
subsequent O
intimacy O
of O
maternal O
or O

abnormality O
. O

This O
case O
- O
control O
study O
was O
conducted O
between O
January O
2016 O
and O
October O
2016 O
at O
a O
tertiary O
care O
hospital O
in O
Karachi O
. O

A O
total O
of O
thirty O
- O

couples O
were O
selected O
who O
had O
suffered O
with O
recurrent O
spontaneous O

( O

) O
. O

Using O
conventional O
cytogenetic O
technique O
karyotyping O
was O
performed O
on O
all O
of O
the O
subjects O
. O

For O
the O
control O
twenty O
couples O
were O
also O
selected O
with O
no O
history O
of O
pregnancy O
loss O
. O

All O
the O

were O
recorded O
on O
the O
standard O
method O
. O

Data O
was O
analyzed O
through O
SPSS O
version O
22 O
. O

Among O
thirty O
- O
two O
cases O
nine O
cases O
were O

to O
have O
abnormal O

. O

which O

with O

Genetic O
and O

of O

Genetic O

of O

. O

to O

and O

in O

. O

A O

of O

with O

underwent O

analysis O
at O
The O
Sixth O

of O
Guangzhou O

. O

The O

of O

, O

. O

, O

. O

. O

Emotion O
regulation O
in O

47 O
, O

) O
: O

. O

The O

and O

of O

. O

A O

of O

with O

completed O

of O
cognitive O

, O

, O
and O

of O

. O

( O

, O

( O

) O
. O

Single O
- O
Cell O
Sequencing O
Reveals O
the O
Relationship O
between O
Phenotypes O
and O
Genotypes O
of O
Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
one O
of O
the O
most O
common O
congenital O
disorders O
of O
male O
infertility O
. O

Given O
its O
high O
heterogeneity O
in O
clinical O
and O
genetic O
presentation O
, O
the O
relationship O
between O
transcriptome O
, O
clinical O
phenotype O
, O
and O
associated O
co O
- O
morbidities O
seen O
in O
KS O
has O
not O
been O
fully O
clarified O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
report O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
Chinese O
male O
with O
infertility O
and O
analyzed O
the O
differences O
in O
gene O
expression O
patterns O
of O
peripheral O
blood O
mononuclear O
cells O
( O
PBMCs O
) O
with O
regard O
to O
a O
Chinese O
male O
and O
a O
female O
control O
with O
normal O
karyotype O
by O
single O
- O
cell O
sequencing O
. O

A O
total O
of O
24 O
, O
439 O
cells O
were O
analyzed O
and O
divided O
into O
5 O
immune O
cell O
types O
( O
including O
B O
cells O
, O
T O
cells O
, O
macrophage O
cells O
, O
dendritic O
cells O
, O
and O
natural O
killer O
cells O
) O
according O
to O
marker O
genes O
. O

Using O
unsupervised O
dimensionality O
reduction O
and O
clustering O
algorithms O
, O
we O
identified O
molecularly O
distinct O
subpopulations O
of O
cells O
between O
the O
KS O
patient O
and O
both O
controls O
. O

Gene O
ontology O
enrichment O
analyses O
yielded O
terms O
associated O
with O
well O
- O
known O
comorbidities O
seen O
in O
KS O
as O
well O
as O
an O
affected O
immune O
system O
and O
type O
I O

. O

Based O
on O
our O
data O
, O
we O
identified O
several O
candidate O
genes O
which O
may O
be O

in O

of O

. O

Overall O
, O

analysis O
provides O
a O

of O

cell O

of O

in O

to O

and O

of O

patients O

Quantifying O
the O
polygenic O
contribution O
to O
variable O
expressivity O
in O
eleven O
rare O
genetic O
disorders O
. O

Rare O
genetic O
disorders O
( O
RGDs O
) O
often O
exhibit O
significant O
clinical O
variability O
among O
affected O
individuals O
, O
a O
disease O
characteristic O
termed O
variable O
expressivity O
. O

Recently O
, O
the O
aggregate O
effect O
of O
common O
variation O
, O
quantified O
as O
polygenic O
scores O
( O
PGSs O
) O
, O
has O
emerged O
as O
an O
effective O
tool O
for O
predictions O
of O
disease O
risk O
and O
trait O
variation O
in O
the O
general O
population O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
measure O
the O
effect O
of O
PGSs O
on O
11 O
RGDs O
including O
four O
sex O
- O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
( O
47 O
, O
XXX O
; O
47 O
, O
XXY O
; O
47 O
, O
XYY O
; O
45 O
, O
X O
) O
that O
affect O
height O
; O
two O
copy O
- O
number O
variant O
( O
CNV O
) O
disorders O
( O
16p11 O
. O
2 O
deletions O
and O
duplications O
) O
and O
a O
Mendelian O
disease O
( O
melanocortin O
4 O
receptor O
deficiency O
( O
MC4R O
) O
) O
that O
affect O
BMI O
; O
and O
two O
Mendelian O
diseases O
affecting O
cholesterol O
: O
familial O
hypercholesterolemia O

( O
FH O
; O
LDLR O
and O
APOB O
) O
and O
familial O
hypobetalipoproteine O
( O
FHBL O
; O
PCSK9 O
and O
APOB O
) O
. O

Our O
results O
demonstrate O
that O
common O
, O
polygenic O
factors O
of O
relevant O
complex O
traits O
frequently O
contribute O
to O
variable O
expressivity O
of O
RGDs O
and O
that O
PGSs O
may O
be O
a O
useful O
metric O
for O
predicting O
clinical O
severity O
in O
affected O
individuals O
and O
for O
risk O
stratification O
. O

Different O
parental O
origins O
of O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosomes O
in O
brothers O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
: O
A O
case O
report O
. O

Recurrence O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
in O
non O
- O
twin O
brothers O
is O
very O
rare O
. O

This O
study O
examined O
the O
inheritance O
pattern O
of O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosomes O
in O
non O
- O
twin O
brothers O
. O

A O
16 O
- O
year O
- O
old O
man O
presented O
with O
small O
- O
sized O
testicles O
. O

During O
his O
diagnostic O
work O
- O
up O
, O
his O
brother O
, O
in O
his O
late O
20 O
' O
s O
, O
also O
complained O
of O
small O
testes O
and O
erectile O
dysfunction O
. O

Chromosome O
analysis O
in O
peripheral O
blood O
revealed O
non O
- O
mosaic O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
in O
both O
brothers O
. O

Their O
mother O
showed O
a O
normal O
46 O
, O
XX O
karyotype O
. O

To O
examine O
the O
inheritance O
pattern O
of O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosomes O
, O
quantitative O
- O
fluorescence O
PCR O
was O
performed O
with O
small O
tandem O
repeat O
markers O
. O

It O
revealed O
that O
their O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosomes O
were O
inherited O
from O
different O
parents O
. O

After O
the O
diagnosis O
of O
KS O
, O
2 O
brothers O
started O
to O
receive O
testosterone O
treatment O
. O

This O
case O
report O
is O
the O
first O
to O
report O
differences O
in O
the O
origins O
of O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosomes O
in O
brothers O
with O
KS O
and O
furthers O
the O
current O
understanding O
of O
the O
cytogenetic O
mechanisms O
in O
KS O
. O

Update O
On O
The O
Clinical O
Perspectives O
And O
Care O
Of O
The O
Child O
With O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
) O
. O

47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
[ O
KS O
] O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
( O
1 O
: O
660 O
) O
, O
yet O
, O
despite O
this O
, O
only O
25 O
% O
of O
the O
males O
are O
ever O
diagnosed O
. O

Males O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
present O
with O
characteristic O
symptoms O
throughout O
their O
lifetime O
with O
typical O
physical O
and O
neurodevelopmental O
manifestations O
focused O
in O
growth O
, O
cognitive O
development O
, O
endocrine O
function O
, O
and O
reproduction O
. O

Studies O
have O
demonstrated O
that O
optimal O
outcomes O
are O
dependent O
on O
early O
detection O
combined O
with O
consistent O
and O
targeted O
neurodevelopmental O
treatment O
throughout O
the O
lifespan O
. O

During O
infancy O
and O
into O
the O
preschool O
years O
, O
individuals O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
commonly O
face O
deficits O
in O
growth O
and O
development O
in O
the O
areas O
of O
early O
hormonal O
, O
motor O
, O
speech O
, O
and O
behavioral O
development O
. O

As O
they O
transition O
into O
school O
, O
the O
primary O
neurodevelopmental O
concerns O
include O
language O
difficulty O
, O
executive O
dysfunction O
, O
behavior O
, O
and O
learning O
and O
reading O
deficits O
. O

Adults O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
often O
present O
with O
taller O
than O
average O
height O
, O
low O
levels O
of O
fertility O
, O
azoospermia O
, O
and O
elevated O
gonadotropin O
levels O
. O

These O
presentations O
may O
persist O
from O
early O
childhood O
through O
adulthood O
but O
can O
be O
mitigated O
by O
appropriate O
interventions O
. O

Early O
neurodevelopmental O
and O
hormonal O
treatment O
has O
been O
shown O
to O
have O
a O
minimizing O
effect O
on O
the O
physical O
and O
neurodevelopmental O
manifestations O
in O
individuals O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

With O
innovative O
and O
current O
research O
studies O
, O
the O
features O
common O
to O
the O
neurodevelopmental O
profile O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
have O
been O
further O
expanded O
and O
defined O
. O

Further O
research O
is O
necessary O
to O
elucidate O
and O
understand O
the O
relationship O
between O
the O
brain O
, O
behavior O
, O
and O
the O
phenotypic O
profile O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

Blood O
Testis O
Barrier O
and O
Somatic O
Cells O
Impairment O
in O
a O
Series O
of O
35 O
Adult O
Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
Patients O
. O

Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O
genetic O
cause O
of O
infertility O
in O
men O
. O

Degeneration O
of O
the O
testicular O
tissue O
starts O
in O
utero O
and O
accelerates O
at O
puberty O
with O
hyalinisation O
of O
seminiferous O
tubules O
, O
spermatogonia O
apoptosis O
and O
germ O
cell O
maturation O
arrest O
. O

Therefore O
, O
fertility O
preservation O
in O
young O
KS O
boys O
has O
been O
proposed O
, O
although O
this O
measure O
is O
still O
debated O
due O
to O
insufficient O
knowledge O
of O
the O
pathophysiology O
of O
the O
disease O
. O

To O
better O
understand O
the O
underlying O
mechanisms O
of O
testicular O
failure O
and O
germ O
cell O
loss O
, O
we O
analysed O
functional O
and O
morphological O
alterations O
in O
the O
somatic O
compartment O
of O
KS O
testis O
, O
i O
. O
e O
. O
, O
Sertoli O
cells O
, O
including O
the O
blood O
- O
testis O
barrier O
( O
BTB O
) O
and O
Leydig O
cells O
( O
LC O
) O
. O

We O
compared O
three O
populations O
: O
35 O
KS O
47 O
, O
XXY O
non O
- O
mosaic O
patients O
, O
28 O
Sertoli O
- O
cell O
- O
only O
( O
SCO O
) O
syndrome O
patients O
and O
9 O
patients O
with O
normal O
spermatogenesis O
. O

In O
KS O
patients O
the O
expression O
of O
BTB O
proteins O
connexin O
- O
43 O
and O
claudin O
- O
11 O
assessed O
with O
a O
semi O
- O
quantitative O
scoring O
system O
appeared O
significantly O
reduced O
with O
a O
disorganised O
pattern O
. O

A O
significant O
reduction O
in O
seminiferous O
tubules O
expressing O
androgen O
receptors O
( O
AR O
) O
was O
observed O
in O
KS O
compared O
to O
normal O
spermatogenesis O
controls O
. O

INSL3 O
expression O
, O
a O
marker O
of O
LC O
maturation O
, O
was O
also O
significantly O
reduced O
in O
KS O
compared O
to O
patients O
with O
normal O
spermatogenesis O
or O
SCO O
. O

Hence O
, O
the O
somatic O
compartment O
impairment O
in O
KS O
could O
be O
involved O
in O
degeneration O
of O
seminiferous O
tubules O
. O

Testosterone O
Treatment O
in O
Infants O
With O
47 O
, O
XXY O
: O
Effects O
on O
Body O
Composition O
. O

Boys O
with O
XXY O
have O
greater O
adiposity O
and O
a O
higher O
risk O
of O
cardiovascular O
disease O
. O

Infants O
with O
XXY O
have O
lower O
testosterone O
concentrations O
than O
typical O
boys O
, O
but O
no O
studies O
have O
evaluated O
adiposity O
in O
infants O
with O
XXY O
or O
the O
physiologic O
effects O
of O
giving O
testosterone O
replacement O
. O

To O
determine O
the O
effect O
of O
testosterone O
on O
body O
composition O
in O
infants O
with O
XXY O
. O

Prospective O
, O
randomized O
trial O
. O

Tertiary O
care O

referral O
center O
. O
20 O
infants O
6 O
to O
15 O
weeks O
of O
age O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

Testosterone O
cypionate O
25 O
mg O
intramuscularly O
monthly O
for O
three O
doses O
vs O
no O
treatment O
. O

Difference O
in O
change O
in O
adiposity O
( O
percent O
fat O
mass O
z O
scores O
) O
; O
other O
body O
composition O
measures O
, O
penile O
length O
, O
and O
safety O
outcomes O
between O
treated O
and O
untreated O
infants O
; O
and O
comparison O
with O
typical O
infants O
. O

The O
increase O
in O
percent O
fat O

( O
% O
FM O
) O

scores O
was O
greater O
in O

than O

group O
( O
+ O
0 O
. O
92 O
± O
0 O
. O

- O
0 O
. O

± O
0 O
. O
65 O
, O

= O
0 O
. O

) O
. O

for O

, O

( O

< O

. O

At O

. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
and O
testosterone O
treatment O
: O
a O
national O
cohort O
study O
on O
thrombosis O
risk O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
can O
be O
viewed O
as O
a O
disease O
model O
for O
investigating O
the O
risk O
of O
thrombosis O
in O
male O
hypogonadism O
and O
the O
subsequent O
risk O
related O
to O
testosterone O
treatment O
. O

We O
describe O
rates O
of O
thrombotic O
risk O
factors O
, O
thrombosis O
and O
thrombosis O
mortality O
in O
KS O
and O
the O
association O
with O
testosterone O
treatment O
. O

National O
registry O
- O
based O
matched O
cohort O
study O
with O
follow O
- O
up O
from O
1995 O
to O
2016 O
set O
in O
Denmark O
. O

For O
the O
study O
, O
1155 O
men O
with O
KS O
were O
each O
matched O
by O
year O
and O
month O
of O
birth O
to O
100 O
men O
from O
the O
background O
population O
. O

First O
thrombotic O
events O
and O
thrombosis O
mortality O
was O
evaluated O
by O
event O
rates O
and O
hazard O
ratios O
( O
HRs O
) O
and O
by O
applying O
testosterone O
treatment O
as O
a O
time O
- O
dependent O
covariate O
. O

The O
KS O
cohort O
had O
higher O
incidence O
of O
venous O
thromboembolism O
relative O
to O
the O
comparison O
cohort O
( O
HR O
, O
3 O
. O
95 O
; O
95 O
% O
CI O
, O
2 O
. O
83 O
- O
5 O
. O
52 O
) O
. O

Total O
thrombotic O
deaths O
were O
increased O
in O
KS O
( O

, O
1 O
. O
76 O
; O
95 O
% O
CI O
, O
1 O
. O
18 O
- O
2 O
. O
62 O
) O
, O
and O
all O
- O
cause O

was O
increased O
in O

following O

( O
HR O
1 O
. O
73 O
; O
95 O
% O
CI O
1 O
. O

- O
2 O
. O

) O
. O

Only O
48 O
. O
7 O
% O
of O

for O

. O

Untreated O

were O
on O

, O
and O

. O

Testosterone O
treatment O
in O

was O
associated O
with O
a O

- O

decrease O
in O

and O

. O

Thrombosis O
and O

are O
increased O
in O
KS O
. O

Only O
half O
of O
the O

with O

ever O

, O
despite O
overt O

Testosterone O
treatment O
in O
Klinefelter O

was O
insignificantly O
associated O
with O

of O

and O

A O
Case O
Report O
of O
Exacerbation O
of O

Ulcers O
Associated O
with O

- O
dose O
Acetylsalicylic O
Acid O
in O
a O
Patient O
with O
Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
the O
most O
frequent O
type O
of O
congenital O
sex O
- O
chromosomal O
disorder O
caused O
by O
at O
least O
one O
extra O
X O
chromosome O
and O
commonly O
treated O
with O
lifetime O
testosterone O
therapy O
. O

Ulcerative O
lesions O
on O
lower O
extremities O
may O
occur O
as O
a O
complication O
of O
KS O
. O

The O
pathogenesis O
of O
ulcers O
in O
KS O
patients O
has O
not O
been O
clarified O
on O
a O
molecular O
level O
. O

Here O
we O
present O
a O
case O
of O
leg O
ulcers O
exacerbation O
associated O
with O
the O

of O
a O
high O

of O

acid O
in O
a O

- O

- O

patient O
with O
karyotype O
47 O
, O
XXY O
undergoing O

for O
the O

20 O

. O

The O

of O
the O
ulcer O
on O
the O
patient O
' O
s O

occurred O
during O
one O

of O

intake O
( O
1 O
. O
2 O
g O
daily O
) O
. O

The O
patient O
was O

to O
return O
to O
his O
standard O
daily O
dose O
of O
0 O
. O
1 O
g O
of O
acetylsalicylic O
acid O
and O
significant O
improvement O
of O
his O
leg O
ulcer O
was O
observed O
after O
two O
weeks O
. O

We O
hypothesize O
that O
testosterone O
- O
mediated O
nitric O
oxide O
balance O
in O
KS O
patient O
is O
perturbed O
under O
the O

of O
acute O
high O
- O
dose O

acid O

. O

We O
propose O
that O

of O
approximately O
0 O
. O
1 O
g O
/ O
day O
of O
acetylsalicylic O
acid O
have O
no O
apparent O
effect O
on O
nitric O
oxide O
status O
, O
whereas O
higher O
doses O
may O
cause O
dysregulation O
of O
nitric O
oxide O
production O
and O
/ O
or O
utilization O
, O
creating O
conditions O
which O
may O
cause O
the O
appearance O
of O
leg O
ulcers O
in O
the O
KS O
patients O
. O

of O

: O

- O

. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
characterized O
by O
an O
additional O
X O
chromosome O
in O
males O
leading O
to O
a O
karyotype O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

It O
is O
associated O
with O
an O
increased O
risk O
of O
certain O
malignancies O
, O
including O
leukemia O
, O
breast O
cancer O
and O
extragonadal O
germ O
cell O
tumor O
such O
as O
mediastinal O
germ O
cell O
tumors O
and O
rarely O
intracranial O
germ O
cell O
tumors O
. O

It O
is O
possible O
that O
the O
increased O
risk O
of O
developing O
certain O
cancers O
can O
be O
attributed O
to O
a O
direct O
effect O
of O
the O
chromosomal O
abnormality O
or O
the O
combined O
action O
of O
the O
abnormal O
chromosomes O
and O
hormonal O
imbalances O
. O

Here O
we O
describe O
a O
synchronous O
occurrence O
of O

intracranial O
germinoma O
and O
bilateral O
testicular O
epidermoid O
cyst O
in O
an O
adolescent O
patient O
with O
Klinefelter O
` O
s O
syndrome O
. O

The O
synchronous O

of O

tumors O
in O
this O
patient O
with O
Klinefelter O
` O
s O
syndrome O
might O
be O
resulted O
from O
the O
migration O
defect O
during O
embriyogenesis O
due O
to O
underlying O
genetic O
disease O
or O

is O

condition O
, O
yet O
there O
has O
been O
no O
case O
reported O
in O
the O

, O
so O
far O
. O

Random O
X O
chromosome O
inactivation O
in O
patients O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

X O
chromosome O
inactivation O
( O
XCI O
) O
is O
an O
indispensable O
process O
in O
the O
development O
of O
human O
female O
embryos O
. O

Reportedly O
, O
XCI O
occurs O
when O
a O
blastocyst O
contains O
10 O
- O
12 O
embryonic O
progenitor O
cells O
. O

To O
date O
, O
it O
remains O
unclear O
whether O
XCI O
ratios O
are O
normally O
preserved O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
patients O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
. O

We O
examined O
XCI O
ratios O
in O
18 O
KS O
patients O
through O
DNA O
methylation O
analysis O
for O
the O
polymorphic O
trinucleotide O
locus O
in O
the O
AR O
gene O
. O

The O
results O
of O
the O
KS O
patients O
were O
compared O
to O
previous O
data O
from O
healthy O
young O
women O
. O

XCI O
ratios O
in O
KS O
patients O
followed O
a O
normal O
distribution O
. O

Skewed O
XCI O
was O
observed O
in O
two O
patients O
, O
one O
of O
whom O
exhibited O
extremely O
skewed O
XCI O
. O

The O
frequencies O
of O
skewed O
and O
extremely O
skewed O
XCI O
in O
the O
KS O
cohort O
were O
comparable O
to O
those O
in O
healthy O
women O
. O

This O
study O
confirmed O
the O
rarity O
of O
skewed O
XCI O
in O
KS O
patients O
. O

These O
results O
indicate O
that O
the O
presence O
of O
a O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosome O
during O
the O
cleavage O
and O
early O
blastocyst O
stages O
does O
not O
affect O
the O
developmental O
tempo O
of O
embryos O
. O

Our O
data O
deserve O
further O
validation O
. O

Generation O
of O
an O
induced O
pluripotent O
stem O
cell O

( O
SDQLCHi009 O

) O

. O

A O
review O
of O

Although O

( O

) O

The O

between O

, O

. O

Current O

that O

of O

a O

on O

Cell O
- O

for O

- O

( O

) O

, O

. O

However O
, O

in O

( O

) O

. O

High O
- O

( O

) O

was O
used O
to O

. O

Human O
sex O

aneuploidies O
: O
The O
hypothalamic O
- O
pituitary O
- O
gonadal O
axis O
. O

Sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
( O
SCA O
) O
are O
relatively O
common O
as O
a O
group O
, O
perhaps O
1 O
per O
500 O
births O
, O
but O
much O
more O
common O
at O
conception O
. O

Many O
syndromes O
have O
been O
noted O
in O
those O
with O
these O
conditions O
, O
but O
not O
so O
many O
data O
are O
available O
concerning O
the O
hypothalamic O
- O
pituitary O
- O
gonadal O
( O
HPG O
) O
axis O
. O

The O
physiology O
of O
the O
HPG O
axis O
is O
first O
reviewed O
at O
four O
epochs O
in O
time O
: O

, O

and O
mini O
- O
puberty O
, O

, O
and O
adolescence O
( O
puberty O
) O
. O

Those O
sections O
are O
followed O
by O

of O

functioning O
of O

axis O
in O

with O

ranging O
from O
45 O
to O

. O

Robust O
data O
are O
available O
for O
the O

complements O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
47 O
, O
XXX O
with O
fewer O
data O
available O
for O

the O

. O

Neurodevelopmental O
outcome O
of O
prenatally O
diagnosed O
boys O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
) O

the O

of O
early O

therapy O
. O

This O
cross O
- O
sectional O
study O
examined O
the O
neurodevelopment O
of O
a O
large O
, O

population O
of O

, O

; O

the O

of O

therapy O
( O

) O
on O
language O
, O

, O
and O

; O
and O
identified O
novel O
at O
risk O

associated O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

Two O
- O
hundred O
and O

two O

were O

from O
148 O
prenatally O

boys O
with O
47 O

between O

and O
36 O
months O
and O
separated O
into O
one O
of O
three O
groups O
, O
depending O
on O
visit O
age O
: O
Y1 O
( O
0 O
- O
12 O
months O
; O
n O
= O
100 O
) O
, O
Y2 O
( O
13 O
- O
24 O
months O
; O
n O
= O
90 O
) O
, O
and O
Y3 O
( O
25 O
- O
36 O
months O
; O
n O
= O
82 O
) O
. O

Those O
who O
received O
EHT O
( O
administered O
by O
12 O

) O

further O
separated O
( O

, O

= O

; O
Y2 O

; O

, O

= O

) O
. O

Neurodevelopmental O
evaluations O
consisted O
of O
Preschool O
Language O
Scales O
, O

Language O

, O
and O

of O

of O

on O

, O

, O

, O

, O
and O

. O

EHT O
was O
found O
to O
be O
associated O
with O
a O
positive O
effect O
within O
the O
first O
year O
of O
life O
in O
these O

, O

well O

in O
the O

and O

of O

. O

Additionally O
, O
three O
novel O

- O
risk O

were O
identified O
in O

: O

in O

, O

, O

The O
positive O
effects O
of O

observed O
in O

, O

, O
and O
motor O
at O
variable O
stages O

years O
of O
life O
provide O

evidence O
into O
the O
possible O
efficacy O
of O
early O

treatment O
for O
boys O

47 O
, O
XXY O
to O
address O
the O

dysfunction O
. O

Comparison O
of O
NGS O
panel O
and O
Sanger O
sequencing O
for O
genotyping O
CAG O
repeats O
in O
the O
AR O
gene O
. O

The O
androgen O
receptor O
( O
AR O
) O
is O
a O
nuclear O
receptor O
, O
encoded O
by O
the O
AR O
gene O
on O
the O
X O
chromosome O
. O

Within O
the O
first O
exon O
of O
the O
AR O
gene O
, O
two O
short O
tandem O
repeats O
( O
STR O
) O
, O
CAG O
and O
GGC O
, O
are O
a O
source O
of O
polymorphism O
in O
the O
population O
. O

Therefore O
, O
high O
- O
throughput O
methods O
for O
screening O
AR O
, O
such O
as O
next O
- O
generation O
sequencing O
( O
NGS O
) O
, O
are O
sought O
after O
; O
however O
, O
data O
generated O
by O
NGS O
are O
limited O
by O
the O
availability O
of O
bioinformatics O
tools O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
evaluated O
the O
accuracy O
of O
the O
bioinformatics O
tool O
HipSTR O
in O
detecting O
and O
quantify O
CAG O
repeats O
within O
the O
AR O
gene O
. O

The O
AR O
gene O
of O
228 O
infertile O
men O
was O
sequenced O
using O
NGSgene O
panel O
. O

Data O
generated O
were O
analyzed O
with O
HipSTR O
to O
detect O
CAG O
repeats O
. O

The O
accuracy O
was O
compared O
with O
the O
results O
obtained O
with O
Sanger O
. O

We O
found O
that O

was O
more O
accurate O
than O

in O
genotyping O

) O
. O

Our O
findings O
show O
that O

bioinformatics O
tool O

is O
100 O
% O

in O

) O

. O

[ O

for O

. O

Clinical O
experience O
regarding O

in O

. O

The O

study O
aimed O
to O

( O

) O

) O

. O

Among O
a O

of O

. O

The O

. O

Children O
with O
SCT O
have O

of O
suboptimal O

. O

Previous O
studies O
have O
shown O
an O

risk O
for O

in O
individuals O
with O
SCT O
. O

However O
, O
not O
much O
is O
known O
about O
neurobehavioral O

in O
very O
young O
children O
; O
knowledge O
that O
could O

at O

for O

, O

. O

This O

addressed O
the O
question O
of O

looks O

. O

In O

, O

( O

. O

Recruitment O
and O

and O

. O

The O

was O

, O

Behavioral O

were O

with O

and O
the O
ages O

and O
- O

- O

. O

Levels O
of O
parent O
- O

problem O
behavior O
were O
higher O
in O
children O
with O
SCT O
. O

Difficulties O
with O
overall O
social O
- O

functioning O
were O
already O
present O
in O
1 O
- O
year O
- O

, O

scores O
were O

across O

. O

Affective O
and O
pervasive O
developmental O
behaviors O
were O
seen O
in O
late O

and O
prominent O
at O

. O

Anxiety O
, O

deficit O
, O
and O

were O
seen O
in O

- O

. O

Within O
this O
cross O
- O
sectional O
study O
, O
the O

trajectory O
of O

seemed O

be O
different O
for O

children O
than O
nonclinical O
controls O
. O

Collectively O
, O

results O
demonstrate O

of O

for O

for O

from O

. O

Social O
- O
emotional O
problems O
may O

, O

these O

seem O
most O

, O

three O
SCT O
karyotypes O
. O

41 O
, O
XXY O
* O
male O
mice O
: O
An O
animal O
model O
for O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
is O
the O
most O
frequent O
male O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
resulting O
in O
a O
highly O
heterogeneous O
clinical O
phenotype O
associated O
with O
hormonal O
dysbalance O
, O
increased O
rate O
of O
co O
- O
morbidities O
, O
and O
reduced O
lifespan O
. O

Two O
hallmarks O
of O
KS O
- O
affecting O
testicular O
functions O
are O
consistently O
observed O
: O
Hypergonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
and O
germ O
cell O
( O
GC O
) O
loss O
resulting O
in O
infertility O
. O

Although O
KS O
is O
being O
studied O
for O
decades O
, O
the O
underlying O
mechanisms O
for O
the O
observed O
pathophysiology O
are O
still O
unclear O
. O

Due O
to O
ethical O
restrictions O
, O
studies O
in O
humans O
are O
limited O
, O
and O
consequently O
, O
suitable O
animal O
models O
are O
needed O
to O
address O
the O
consequences O
of O
a O
supernumerary O
X O
chromosome O
. O

Mouse O
strains O
with O
comparable O
aneuploidies O
have O
been O
generated O
and O
yielded O
highly O
relevant O
insights O
into O
KS O
. O

We O
briefly O
describe O
the O
establishment O
of O
the O
KS O
mouse O
models O
, O
summarize O
the O
knowledge O
gained O
by O
their O
use O
, O
compare O
findings O
from O
the O
mouse O
models O
to O
those O
obtained O
in O
clinical O
studies O
, O
and O
also O
reflect O
on O
limitations O
of O
the O
currently O
used O
models O
derived O
from O
the O
B6Ei O
. O
Lt O
- O
Y O
* O
mouse O
strain O
, O
in O
which O
the O
Y O
chromosome O
is O
altered O
and O
its O
centromere O
position O
changed O
into O
a O
more O
distal O
location O
provoking O
meiotic O
non O
- O
disjunction O
. O

Breeding O
such O
as O
XY O
* O
males O
to O
XX O
females O
, O
the O
target O
41 O
, O
XXY O
* O
, O
and O
41 O
, O
XXY O
males O
are O
generated O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
summarize O
features O
of O
both O
models O
but O
report O
in O
particular O
findings O
from O
our O
41 O
, O
XXY O
* O
mice O
including O
some O
novel O
data O
on O
Sertoli O
cell O
characteristics O
. O

Meiotic O
Behavior O
of O
Extra O
Sex O
Chromosomes O
in O
Patients O
with O
the O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
Karyotype O
and O
Its O
Ultimate O
Consequences O
for O
Spermatogenesis O
. O

Infertility O
is O
one O
of O
the O
most O
important O
and O
burning O
issues O
in O
present O
times O
, O
as O
a O
marked O
increase O
in O
the O
frequency O
of O
infertile O
cases O
has O
been O
observed O
all O
over O
the O
world O
. O

Chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
is O
among O
the O
known O
factors O
associated O
with O
infertility O
, O
and O
among O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
constitute O
the O
most O
common O
class O
of O
chromosome O
abnormality O
in O
human O
live O
births O
. O

Considerable O
attention O
has O
been O
given O
to O
the O
somatic O
abnormalities O
associated O
with O
these O
conditions O
, O
but O
less O
is O
known O
about O
their O
meiotic O
progression O
; O
that O
is O
, O
how O
sex O
chromosome O
imbalance O
influences O
the O
meiotic O
process O
. O

It O
has O
been O
documented O
that O
men O
with O
the O
same O
underlying O
genetic O
cause O
of O
infertility O
do O
not O
present O
with O
uniform O
pathology O
, O
so O
it O
is O
informative O
to O
find O
out O
how O
meiotic O
progression O
differs O
in O
patients O
with O
similar O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
having O
different O
phenotypes O
. O

The O
importance O
of O
studying O
meiotic O
progression O
in O
patients O
with O
sex O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
has O
increased O
many O
fold O
with O
the O
introduction O
of O
assisted O
reproductive O
technologies O
that O
have O
made O
it O
possible O
for O
infertile O
men O
to O
become O
biological O
parents O
. O

Hence O
, O
exploring O
the O
possible O
consequences O
of O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
for O
meiotic O
chromosome O
segregation O
is O
worthwhile O
. O

The O
objective O
of O
this O
review O
, O
in O
the O
context O
of O
current O
knowledge O
, O
is O
to O
discuss O
problems O
associated O
with O
fertility O
and O
progression O
of O
meiosis O
in O
two O
relatively O
common O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
, O
reported O
in O
humans O
. O

Neuropsychological O
functions O
, O
sleep O
, O
and O
mental O
health O
in O
adults O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

A O
few O
studies O
have O
examined O
neuropsychological O
functions O
, O
sleep O
, O
and O
mental O
health O
combined O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
; O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
. O

We O
investigated O
neuropsychological O
functions O
with O
standard O
tests O
, O
sleep O
with O
actigraphy O
, O
and O
self O
- O
reported O
mental O
health O
in O
30 O
men O
with O
KS O
( O
Mean O
age O
= O
36 O
. O
7 O
years O
) O
compared O
to O
21 O
controls O
( O
Mean O
age O
= O
36 O
. O
8 O
years O
) O
. O

Men O
with O
KS O
scored O
significantly O
lower O
on O
mental O
speed O
, O
attention O
span O
, O
working O
memory O
, O
inhibition O
, O
and O
set O
- O
shifting O
tests O
, O
as O
well O
as O
overall O
IQ O
( O
mean O
effect O
size O
difference O
Cohen O
' O
s O
d O
= O
0 O
. O
79 O
) O
. O

Men O
with O
KS O
had O
significantly O
longer O
night O
wakes O
, O
with O
no O
differences O
in O
other O
sleep O
variables O
( O
mean O
d O
= O
0 O
. O
34 O
) O
. O

Men O
with O
KS O
reported O
poorer O
mental O
health O
than O
controls O
( O
mean O
d O
= O
1 O
. O
16 O
) O
. O

Regression O
analyses O
showed O
neuropsychological O
functions O
explained O
variance O
in O
some O
sleep O
domains O
for O
men O
with O
KS O
but O
not O
for O
controls O
. O

Neuropsychological O
functions O
explained O
variance O
in O
some O
mental O
health O
domains O
for O
controls O
. O

For O
men O
with O
KS O
, O
however O
, O
verbal O
IQ O
was O
the O
only O
significant O
predictor O
of O
mental O
health O
. O

Altogether O
, O
men O
with O
KS O
display O
problems O
in O
neuropsychological O
functions O
and O
mental O
health O
but O
do O
not O
appear O
different O
from O
controls O
on O
most O
sleep O
parameters O
. O

Our O
findings O
indicate O
that O
relations O
between O
neuropsychological O
functions O
, O
sleep O
, O
and O
mental O
health O
differ O
between O

with O
KS O
and O
controls O
. O

Gonadal O
dysfunction O
and O
beyond O
: O
Clinical O
challenges O
in O
children O
, O
adolescents O
, O
and O
adults O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
is O
the O
most O
frequent O
sex O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
. O

The O
karyotype O
47 O
, O
XXY O
originates O
from O
either O
paternal O
or O
maternal O
meiotic O
nondisjunction O
during O
gametogenesis O
. O

KS O
males O
are O
very O
likely O
to O
exhibit O
marked O
gonadal O
dysfunctions O
, O
presenting O
both O
in O
severely O
attenuated O
spermatogenesis O
as O
well O
as O
hypergonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
neurocognitive O
and O
psychosocial O
impairments O
, O
as O
well O
as O
cardiovascular O
, O
metabolic O
and O
bone O
disorders O
are O
often O
found O
in O
KS O
and O
might O
explain O
for O
an O
increased O
morbidity O
/ O
mortality O
. O

All O
conditions O
in O
KS O
are O
likely O
to O
be O
induced O
by O
both O
gene O
overdosage O
effects O
resulting O
from O
supernumerary O
X O
- O
chromosomal O
genes O
as O
well O
as O
testosterone O
deficiency O
. O

Notwithstanding O
, O
the O
clinical O
features O
are O
highly O
variable O
between O
KS O
men O
. O

Symptoms O
can O
become O
obvious O
at O
infancy O
, O
childhood O
, O
or O
adolescence O
. O

However O
, O
the O
majority O
of O
KS O
subjects O
is O
diagnosed O
during O
adulthood O
. O

KS O
adolescents O
require O
specific O
attention O
regarding O
pubertal O
development O
, O
in O
order O
to O
exploit O
their O
remaining O
fertility O
potential O
and O
allow O
for O
timely O
and O
tailored O
testosterone O
replacement O
. O

The O
chances O
for O
sperm O
retrieval O
might O
decline O
with O
age O
and O
could O
be O
hampered O
by O
testosterone O
replacement O
; O
therefore O
, O
cryostorage O
of O
spermatozoa O
is O
an O
option O
during O
adolescence O
, O
before O
the O
decompensation O
of O
endocrine O
and O
exocrine O
testicular O
functions O
becomes O
more O
overt O
. O

Sperm O
from O
semen O
or O
surgically O
retrieved O
, O
in O
combination O
with O
intracytoplasmic O
sperm O
injection O
enables O
KS O
males O
to O
become O
biological O
fathers O
of O
healthy O
children O
. O

The O
aim O
of O
this O
article O
is O
to O
present O
the O
current O
knowledge O
on O
KS O
, O
to O
guide O
clinical O
care O
and O
to O
highlight O
research O
needs O
. O

Metabolic O
and O
cardiovascular O
risk O
factors O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
, O
which O
normally O
presents O
with O
a O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
, O
is O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
chromosome O
disorder O
in O
males O
. O

It O
is O
also O
the O
most O
common O
genetic O
cause O
of O
male O
infertility O
. O

KS O
subjects O
are O
typically O
tall O
, O
with O
small O
and O
firm O
testes O
, O
gynecomastia O
, O
broad O
hips O
, O
and O
sparse O
body O
hair O
, O
although O
a O
less O
evident O
presentation O
is O
also O
possible O
. O

KS O
is O
also O
characterized O
by O
a O
high O
prevalence O
of O
hypogonadism O
, O
metabolic O
syndrome O
( O
MetS O
) O
and O
cardiovascular O
disease O
. O

The O
aim O
of O
this O
article O
is O
to O
systematically O
review O
metabolic O
and O
the O
cardiovascular O
risk O
factors O
in O
KS O
patients O
. O

Hypogonadism O
has O
an O
important O
role O
in O
the O
pathogenesis O
of O
the O
changes O
in O
body O
composition O
( O
particularly O
visceral O
obesity O
) O
and O
hence O
of O
insulin O
resistance O
and O
MetS O
, O
but O
the O
association O
between O
KS O
and O
MetS O
may O
go O
beyond O
hypogonadism O
alone O
. O

From O
childhood O
, O
KS O
patients O
may O
show O
an O
increase O
in O
visceral O
fat O
with O
a O
reduction O
in O
lean O
body O
mass O
and O
an O
increase O
in O
glucose O
and O
impaired O
fat O
metabolism O
. O

Their O
increased O
incidence O
of O
congenital O
anomalies O
, O
epicardial O
adipose O
tissue O
, O
and O
thromboembolic O
disease O
suggests O
they O
have O
a O
higher O
risk O
of O
cardiovascular O
disease O
. O

There O
is O
conflicting O
evidence O
on O
the O
effects O
of O
testosterone O
therapy O
on O
body O
composition O
and O
metabolism O
. O

Integration O
and O
reanalysis O
of O
transcriptomics O
and O
methylomics O
data O
derived O
from O
blood O
and O
testis O
tissue O
of O
men O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
indicates O
the O
primary O
involvement O
of O
Sertoli O
cells O
in O
the O
testicular O
pathogenesis O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
; O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
chromosomal O
anomaly O
and O
causes O
a O
multitude O
of O
symptoms O
. O

Often O
the O
most O
noticeable O
symptom O
is O
infertility O
caused O
by O
azoospermia O
with O
testicular O
histology O
showing O
hyalinization O
of O
tubules O
, O
germ O
cells O
loss O
, O
and O
Leydig O
cell O
hyperplasia O
. O

The O
germ O
cell O
loss O
begins O
early O
in O
life O
leading O
to O
partial O
hyalinization O
of O
the O
testis O
at O
puberty O
, O
but O
the O
mechanistic O
drivers O
behind O
this O
remain O
poorly O
understood O
. O

In O
this O
systematic O
review O
, O
we O
summarize O
the O
current O
knowledge O
on O
developmental O
changes O
in O
the O
cellularity O
of O
KS O
gonads O
supplemented O
by O
a O
comparative O
analysis O
of O
the O
fetal O
and O
adult O
gonadal O
transcriptome O
, O
and O
blood O
transcriptome O
and O
methylome O
of O
men O
with O
KS O
. O

We O
identified O
a O
high O
fraction O
of O
upregulated O
genes O
that O
escape O
X O
- O
chromosome O
inactivation O
, O
thus O
supporting O
previous O
hypotheses O
that O
these O
are O
the O
main O
drivers O
of O

in O
KS O
. O

Enrichment O
analysis O
showed O
overrepresentation O
of O
genes O
from O
the O
X O
- O
and O
Y O
- O
chromosome O
and O
testicular O
transcription O
factors O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
by O
re O
- O
evaluation O
of O
recent O

cell O

- O
sequencing O
data O
originating O
from O
adult O

testis O
, O
we O
found O
novel O
evidence O
that O
the O
Sertoli O
cell O
is O
the O
most O
affected O
cell O
type O
. O

Our O
results O
are O
consistent O
with O
disturbed O
cross O
- O
talk O
between O
somatic O
and O
germ O
cells O
in O
the O
KS O
testis O
, O
and O
with O
X O
- O
escapee O
genes O
acting O
as O
mediators O
. O

Morbidity O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
and O
the O
effect O
of O
testosterone O
treatment O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
; O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
is O
the O
most O
common O
sex O
chromosome O
abnormality O
in O
males O
( O
150 O
per O
100 O
, O
000 O
males O
) O
. O

The O
condition O
leads O
to O
hypergonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
and O
ever O
since O
the O
condition O
was O
described O
approximately O
80 O
years O
ago O
, O
testosterone O
treatment O
has O
been O
the O
cornerstone O
in O
care O
for O
individuals O
with O
KS O
. O

However O
, O
KS O
is O
associated O
with O
an O
array O
of O
health O
- O
related O
and O
socioeconomic O
challenges O
and O
it O
is O
becoming O
progressively O
clear O
that O
proper O
care O
for O
boys O
and O
men O
with O
KS O
reaches O
far O
beyond O
simply O
supplementing O
with O
testosterone O
. O

There O
are O
no O
widely O
implemented O
guidelines O
for O
KS O
care O
, O
and O
studies O
investigating O
crucial O
aspects O
of O
testosterone O
treatment O
in O
individuals O
with O
KS O
, O
including O
both O
beneficial O
and O
potentially O
adverse O
effects O
, O
have O
only O
begun O
to O
emerge O
during O
the O
last O
decades O
. O

For O
this O
descriptive O
review O
, O
we O
present O
an O
overview O
of O
literature O
describing O
health O
- O
related O
outcomes O
of O
testosterone O
treatment O
in O
KS O
and O
outline O
the O
clinical O
applications O
of O
testosterone O
treatment O
in O
KS O
. O

Collectively O
, O
beneficial O
effects O
of O
testosterone O
treatment O
on O
overall O
health O
in O
KS O
are O
described O
with O
few O
apparent O
adverse O
effects O
. O

However O
, O
larger O
randomized O
studies O
in O
adult O
and O
pediatric O
patients O
are O
warranted O
to O
elucidate O
key O
aspects O
of O
treatment O
. O

We O
stress O
the O
implementation O
of O
centralized O
multidisciplinary O
clinics O
and O
the O
need O
for O
a O
dedicated O
international O
guideline O
to O
ensure O
optimal O
care O
of O
boys O
and O
men O
with O
KS O
. O

Psychological O
functioning O
, O
brain O
morphology O
, O
and O
functional O
neuroimaging O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
; O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
impacts O
neurodevelopment O
and O
is O
associated O
with O
an O
increased O
risk O
of O
cognitive O
, O
psychological O
and O
social O
impairments O
, O
although O
significant O
heterogeneity O
in O
the O
neurodevelopmental O
profile O
is O
seen O
. O

KS O
is O
characterized O
by O
a O
specific O
cognitive O
profile O
with O
predominantly O
verbal O
deficits O
, O
preserved O
function O
in O
non O
- O
verbal O
and O
visuo O
- O
spatial O
domains O
, O
executive O
dysfunction O
and O
social O
impairments O
, O
and O
by O
an O
increased O
vulnerability O
toward O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O

The O
neurobiological O
underpinnings O
of O
the O
observed O
neuropsychological O
profile O
have O
not O
been O
established O
. O

A O
distinct O
pattern O
of O
both O
global O
and O
regional O
brain O
volumetric O
differences O
has O
been O
demonstrated O
in O
addition O
to O
preliminary O
findings O
of O
functional O
brain O
alterations O
related O
to O
auditory O
, O
motor O
, O
language O
and O
social O
processing O
. O

When O
present O
, O
the O
combination O
of O
cognitive O
, O
psychological O
and O
social O
challenges O
has O
the O
potential O
to O
negatively O
affect O
quality O
of O
life O
. O

This O
review O
intends O
to O
provide O
information O
and O
insight O
to O
the O
neuropsychological O
outcome O
and O
brain O
correlates O
of O
KS O
. O

Possible O
clinical O
intervention O
and O
future O
directions O
of O
research O
will O
be O
discussed O
. O

Rare O
sex O
chromosome O
variation O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
: O
An O
integrative O
review O
. O

While O
the O
most O
common O
Sex O
Chromosome O
Aneuploidy O
( O
SCA O
) O
is O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
other O

such O
as O
48 O
, O
XXYY O

are O
less O
studied O
, O
perhaps O
due O
to O
its O
rarity O
. O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
occurs O
with O
an O
estimated O
prevalence O
of O
1 O
: O
18 O
, O
000 O
- O
40 O
, O
000 O
male O
births O
. O

This O
SCA O
is O
associated O
with O
a O
variety O
of O
complex O

, O

, O
and O

. O

The O
purpose O
of O
this O

is O
to O

the O

evidence O
related O
to O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
and O

gaps O
in O
the O

. O

This O
study O
utilized O
integrative O
review O
and O
PRISMA O
- O
guided O
methodology O
to O
search O
six O

for O
information O
pertaining O
to O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
. O

There O
were O
no O
exclusion O
criteria O
related O
to O
design O
methodology O
, O
given O
the O
paucity O
of O
available O
research O
. O

Among O
397 O
articles O
reviewed O
for O
potential O
inclusion O
, O
30 O
articles O
remained O
after O
inclusion O
and O
exclusion O
criteria O
were O
applied O
. O

Seven O
of O
these O
articles O
concentrated O
solely O
on O
participants O
with O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
. O

Literature O
was O
summarized O
into O
categories O
of O
physical O
phenotype O
, O
psychosocial O
, O
behavioral O
, O
neurocognitive O
, O
and O
brain O
function O
. O

Clinical O
description O
of O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
has O
evolved O
over O
time O
to O
develop O
a O
deeper O
understanding O
of O
this O
complex O
disorder O
. O

Large O
gaps O
remain O
, O
especially O
a O
lack O
of O
experimental O
studies O
, O
clinical O
guidelines O
, O
and O
treatments O
. O

Additionally O
, O
few O
studies O
explore O
methodologies O
such O
as O
interviews O
or O
self O
- O
report O
surveys O
in O
this O
population O
. O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
presents O
with O
a O
wide O
spectrum O
of O
physical O
, O
psychological O
, O
and O
neurocognitive O
symptoms O
, O
and O
frequently O
requires O
complex O
interdisciplinary O
care O
. O

In O
order O
to O
better O
understand O
this O
disorder O
and O
to O
appropriately O
treat O
the O
individuals O
affected O
by O
it O
, O
future O
research O
should O
focus O
on O
experimental O
studies O
and O
research O
that O
utilizes O
a O
variety O
of O
methods O
, O
including O
participant O
interviews O
and O
patient O
- O
report O
surveys O
. O

High O
prevalence O
of O
cardiometabolic O
risk O
features O
in O
adolescents O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
/ O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
occurs O
in O
1 O
: O
600 O
males O
and O
is O
associated O
with O
high O
morbidity O
and O
mortality O
due O
to O
diabetes O
and O
cardiovascular O
disease O
. O

Up O
to O
50 O
% O
of O
men O
with O
KS O
have O
metabolic O
syndrome O
, O
a O
cluster O
of O
features O
conferring O
increased O
risk O
for O
diabetes O
and O
cardiovascular O
disease O
. O

These O
cardiometabolic O
( O
CM O
) O
risk O
features O
have O
not O
been O
studied O
in O
adolescents O
with O
KS O
. O

The O
objective O
of O
this O
cohort O
study O
was O
to O
compare O
CM O
risk O
features O
in O
adolescents O
with O
KS O
to O
controls O
matched O
for O
sex O
, O
age O
, O
and O
BMI O
z O
score O
. O

Fifty O
males O
with O
KS O
( O
age O
10 O
- O
17 O
years O
) O
were O
well O
- O
matched O
to O
male O
controls O
( O
n O
= O
50 O
) O
for O
age O
( O
14 O
. O
0 O
± O
1 O
. O
7 O
vs O
. O

Rare O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
mosaicism O
46 O
, O
XX O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
is O
an O
extremely O
rare O
disorder O
of O
sex O
development O
characterized O
by O
the O
presence O
of O
both O
ovarian O
and O
testicular O
tissues O
in O
the O
same O
individual O
. O

Both O
elements O
can O
be O
present O
in O
the O
same O
gonad O
( O
ovotestis O
) O
or O
separately O
in O
the O
same O
individual O
or O
as O
a O
unilateral O
ovotestis O
and O
the O
other O
side O
with O
testis O
or O
ovary O
. O

A O
mosaic O
with O
46 O
, O
XY O
would O
present O
with O
problems O
related O
to O
male O
infertility O
and O
in O
general O
, O
testicular O
insufficiency O
, O
but O
with O
a O
46 O
, O
XX O
mosaic O
, O
it O
is O
a O
completely O
rare O
presentation O
. O

As O
adolescents O
, O
these O
boys O
may O
experience O
severe O
emotional O
and O
behavioral O
issues O
; O
it O
is O
up O
to O

to O

and O
get O
them O
physician O
evaluated O
for O

of O
treatment O
. O

of O

A O
novel O
use O
for O
Levey O
- O
Jennings O
charts O
in O
prenatal O

. O

The O

this O

to O

- O

, O

to O
create O
standardized O

( O

) O
for O

. O

: O

Syndrome O
Mosaicism O

Most O
cases O
of O

( O

) O
have O
47 O
, O

. O

We O
reported O

of O
46 O
, O

/ O

, O

and O

of O

( O

- O

) O
. O

The O

of O

X O

Additional O

. O

The O

of O

/ O

- O

with O

and O

and O

. O

The O
46 O
, O
XX O
is O
the O
predominant O
karyotype O
both O
in O
peripheral O
blood O
and O
gonadal O
tissue O
. O

The O
risk O
of O

cell O
tumor O
is O
very O
high O
throughout O

in O
these O
individuals O
. O

Individuals O

, O

/ O
47 O
, O

more O
as O

- O

other O
than O
a O
simple O

. O

A O

and O
long O
- O
term O
monitoring O
are O
necessary O
. O

. O

For O
the O
other O
SCAs O
, O
the O
differences O
were O
not O
significant O
. O

PPV O
of O
an O
abnormal O
cfDNA O
test O
for O
SCAs O
is O
low O
, O
particularly O
for O
monosomy O
X O
. O

The O
confirmation O
rate O
depends O
on O
the O
type O
of O
confirmatory O
test O
. O

[ O
Application O
of O
in O
situ O
amniocyte O
culture O
for O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
] O
. O

To O
explore O
the O
value O
of O
in O
situ O
amniocyte O
culture O
for O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
. O
2716 O
amniotic O
fluid O
samples O
were O
cultured O
in O
situ O
on O
slides O
. O

After O
the O
culture O
, O
the O
slides O
were O
stained O
, O
photographed O
and O
analyzed O
. O

All O
samples O
were O
successfully O
analyzed O
, O
with O
the O
success O
rates O
for O
primary O
culture O
and O
subculture O
being O
98 O
. O
42 O
% O
and O
1 O
. O
58 O
% O
, O
respectively O
. O
224 O
samples O
( O
8 O
. O
25 O
% O
) O
were O
detected O
with O
chromosomal O
aberrations O
, O
which O
included O
125 O
cases O
with O
trisomy O
21 O
, O
31 O
with O
trisomy O
18 O
, O
3 O
with O
trisomy O
13 O
, O
4 O
with O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
17 O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
5 O

with O
48 O
, O
XXYY O
, O
26 O
with O
structural O
chromosomal O
aberrations O
, O
and O

11 O
with O
mosaicisms O
for O
aneuploidies O
. O

In O
situ O
amniocyte O
culture O
is O
stable O
and O
has O
a O
high O
success O
rate O
, O
and O
is O
capable O
of O
identifying O
true O
and O
false O
mosaicisms O
, O
which O
can O
improve O
the O
accuracy O
of O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
. O

Identification O
of O
common O
differentially O
expressed O
genes O
in O
Turner O
( O
45 O
, O
X O
) O
and O
Klinefelter O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
syndromes O
using O
bioinformatics O
analysis O
. O

Analysis O
of O
patients O
with O
chromosomal O
abnormalities O
, O
including O
Turner O
syndrome O
and O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
, O
has O
highlighted O
the O
importance O
of O
X O
- O
linked O
gene O
dosage O
as O
a O
contributing O
factor O
for O
disease O
susceptibility O
. O

Escape O
from O
X O
- O
inactivation O
and O
X O
- O
linked O
imprinting O
can O
result O
in O
transcriptional O
differences O
between O
normal O
men O
and O
women O
as O
well O
as O
in O
patients O
with O
sex O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
. O

To O
identify O
differentially O
expressed O
genes O
among O
patients O
with O
Turner O
( O
45 O
, O
X O
) O
and O
Klinefelter O
( O
46 O
, O
XXY O
) O
syndrome O
using O
bioinformatics O
analysis O
. O

Two O
gene O
expression O
data O
sets O
of O
Turner O
( O
45 O
, O
X O
) O
and O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
were O
obtained O
from O
the O
Gene O
Omnibus O
Expression O
( O
GEO O
) O
database O
of O
the O
National O
Center O
for O
Biotechnology O
Information O
( O
NCBI O
) O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
was O
performed O
using O
R O
Bioconductor O
libraries O
. O

Differentially O
expressed O
genes O
( O
DEGs O
) O
were O
determined O
using O
significance O
analysis O
of O
microarray O
( O
SAM O
) O
. O

The O
functional O
annotation O
of O
the O
DEGs O
was O
performed O
with O
DAVID O
v6 O
. O
8 O
( O
The O
Database O
for O
Annotation O
, O
Visualization O
, O
and O
Integrated O
Discovery O
) O
. O

There O
are O
no O
genes O
over O
- O
expressed O
simultaneously O
in O
both O
diseases O
. O

However O
, O
when O
crossing O
the O
list O
of O
under O
- O
expressed O
genes O
for O
45 O
, O
X O
cells O
and O
the O
list O
of O
over O
- O
expressed O
genes O
for O
47 O
, O
XXY O
cells O
, O
there O
are O
16 O
common O
genes O
: O
SLC25A6 O

CSF2RA O
, O
DHRSX O
, O
CD99 O
, O
ZBED1 O
, O
EIF1AX O
, O
MVB12B O
, O
