, O
P2RY8 O
, O
DOCK7 O
, O
DDX3X O
, O
eight O
of O
which O
are O
involved O
in O
the O
regulation O

of O
gene O
expression O
by O
epigenetic O
mechanisms O
, O
regulation O
of O
splicing O
processes O
and O
protein O
synthesis O
. O

Of O
the O
16 O
identified O
as O
under O
- O
expressed O
in O
45 O
, O
X O
cells O
and O
over O
- O
expressed O
in O
47 O
, O
XXY O
cells O
, O
14 O
are O
located O
in O
X O
chromosome O
and O
2 O
in O
autosomal O
chromosome O
; O
8 O
of O
these O
genes O
are O
involved O
in O
the O
regulation O
of O
gene O
expression O
: O
5 O
genes O
are O
related O
to O
epigenetic O
mechanisms O
, O
2 O
in O
regulation O
of O
splicing O
processes O
, O
and O
1 O
in O
the O
protein O
synthesis O
process O
. O

Our O
results O
are O
limited O
by O
it O
being O
the O
product O
of O
a O
bioinformatic O
analysis O
from O
mRNA O
isolated O
from O
whole O
blood O
, O
this O
makes O
necessary O
further O
exploration O
of O
the O
relationships O
between O
these O
genes O
and O
Turner O
syndrome O
and O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
in O
the O
future O
. O

Oncologic O
manifestations O
of O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
has O
a O
prevalence O
of O
approximately O
1 O
in O
500 O
males O
. O

It O
is O
a O
condition O
characterized O
by O
an O
extra O
X O
chromosome O
and O
is O
an O
underdiagnosed O
clinical O
entity O
. O

Inactivation O
of O
genes O
enables O
their O
escape O
from O
regulatory O
mechanisms O
, O
which O
can O
result O
in O
such O
classic O
physical O
manifestations O
as O
hypogonadism O
, O
gynecomastia O
, O
infertility O
, O
and O
various O
hormonal O
and O
physical O
abnormalities O
. O

While O
the O
endocrine O
manifestations O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
are O
well O
- O
known O
, O
the O
oncologic O
manifestations O
have O
received O
less O
attention O
. O

An O
association O
between O
cancer O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
has O
not O
as O
yet O
been O
clearly O
defined O
, O
with O
variability O
noted O
in O
the O
prevalence O
of O
different O
malignancies O
in O
47 O
, O
XXY O
patients O
. O

The O
mechanisms O
underlying O
these O
altered O
oncologic O
risks O
are O
still O
under O
debate O
. O

Some O
of O
the O
proposed O
explanations O
include O
hormone O
imbalance O
, O
developmental O
malfunctions O
, O
and O
failed O
DNA O
repair O
mechanisms O
. O

However O
, O
the O
recognition O
of O
the O
oncological O
associations O
linked O
to O
47 O
, O
XXY O
could O
be O
helpful O
. O

Screening O
measures O
in O
certain O
malignancies O
may O
enable O
an O
earlier O
diagnosis O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
the O
implementation O
of O
more O
customized O
care O
in O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
the O
mosaic O
variants O
. O
. O

The O
data O
for O
this O
review O
was O
compiled O
from O
relevant O
PubMed O
articles O
published O
within O
the O
last O
three O
decades O
and O
organized O
based O
on O
cancer O
type O
. O

Clinical O
Review O
of O
Noninvasive O
Prenatal O
Testing O
: O
Experience O
from O
551 O
Pregnancies O
with O
Noninvasive O
Prenatal O
Testing O
- O
Positive O
Results O
in O
a O
Tertiary O
Referral O
Center O
. O

A O
total O
of O
551 O
pregnancies O
with O
positive O
results O
for O
noninvasive O
prenatal O
testing O
( O
NIPT O
) O
using O
traditional O
karyotyping O
and O
chromosomal O
microarray O
analysis O
were O
analyzed O
. O

Confirmatory O
results O
, O
positive O
predictive O
values O
, O
etiology O
exploration O
of O
false O
- O
positive O
results O
, O
and O
pregnancy O
outcomes O
were O
recorded O
. O

The O
study O
demonstrated O
that O
NIPT O
performed O
better O
in O
predicting O
trisomy O
21 O
and O
trisomy O
18 O
for O
pregnancies O
with O
advanced O
maternal O
age O
than O
for O
pregnancies O
with O
young O
maternal O
age O
; O
as O
for O
trisomy O
13 O
and O
sex O
chromosomal O
aneuploidy O
( O
SCA O
) O
prediction O
, O
there O
was O
no O
significant O
difference O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
. O

The O
positive O
predictive O
values O
for O
trisomy O
21 O
, O
trisomy O
18 O
, O
trisomy O
13 O
, O
and O
SCA O
showed O
no O
significant O
upward O
trend O
when O
compared O
based O
on O
specific O
age O
categories O
( O
an O
interval O
of O
5 O
years O
) O
, O
which O
suggested O
that O
NIPT O
- O
positive O
result O
deserves O
equal O
attention O
from O
both O
providers O
and O
patients O
regardless O
of O
maternal O
age O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
the O
termination O
rates O
of O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
, O
47 O

, O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
were O
100 O
% O
( O
2 O
/ O
2 O
) O
, O
92 O
. O
9 O
% O
( O
26 O
/ O
28 O
) O
, O
33 O
. O
3 O
% O
( O
5 O
/ O
15 O
) O
, O
and O
9 O
. O
5 O
% O
( O
2 O
/ O
21 O
) O
, O
respectively O
, O
which O
demonstrated O
that O
the O
decision O
- O

regarding O
pregnancies O
varied O
greatly O
according O
to O
the O

of O

, O
and O
further O
reinforce O
the O

of O

. O

The O
current O

the O

that O

of O

- O

. O

A O
Novel O
External O
Quality O
Assessment O
of O
Chromosomal O
Karyotype O
Analysis O
Based O
on O
Chimera O
Image O
Assembly O
. O

This O
study O
aimed O
to O
establish O
a O
new O
external O
quality O
assessment O
( O

) O
of O
chromosomal O
karyotype O
analysis O
. O

Chimeric O
assembly O
A1 O
was O
established O
by O
collecting O

chromosome O
images O
prepared O
artificially O
from O
chromosomally O
abnormal O
amniocytes O
remaining O
after O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
. O

Chimeric O
assembly O
B1 O
and O
nonchimeric O
assembly O

were O
constructed O
through O
the O
collection O
of O
chimeric O
and O
nonchimeric O
chromosome O
images O
from O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
, O
respectively O
. O

Then O
, O

images O
were O
selected O
randomly O
from O
assemblies O

, O
B1 O
, O
or O

to O
send O
to O
20 O
technicians O
via O
email O
to O
verify O
the O
validity O
of O
a O
new O
EQA O
of O
chromosomal O
karyotype O
analysis O
. O

to O
the O
EQA O
of O
20 O

, O
47 O
, O
XX O
, O
+ O

from O

, O

; O

) O

as O
45 O
, O
XX O
, O
13S O
+ O
, O
- O

. O

The O
total O

rate O
was O
3 O
. O
8 O
% O
. O

For O
assembly O
B O
, O
46 O
, O
X O

The O

of O

. O

Colchicine O
treatment O
increases O
the O
risk O
for O
fetal O
chromosomal O
aberrations O
- O
an O
observational O
study O
and O
systematic O
literature O
review O
. O

To O
examine O
the O
risk O
for O
chromosomal O
aberrations O
in O
fetuses O
of O
colchicine O
- O
treated O
patients O
in O
a O
large O
cohort O
, O
and O
to O
perform O
a O
systematic O
literature O
review O
on O
the O
subject O
. O

For O
the O
observational O
study O
, O
a O
retrospective O
search O
was O
performed O
through O
the O
Ministry O
of O
Health O
computerized O
database O
, O
for O
all O
invasive O
tests O
performed O
due O
to O
parental O
colchicine O
treatment O
over O
the O
years O
2003 O
- O
19 O
. O

The O
rate O
of O
aberrant O
karyotypes O
in O
pregnancies O
exposed O
to O
colchicine O
was O
compared O
with O
a O
local O
cohort O
of O
2752 O
normal O
pregnancies O
, O
yielding O
six O
( O
0 O
. O
2 O
% O
) O
karyotype O
- O
detectable O
findings O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
a O
systematic O
literature O
search O
was O
conducted O
for O
studies O
examining O
the O
rate O
of O
chromosomal O
aberrations O
in O
pregnancies O
exposed O
to O
colchicine O
. O

The O
study O
group O
consisted O
of O
755 O
pregnancies O
karyotyped O
due O
to O
colchicine O
exposure O
. O

A O
marked O
decrease O
due O
to O
this O
indication O
was O
noted O
over O
the O
years O
( O
i O
. O
e O
. O
67 O
cases O
in O
2003 O
vs O
8 O
in O
2019 O
) O
. O

Five O
( O
0 O
. O
66 O
% O
) O
chromosomal O
aberrations O
were O
noted O
: O
47 O
, O
XXY O
; O
45 O
, O
X0 O
; O
47 O
, O
XYY O
; O
and O

with O

21 O
. O

This O
rate O
was O
significantly O
increased O
compared O
with O
the O
control O
population O
[ O
relative O
risk O
2 O
. O
2 O
( O
95 O
% O
CI O
: O
1 O
. O
1 O
, O
4 O
. O
2 O
) O
] O
. O

Literature O
search O
yielded O
four O
studies O
encompassing O
740 O
pregnancies O
. O

The O
rate O
of O
chromosomal O
aberrations O
ranged O
from O
' O
none O
' O
( O
in O
three O
studies O
) O
up O
to O
1 O
. O
5 O
% O
. O

Quality O
assessment O
of O
the O
evidence O
was O
defined O
as O
' O
low O
' O
. O

The O
results O
of O
our O
observational O
study O
support O
the O
concern O
that O
colchicine O
treatment O
is O
associated O
with O
increased O
risk O
for O
fetal O
chromosomal O
aberrations O
; O
however O
, O
the O
absolute O
risk O
is O
relatively O
low O
( O
one O
in O
151 O
pregnancies O
) O
. O

This O
information O
should O
be O
taken O
into O
account O
when O
considering O
invasive O
testing O
in O
such O
pregnancies O
. O

Idiopathic O
central O
precocious O
puberty O
in O
a O
Klinefelter O
patient O
: O
highlights O
on O
gonadotropin O
levels O
and O
pathophysiology O
. O

Idiopathic O
central O
precocious O
puberty O
( O
ICPP O
) O
is O
supposed O
to O
be O
non O
- O
existent O
in O
a O
context O
of O
testicular O
destruction O
that O
is O
typically O
present O
in O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
. O

Herein O
, O
we O
describe O
a O
rare O
case O
of O
ICPP O
in O
a O
Klinefelter O
patient O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
with O
2 O
maternal O
X O
chromosomes O
. O

Moreover O
, O
we O
highlight O
the O
differences O
in O
gonadotropin O
levels O
in O
comparison O
to O
males O
with O
ICPP O
and O
a O
normal O
karyotype O
. O

An O
8 O
years O
old O
boy O
with O
a O
history O
of O
cryptorchidism O
was O
evaluated O
for O
precocious O
puberty O
( O
Tanner O
staging O
: O
P2 O
/ O
G3 O
) O
. O

Both O
testes O
measured O
25x35mm O
. O

His O
hormonal O
profile O
confirmed O
a O
central O
origin O
of O
precocious O
puberty O
with O
high O
serum O
testosterone O
( O
4 O
. O
3 O
ng O
/ O
ml O
) O
, O
luteinizing O
hormone O
[ O
LH O
( O
3 O
. O
5 O
UI O
/ O
l O
) O
] O
and O
follicle O
stimulating O
hormone O
[ O
FSH O
( O
7 O
. O
7 O
UI O
/ O
l O
) O
] O
levels O
. O

Luteinizing O
hormone O
- O
releasing O
hormone O
( O
LHRH O
) O
test O
amplified O
LH O
and O
FSH O
secretion O
to O
24 O
and O
14 O
UI O
/ O
l O
respectively O
. O

Brain O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
MRI O
) O
was O
normal O
. O

No O
MKRN3 O
mutation O
was O
detected O
. O

He O
was O
treated O
for O
ICPP O
for O
two O
years O
. O

During O
puberty O
, O
he O
suffered O
from O
hypergonadotropic O
hypogonadism O
leading O
to O
the O
diagnosis O
of O
KS O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
karyotype O
) O
. O

Chromosomal O
analysis O
by O
fluorescent O
multiplex O
polymerase O
chain O
reaction O
( O
PCR O
) O
using O
X O
chromosome O
microsatellite O
markers O
identified O
2 O
maternal O
X O
chromosomes O
. O

Analysing O
8 O
cases O
of O
KS O
developing O
ICPP O
( O
our O
reported O
case O
and O
7 O
other O
published O
cases O
) O
revealed O
that O
these O
KS O
patients O
with O
ICPP O
have O
higher O
LH O
and O
FSH O
levels O
during O
ICPP O
episode O
than O
in O
ICPP O
patients O
with O
a O
normal O
karyotype O
( O
ICPP O
with O
KS O
vs O
ICPP O
with O
a O
normal O
karyotype O
: O
LH O
levels O
9 O
. O
4 O
± O
12 O
vs O
1 O
. O
1 O
± O
0 O
. O
6 O
UI O
/ O
l O
; O
FSH O
levels O
23 O
. O
1 O
± O
38 O
. O
5 O
vs O
2 O
. O
7 O
± O
1 O
. O
5 O
UI O
/ O
l O
) O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
their O
response O
to O
gonadotropin O
- O
releasing O
hormone O
( O
GnRH O
) O
stimulation O
is O
characterized O
by O
excessive O
LH O
and O
FSH O
secretion O
( O
LH O
levels O
post O
- O
GnRH O
: O
58 O
± O
48 O
vs O
15 O
. O
5 O
± O
0 O
. O
8 O
UI O
/ O
l O
; O
FSH O
levels O
post O
- O
GnRH O
: O
49 O
. O
1 O
± O
62 O
. O
1 O
vs O
5 O
. O
7 O
± O
3 O
. O
9 O
UI O
/ O
l O
) O
. O

ICPP O
in O
boys O
is O
extremely O
rare O
. O

The O
pathophysiology O
of O
ICPP O
in O
KS O
is O
unknown O
. O

However O
, O
maternal O
X O
supplementary O
chromosome O
and O
early O
testicular O
destruction O
may O
play O
a O
significant O
role O
in O
the O
initiation O
of O
ICPP O
, O
in O
part O
explaining O
the O
relative O
" O
overrepresentation O
of O
ICPP O
in O
KS O
. O

Thus O
, O
karyotype O
analysis O
could O
be O
considered O
for O
boys O
suffering O
from O
ICPP O
, O
especially O
if O
testicular O
size O
is O
smaller O
or O
gonadotropins O
are O
significantly O
elevated O
. O

Social O
Management O
Training O
in O
Males O
With O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
Klinefelter O
Syndrome O
) O
: O
A O
Pilot O
Study O
of O
a O
Neurocognitive O
- O
Behavioral O
Treatment O
Targeting O
Social O
, O
Emotional O
, O
and O
Behavioral O
Problems O
. O

Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
is O
associated O
with O
problems O
in O
social O
interaction O
and O
behavioral O
adaptation O
. O

Sixteen O
adolescents O
and O
adult O
men O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
enrolled O
in O
a O
pilot O
- O
study O
evaluating O
the O
effectiveness O
of O
Social O
Management O
Training O
( O
SMT O
) O
, O
a O
novel O
neurocognitive O
- O
behavioral O
treatment O
program O
targeted O
at O
improving O
social O
, O
emotional O
, O
and O
behavioral O
functioning O
. O

Participants O
reported O
improved O
emotional O
stability O
from O
pre O
- O
to O
post O
- O
test O
( O
5 O
months O
) O
. O

Informants O
reported O
reductions O
in O
internalizing O
and O
externalizing O
symptoms O
, O
including O
improvement O
in O
self O
- O
regulation O
. O

Although O
informants O
did O
not O
report O
changes O
in O
autism O
- O
like O
symptoms O
, O
increased O
awareness O
of O
social O
challenges O
was O
found O
. O

SMT O
may O
improve O
emotional O
stability O
, O
self O
- O
regulation O
, O
and O
self O
- O
reflection O
in O
people O
males O
with O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
. O

This O
potentially O
efficacious O
treatment O
approach O
may O
prove O
to O
be O
a O
promising O
psychosocial O
therapeutic O
intervention O
for O
this O
population O
. O

RISK O
FOR O
47 O
, O

- O

: O

Noninvasive O
prenatal O
testing O
for O
assessing O
foetal O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
: O
a O
retrospective O
study O
of O
45 O
, O
773 O
cases O
. O

To O
assess O
the O
positive O
predictive O
value O
( O
PPV O
) O
of O
noninvasive O
prenatal O
testing O
( O
NIPT O
) O
as O
a O
screening O
test O
for O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidy O
( O
SCA O
) O
with O
different O
maternal O
characteristics O
and O
prenatal O
decisions O
in O
positive O
cases O
. O

We O
retrospectively O
analysed O
45 O
, O
773 O
singleton O
pregnancies O
with O
different O
characteristics O
that O
were O
subjected O
to O
NIPT O
in O
the O
Maternity O
and O
Child O
Health O
Hospital O
of O
Anhui O
Province O
. O

The O
results O
were O
validated O
by O
karyotyping O
. O

Clinical O
data O
, O
diagnostic O
results O
, O
and O
data O
on O
pregnancy O
outcomes O
were O
collected O
. O

In O
total O
, O
314 O
cases O
were O
SCA O
positive O
by O
NIPT O
; O
among O
those O
, O
143 O
underwent O
invasive O
prenatal O
diagnostic O
testing O
, O
and O
58 O
were O
true O
- O
positive O
. O

Overall O
, O
the O
PPVs O
for O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
were O
12 O
. O
5 O
% O
, O
51 O
. O
72 O
% O
, O
66 O
. O
67 O
% O
and O
83 O
. O
33 O
% O
, O
respectively O
. O

Interestingly O
, O
when O
only O
pregnant O
women O
of O
advanced O
maternal O
age O
( O
AMA O
) O
were O
screened O
, O
the O
PPVs O
for O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
47 O
, O
XXY O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
were O
23 O
. O
81 O
% O
, O
53 O
. O
33 O
% O
, O
78 O
. O
95 O
% O
, O
and O
66 O
. O
67 O
% O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
frequency O
of O
SCA O
was O
significantly O
higher O
in O
the O
AMA O
group O
than O
in O
the O
non O
- O
AMA O
group O
. O

The O
frequencies O
of O
47 O
, O
XXX O
and O
47 O
, O
XXY O
were O
significantly O
correlated O
with O
maternal O
age O
. O

NIPT O
performed O
better O
in O
predicting O
sex O
chromosome O
trisomies O
than O
monosomy O
X O
, O
and O
patients O
with O
45 O
, O
X O
positive O
foetuses O
were O
more O
eager O
to O
terminate O
pregnancy O
than O
those O
with O
47 O
, O
XXX O
and O
47 O
, O
XYY O
. O

AMA O
may O
be O
a O
risk O
factor O
of O
having O
a O
foetus O
with O
SCA O
. O

Our O
findings O
may O
assist O
in O
genetic O
counselling O
of O
AMA O
pregnant O
women O
. O

Our O
pre O
- O
and O
posttest O
counselling O
are O
essential O
for O
familiarizing O
pregnant O
women O
with O
the O
benefits O
and O
limitations O
of O
NIPT O
, O
which O
may O
ease O
their O
anxiety O
and O
enable O
them O
to O
make O
informed O
choices O
for O
further O
diagnosis O
and O
pregnancy O
decisions O
. O

Noninvasive O
prenatal O
detection O
of O
fetal O
sex O
chromosome O
abnormalities O
using O
the O
semiconductor O
sequencing O
platform O
( O
SSP O
) O
in O
Southern O
China O
. O

Noninvasive O
prenatal O
testing O
( O
NIPT O
) O
has O
been O
widely O
used O
to O
screen O
for O
fetal O
aneuploidies O
, O
including O
fetal O
sex O
chromosome O
aneuploidies O
( O
SCAs O
) O
. O

However O
, O
there O
is O
less O
information O
on O
the O
performance O
of O
NIPT O
in O
detecting O
SCAs O
. O

A O
cohort O
of O
47 O
, O
800 O
pregnancies O
was O
recruited O
to O
review O
the O
high O
- O
risk O
NIPT O
results O
for O
SCAs O
. O

Cell O
- O
free O
fetal O
DNA O
( O
cffDNA O
) O
was O
extracted O
and O
sequenced O
. O

All O
NIPT O
high O
- O
risk O
cases O
were O
recommended O
to O
undergo O
invasive O
prenatal O
diagnosis O
for O
karyotyping O
analysis O
and O
chromosome O
microarray O
analysis O
( O
CMA O
) O
. O

A O
total O
of O
238 O
high O
- O
risk O
cases O
were O
detected O
by O
NIPT O
, O
including O
137 O
cases O
of O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
27 O
cases O
of O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
and O
74 O
cases O
of O
47 O
, O
XYY O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

Prenatal O
diagnosis O
, O
including O
karyotyping O
analysis O
and O
CMA O
, O
was O
available O
in O
170 O
cases O
. O

The O
positive O
predictive O
value O
( O
PPV O
) O
was O
30 O
. O
00 O
% O
for O
45 O
, O
X O
, O
70 O
. O
58 O
% O
for O
47 O
, O
XXX O
, O
and O
81 O
. O
13 O
% O
for O
47 O
, O
XYY O
/ O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
13 O
cases O
of O
sex O
chromosome O
mosaicism O
and O
9 O
cases O
of O
sex O
chromosome O
CNVs O
were O
incidentally O
found O
in O
this O
study O
. O

Our O
study O
showed O
that O
NIPT O
was O
reliable O
for O
screening O
SCAs O
based O
on O
a O
large O
sample O
, O
and O
it O
performed O
better O
in O
predicting O
sex O
chromosome O
trisomies O
than O
monosomy O
X O
. O

Our O
study O
will O
provide O
an O
important O
reference O
for O
clinical O
genetic O
counseling O
and O
further O
processing O
of O
the O
results O
. O

The O
contribution O
of O
Xp22 O
. O
31 O
gene O
dosage O
to O
Turner O
and O
Klinefelter O
syndromes O
and O
sex O
- O
biased O
phenotypes O
. O

Turner O
syndrome O
( O
TS O
) O
is O
a O
rare O
developmental O
condition O
in O
females O
caused O
by O
complete O
, O
or O
partial O
, O
loss O
of O
the O
second O
sex O
chromosome O
; O
it O
is O
associated O
with O
a O
number O
of O
phenotypes O
including O
short O
stature O
, O
ovarian O
failure O
and O
infertility O
, O
as O
well O
as O
neurobehavioural O
and O
cognitive O
manifestations O
. O

In O
contrast O
, O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
( O
KS O
) O
arises O
from O
an O
excess O
of O
X O
chromosome O
material O
in O
males O
( O
typical O
karyotype O
is O
47 O
, O
XXY O
) O
; O
like O
TS O
, O
KS O
is O
associated O
with O
infertility O
and O
hormonal O
imbalance O
, O
and O
behavioural O
/ O
neurocognitive O
differences O
from O
gonadal O
sex O
- O
matched O
counterparts O
. O

Lower O
dosage O
of O
genes O
that O
escape O
X O
- O
inactivation O
may O
partially O
explain O
TS O
phenotypes O
, O
whilst O
overdosage O
of O
these O
genes O
may O
contribute O
towards O
KS O
- O
related O
symptoms O
. O

Here O
, O
I O
discuss O
new O
findings O
from O
individuals O
with O
deletions O
or O
duplications O
limited O
to O
Xp22 O
. O
31 O
( O
a O
region O
escaping O
X O
- O
inactivation O
) O
, O
and O
consider O
the O
extent O
to O
which O
altered O
gene O
dosage O
within O
this O
small O
interval O
( O
and O
of O
the O
steroid O
sulfatase O
( O
STS O
) O
gene O
in O
particular O
) O
may O
influence O
the O
phenotypic O
profiles O
of O
TS O
and O
KS O
. O

The O
expression O
of O
X O
- O
escapees O
can O
be O
higher O
in O
female O
than O
male O
tissues O
; O
I O
conclude O
by O
considering O
how O
lower O
Xp22 O
. O
31 O
gene O
dosage O
in O
males O
may O
increase O
their O
likelihood O
of O
exhibiting O
particular O
phenotypes O
relative O
to O
females O
. O

Understanding O
the O
genetic O
contribution O
to O
specific O
phenotypes O
in O
rare O
disorders O
such O
as O
TS O
and O
KS O
, O
and O
to O
more O
common O
sex O
- O
biased O
phenotypes O
, O
will O
be O
important O
for O
developing O
more O
effective O
, O
and O
more O
personalised O
, O
therapeutic O
approaches O
. O

The O
effect O
of O
early O
hormonal O
treatment O
( O
EHT O
) O
on O
expressive O
and O
receptive O
language O
capabilities O
in O
boys O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
( O
Klinefelter O
syndrome O
) O
during O
infancy O
and O
early O
childhood O
. O

47 O
, O
XXY O
is O
associated O
with O
variable O
neurodevelopmental O
outcomes O
including O
deficits O
in O
expressive O
and O
receptive O
language O
development O
. O

Early O
hormonal O
treatment O
( O
EHT O
) O
has O
been O
associated O
with O
mitigating O
some O
deficiencies O
in O
boys O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
. O

This O
study O
investigates O
these O
language O
capabilities O
of O
47 O
, O
XXY O
boys O
in O
the O
first O
five O
years O
of O
life O
and O
the O
associated O
effects O
of O
EHT O
on O
these O
capabilities O
. O

One O
hundred O
and O
seventy O
- O
five O
boys O
with O
47 O
, O
XXY O
between O
the O
ages O
of O
0 O
and O
5 O
years O
, O
11 O
months O
completed O
neurodevelopmental O
assessments O
specific O
to O
age O
examining O
their O
expressive O
and O
receptive O
language O
capabilities O
. O

Subjects O
were O
grouped O
by O
treatment O
( O
EHT O
and O
No O
- O
T O
) O
and O
differences O
were O
analyzed O
. O

In O
the O
age O
groups O
of O
under O
12 O
months O
, O
24 O
- O
35 O
months O
, O
36 O
- O
47 O
months O
, O
and O
60 O
- O
71 O
months O
, O
the O
EHT O
group O
scored O
significantly O
higher O
on O
expressive O
language O
assessments O
than O
the O
No O
- O
T O
group O
( O
p O
= O
0 O
. O
09 O
, O
p O
= O
0 O
. O
0002 O
, O
p O
= O
0 O
. O
009 O
, O
and O
p O
= O
0 O
. O
02 O
, O
respectively O
) O
. O

In O
the O
age O
groups O
of O
under O
12 O
months O
and O
24 O
- O
35 O
months O
, O

significantly O

on O
the O

of O
the O

- O
4 O
/ O
5 O
( O
